00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
Basically, Rome had access to the sea,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
which made it possible for it to import food from a very long way away.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
This is the only way it was possible to do this in the ancient world,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
because it was very difficult to transport food over roads,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
which were rough.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
And the food obviously went off very quickly.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
So Rome effectively waged war

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
on places like Carthage and Egypt

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
just to get its paws on their grain reserves.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
And, in fact, you could say that the expansion of the Empire

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
was really sort of one long, drawn out

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
militarized shopping spree, really.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
(Laughter)

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
In fact -- I love the fact, I just have to mention this:

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
Rome in fact used to import oysters from London,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
at one stage. I think that's extraordinary.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
So Rome shaped its hinterland

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
through its appetite.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
But the interesting thing is that the other thing also

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
happened in the pre-industrial world.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
If we look at a map of London in the 17th century,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
we can see that its grain, which is coming in from the Thames,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
along the bottom of this map.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
So the grain markets were to the south of the city.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
And the roads leading up from them

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
to Cheapside, which was the main market,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
were also grain markets.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
And if you look at the name of one of those streets,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
Bread Street, you can tell

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
what was going on there 300 years ago.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
And the same of course was true for fish.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
Fish was, of course, coming in by river as well. Same thing.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
And of course Billingsgate, famously, was London's fish market,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:37.958
operating on-site here until the mid-1980s.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
Which is extraordinary, really, when you think about it.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
Everybody else was wandering around

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
with mobile phones that looked like bricks

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
and sort of smelly fish happening down on the port.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
This is another thing about food in cities:

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
Once its roots into the city are established,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
they very rarely move.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
Meat is a very different story

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
because, of course, animals could walk into the city.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
So much of London's meat

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
was coming from the northwest,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
from Scotland and Wales.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
So it was coming in, and arriving at the city at the northwest,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
which is why Smithfield,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
London's very famous meat market, was located up there.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:16.958
Poultry was coming in from East Anglia and so on, to the northeast.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:17.958
I feel a bit like a weather woman doing this. Anyway,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:21.958
and so the birds were coming in

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
with their feet protected with little canvas shoes.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
And then when they hit the eastern end

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
of Cheapside, that's where they were sold,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
which is why it's called Poultry.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
And, in fact, if you look at the map of any city

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
built before the industrial age,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
you can trace food coming in to it.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
You can actually see how it was physically shaped by food,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
both by reading the names of the streets, which give you a lot of clues.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Friday Street, in a previous life,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
is where you went to buy your fish on a Friday.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
But also you have to imagine it full of food.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
Because the streets and the public spaces

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
were the only places where food was bought and sold.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
And if we look at an image of Smithfield in 1830

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
you can see that it would have been very difficult to live in a city like this

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and be unaware of where your food came from.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
In fact, if you were having Sunday lunch,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
the chances were it was mooing or bleating outside your window

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
about three days earlier.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
So this was obviously an organic city,

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
part of an organic cycle.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
And then 10 years later everything changed.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
This is an image of the Great Western in 1840.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
And as you can see, some of the earliest train passengers

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
were pigs and sheep.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:31.958
So all of a sudden, these animals are no longer walking into market.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
They're being slaughtered out of sight and mind,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
somewhere in the countryside.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
And they're coming into the city by rail.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
And this changes everything.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
To start off with, it makes it possible

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:43.958
for the first time to grow cities,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
really any size and shape, in any place.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:49.958
Cities used to be constrained by geography;

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
they used to have to get their food through very difficult physical means.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:56.958
All of a sudden they are effectively emancipated from geography.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
And as you can see from these maps of London,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
in the 90 years after the trains came,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:05.958
it goes from being a little blob that was quite easy to feed

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
by animals coming in on foot, and so on,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
to a large splurge,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
that would be very, very difficult to feed with anybody on foot,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
either animals or people.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
And of course that was just the beginning. After the trains came cars,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:22.958
and really this marks the end of this process.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
It's the final emancipation of the city

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
from any apparent relationship with nature at all.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
And this is the kind of city that's devoid of smell,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
devoid of mess, certainly devoid of people,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
because nobody would have dreamed of walking in such a landscape.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
In fact, what they did to get food was they got in their cars,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
drove to a box somewhere on the outskirts,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
came back with a week's worth of shopping,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
and wondered what on earth to do with it.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
And this really is the moment when our relationship,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
both with food and cities, changes completely.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
Here we have food -- that used to be the center,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
the social core of the city -- at the periphery.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
It used to be a social event, buying and selling food.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Now it's anonymous.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
We used to cook; now we just add water,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:08.958
or a little bit of an egg if you're making a cake or something.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
We don't smell food to see if it's okay to eat.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
We just read the back of a label on a packet.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
And we don't value food. We don't trust it.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
So instead of trusting it, we fear it.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:24.958
And instead of valuing it, we throw it away.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
One of the great ironies of modern food systems

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
is that they've made the very thing they promised

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
to make easier much harder.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:35.958
By making it possible to build cities anywhere and any place,

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:39.958
they've actually distanced us from our most important relationship,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
which is that of us and nature.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
And also they've made us dependent on systems that only they can deliver,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
that, as we've seen, are unsustainable.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
So what are we going to do about that?

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
It's not a new question.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
500 years ago it's what Thomas More was asking himself.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
This is the frontispiece of his book "Utopia."

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
And it was a series of semi-independent city-states,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
if that sounds remotely familiar,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
a day's walk from one another where everyone was basically farming-mad,

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
and grew vegetables in their back gardens,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
and ate communal meals together, and so on.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
And I think you could argue that

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
food is a fundamental ordering principle of Utopia,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
even though More never framed it that way.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
And here is another very famous "Utopian" vision,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
that of Ebenezer Howard, "The Garden City."

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
Same idea: series of semi-independent city-states,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:31.958
little blobs of metropolitan stuff with arable land around,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
joined to one another by railway.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
And again, food could be said to be

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
the ordering principle of his vision.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
It even got built, but nothing to do with

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
this vision that Howard had.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
And that is the problem with these Utopian ideas,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
that they are Utopian.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
Utopia was actually a word that Thomas Moore used deliberately.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:54.958
It was a kind of joke, because it's got a double derivation from the Greek.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
It can either mean a good place, or no place.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:12:00.958
Because it's an ideal. It's an imaginary thing. We can't have it.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
And I think, as a conceptual tool

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
for thinking about the very deep problem of human dwelling,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
that makes it not much use.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
So I've come up with an alternative,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
which is Sitopia, from the ancient Greek,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
"sitos" for food, and "topos" for place.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
I believe we already live in Sitopia.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
We live in a world shaped by food,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and if we realize that, we can use food as a really powerful tool --

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
a conceptual tool, design tool, to shape the world differently.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:32.958
So if we were to do that, what might Sitopia look like?

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
Well I think it looks a bit like this.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
I have to use this slide. It's just the look on the face of the dog.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
But anyway, this is -- (Laughter)

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
it's food at the center of life,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
at the center of family life, being celebrated,

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
being enjoyed, people taking time for it.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
This is where food should be in our society.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:53.958
But you can't have scenes like this unless you have people like this.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
By the way, these can be men as well.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
It's people who think about food,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
who think ahead, who plan,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
who can stare at a pile of raw vegetables

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
and actually recognize them.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
We need these people. We're part of a network.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
Because without these kinds of people we can't have places like this.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
Here, I deliberately chose this because it is a man buying a vegetable.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:17.958
But networks, markets where food is being grown locally.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
It's common. It's fresh.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
It's part of the social life of the city.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
Because without that, you can't have this kind of place,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
food that is grown locally and also is part of the landscape,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
and is not just a zero-sum commodity

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
off in some unseen hell-hole.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
Cows with a view.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
Steaming piles of humus.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
This is basically bringing the whole thing together.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
And this is a community project

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
I visited recently in Toronto.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
It's a greenhouse, where kids get told

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
all about food and growing their own food.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
Here is a plant called Kevin, or maybe it's a

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
plant belonging to a kid called Kevin. I don't know.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
But anyway, these kinds of projects

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:59.958
that are trying to reconnect us with nature is extremely important.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
So Sitopia, for me, is really a way of seeing.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
It's basically recognizing that Sitopia

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
already exists in little pockets everywhere.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
The trick is to join them up,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
to use food as a way of seeing.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
And if we do that, we're going to stop seeing cities

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
as big, metropolitan, unproductive blobs, like this.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
We're going to see them more like this,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
as part of the productive, organic framework

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
of which they are inevitably a part,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
symbiotically connected.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
But of course, that's not a great image either,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
because we need not to be producing food like this anymore.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
We need to be thinking more about permaculture,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
which is why I think this image just

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
sums up for me the kind of thinking we need to be doing.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
It's a re-conceptualization

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
of the way food shapes our lives.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
The best image I know of this is from 650 years ago.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
It's Ambrogio Lorenzetti's "Allegory of Good Government."

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
It's about the relationship between the city and the countryside.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
And I think the message of this is very clear.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
If the city looks after the country,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
the country will look after the city.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
And I want us to ask now,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
what would Ambrogio Lorenzetti paint

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
if he painted this image today?

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
What would an allegory of good government look like today?

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
Because I think it's an urgent question.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
It's one we have to ask,

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
and we have to start answering.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
We know we are what we eat.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
We need to realize that the world is also what we eat.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
But if we take that idea, we can use food

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.958
as a really powerful tool to shape the world better.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
Thank you very much.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
(Applause)

title: Tribal leadership
transcript: What we're really here to talk about is the "how." Okay, so how exactly do we create this world-shattering, if you will, innovation? Now, I want to tell you a quick story. We'll go back a little more than a year. In fact, the date — I'm curious to know if any of you know what happened on this momentous date? It was February 3rd, 2008. Anyone remember what happened, February 3rd, 2008? Super Bowl. I heard it over here. It was the date of the Super Bowl.And the reason that this date was so momentous is that what my colleagues, John King and Halee Fischer-Wright, and I noticed as we began to debrief various Super Bowl parties, is that it seemed to us that across the United States, if you will, tribal councils had convened. And they had discussed things of great national importance. Like, "Do we like the Budweiser commercial?" and, "Do we like the nachos?" and, "Who is going to win?" But they also talked about which candidate they were going to support.And if you go back in time to February 3rd, it looked like Hilary Clinton was going to get the Democratic nomination. And there were even some polls that were saying she was going to go all the way. But when we talked to people, it appeared that a funnel effect had happened in these tribes all across the United States. Now what is a tribe? A tribe is a group of about 20 — so kind of more than a team — 20 to about 150 people. And it's within these tribes that all of our work gets done. But not just work. It's within these tribes that societies get built, that important things happen.And so as we surveyed the, if you will, representatives from various tribal councils that met, also known as Super Bowl parties, we sent the following email off to 40 newspaper editors the following day. February 4th, we posted it on our website. This was before Super Tuesday. We said, "The tribes that we're in are saying it's going to be Obama." Now, the reason we knew that was because we spent the previous 10 years studying tribes, studying these naturally occurring groups.All of you are members of tribes. In walking around at the break, many of you had met members of your tribe. And you were talking to them. And many of you were doing what great, if you will, tribal leaders do, which is to find someone who is a member of a tribe, and to find someone else who is another member of a different tribe, and make introductions. That is in fact what great tribal leaders do.So here is the bottom line. If you focus in on a group like this — this happens to be a USC game — and you zoom in with one of those super satellite cameras and do magnification factors so you could see individual people, you would in fact see not a single crowd, just like there is not a single crowd here, but you would see these tribes that are then coming together. And from a distance it appears that it's a single group. And so people form tribes. They always have. They always will. Just as fish swim and birds fly, people form tribes. It's just what we do. But here's the rub. Not all tribes are the same, and what makes the difference is the culture.Now here is the net out of this. You're all a member of tribes. If you can find a way to take the tribes that you're in and nudge them forward, along these tribal stages to what we call Stage Five, which is the top of the mountain. But we're going to start with what we call Stage One. Now, this is the lowest of the stages. You don't want this. Okay? This is a bit of a difficult image to put up on the screen. But it's one that I think we need to learn from.Stage One produces people who do horrible things. This is the kid who shot up Virginia Tech. Stage One is a group where people systematically sever relationships from functional tribes, and then pool together with people who think like they do. Stage One is literally the culture of gangs and it is the culture of prisons. Now, again, we don't often deal with Stage One. And I want to make the point that as members of society, we need to. It's not enough to simply write people off.But let's move on to Stage Two. Now, Stage One, you'll notice, says, in effect, "Life Sucks." So, this other book that Steve mentioned, that just came out, called "The Three Laws of Performance," my colleague, Steve Zaffron and I, argue that as people see the world, so they behave. Well, if people see the world in such a way that life sucks, then their behavior will follow automatically from that. It will be despairing hostility. They'll do whatever it takes to survive, even if that means undermining other people.Now, my birthday is coming up shortly, and my driver's license expires. And the reason that that's relevant is that very soon I will be walking into what we call a Stage Two tribe, which looks like this. (Laughter) Now, am I saying that in every Department of Motor Vehicles across the land, you find a Stage Two culture? No. But in the one near me, where I have to go in just a few days, what I will say when I'm standing in line is, "How can people be so dumb, and yet live?" (Laughter)Now, am I saying that there are dumb people working here? Actually, no, I'm not. But I'm saying the culture makes people dumb. So in a Stage Two culture — and we find these in all sorts of different places — you find them, in fact, in the best organizations in the world. You find them in all places in society. I've come across them at the organizations that everybody raves about as being best in class. But here is the point. If you believe and you say to people in your tribe, in effect, "My life sucks. I mean, if I got to go to TEDx USC my life wouldn't suck. But I don't. So it does." If that's how you talked, imagine what kind of work would get done. What kind of innovation would get done? The amount of world-changing behavior that would happen? In fact it would be basically nil.Now when we go on to Stage Three: this is the one that hits closest to home for many of us. Because it is in Stage Three that many of us move. And we park. And we stay. Stage Three says, "I'm great. And you're not." (Laughter) I'm great and you're not. Now imagine having a whole room of people saying, in effect, "I'm great and you're not." Or, "I'm going to find some way to compete with you and come out on top as a result of that." A whole group of people communicating that way, talking that way.I know this sounds like a joke. Three doctors walk into a bar. But, in this case, three doctors walk into an elevator. I happened to be in the elevator collecting data for this book. And one doctor said to the others, "Did you see my article in the New England Journal of Medicine?" And the other said, "No. That's great. Congratulations!"The next one got kind of a wry smile on his face and said, "Well while you were, you know, doing your research," — notice the condescending tone — "While you were off doing your research, I was off doing more surgeries than anyone else in the department of surgery at this institution."And the third one got the same wry smile and said, "Well, while you were off doing your research, and you were off doing your monkey meatball surgery, that eventually we'll train monkeys to do, or cells or robots, or maybe not even need to do it at all, I was off running the future of the residency program, which is really the future of medicine."And they all kind of laughed and they patted him on the back. And the elevator door opened, and they all walked out. That is a meeting of a Stage Three tribe. Now, we find these in places where really smart, successful people show up. Like, oh, I don't know, TEDx USC. (Laughter)Here is the greatest challenge we face in innovation. It is moving from Stage Three to Stage Four. Let's take a look at a quick video snippet. This is from a company called Zappos, located outside Las Vegas. And my question on the other side is just going to be, "What do you think they value?" It was not Christmas time. There was a Christmas tree. This is their lobby. Employees volunteer time in the advice booth. Notice it looks like something out of a Peanuts cartoon.Okay, we're going through the hallway here at Zappos. This is a call center. Notice how it's decorated. Notice people are applauding for us. They don't know who we are and they don't care. And if they did they probably wouldn't applaud. But you'll notice the level of excitement. Notice, again, how they decorate their office. Now, what's important to people at Zappos, these may not be the things that are important to you. But they value things like fun. And they value creativity. One of their stated values is, "Be a little bit weird." And you'll notice they are a little bit weird.So when individuals come together and find something that unites them that's greater than their individual competence, then something very important happens. The group gels. And it changes from a group of highly motivated but fairly individually-centric people into something larger, into a tribe that becomes aware of its own existence. Stage Four tribes can do remarkable things. But you'll notice we're not at the top of the mountain yet. There is, in fact, another stage.Now, some of you may not recognize the scene that's up here. And if you take a look at the headline of Stage Five, which is "Life is Great," this may seem a little incongruous. This is a scene or snippet from the Truth and Reconciliation process in South Africa for which Desmond Tutu won the Nobel Prize. Now think about that. South Africa, terrible atrocities had happened in the society. And people came together focused only on those two values: truth and reconciliation. There was no road map. No one had ever done anything like this before.And in this atmosphere, where the only guidance was people's values and their noble cause, what this group accomplished was historic. And people, at the time, feared that South Africa would end up going the way that Rwanda has gone, descending into one skirmish after another in a civil war that seems to have no end. In fact, South Africa has not gone down that road. Largely because people like Desmond Tutu set up a Stage Five process to involve the thousands and perhaps millions of tribes in the country, to bring everyone together. So, people hear this and they conclude the following, as did we in doing the study.Okay, got it. I don't want to talk Stage One. That's like, you know, "Life sucks." Who wants to talk that way? I don't want to talk like they do at the particular DMV that's close to where Dave lives. I really don't want to just say "I'm great," because that kind of sounds narcissistic, and then I won't have any friends. Saying, "We're great" — that sounds pretty good. But I should really talk Stage Five, right? "Life is great."Well, in fact, there are three somewhat counter-intuitive findings that come out of all this. The first one, if you look at the Declaration of Independence and actually read it, the phrase that sticks in many of our minds is things about inalienable rights. I mean, that's Stage Five, right? Life is great, oriented only by our values, no other guidance. In fact, most of the document is written at Stage Two. "My life sucks because I live under a tyrant, also known as King George. We're great! Who is not great? England!" Sorry. (Laughter)Well, what about other great leaders? What about Gandhi? What about Martin Luther King? I mean, surely these were just people who preached, "Life is great," right? Just one little bit of happiness and joy after another. In fact, Martin Luther King's most famous line was at Stage Three. He didn't say "We have a dream." He said, "I have a dream." Why did he do that? Because most people are not at Stage Five.Two percent are at Stage One. About 25 percent are at Stage Two, saying, in effect, "My life sucks." 48 percent of working tribes say, these are employed tribes, say, "I'm great and you're not." And we have to duke it out every day, so we resort to politics. Only about 22 percent of tribes are at Stage Four, oriented by our values, saying "We're great. And our values are beginning to unite us." Only two percent, only two percent of tribes get to Stage Five. And those are the ones that change the world.So the first little finding from this is that leaders need to be able to talk all the levels so that you can touch every person in society. But you don't leave them where you found them. Okay? Tribes can only hear one level above and below where they are. So we have to have the ability to talk all the levels, to go to where they are. And then leaders nudge people within their tribes to the next level. I'd like to show you some examples of this.One of the people we interviewed was Frank Jordan, former Mayor of San Francisco. Before that he was Chief of Police in San Francisco. And he grew up essentially in Stage One. And you know what changed his life? It was walking into one of these, a Boys and Girls Club. Now here is what happened to this person who eventually became Mayor of San Francisco. He went from being alive and passionate at Stage One — remember, "Life sucks, despairing hostility, I will do whatever it takes to survive" — to walking into a Boys and Girls Club, folding his arms, sitting down in a chair, and saying, "Wow. My life really sucks. I don't know anybody. I mean, if I was into boxing, like they were, then my life wouldn't suck. But I don't. So it does. So I'm going to sit here in my chair and not do anything."In fact, that's progress. We move people from Stage One to Stage Two by getting them in a new tribe and then, over time, getting them connected. So, what about moving from Stage Three to Stage Four? I want to argue that we're doing that right here. TED represents a set of values, and as we unite around these values, something really interesting begins to emerge.If you want this experience to live on as something historic, then at the reception tonight I'd like to encourage you to do something beyond what people normally do and call networking. Which is not just to meet new people and extend your reach, extend your influence, but instead, find someone you don't know, and find someone else you don't know, and introduce them. That's called a triadic relationship.See, people who build world-changing tribes do that. They extend the reach of their tribes by connecting them, not just to myself, so that my following is greater, but I connect people who don't know each other to something greater than themselves. And ultimately that adds to their values.But we're not done yet. Because then how do we go from Stage Four, which is great, to Stage Five? The story that I like to end with is this. It comes out of a place called the Gallup Organization. You know they do polls, right? So it's Stage Four. We're great. Who is not great? Pretty much everybody else who does polls. If Gallup releases a poll on the same day that NBC releases a poll, people will pay attention to the Gallup poll. Okay, we understand that. So, they were bored. They wanted to change the world. So here is the question someone asked."How could we, instead of just polling what Asia thinks or what the United States thinks, or who thinks what about Obama versus McCain or something like that, what does the entire world think?" And they found a way to do the first-ever world poll. They had people involved who were Nobel laureates in economics, who reported being bored. And suddenly they pulled out sheets of paper and were trying to figure out, "How do we survey the population of Sub-Saharan Africa? How do we survey populations that don't have access to technology, and speak languages we don't speak, and we don't know anyone who speaks those languages. Because in order to achieve on this great mission, we have to be able to do it. Incidentally, they did pull it off. And they released the first-ever world poll.So I'd like to leave you with these thoughts. First of all: we all form tribes, all of us. You're in tribes here. Hopefully you're extending the reach of the tribes that you have. But the question on the table is this: What kind of an impact are the tribes that you are in making? You're hearing one presentation after another, often representing a group of people, a tribe, about how they have changed the world. If you do what we've talked about, you listen for how people actually communicate in the tribes that you're in. And you don't leave them where they are. You nudge them forward. You remember to talk all five culture stages. Because we've got people in all five, around us. And the question that I'd like to leave you with is this: Will your tribes change the world? Thank you very much. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
What we're really here to talk about is the "how."

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
Okay, so how exactly do we create this

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:20.958
world-shattering, if you will, innovation?

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:22.958
Now, I want to tell you a quick story.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
We'll go back a little more than a year.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
In fact, the date -- I'm curious to know

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
if any of you know what happened on this momentous date?

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
It was February 3rd, 2008.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
Anyone remember what happened,

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
February 3rd, 2008?

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:40.958
Super Bowl. I heard it over here. It was the date of the Super Bowl.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:43.958
And the reason that this date was so momentous

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
is that what my colleagues, John King

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
and Halee Fischer-Wright, and I noticed

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
as we began to debrief various Super Bowl parties,

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
is that it seemed to us

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
that across the United States,

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
if you will, tribal councils had convened.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:02.958
And they had discussed things of great national importance.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
Like, "Do we like the Budweiser commercial?"

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
and, "Do we like the nachos?" and, "Who is going to win?"

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:12.958
But they also talked about which candidate they were going to support.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
And if you go back in time to February 3rd,

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:19.958
it looked like Hilary Clinton was going to get the Democratic nomination.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.958
And there were even some polls that were saying she was going to go all the way.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
But when we talked to people,

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
it appeared that a funnel effect had happened

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
in these tribes all across the United States.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
Now what is a tribe? A tribe is a group of

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
about 20 -- so kind of more than a team --

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.958
20 to about 150 people.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
And it's within these tribes that all of our work gets done.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
But not just work. It's within these tribes

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
that societies get built,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
that important things happen.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
And so as we surveyed the, if you will, representatives

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
from various tribal councils that met,

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:53.958
also known as Super Bowl parties,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
we sent the following email off to 40 newspaper editors the following day.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:02:00.958
February 4th, we posted it on our website. This was before Super Tuesday.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
We said, "The tribes that we're in

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
are saying it's going to be Obama."

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
Now, the reason we knew that

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
was because we spent the previous 10 years

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:13.958
studying tribes, studying these naturally occurring groups.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
All of you are members of tribes.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
In walking around at the break,

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
many of you had met members of your tribe. And you were talking to them.

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:25.958
And many of you were doing what great, if you will, tribal leaders do,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
which is to find someone

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
who is a member of a tribe,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
and to find someone else who is another member of a different tribe,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
and make introductions.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
That is in fact what great tribal leaders do.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
So here is the bottom line.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
If you focus in on a group like this --

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
this happens to be a USC game --

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
and you zoom in with one of those super satellite cameras

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:51.958
and do magnification factors so you could see individual people,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
you would in fact see not a single crowd,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
just like there is not a single crowd here,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
but you would see these tribes that are then coming together.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:02.958
And from a distance it appears that it's a single group.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
And so people form tribes.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
They always have. They always will.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
Just as fish swim and birds fly,

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
people form tribes. It's just what we do.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
But here's the rub.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
Not all tribes are the same,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
and what makes the difference is the culture.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
Now here is the net out of this.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
You're all a member of tribes.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
If you can find a way to take the tribes that you're in

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
and nudge them forward,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
along these tribal stages

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
to what we call Stage Five, which is the top of the mountain.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
But we're going to start with what we call Stage One.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
Now, this is the lowest of the stages.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
You don't want this. Okay?

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.958
This is a bit of a difficult image to put up on the screen.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
But it's one that I think we need to learn from.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
Stage One produces people

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
who do horrible things.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
This is the kid who shot up Virginia Tech.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
Stage One is a group where people

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
systematically sever relationships from functional tribes,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
and then pool together

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
with people who think like they do.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
Stage One is literally the culture of gangs

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
and it is the culture of prisons.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
Now, again, we don't often deal with Stage One.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
And I want to make the point

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
that as members of society, we need to.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
It's not enough to simply write people off.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
But let's move on to Stage Two.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
Now, Stage One, you'll notice, says, in effect, "Life Sucks."

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
So, this other book that Steve mentioned,

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
that just came out, called "The Three Laws of Performance,"

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
my colleague, Steve Zaffron and I,

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:30.958
argue that as people see the world, so they behave.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:34.958
Well, if people see the world in such a way that life sucks,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
then their behavior will follow automatically from that.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
It will be despairing hostility.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
They'll do whatever it takes to survive,

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
even if that means undermining other people.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
Now, my birthday is coming up shortly,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
and my driver's license expires.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
And the reason that that's relevant is that very soon

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
I will be walking into what we call

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
a Stage Two tribe,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
which looks like this.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:58.958
(Laughter)

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
Now, am I saying that in every Department of Motor Vehicles

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
across the land, you find a Stage Two culture?

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
No. But in the one near me,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
where I have to go in just a few days,

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
what I will say when I'm standing in line is,

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
"How can people be so dumb, and yet live?"

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
(Laughter)

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
Now, am I saying that there are dumb people working here?

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
Actually, no, I'm not.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
But I'm saying the culture makes people dumb.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
So in a Stage Two culture --

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
and we find these in all sorts of different places --

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
you find them, in fact, in the best organizations in the world.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
You find them in all places in society.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
I've come across them at the organizations

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
that everybody raves about as being best in class.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
But here is the point. If you believe and you say

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
to people in your tribe, in effect,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
"My life sucks.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
I mean, if I got to go to TEDx USC

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
my life wouldn't suck. But I don't. So it does."

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
If that's how you talked, imagine what kind of work would get done.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
What kind of innovation would get done?

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
The amount of world-changing behavior that would happen?

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
In fact it would be basically nil.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
Now when we go on to Stage Three: this is the one

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
that hits closest to home for many of us.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
Because it is in Stage Three that many of us move.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
And we park. And we stay.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:15.958
Stage Three says, "I'm great. And you're not."

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:16.958
(Laughter)

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
I'm great and you're not.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
Now imagine having a whole room of people

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
saying, in effect, "I'm great and you're not."

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Or, "I'm going to find some way to compete with you

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
and come out on top as a result of that."

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
A whole group of people communicating that way, talking that way.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
I know this sounds like a joke. Three doctors walk into a bar.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
But, in this case, three doctors walk into an elevator.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
I happened to be in the elevator collecting data for this book.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
And one doctor said to the others, "Did you see my article

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
in the New England Journal of Medicine?"

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
And the other said, "No. That's great. Congratulations!"

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
The next one got kind of a wry smile on his face and said,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
"Well while you were, you know, doing your research," --

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
notice the condescending tone --

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
"While you were off doing your research, I was off doing more surgeries

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
than anyone else in the department of surgery at this institution."

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
And the third one got the same wry smile and said,

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
"Well, while you were off doing your research,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
and you were off doing your monkey meatball surgery,

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
that eventually we'll train monkeys to do,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
or cells or robots, or maybe not even need to do it at all,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
I was off running the future of the residency program,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
which is really the future of medicine."

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
And they all kind of laughed and they patted him on the back.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
And the elevator door opened, and they all walked out.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
That is a meeting of a Stage Three tribe.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
Now, we find these in places

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
where really smart, successful people show up.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.958
Like, oh, I don't know, TEDx USC.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:36.958
(Laughter)

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
Here is the greatest challenge we face in innovation.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
It is moving from Stage Three

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
to Stage Four.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
Let's take a look at a quick video snippet.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
This is from a company called Zappos, located outside Las Vegas.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
And my question on the other side is just going to be,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
"What do you think they value?"

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:58.958
It was not Christmas time. There was a Christmas tree.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
This is their lobby.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Employees volunteer time in the advice booth.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
Notice it looks like something out of a Peanuts cartoon.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
Okay, we're going through the hallway here at Zappos.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
This is a call center. Notice how it's decorated.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
Notice people are applauding for us.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
They don't know who we are and they don't care. And if they did

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
they probably wouldn't applaud.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
But you'll notice the level of excitement.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
Notice, again, how they decorate their office.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
Now, what's important to people at Zappos,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
these may not be the things that are important to you.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
But they value things like fun. And they value creativity.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
One of their stated values is, "Be a little bit weird."

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:43.958
And you'll notice they are a little bit weird.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
So when individuals come together

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
and find something that unites them

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
that's greater than their individual competence,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
then something very important happens.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
The group gels. And it changes

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
from a group of highly motivated

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
but fairly individually-centric people

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
into something larger,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
into a tribe that becomes aware of its own existence.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
Stage Four tribes can do remarkable things.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
But you'll notice we're not at the top of the mountain yet.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
There is, in fact, another stage.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
Now, some of you may not recognize the scene that's up here.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:20.958
And if you take a look at the headline of Stage Five, which is "Life is Great,"

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
this may seem a little incongruous.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
This is a scene or snippet

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
from the Truth and Reconciliation process in South Africa

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
for which Desmond Tutu won the Nobel Prize.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
Now think about that. South Africa,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
terrible atrocities had happened in the society.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
And people came together

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:41.958
focused only on those two values: truth and reconciliation.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
There was no road map. No one had ever done

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
anything like this before.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
And in this atmosphere, where the only guidance

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
was people's values and their noble cause,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
what this group accomplished was historic.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And people, at the time, feared that South Africa

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
would end up going the way that Rwanda has gone,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
descending into one skirmish after another

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
in a civil war that seems to have no end.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
In fact, South Africa has not gone down that road.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
Largely because people like Desmond Tutu

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
set up a Stage Five process

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
to involve the thousands and perhaps millions

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
of tribes in the country, to bring everyone together.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
So, people hear this and they conclude the following,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
as did we in doing the study.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
Okay, got it. I don't want to talk Stage One.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
That's like, you know, "Life sucks." Who wants to talk that way?

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
I don't want to talk like they do

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
at the particular DMV that's close to where Dave lives.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
I really don't want to just say "I'm great,"

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
because that kind of sounds narcissistic, and then I won't have any friends.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
Saying, "We're great" -- that sounds pretty good.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:43.958
But I should really talk Stage Five, right? "Life is great."

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:47.958
Well, in fact, there are three somewhat counter-intuitive findings

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
that come out of all this.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
The first one, if you look at the Declaration of Independence

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
and actually read it,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
the phrase that sticks in many of our minds

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
is things about inalienable rights.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
I mean, that's Stage Five, right? Life is great,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
oriented only by our values,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
no other guidance.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
In fact, most of the document is written at Stage Two.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
"My life sucks because I live under a tyrant,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
also known as King George.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
We're great! Who is not great? England!"

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
Sorry. (Laughter)

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
Well, what about other great leaders? What about Gandhi?

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
What about Martin Luther King?

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
I mean, surely these were just people who preached, "Life is great," right?

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:28.958
Just one little bit of happiness and joy after another.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:32.958
In fact, Martin Luther King's most famous line was at Stage Three.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
He didn't say "We have a dream." He said, "I have a dream."

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
Why did he do that? Because most people

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
are not at Stage Five.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
Two percent are at Stage One.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:45.958
About 25 percent are at Stage Two,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
saying, in effect, "My life sucks."

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:53.958
48 percent of working tribes say, these are employed tribes,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
say, "I'm great and you're not."

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
And we have to duke it out every day, so we resort to politics.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
Only about 22 percent of tribes

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
are at Stage Four,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
oriented by our values, saying "We're great.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
And our values are beginning to unite us."

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
Only two percent, only two percent of tribes

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
get to Stage Five.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
And those are the ones that change the world.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
So the first little finding from this

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
is that leaders need to be able to talk all the levels

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
so that you can touch every person in society.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
But you don't leave them where you found them. Okay?

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:28.958
Tribes can only hear one level above and below where they are.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
So we have to have the ability to talk

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
all the levels, to go to where they are.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
And then leaders nudge people

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
within their tribes to the next level.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
I'd like to show you some examples of this.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
One of the people we interviewed was Frank Jordan,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
former Mayor of San Francisco. Before that

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
he was Chief of Police in San Francisco.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
And he grew up essentially in Stage One.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
And you know what changed his life? It was walking into

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
one of these, a Boys and Girls Club.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
Now here is what happened to this person

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
who eventually became Mayor of San Francisco.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
He went from being alive and passionate

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
at Stage One -- remember, "Life sucks,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
despairing hostility, I will do whatever it takes to survive" --

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
to walking into a Boys and Girls Club,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
folding his arms, sitting down in a chair,

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
and saying, "Wow. My life really sucks.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
I don't know anybody.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
I mean, if I was into boxing, like they were,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
then my life wouldn't suck. But I don't. So it does.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
So I'm going to sit here in my chair and not do anything."

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
In fact, that's progress.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
We move people from Stage One to Stage Two

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
by getting them in a new tribe

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
and then, over time, getting them connected.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
So, what about moving

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
from Stage Three to Stage Four?

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
I want to argue that we're doing that right here.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
TED represents a set of values,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
and as we unite around these values,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
something really interesting begins to emerge.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
If you want this experience to live on

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
as something historic,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
then at the reception tonight I'd like to encourage you to do something

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
beyond what people normally do

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
and call networking.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
Which is not just to meet new people

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
and extend your reach, extend your influence,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
but instead, find someone you don't know,

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
and find someone else you don't know,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
and introduce them.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
That's called a triadic relationship.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
See, people who build world-changing tribes do that.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
They extend the reach of their tribes

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
by connecting them, not just to myself,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
so that my following is greater,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
but I connect people who don't know each other

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
to something greater than themselves.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
And ultimately that adds to their values.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:32.958
But we're not done yet. Because then how do we go from Stage Four,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
which is great, to Stage Five?

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
The story that I like to end with is this. It comes out of

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
a place called the Gallup Organization.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
You know they do polls, right?

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
So it's Stage Four. We're great. Who is not great?

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
Pretty much everybody else who does polls.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
If Gallup releases a poll on the same day that NBC releases a poll,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
people will pay attention to the Gallup poll. Okay, we understand that.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
So, they were bored.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
They wanted to change the world. So here is the question someone asked.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
"How could we,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
instead of just polling what Asia thinks

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
or what the United States thinks,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
or who thinks what about Obama

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
versus McCain or something like that,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.958
what does the entire world think?"

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
And they found a way to do the first-ever world poll.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
They had people involved who were Nobel laureates

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
in economics, who reported being bored.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
And suddenly they pulled out sheets of paper

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
and were trying to figure out, "How do we survey the population

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
of Sub-Saharan Africa?

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
How do we survey populations that don't have access to technology,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
and speak languages we don't speak,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
and we don't know anyone who speaks those languages. Because in order

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
to achieve on this great mission,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
we have to be able to do it.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
Incidentally, they did pull it off.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
And they released the first-ever world poll.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
So I'd like to leave you with these thoughts.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
First of all: we all form tribes, all of us.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
You're in tribes here. Hopefully you're extending the reach

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
of the tribes that you have.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
But the question on the table is this:

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
What kind of an impact are the tribes

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
that you are in making?

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
You're hearing one presentation after another,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
often representing a group of people, a tribe,

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
about how they have changed the world.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
If you do what we've talked about, you listen

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
for how people actually communicate in the tribes that you're in.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
And you don't leave them where they are. You nudge them forward.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
You remember to talk all five culture stages.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
Because we've got people in all five, around us.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
And the question that I'd like to leave you with is this:

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
Will your tribes change the world?

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
Thank you very much.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
(Applause)

title: The danger of a single story
transcript: I'm a storyteller. And I would like to tell you a few personal stories about what I like to call "the danger of the single story." I grew up on a university campus in eastern Nigeria. My mother says that I started reading at the age of two, although I think four is probably close to the truth. So I was an early reader, and what I read were British and American children's books.I was also an early writer, and when I began to write, at about the age of seven, stories in pencil with crayon illustrations that my poor mother was obligated to read, I wrote exactly the kinds of stories I was reading: All my characters were white and blue-eyed, they played in the snow, they ate apples,(Laughter)and they talked a lot about the weather, how lovely it was that the sun had come out.(Laughter)Now, this despite the fact that I lived in Nigeria. I had never been outside Nigeria. We didn't have snow, we ate mangoes, and we never talked about the weather, because there was no need to.My characters also drank a lot of ginger beer, because the characters in the British books I read drank ginger beer. Never mind that I had no idea what ginger beer was.(Laughter)And for many years afterwards, I would have a desperate desire to taste ginger beer. But that is another story.What this demonstrates, I think, is how impressionable and vulnerable we are in the face of a story, particularly as children. Because all I had read were books in which characters were foreign, I had become convinced that books by their very nature had to have foreigners in them and had to be about things with which I could not personally identify. Now, things changed when I discovered African books. There weren't many of them available, and they weren't quite as easy to find as the foreign books.But because of writers like Chinua Achebe and Camara Laye, I went through a mental shift in my perception of literature. I realized that people like me, girls with skin the color of chocolate, whose kinky hair could not form ponytails, could also exist in literature. I started to write about things I recognized.Now, I loved those American and British books I read. They stirred my imagination. They opened up new worlds for me. But the unintended consequence was that I did not know that people like me could exist in literature. So what the discovery of African writers did for me was this: It saved me from having a single story of what books are.I come from a conventional, middle-class Nigerian family. My father was a professor. My mother was an administrator. And so we had, as was the norm, live-in domestic help, who would often come from nearby rural villages. So, the year I turned eight, we got a new house boy. His name was Fide. The only thing my mother told us about him was that his family was very poor. My mother sent yams and rice, and our old clothes, to his family. And when I didn't finish my dinner, my mother would say, "Finish your food! Don't you know? People like Fide's family have nothing." So I felt enormous pity for Fide's family.Then one Saturday, we went to his village to visit, and his mother showed us a beautifully patterned basket made of dyed raffia that his brother had made. I was startled. It had not occurred to me that anybody in his family could actually make something. All I had heard about them was how poor they were, so that it had become impossible for me to see them as anything else but poor. Their poverty was my single story of them.Years later, I thought about this when I left Nigeria to go to university in the United States. I was 19. My American roommate was shocked by me. She asked where I had learned to speak English so well, and was confused when I said that Nigeria happened to have English as its official language. She asked if she could listen to what she called my "tribal music," and was consequently very disappointed when I produced my tape of Mariah Carey.(Laughter)She assumed that I did not know how to use a stove.What struck me was this: She had felt sorry for me even before she saw me. Her default position toward me, as an African, was a kind of patronizing, well-meaning pity. My roommate had a single story of Africa: a single story of catastrophe. In this single story, there was no possibility of Africans being similar to her in any way, no possibility of feelings more complex than pity, no possibility of a connection as human equals.I must say that before I went to the U.S., I didn't consciously identify as African. But in the U.S., whenever Africa came up, people turned to me. Never mind that I knew nothing about places like Namibia. But I did come to embrace this new identity, and in many ways I think of myself now as African. Although I still get quite irritable when Africa is referred to as a country, the most recent example being my otherwise wonderful flight from Lagos two days ago, in which there was an announcement on the Virgin flight about the charity work in "India, Africa and other countries."(Laughter)So, after I had spent some years in the U.S. as an African, I began to understand my roommate's response to me. If I had not grown up in Nigeria, and if all I knew about Africa were from popular images, I too would think that Africa was a place of beautiful landscapes, beautiful animals, and incomprehensible people, fighting senseless wars, dying of poverty and AIDS, unable to speak for themselves and waiting to be saved by a kind, white foreigner. I would see Africans in the same way that I, as a child, had seen Fide's family.This single story of Africa ultimately comes, I think, from Western literature. Now, here is a quote from the writing of a London merchant called John Lok, who sailed to west Africa in 1561 and kept a fascinating account of his voyage. After referring to the black Africans as "beasts who have no houses," he writes, "They are also people without heads, having their mouth and eyes in their breasts."Now, I've laughed every time I've read this. And one must admire the imagination of John Lok. But what is important about his writing is that it represents the beginning of a tradition of telling African stories in the West: A tradition of Sub-Saharan Africa as a place of negatives, of difference, of darkness, of people who, in the words of the wonderful poet Rudyard Kipling, are "half devil, half child."And so, I began to realize that my American roommate must have throughout her life seen and heard different versions of this single story, as had a professor, who once told me that my novel was not "authentically African." Now, I was quite willing to contend that there were a number of things wrong with the novel, that it had failed in a number of places, but I had not quite imagined that it had failed at achieving something called African authenticity. In fact, I did not know what African authenticity was. The professor told me that my characters were too much like him, an educated and middle-class man. My characters drove cars. They were not starving. Therefore they were not authentically African.But I must quickly add that I too am just as guilty in the question of the single story. A few years ago, I visited Mexico from the U.S. The political climate in the U.S. at the time was tense, and there were debates going on about immigration. And, as often happens in America, immigration became synonymous with Mexicans. There were endless stories of Mexicans as people who were fleecing the healthcare system, sneaking across the border, being arrested at the border, that sort of thing.I remember walking around on my first day in Guadalajara, watching the people going to work, rolling up tortillas in the marketplace, smoking, laughing. I remember first feeling slight surprise. And then, I was overwhelmed with shame. I realized that I had been so immersed in the media coverage of Mexicans that they had become one thing in my mind, the abject immigrant. I had bought into the single story of Mexicans and I could not have been more ashamed of myself.So that is how to create a single story, show a people as one thing, as only one thing, over and over again, and that is what they become.It is impossible to talk about the single story without talking about power. There is a word, an Igbo word, that I think about whenever I think about the power structures of the world, and it is "nkali." It's a noun that loosely translates to "to be greater than another." Like our economic and political worlds, stories too are defined by the principle of nkali: How they are told, who tells them, when they're told, how many stories are told, are really dependent on power.Power is the ability not just to tell the story of another person, but to make it the definitive story of that person. The Palestinian poet Mourid Barghouti writes that if you want to dispossess a people, the simplest way to do it is to tell their story and to start with, "secondly." Start the story with the arrows of the Native Americans, and not with the arrival of the British, and you have an entirely different story. Start the story with the failure of the African state, and not with the colonial creation of the African state, and you have an entirely different story.I recently spoke at a university where a student told me that it was such a shame that Nigerian men were physical abusers like the father character in my novel. I told him that I had just read a novel called "American Psycho" —(Laughter)— and that it was such a shame that young Americans were serial murderers.(Laughter)(Applause)Now, obviously I said this in a fit of mild irritation.(Laughter)But it would never have occurred to me to think that just because I had read a novel in which a character was a serial killer that he was somehow representative of all Americans. This is not because I am a better person than that student, but because of America's cultural and economic power, I had many stories of America. I had read Tyler and Updike and Steinbeck and Gaitskill. I did not have a single story of America.When I learned, some years ago, that writers were expected to have had really unhappy childhoods to be successful, I began to think about how I could invent horrible things my parents had done to me.(Laughter)But the truth is that I had a very happy childhood, full of laughter and love, in a very close-knit family.But I also had grandfathers who died in refugee camps. My cousin Polle died because he could not get adequate healthcare. One of my closest friends, Okoloma, died in a plane crash because our fire trucks did not have water. I grew up under repressive military governments that devalued education, so that sometimes, my parents were not paid their salaries. And so, as a child, I saw jam disappear from the breakfast table, then margarine disappeared, then bread became too expensive, then milk became rationed. And most of all, a kind of normalized political fear invaded our lives.All of these stories make me who I am. But to insist on only these negative stories is to flatten my experience and to overlook the many other stories that formed me. The single story creates stereotypes, and the problem with stereotypes is not that they are untrue, but that they are incomplete. They make one story become the only story.Of course, Africa is a continent full of catastrophes: There are immense ones, such as the horrific rapes in Congo and depressing ones, such as the fact that 5,000 people apply for one job vacancy in Nigeria. But there are other stories that are not about catastrophe, and it is very important, it is just as important, to talk about them.I've always felt that it is impossible to engage properly with a place or a person without engaging with all of the stories of that place and that person. The consequence of the single story is this: It robs people of dignity. It makes our recognition of our equal humanity difficult. It emphasizes how we are different rather than how we are similar.So what if before my Mexican trip, I had followed the immigration debate from both sides, the U.S. and the Mexican? What if my mother had told us that Fide's family was poor and hardworking? What if we had an African television network that broadcast diverse African stories all over the world? What the Nigerian writer Chinua Achebe calls "a balance of stories."What if my roommate knew about my Nigerian publisher, Muhtar Bakare, a remarkable man who left his job in a bank to follow his dream and start a publishing house? Now, the conventional wisdom was that Nigerians don't read literature. He disagreed. He felt that people who could read, would read, if you made literature affordable and available to them.Shortly after he published my first novel, I went to a TV station in Lagos to do an interview, and a woman who worked there as a messenger came up to me and said, "I really liked your novel. I didn't like the ending. Now, you must write a sequel, and this is what will happen ..."(Laughter)And she went on to tell me what to write in the sequel. I was not only charmed, I was very moved. Here was a woman, part of the ordinary masses of Nigerians, who were not supposed to be readers. She had not only read the book, but she had taken ownership of it and felt justified in telling me what to write in the sequel.Now, what if my roommate knew about my friend Funmi Iyanda, a fearless woman who hosts a TV show in Lagos, and is determined to tell the stories that we prefer to forget? What if my roommate knew about the heart procedure that was performed in the Lagos hospital last week? What if my roommate knew about contemporary Nigerian music, talented people singing in English and Pidgin, and Igbo and Yoruba and Ijo, mixing influences from Jay-Z to Fela to Bob Marley to their grandfathers.What if my roommate knew about the female lawyer who recently went to court in Nigeria to challenge a ridiculous law that required women to get their husband's consent before renewing their passports? What if my roommate knew about Nollywood, full of innovative people making films despite great technical odds, films so popular that they really are the best example of Nigerians consuming what they produce? What if my roommate knew about my wonderfully ambitious hair braider, who has just started her own business selling hair extensions? Or about the millions of other Nigerians who start businesses and sometimes fail, but continue to nurse ambition?Every time I am home I am confronted with the usual sources of irritation for most Nigerians: our failed infrastructure, our failed government, but also by the incredible resilience of people who thrive despite the government, rather than because of it. I teach writing workshops in Lagos every summer, and it is amazing to me how many people apply, how many people are eager to write, to tell stories.My Nigerian publisher and I have just started a non-profit called Farafina Trust, and we have big dreams of building libraries and refurbishing libraries that already exist and providing books for state schools that don't have anything in their libraries, and also of organizing lots and lots of workshops, in reading and writing, for all the people who are eager to tell our many stories.Stories matter. Many stories matter. Stories have been used to dispossess and to malign, but stories can also be used to empower and to humanize. Stories can break the dignity of a people, but stories can also repair that broken dignity.The American writer Alice Walker wrote this about her Southern relatives who had moved to the North. She introduced them to a book about the Southern life that they had left behind. "They sat around, reading the book themselves, listening to me read the book, and a kind of paradise was regained."I would like to end with this thought: That when we reject the single story, when we realize that there is never a single story about any place, we regain a kind of paradise.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.934
I'm a storyteller.

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:16.934
And I would like to tell you
a few personal stories

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:21.934
about what I like to call
"the danger of the single story."

00:00:22.704 --> 00:00:25.934
I grew up on a university campus
in eastern Nigeria.

00:00:26.116 --> 00:00:29.425
My mother says that I started
reading at the age of two,

00:00:29.449 --> 00:00:32.465
although I think four
is probably close to the truth.

00:00:33.711 --> 00:00:35.522
So I was an early reader,

00:00:35.546 --> 00:00:38.934
and what I read were British
and American children's books.

00:00:39.664 --> 00:00:41.934
I was also an early writer,

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:45.934
and when I began to write,
at about the age of seven,
