00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
It's energy that creates extraordinary interviews

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
and extraordinary lives.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
I'm convinced of it.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.958
And it had nothing to do with the energy of being young.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
These were people through their 90s.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
In fact, the first person I interviewed

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
was George Abbott, who was 97,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
and Abbott was filled with the life force --

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
I guess that's the way I think about it -- filled with it.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
And so he filled the room,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
and we had an extraordinary conversation.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
He was supposed to be the toughest interview that anybody would ever do

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:59.958
because he was famous for being silent,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
for never ever saying anything

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
except maybe a word or two.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
And, in fact, he did wind up opening up --

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:09.958
by the way, his energy is evidenced in other ways.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
He subsequently got married again at 102,

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:16.958
so he, you know, he had a lot of the life force in him.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
But after the interview, I got a call,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.958
very gruff voice, from a woman.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
I didn't know who she was,

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:28.958
and she said, "Did you get George Abbott to talk?"

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
And I said, "Yeah. Apparently I did."

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.958
And she said, "I'm his old girlfriend, Maureen Stapleton,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and I could never do it."

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
And then she made me go up with the tape of it

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
and prove that George Abbott actually could talk.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
So, you know, you want energy,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
you want the life force,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:51.958
but you really want them also to think

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:55.958
that they have a story worth sharing.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
The worst interviews that you can ever have

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
are with people who are modest.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
Never ever get up on a stage with somebody who's modest,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
because all of these people have been assembled

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
to listen to them, and they sit there and they say,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
"Aw, shucks, it was an accident."

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
There's nothing that ever happens that justifies

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:19.958
people taking good hours of the day to be with them.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
The worst interview I ever did: William L. Shirer.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:27.958
The journalist who did "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich."

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:31.958
This guy had met Hitler and Gandhi within six months,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
and every time I'd ask him about it, he'd say, "Oh, I just happened to be there.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
Didn't matter." Whatever.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
Awful.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
I never would ever agree to interview a modest person.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
They have to think that they did something

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
and that they want to share it with you.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:50.958
But it comes down, in the end,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:57.958
to how do you get through all the barriers we have.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
All of us are public and private beings,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:06.958
and if all you're going to get from the interviewee is their public self,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
there's no point in it.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
It's pre-programmed. It's infomercial,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
and we all have infomercials about our lives.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
We know the great lines, we know the great moments,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
we know what we're not going to share,

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
and the point of this was not to embarrass anybody.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
This wasn't -- and some of you will remember

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
Mike Wallace's old interviews --

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
tough, aggressive and so forth. They have their place.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:33.958
I was trying to get them to say what they probably wanted to say,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:40.958
to break out of their own cocoon of the public self,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and the more public they had been,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:47.958
the more entrenched that person, that outer person was.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
And let me tell you at once the worse moment and the best moment

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
that happened in this interview series.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:57.958
It all has to do with that shell that most of us have,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
and particularly certain people.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
There's an extraordinary woman named Clare Boothe Luce.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
It'll be your generational determinant

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
as to whether her name means much to you.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:14.958
She did so much. She was a playwright.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
She did an extraordinary play called "The Women."

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
She was a congresswoman

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
when there weren't very many congresswomen.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
She was editor of Vanity Fair,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:28.958
one of the great phenomenal women of her day.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
And, incidentally, I call her

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
the Eleanor Roosevelt of the Right.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
She was sort of adored on the Right

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
the way Eleanor Roosevelt was on the Left.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
And, in fact, when we did the interview --

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
I did the living self-portrait with her --

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
there were three former directors of the CIA

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
basically sitting at her feet,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
just enjoying her presence.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
And I thought, this is going to be a piece of cake,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:57.958
because I always have preliminary talks with these people

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
for just maybe 10 or 15 minutes.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
We never talk before that because if you talk before,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
you don't get it on the stage.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:09.958
So she and I had a delightful conversation.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
We were on the stage and then --

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
by the way, spectacular.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
It was all part of Clare Boothe Luce's look.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
She was in a great evening gown.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
She was 80, almost that day of the interview,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
and there she was and there I was,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
and I just proceeded into the questions.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:32.958
And she stonewalled me. It was unbelievable.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:37.958
Anything that I would ask, she would turn around, dismiss,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
and I was basically up there -- any of you

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
in the moderate-to-full entertainment world

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
know what it is to die onstage.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:49.958
And I was dying. She was absolutely not giving me a thing.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
And I began to wonder what was going on,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
and you think while you talk,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
and basically, I thought, I got it.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
When we were alone, I was her audience.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Now I'm her competitor for the audience.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:06.958
That's the problem here, and she's fighting me for that,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
and so then I asked her a question --

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
I didn't know how I was going to get out of it --

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:16.958
I asked her a question about her days as a playwright,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
and again, characteristically,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
instead of saying, "Oh yes, I was a playwright, and this is what blah blah blah,"

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
she said, "Oh, playwright. Everybody knows I was a playwright.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:28.958
Most people think that I was an actress. I was never an actress."

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:32.958
But I hadn't asked that, and then she went off on a tear,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
and she said, "Oh, well, there was that one time that I was an actress.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
It was for a charity in Connecticut when I was a congresswoman,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
and I got up there," and she went on and on, "And then I got on the stage."

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
And then she turned to me and said,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
"And you know what those young actors did?

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
They upstaged me." And she said, "Do you know what that is?"

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
Just withering in her contempt.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
And I said, "I'm learning."

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
(Laughter)

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:59.958
And she looked at me, and it was like the successful arm-wrestle,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:03.958
and then, after that, she delivered an extraordinary account

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
of what her life really was like.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
I have to end that one. This is my tribute to Clare Boothe Luce.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
Again, a remarkable person.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
I'm not politically attracted to her, but through her life force,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
I'm attracted to her.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:21.958
And the way she died -- she had, toward the end, a brain tumor.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
That's probably as terrible a way to die as you can imagine,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:30.958
and very few of us were invited to a dinner party.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
And she was in horrible pain.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
We all knew that.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
She stayed in her room.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
Everybody came. The butler passed around canapes.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
The usual sort of thing.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
Then at a certain moment, the door opened

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.958
and she walked out perfectly dressed, completely composed.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:53.958
The public self, the beauty, the intellect,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:57.958
and she walked around and talked to every person there

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
and then went back into the room and was never seen again.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:06.958
She wanted the control of her final moment, and she did it amazingly.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
Now, there are other ways that you get somebody to open up,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:14.958
and this is just a brief reference.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
It wasn't this arm-wrestle,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
but it was a little surprising for the person involved.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
I interviewed Steve Martin. It wasn't all that long ago.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
And we were sitting there,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
and almost toward the beginning of the interview,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:32.958
I turned to him and I said, "Steve," or "Mr. Martin,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:38.958
it is said that all comedians have unhappy childhoods.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
Was yours unhappy?"

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
And he looked at me, you know, as if to say,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
"This is how you're going to start this thing, right off?"

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
And then he turned to me, not stupidly,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
and he said, "What was your childhood like?"

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
And I said -- these are all arm wrestles, but they're affectionate --

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
and I said, "My father was loving and supportive,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
which is why I'm not funny."

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
(Laughter)

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:06.958
And he looked at me, and then we heard the big sad story.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
His father was an SOB,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:12.958
and, in fact, he was another comedian with an unhappy childhood,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
but then we were off and running.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:16.958
So the question is:

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
What is the key that's going to allow this to proceed?

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
Now, these are arm wrestle questions,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
but I want to tell you about questions

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
that are more related to empathy

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
and that really, very often, are the questions

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
that people have been waiting their whole lives to be asked.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:37.958
And I'll just give you two examples of this because of the time constraints.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:43.958
One was an interview I did with one of the great American biographers.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
Again, some of you will know him, most of you won't, Dumas Malone.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:49.958
He did a five-volume biography of Thomas Jefferson,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:54.958
spent virtually his whole life with Thomas Jefferson,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
and by the way, at one point I asked him,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
"Would you like to have met him?"

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
And he said, "Well, of course,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
but actually, I know him better than anyone who ever met him,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
because I got to read all of his letters."

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:11.958
So, he was very satisfied with the kind of relationship they had over 50 years.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
And I asked him one question.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
I said, "Did Jefferson ever disappoint you?"

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:23.958
And here is this man who had given his whole life to uncovering Jefferson

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
and connecting with him,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:30.958
and he said, "Well ..." -- I'm going to do a bad southern accent.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:33.958
Dumas Malone was from Mississippi originally.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
But he said, "Well," he said, "I'm afraid so."

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
He said, "You know, I've read everything,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:48.958
and sometimes Mr. Jefferson would smooth the truth a bit."

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
And he basically was saying that this was a man

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
who lied more than he wished he had,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
because he saw the letters.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:00.958
He said, "But I understand that." He said, "I understand that."

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:05.958
He said, "We southerners do like a smooth surface,

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:09.958
so that there were times when he just didn't want the confrontation."

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.958
And he said, "Now, John Adams was too honest."

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
And he started to talk about that, and later on he invited me to his house,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
and I met his wife who was from Massachusetts,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
and he and she had exactly the relationship

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
of Thomas Jefferson and John Adams.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
She was the New Englander and abrasive,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
and he was this courtly fellow.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
But really the most important question I ever asked,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
and most of the times when I talk about it,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:40.958
people kind of suck in their breath at my audacity, or cruelty,

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:44.958
but I promise you it was the right question.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
This was to Agnes de Mille.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
Agnes de Mille is one of the great choreographers in our history.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:55.958
She basically created the dances in "Oklahoma,"

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
transforming the American theater.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
An amazing woman.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:04.958
At the time that I proposed to her that --

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
by the way, I would have proposed to her; she was extraordinary --

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
but proposed to her that she come on.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
She said, "Come to my apartment."

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
She lived in New York.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:16.958
"Come to my apartment and we'll talk for those 15 minutes,

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
and then we'll decide whether we proceed."

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:23.958
And so I showed up in this dark, rambling New York apartment,

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
and she called out to me, and she was in bed.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
I had known that she had had a stroke,

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:30.958
and that was some 10 years before.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:35.958
And so she spent almost all of her life in bed,

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
but -- I speak of the life force --

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
her hair was askew.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:42.958
She wasn't about to make up for this occasion.

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.958
And she was sitting there surrounded by books,

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:49.958
and her most interesting possession she felt at that moment

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:55.958
was her will, which she had by her side.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:59.958
She wasn't unhappy about this. She was resigned.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:05.958
She said, "I keep this will by my bed, memento mori,

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
and I change it all the time

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
just because I want to."

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:15.958
And she was loving the prospect of death as much as she had loved life.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:18.958
I thought, this is somebody I've got to get in this series.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:20.958
She agreed.

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:23.958
She came on. Of course she was wheelchaired on.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:26.958
Half of her body was stricken, the other half not.

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:29.958
She was, of course, done up for the occasion,

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:33.958
but this was a woman in great physical distress.

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
And we had a conversation,

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:39.958
and then I asked her this unthinkable question.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:48.958
I said, "Was it a problem for you in your life that you were not beautiful?"

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:51.958
And the audience just -- you know,

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:54.958
they're always on the side of the interviewee,

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:57.958
and they felt that this was a kind of assault,

00:18:57.958 --> 00:18:59.958
but this was the question she had

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:02.958
wanted somebody to ask her whole life.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:07.958
And she began to talk about her childhood, when she was beautiful,

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:10.958
and she literally turned -- here she was, in this broken body --

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:13.958
and she turned to the audience and

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:15.958
described herself as the fair demoiselle

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:21.958
with her red hair and her light steps and so forth,

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:24.958
and then she said, "And then puberty hit."

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:26.958
And she began to talk about things that had happened

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:28.958
to her body and her face,

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:32.958
and how she could no longer count on her beauty,

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:39.958
and her family then treated her like the ugly sister of the beautiful one

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:41.958
for whom all the ballet lessons were given.

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:46.958
And she had to go along just to be with her sister for company,

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:49.958
and in that process, she made a number of decisions.

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:51.958
First of all, was that dance, even though

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:53.958
it hadn't been offered to her, was her life.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:55.958
And secondly, she had better be,

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:57.958
although she did dance for a while, a choreographer

title: How low-cost eye care can be world-class
transcript: Good morning. I've come here to share with you an experiment of how to get rid of one form of human suffering. It really is a story of Dr. Venkataswamy. His mission and his message is about the Aravind Eye Care System. I think first it's important for us to recognize what it is to be blind.(Music)Woman: Everywhere I went looking for work, they said no, what use do we have for a blind woman? I couldn't thread a needle or see the lice in my hair. If an ant fell into my rice, I couldn't see that either.Thulasiraj Ravilla: Becoming blind is a big part of it, but I think it also deprives the person of their livelihood, their dignity, their independence, and their status in the family. So she is just one amongst the millions who are blind. And the irony is that they don't need to be.A simple, well-proven surgery can restore sight to millions, and something even simpler, a pair of glasses, can make millions more see. If we add to that the many of us here now who are more productive because they have a pair of glasses, then almost one in five Indians will require eye care, a staggering 200 million people. Today, we're reaching not even 10 percent of them.So this is the context in which Aravind came into existence about 30 years back as a post-retirement project of Dr. V. He started this with no money. He had to mortgage all his life savings to make a bank loan. And over time, we have grown into a network of five hospitals, predominately in the state of Tamil Nadu and Puducherry, and then we added several, what we call Vision Centers as a hub-and-spoke model. And then more recently we started managing hospitals in other parts of the country and also setting up hospitals in other parts of the world as well.The last three decades, we have done about three-and-a-half million surgeries, a vast majority of them for the poor people. Now, each year we perform about 300,000 surgeries. A typical day at Aravind, we would do about a thousand surgeries, maybe see about 6,000 patients, send out teams into the villages to examine, bring back patients, lots of telemedicine consultations, and, on top of that, do a lot of training, both for doctors and technicians who will become the future staff of Aravind.And then doing this day-in and day-out, and doing it well, requires a lot of inspiration and a lot of hard work. And I think this was possible thanks to the building blocks put in place by Dr. V., a value system, an efficient delivery process, and fostering the culture of innovation.(Music)Dr. V: I used to sit with the ordinary village man because I am from a village, and suddenly you turn around and seem to be in contact with his inner being, you seem to be one with him. Here is a soul which has got all the simplicity of confidence. Doctor, whatever you say, I accept it. An implicit faith in you and then you respond to it. Here is an old lady who has got so much faith in me, I must do my best for her. When we grow in spiritual consciousness, we identify ourselves with all that is in the world, so there is no exploitation. It is ourselves we are helping. It is ourselves we are healing.(Applause)This helped us build a very ethical and very highly patient-centric organization and systems that support it. But on a practical level, you also have to deliver services efficiently, and, odd as it may seem, the inspiration came from McDonald's.Dr. V: See, McDonald's' concept is simple. They feel they can train people all over the world, irrespective of different religions, cultures, all those things, to produce a product in the same way and deliver it in the same manner in hundreds of places.Larry Brilliant: He kept talking about McDonalds and hamburgers, and none of it made any sense to us. He wanted to create a franchise, a mechanism of delivery of eye care with the efficiency of McDonald's.Dr. V: Supposing I'm able to produce eye care, techniques, methods, all in the same way, and make it available in every corner of the world. The problem of blindness is gone.TR: If you think about it, I think the eyeball is the same, as American or African, the problem is the same, the treatment is the same. And yet, why should there be so much variation in quality and in service, and that was the fundamental principle that we followed when we designed the delivery systems. And, of course, the challenge was that it's a huge problem, we are talking of millions of people, very little resource to deal with it, and then lots of logistics and affordability issues.And then so, one had to constantly innovate. And one of the early innovations, which still continues, is to create ownership in the community to the problem, and then engage with them as a partner, and here is one such event. Here a community camp just organized by the community themselves, where they find a place, organize volunteers, and then we'll do our part. You know, check their vision, and then you have doctors who you find out what the problem is and then determine what further testing should be done, and then those tests are done by technicians who check for glasses, or check for glaucoma.And then, with all these results, the doctor makes a final diagnosis, and then prescribes a line of treatment, and if they need a pair of glasses, they are available right there at the camp site, usually under a tree. But they get glasses in the frames of their choice, and that's very important because I think glasses, in addition to helping people see, is also a fashion statement, and they're willing to pay for it. So they get it in about 20 minutes and those who require surgery, are counseled, and then there are buses waiting, which will transport them to the base hospital.And if it was not for this kind of logistics and support, many people like this would probably never get services, and certainly not when they most need it. They receive surgery the following day, and then they will stay for a day or two, and then they are put back on the buses to be taken back to where they came from, and where their families will be waiting to take them back home.(Applause)And this happens several thousand times each year. It may sound impressive that we're seeing lots of patients, very efficient process, but we looked at, are we solving the problem? We did a study, a scientifically designed process, and then, to our dismay, we found this was only reaching seven percent of those in need, and we're not adequately addressing more, bigger problems.So we had to do something different, so we set up what we call primary eye care centers, vision centers. These are truly paperless offices with completely electronic medical records and so on. They receive comprehensive eye exams. We kind of changed the simple digital camera into a retinal camera, and then every patient gets their teleconsultation with a doctor.The effect of this has been that, within the first year, we really had a 40 percent penetration in the market that it served, which is over 50,000 people. And the second year went up to 75 percent. So I think we have a process by which we can really penetrate into the market and reach everyone who needs it, and in this process of using technology, make sure that most don't need to come to the base hospital.And how much will they pay for this? We fixed the pricing, taking into account what they would save in bus fare in coming to a city, so they pay about 20 rupees, and that's good for three consultations.(Applause)The other challenge was, how do you give high-tech or more advanced treatment and care? We designed a van with a VSAT, which sends out images of patients to the base hospital where it is diagnosed, and then as the patient is waiting, the report goes back to the patient, it gets printed out, the patient gets it, and then gets a consultation about what they should be doing — I mean, go see a doctor or come back after six months, and then this happens as a way of bridging the technology competence.So the impact of all this has been essentially one of growing the market, because it focused on the non-customer, and then by reaching the unreached, we're able to significantly grow the market.The other aspect is how do you deal with this efficiently when you have very few ophthalmologists? So what is in this video is a surgeon operating, and then you see on the other side, another patient is getting ready. So, as they finish the surgery, they just swing the microscope over, the tables are placed so that their distance is just right, and then we need to do this, because, by doing this kind of process, we're able to more than quadruple the productivity of the surgeon.And then to support the surgeon, we require a certain workforce. And then we focused on village girls that we recruited, and then they really are the backbone of the organization. They do almost all of the skill-based routine tasks. They do one thing at a time. They do it extremely well. With the result we have very high productivity, very high quality at very, very low cost. So, putting all this together, what really happened was the productivity of our staff was significantly higher than anyone else.(Applause)This is a very busy table, but what this really is conveying is that, when it comes to quality, we have put in very good quality-assurance systems. As a result, our complications are significantly lower than what has been reported in the United Kingdom, and you don't see those kind of numbers very often.(Applause)So the final part of the puzzle is, how do you make all this work financially, especially when the people can't pay for it? So what we did was, we gave away a lot of it for free, and then those who pay, I mean, they paid local market rates, nothing more, and often much less. And we were helped by the market inefficiency. I think that has been a big savior, even now. And, of course, one needs the mindset to be wanting to give away what you have as a surplus.The result has been, over the years, the expenditure has increased with volumes. The revenues increase at a higher level, giving us a healthy margin while you're treating a large number of people for free. I think in absolute terms, last year we earned about 20-odd million dollars, spent about 13 million, with over a 40 percent EBITA.(Applause)But this really requires going beyond what we do, or what we have done, if you really want to achieve solving this problem of blindness. And what we did was a couple of very counter-intuitive things. We created competition for ourselves, and then we made eye care affordable by making low-cost consumables. We proactively and systematically promoted these practices to many hospitals in India, many in our own backyards and then in other parts of the world as well. The impact of this has been that these hospitals, in the second year after our consultation, are double their output and then achieve financial recovery as well.The other part was how do you address this increase in cost of technology? There was a time when we failed to negotiate the [intra-ocular lens] prices to be at affordable levels, so we set up a manufacturing unit. And then, over time, we were able to bring down the cost significantly to about two percent of what it used to be when we started out. Today, we believe we have about seven percent of the global market, and they're used in about 120-odd countries.To conclude, I mean, what we do, does it have a broader relevance, or is it just India or developing countries? So to address this, we studied UK versus Aravind. What it shows is that we do roughly about 60 percent of the volume of what the UK does, near a half-million surgeries as a whole country. And we do about 300,000. And then we train about 50 ophthalmologists against the 70 trained by them, comparable quality, both in training and in patient care. So we're really comparing apples to apples. We looked at cost. (Laughter)(Applause)So, I think it is simple to say just because the U.K. isn't India the difference is happening. I think there is more to it. I mean, I think one has to look at other aspects as well. Maybe there is — the solution to the cost could be in productivity, maybe in efficiency, in the clinical process, or in how much they pay for the lenses or consumables, or regulations, their defensive practice. So, I think decoding this can probably bring answers to most developed countries including the U.S., and maybe Obama's ratings can go up again.(Laughter)Another insight, which, again, I want to leave with you, in conditions where the problem is very large, which cuts across all economic strata, where we have a good solution, I think the process I described, you know, productivity, quality, patient-centered care, can give an answer, and there are many which fit this paradigm. You take dentistry, hearing aid, maternity and so on. There are many where this paradigm can now play, but I think probably one of the most challenging things is on the softer side.Now, how do you create compassion? Now, how do you make people own the problem, want to do something about it? There are a bit harder issues. And I'm sure people in this crowd can probably find the solutions to these.So I want to end my talk leaving this thought and challenge to you.Dr. V: When you grow in spiritual consciousness, we identify with all that is in the world so there is no exploitation. It is ourselves we are helping. It is ourselves we are healing.TR: Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
what they would save in bus fare in coming to a city,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:37.958
so they pay about 20 rupees, and that's good for three consultations.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
(Applause)

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
The other challenge was, how do you give high-tech

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
or more advanced treatment and care?

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
We designed a van with a VSAT,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:53.958
which sends out images of patients to the base hospital

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
where it is diagnosed,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:00.958
and then as the patient is waiting, the report goes back to the patient,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
it gets printed out, the patient gets it,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
and then gets a consultation about what they should be doing --

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
I mean, go see a doctor or come back after six months,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
and then this happens as a way of

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
bridging the technology competence.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:20.958
So the impact of all this has been essentially one of growing the market,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
because it focused on the non-customer,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
and then by reaching the unreached,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
we're able to significantly grow the market.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
The other aspect is how do you deal with this efficiently

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
when you have very few ophthalmologists?

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
So what is in this video is a surgeon operating,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
and then you see on the other side,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
another patient is getting ready.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
So, as they finish the surgery,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
they just swing the microscope over,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
the tables are placed so that their distance is just right,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
and then we need to do this, because, by doing this kind of process,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:11:00.958
we're able to more than quadruple the productivity of the surgeon.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
And then to support the surgeon,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
we require a certain workforce.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:09.958
And then we focused on village girls that we recruited,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
and then they really are the backbone of the organization.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:16.958
They do almost all of the skill-based routine tasks.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
They do one thing at a time. They do it extremely well.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
With the result we have very high productivity,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
very high quality at very, very low cost.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
So, putting all this together, what really happened was

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
the productivity of our staff was

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
significantly higher than anyone else.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:42.958
(Applause)

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
This is a very busy table,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
but what this really is conveying is that,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
when it comes to quality, we have put in

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
very good quality-assurance systems.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
As a result, our complications are significantly lower

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
than what has been reported in the United Kingdom,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
and you don't see those kind of numbers very often.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
(Applause)

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
So the final part of the puzzle is,

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
how do you make all this work financially,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
especially when the people can't pay for it?

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:14.958
So what we did was, we gave away a lot of it for free,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
and then those who pay, I mean, they paid local market rates,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
nothing more, and often much less.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And we were helped by the market inefficiency.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
I think that has been a big savior, even now.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:29.958
And, of course, one needs the mindset to be wanting to give away

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
what you have as a surplus.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
The result has been, over the years,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
the expenditure has increased with volumes.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
The revenues increase at a higher level,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
giving us a healthy margin

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:44.958
while you're treating a large number of people for free.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
I think in absolute terms,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
last year we earned about 20-odd million dollars,

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:54.958
spent about 13 million, with over a 40 percent EBITA.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:13:02.958
(Applause)

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
But this really requires going beyond what we do,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
or what we have done,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
if you really want to achieve solving this problem of blindness.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:15.958
And what we did was a couple of very counter-intuitive things.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
We created competition for ourselves,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
and then we made eye care affordable

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
by making low-cost consumables.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
We proactively and systematically

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:31.958
promoted these practices to many hospitals in India,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
many in our own backyards and then in other parts of the world as well.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:38.958
The impact of this has been that these hospitals,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
in the second year after our consultation,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
are double their output

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:48.958
and then achieve financial recovery as well.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
The other part was how do you address

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:56.958
this increase in cost of technology?

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
There was a time when we failed to negotiate

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
the [intra-ocular lens] prices to be at affordable levels,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
so we set up a manufacturing unit.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.958
And then, over time, we were able to bring down the cost significantly

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:14.958
to about two percent of what it used to be when we started out.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:18.958
Today, we believe we have about seven percent of the global market,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
and they're used in about 120-odd countries.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:27.958
To conclude, I mean, what we do, does it have a broader relevance,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:32.958
or is it just India or developing countries?

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:38.958
So to address this, we studied UK versus Aravind.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
What it shows is that we do roughly about 60 percent

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
of the volume of what the UK does,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
near a half-million surgeries as a whole country.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
And we do about 300,000.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
And then we train about 50 ophthalmologists

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
against the 70 trained by them,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
comparable quality, both in training and in patient care.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
So we're really comparing apples to apples.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
We looked at cost.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
(Laughter)

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:13.958
(Applause)

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
So, I think it is simple to say

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:19.958
just because the U.K. isn't India the difference is happening.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
I think there is more to it.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
I mean, I think one has to look at other aspects as well.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
Maybe there is --

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:29.958
the solution to the cost could be in productivity,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
maybe in efficiency, in the clinical process,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
or in how much they pay for the lenses or consumables,

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
or regulations, their defensive practice.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
So, I think decoding this can probably bring

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:46.958
answers to most developed countries

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
including the U.S., and maybe

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
Obama's ratings can go up again.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
(Laughter)

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:59.958
Another insight, which, again, I want to leave with you,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
in conditions where the problem is very large,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
which cuts across all economic strata,

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
where we have a good solution,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
I think the process I described,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.958
you know, productivity, quality, patient-centered care,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
can give an answer,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
and there are many which fit this paradigm.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
You take dentistry, hearing aid, maternity and so on.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
There are many where this paradigm can now play,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
but I think probably one of the most challenging things

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
is on the softer side.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
Now, how do you create compassion?

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
Now, how do you make people own the problem,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
want to do something about it?

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
There are a bit harder issues.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:40.958
And I'm sure people in this crowd can probably find the solutions to these.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
So I want to end my talk leaving this thought and challenge to you.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
Dr. V: When you grow in spiritual consciousness,

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
we identify with all that is in the world

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
so there is no exploitation.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
It is ourselves we are helping.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
It is ourselves we are healing.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
TR: Thank you very much.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:16.958
(Applause)

title: Pop culture in the Arab world
transcript: Hello, everyone. Because this is my first time at TED, I've decided to bring along an old friend to help break the ice a bit. Yes. That's right. This is Barbie. She's 50 years old. And she's looking as young as ever. (Laughter) But I'd also like to introduce you to what may be an unfamiliar face. This is Fulla. Fulla is the Arab world's answer to Barbie.Now, according to proponents of the clash of civilizations, Barbie and Fulla occupy these completely separate spheres. They have different interests. They have divergent values. And should they ever come in contact ... well, I've got to tell you, it's just not going to be pretty.My experience, however, in the Islamic world is very different. Where I work, in the Arab region, people are busy taking up Western innovations and changing them into things which are neither conventionally Western, nor are they traditionally Islamic. I want to show you two examples. The first is 4Shbab. It means "for youth" and it's a new Arab TV channel.(Video): Video clips from across the globe. The USA.♫ I am not afraid to stand alone ♫♫ I am not afraid to stand alone, if Allah is by my side ♫♫ I am not afraid to stand alone ♫♫ Everything will be all right ♫♫ I am not afraid to stand alone ♫The Arab world.(Music)♫ She was preserved by modesty of the religion ♫ ♫ She was adorned by the light of the Quran ♫Shereen El Feki: 4Shbab has been dubbed Islamic MTV. Its creator, who is an Egyptian TV producer called Ahmed Abu Haïba, wants young people to be inspired by Islam to lead better lives. He reckons the best way to get that message across is to use the enormously popular medium of music videos. 4Shbab was set up as an alternative to existing Arab music channels. And they look something like this. (Music)That, by the way is Haifa Wehbe. She's a Lebanese pop star and pan-Arab pin-up girl. In the world of 4Shbab, it's not about bump and grind. But it's not about fire and brimstone either. Its videos are intended to show a kinder, gentler face of Islam, for young people to deal with life's challenges.Now, my second example is for a slightly younger crowd. And it's called "The 99." Now, these are the world's first Islamic superheroes. They were created by a Kuwaiti psychologist called Naif Al Mutawa. And his desire is to rescue Islam from images of intolerance, all in a child-friendly format. "The 99." The characters are meant to embody the 99 attributes of Allah: justice, wisdom, mercy, among others. So, for example, there is the character of Noora. She is meant to have the power to look inside people and see the good and bad in everyone. Another character called Jami has the ability to create fantastic inventions.Now, "The 99" is not just a comic book. It's now a theme park. There is an animated series in the works. And by this time next year, the likes of Superman and Wonder Woman will have joined forces with "The 99" to beat injustice wherever they find it."The 99" and 4Shbab are just two of many examples of this sort of Islamic cross-cultural hybridization. We're not talking here about a clash of civilizations. Nor is it some sort of indistinguishable mash. I like to think of it as a mesh of civilizations, in which the strands of different cultures are intertwined.Now, while 4Shbab and "The 99" may look new and shiny, there is actually a very long tradition of this. Throughout its history, Islam has borrowed and adapted from other civilizations both ancient and modern. After all, it's the Quran which encourages us to do this: "We made you into nations and tribes so that you could learn from one another." And to my mind, those are pretty wise words, no matter what your creed. Thank you. (Applause)

title: The intricate economics of terrorism
transcript: I'm going to show you how terrorism actually interacts with our daily life. 15 years ago I received a phone call from a friend. At the time he was looking after the rights of political prisoners in Italian jails. He asked me if I wanted to interview the Red Brigades. Now, as many of you may remember, the Red Brigades was a terrorist, Marxist organization which was very active in Italy from the 1960s until the mid-1980s. As part of their strategy the Red Brigades never spoke with anybody, not even with their lawyers. They sat in silence through their trails, waving occasionally at family and friends.In 1993 they declared the end of the armed struggle. And they drew a list of people with whom they would talk, and tell their story. And I was one of those people. When I asked my friend why the Red Brigades want to talk to me, he said that the female members of the organization had actually supported my name. In particular, one person had put it forward. She was my childhood friend. She had joined the Red Brigades and became a leader of the organization.Naturally, I didn't know that until the day she was arrested. In fact, I read it in the newspaper. At the time of the phone call I just had a baby, I successfully completed a management buyout to the company I was working with, and the last thing I wanted to do was to go back home and touring the high-security prisons. But this is exactly what I did because I wanted to know what had turned my best friend into a terrorist, and why she'd never tried to recruit me. (Laughter) (Applause)So, this is exactly what I did. Now, I found the answer very quickly. I actually had failed the psychological profiling of a terrorist. The center committee of the Red Brigades had judged me too single-minded and too opinionated to become a good terrorist. My friend, on the other hand, she was a good terrorist because she was very good at following orders. She also embraced violence. because the bulk of the money was denominated in U.S. dollars

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
and the money laundering was taking place

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
inside the United States.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
The entry point, of course, of most of this money

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
were the off-shore facilities.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:41.958
So, this was a vital injection of cash

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
into the U.S. economy.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:49.958
Now, when I went to look at the figures of the U.S. money supply,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
the U.S. money supply is the amount

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
of dollars that the Federal Reserve

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
prints every year

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
in order to satisfy

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
the increase in the demand for dollars,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
which, of course, reflects the growth

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
of the economy.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:09.958
So, when I went to look at those figures, I noted that since the late 1960s

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:13.958
a growing number of these dollars

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
was actually leaving the United States,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
never to come back.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
These were money taken out

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
in suitcases or in containers, in cash of course.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
These were money taken out by criminals and money launderers.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
These were money taken out to fund

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
the growth of the terror,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:36.958
illegal and criminal economy.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:40.958
So, you see, what is the relationship?

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:44.958
The United States actually is a country

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:48.958
that is the reserve currency of the world.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
What does it mean? That means that

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
it has a privilege that other countries do not have.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
It can borrow against the total amount of dollars

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
in circulation in the world.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
This privilege is called seigniorage.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
No other country can do that.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
All the other countries, for example the United Kingdom,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
can borrow only against the amount of money

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:15.958
in circulation inside its own borders.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
So, here is the implication of the relationship

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:22.958
between the worlds of crime, terror, and illegal economy, and our economy.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
The U.S. in the 1990s

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
was borrowing against the growth

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958
of the terror, illegal and criminal economy.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:36.958
This is how close we are with this world.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
Now, this situation changed, of course, after 9-11,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
because George Bush launched the War on Terror.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
Part of the War on Terror

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
was the introduction of the Patriot Act.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
Now, many of you know that the Patriot Act

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
is a legislation that greatly reduces

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
the liberties of Americans in order to protect them

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
against terrorism.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
But there is a section of the Patriot Act

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
which refers specifically to finance.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:04.958
And it is, in fact, an anti-money-laundering legislation.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
What the Patriot Act did was

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
to prohibit U.S. bank,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
and U.S.-registered foreign banks

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:14.958
from doing any businesses with off-shore facilities.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
It closed that door between the money laundering

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
in dollars, and the U.S. economy.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:25.958
It also gave the U.S. monetary authorities

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
the right to monitor any dollar transaction

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:32.958
taking place anywhere in the world.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
Now, you can imagine what was the reaction of the international

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
finance and banking.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
All the bankers said to their clients,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
"Get out of the dollars and go and invest somewhere else."

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
Now, the Euro was a newly born currency

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
of great opportunity for business, and, of course, for investment.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
And this is what people did.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
Nobody wants the U.S. monetary authority

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
to check their relationship,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:59.958
to monitor their relationship with their clientele.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
The same thing happened, of course,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
in the world of crime and terror.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:10.958
People simply moved their money-laundering activities

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
away from the United States

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
into Europe.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
Why did this happen? This happened because

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
the Patriot Act was a unilateral legislation.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
It was introduced only in the United States.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
And it was introduced only for the U.S. dollars.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
In Europe, a similar legislation

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
was not introduced.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
So, within six months

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
Europe became the epicenter

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
of the money-laundering activities

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
of the world.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
So, this is how incredible are the relationship

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
between the world of crime

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
and the world of terror,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
and our own life.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
So, why did I tell you this story?

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
I told you this story because you

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
must understand that there is a world

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
that goes well beyond the headlines of the newspapers,

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
including the personal relationship that you have

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
with friends and family.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
You got to question everything that is told to you,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
including what I just told you today.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
(Laughter)

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
This is the only way for you

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
to step into the dark side, and have a look at it.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
And believe me,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
it's going to be scary.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
It's going to be frightful, but it's going to enlighten you.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
And, above all, it's not going to be boring.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
(Laughter)

(Applause)

title: Photographing the hidden story
transcript: My name is Ryan Lobo, and I've been involved in the documentary filmmaking business all over the world for the last 10 years. During the process of making these films I found myself taking photographs, often much to the annoyance of the video cameramen.I found this photography of mine almost compulsive. And at the end of a shoot, I would sometimes feel that I had photographs that told a better story than a sometimes-sensational documentary. I felt, when I had my photographs, that I was holding on to something true, regardless of agendas or politics. In 2007, I traveled to three war zones. I traveled to Iraq, Afghanistan and Liberia. And over there I experienced other people's suffering, up close and personal, immersed myself in some rather intense and emotional stories, and at times I experienced great fear for my own life.As always, I would return to Bangalore, and often to animated discussions at friend's homes, where we would discuss various issues while they complained bitterly about the new pub timings, where a drink often cost more than what they'd paid their 14-year-old maid. I would feel very isolated during these discussions. But at the same time, I questioned myself and my own integrity and purpose in storytelling. And I decided that I had compromised, just like my friends in those discussions, where we told stories in contexts we made excuses for, rather than taking responsibility for.I won't go into details about what led to a decision I made, but let's just say it involved alcohol, cigarettes, other substances and a woman. (Laughter) I basically decided that it was I, not the camera or the network, or anything that lay outside myself, that was the only instrument in storytelling truly worth tuning. In my life, when I tried to achieve things like success or recognition, they eluded me. Paradoxically, when I let go of these objectives, and worked from a place of compassion and purpose, looking for excellence, rather than the results of it, everything arrived on its own, including fulfillment.Photography transcended culture, including my own. And it is, for me, a language which expressed the intangible, and gives voice to people and stories without. I invite you into three recent stories of mine, which are about this way of looking, if you will, which I believe exemplify the tenets of what I like to call compassion in storytelling.In 2007 I went to Liberia, where a group of my friends and I did an independent, self-funded film, still in progress, on a very legendary and brutal war-lord named General Butt Naked. His real name is Joshua, and he's pictured here in a cell where he once used to torture and murder people, including children. Joshua claims to have personally killed more than 10,000 people during Liberia's civil war. He got his name from fighting stark naked. And he is probably the most prolific mass murderer alive on Earth today.This woman witnessed the General murdering her brother. Joshua commanded his child-soldiers to commit unspeakable crimes, and enforced his command with great brutality. Today many of these children are addicted to drugs like heroin, and they are destitute, like these young men in the image. How do you live with yourself if you know you've committed horrific crimes? Today the General is a baptized Christian evangelist. And he's on a mission.We accompanied Joshua, as he walked the Earth, visiting villages where he had once killed and raped. He seeked forgiveness, and he claims to endeavor to improve the lives of his child-soldiers. During this expedition I expected him to be killed outright, and us as well. But what I saw opened my eyes to an idea of forgiveness which I never thought possible. In the midst of incredible poverty and loss, people who had nothing absolved a man who had taken everything from them. He begs for forgiveness, and receives it from the same woman whose brother he murdered. Senegalese, the young man seated on the wheelchair here, was once a child soldier, under the General's command, until he disobeyed orders, and the General shot off both his legs. He forgives the General in this image. He risked his life as he walked up to people whose families he'd murdered.In this photograph a hostile crowd in a slum surrounds him. And Joshua remains silent as they vented their rage against him. This image, to me, is almost like from a Shakespearean play, with a man, surrounded by various influences, desperate to hold on to something true within himself, in a context of great suffering that he has created himself.I was intensely moved during all this. But the question is, does forgiveness and redemption replace justice? Joshua, in his own words, says that he does not mind standing trial for his crimes, and speaks about them from soapboxes across Monrovia, to an audience that often includes his victims. A very unlikely spokesperson for the idea of separation of church and state.The second story I'm going to tell you about is about a group of very special fighting women with rather unique peace-keeping skills. Liberia has been devastated by one of Africa's bloodiest civil wars, which has left more than 200,000 people dead, thousands of women scarred by rape and crime on a spectacular scale. Liberia is now home to an all-woman United Nations contingent of Indian peacekeepers.These women, many from small towns in India, help keep the peace, far away from home and family. They use negotiation and tolerance more often than an armed response. The commander told me that a woman could gauge a potentially violent situation much better than men. And that they were definitely capable of diffusing it non-aggressively. This man was very drunk, and he was very interested in my camera, until he noticed the women, who handled him with smiles, and AK-47s at the ready, of course. (Laughter)This contingent seems to be quite lucky, and it has not sustained any casualties, even though dozens of peacekeepers have been killed in Liberia. And yes, all of those people killed were male. Many of the women are married with children, and they say the hardest part of their deployment was being kept away from their children.I accompanied these women on their patrols, and watched as they walked past men, many who passed very lewd comments incessantly. And when I asked one of the women about the shock and awe response, she said, "Don't worry, same thing back home. We know how to deal with these fellows," and ignored them.In a country ravaged by violence against women, Indian peacekeepers have inspired many local women to join the police force. Sometimes, when the war is over and all the film crews have left, the most inspiring stories are the ones that float just beneath the radar. I came back to India and nobody was interested in buying the story. And one editor told me that she wasn't interested in doing what she called "manual labor stories."In 2007 and 2009 I did stories on the Delhi Fire Service, the DFS, which, during the summer, is probably the world's most active fire department. They answer more than 5,000 calls in just two months. And all this against incredible logistical odds, like heat and traffic jams. Something amazing happened during this shoot. Due to a traffic jam, we were late in getting to a slum, a large slum, which had caught fire. As we neared, angry crowds attacked our trucks and stoned them, by hundreds of people all over the place. These men were terrified, as the mob attacked our vehicle.But nonetheless, despite the hostility, firefighters left the vehicle and successfully fought the fire. Running the gauntlet through hostile crowds, and some wearing motorbike helmets to prevent injury. Some of the local people forcibly took away the hoses from the firemen to put out the fire in their homes. Now, hundreds of homes were destroyed. But the question that lingered in my mind was, what causes people to destroy fire trucks headed to their own homes? Where does such rage come from? And how are we responsible for this? 45 percent of the 14 million people who live in Delhi live in unauthorized slums, which are chronically overcrowded. They lack even the most basic amenities. And this is something that is common to all our big cities.Back to the DFS. A huge chemical depot caught fire, thousands of drums filled with petrochemicals were blazing away and exploding all around us. The heat was so intense, that hoses were used to cool down firefighters fighting extremely close to the fire, and with no protective clothing. In India we often love to complain about our government bodies. But over here, the heads of the DFS, Mr. R.C. Sharman, Mr. A.K. Sharman, led the firefight with their men. Something wonderful in a country where manual labor is often looked down upon. (Applause)Over the years, my faith in the power of storytelling has been tested. And I've had very serious doubt about its efficacy, and my own faith in humanity. However, a film we shot still airs on the National Geographic channel. And when it airs I get calls from all the guys I was with and they tell me that they receive hundreds of calls congratulating them. Some of the firemen told me that they were also inspired to do better because they were so pleased to get thank-yous rather than brick bats.It seems that this story helped change perceptions about the DFS, at least in the minds of an audience in part on televisions, read magazines and whose huts aren't on fire. Sometimes, focusing on what's heroic, beautiful and dignified, regardless of the context, can help magnify these intangibles three ways, in the protagonist of the story, in the audience, and also in the storyteller. And that's the power of storytelling. Focus on what's dignified, courageous and beautiful, and it grows. Thank you. (Applause)
