00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:59.958
And today is a time for me to talk to you about water.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
It's not only because we like to drink lots of it,

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:07.958
and its marvelous derivatives, beer, wine, etc.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
And, of course, watch it fall from the sky

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
and flow in our wonderful rivers,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
but for several other reasons as well.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
When I was a kid, growing up in New York,

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
I was smitten by snakes, the same way most kids are

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:23.958
smitten by tops, marbles, cars, trains, cricket balls.

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:25.958
And my mother, brave lady,

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
was partly to blame,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
taking me to the New York Natural History Museum,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
buying me books on snakes,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:35.958
and then starting this infamous career of mine,

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
which has culminated in

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:41.958
of course, arriving in India 60 years ago,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
brought by my mother, Doris Norden,

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
and my stepfather, Rama Chattopadhyaya.

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:49.958
It's been a roller coaster ride.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
Two animals, two iconic reptiles

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
really captivated me very early on.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.958
One of them was the remarkable gharial.

00:01:57.958 --> 00:01:59.958
This crocodile, which grows to almost 20 feet long

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
in the northern rivers,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:06.958
and this charismatic snake, the king cobra.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
What my purpose of the talk today really is,

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:11.958
is to sort of indelibly scar your minds

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
with these charismatic and majestic creatures.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:17.958
Because this is what you will take away from here,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
a reconnection with nature, I hope.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.958
The king cobra is quite remarkable for several reasons.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.958
What you're seeing here is very recently shot images

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
in a forest nearby here,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
of a female king cobra making her nest.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:36.958
Here is a limbless animal, capable of gathering a huge mound of leaves,

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
and then laying her eggs inside,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:42.958
to withstand 5 to 10 [meters of rainfall],

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
in order that the eggs can incubate over the next 90 days,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
and hatch into little baby king cobras.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.958
So, she protects her eggs,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.958
and after three months,

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
the babies finally do hatch out.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.958
A majority of them will die, of course. There is very high mortality

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:02.958
in little baby reptiles who are just 10 to 12 inches long.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
My first experience with king cobras was in '72

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
at a magical place called Agumbe,

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
in Karnataka, this state.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
And it is a marvelous rain forest.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
This first encounter

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
was kind of like the

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:21.958
Maasai boy who kills the lion to become a warrior.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
It really changed my life totally.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
And it brought me straight into the conservation fray.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
I ended up starting this research

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
and education station in Agumbe,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
which you are all of course invited to visit.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
This is basically a base wherein

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
we are trying to gather and learn

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
virtually everything about the biodiversity

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
of this incredibly complex forest system,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
and try to hang on to what's there,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
make sure the water sources are protected and kept clean,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
and of course, having a good time too.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
You can almost hear the drums

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:57.958
throbbing back in that little cottage where we stay when we're there.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:01.958
It was very important for us to get through to the people.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And through the children is usually the way to go.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
They are fascinated with snakes. They haven't got

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
that steely thing that you end up

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:13.958
either fearing or hating or despising or loathing them in some way.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
They are interested.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
And it really works to start with them.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
This gives you an idea of the size of some of these snakes.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
This is an average size king cobra, about 12 feet long.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
And it actually crawled into somebody's bathroom,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
and was hanging around there for two or three days.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
The people of this part of India

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
worship the king cobra.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
And they didn't kill it. They called us to catch it.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
Now we've caught more than 100 king cobras

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
over the last three years,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
and relocated them in nearby forests.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
But in order to find out the real secrets of these creatures

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
[it was necessary] for us to actually insert

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
a small radio transmitter inside [each] snake.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:52.958
Now we are able to follow them and find out their secrets,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
where the babies go after they hatch,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:59.958
and remarkable things like this you're about to see.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
This was just a few days ago in Agumbe.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:06.958
I had the pleasure of being close to this large king cobra

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
who had caught a venomous pit viper.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
And it does it in such a way that it doesn't get bitten itself.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:15.958
And king cobras feed only on snakes.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
This [little snake] was kind of a tid-bit for it,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
what we'd call a "vadai" or a donut or something like that.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
(Laughter)

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
Usually they eat something a bit larger.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:28.958
In this case a rather strange and inexplicable

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
activity happened over the last breeding season,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:35.958
wherein a large male king cobra actually grabbed a female king cobra,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
didn't mate with it, actually killed it and swallowed it.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
We're still trying to explain and come to terms with

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:45.958
what is the evolutionary advantage of this.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
But they do also a lot of other remarkable things.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
This is again, something [we were able to see] by virtue of the fact

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
that we had a radio transmitter in one of the snakes.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
This male snake, 12 feet long, met another male king cobra.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:06:00.958
And they did this incredible ritual combat dance.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
It's very much like the rutting of mammals, including humans,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
you know, sorting out our differences, but gentler, no biting allowed.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
It's just a wresting match,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
but a remarkable activity.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
Now, what are we doing with all this information?

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
What's the point of all this?

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
Well, the king cobra is literally

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
a keystone species in these rainforests.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:23.958
And our job is to convince the authorities

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
that these forests have to be protected.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
And this is one of the ways we do it,

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
by learning as much as we can

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:33.958
about something so remarkable and so iconic in the rainforests there,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
in order to help protect trees, animals

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
and of course the water sources.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
You've all heard, perhaps, of Project Tiger

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
which started back in the early '70s,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:47.958
which was, in fact, a very dynamic time for conservation.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
We were piloted, I could say,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
by a highly autocratic stateswoman,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:56.958
but who also had an incredible passion for environment.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
And this is the time when Project Tiger emerged.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
And, just like Project Tiger,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
our activities with the king cobra

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
is to look at a species of animal

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
so that we protect its habitat and everything within it.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
So, the tiger is the icon.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
And now the king cobra is a new one.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
All the major rivers in south India

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
are sourced in the Western Ghats,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:23.958
the chain of hills running along the west coast of India.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
It pours out millions of gallons every hour,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
and supplies drinking water to at least 300 million people,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
and washes many, many babies,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
and of course feeds many, many animals,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
both domestic and wild,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
produces thousands of tons of rice.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
And what do we do? How do we respond to this?

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Well, basically, we dam it, we pollute it,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
we pour in pesticides, weedicides, fungicides.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
You drink it in peril of your life.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And the thing is, it's not just big industry.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
It's not misguided river engineers

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
who are doing all this; it's us.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:01.958
It seems that our citizens find the best way to dispose of garbage

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
are in water sources.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
Okay. Now we're going north, very far north.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
North central India, the Chambal River

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
is where we have our base.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:14.958
This is the home of the gharial, this incredible crocodile.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
It is an animal which has been on the Earth

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
for just about 100 million years.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.958
It survived even during the time that the dinosaurs died off.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
It has remarkable features.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
Even though it grows to 20 feet long,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
since it eats only fish it's not dangerous to human beings.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
It does have big teeth, however,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
and it's kind of hard to convince people

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
if an animal has big teeth, that it's a harmless creature.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:42.958
But we, actually, back in the early '70s,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
did surveys,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:48.958
and found that gharial were extremely rare.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
In fact, if you see the map,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
the range of their original habitat

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
was all the way from the Indus in Pakistan

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
to the Irrawaddy in Burma.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
And now it's just limited to a couple of spots

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
in Nepal and India.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
So, in fact at this point

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:08.958
there are only 200 breeding gharial left in the wild.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
So, starting in the mid-'70s

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
when conservation was at the fore,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
we were actually able to start projects which were

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
basically government supported

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
to collect eggs from the wild from the few remaining nests

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
and release 5,000 baby gharial

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
back to the wild.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
And pretty soon we were seeing sights like this.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
I mean, just incredible to see bunches of gharial

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
basking on the river again.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:37.958
But complacency does have a tendency to breed contempt.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
And, sure enough, with all the other pressures on the river,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
like sand mining, for example,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:47.958
very, very heavy cultivation all the way down to the river's edge,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
not allowing the animals to breed anymore,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
we're looking at

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
even more problems building up for the gharial,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
despite the early good intentions.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Their nests hatching along the riverside

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
producing hundreds of hatchlings. It's just an amazing sight.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
This was actually just taken last year.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:10.958
But then the monsoon arrives,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
and unfortunately downriver there is always a dam or

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
there is always a barrage,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:18.958
and, shoop, they get washed down to their doom.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
Luckily there is still a lot of interest.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
My pals in the Crocodile Specialist Group of the IUCN,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
the [Madras Crocodile Bank], an NGO,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
the World Wildlife Fund,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
the Wildlife Institute of India, State Forest Departments,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
and the Ministry of Environment, we all work together on stuff.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:37.958
But it's possibly, and definitely not enough.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:42.958
For example, in the winter of 2007 and 2008,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
there was this incredible die-off of gharial, in the Chambal River.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
Suddenly dozens of gharial appearing on the river, dead.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
Why? How could it happen?

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
This is a relatively clean river.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
The Chambal, if you look at it, has clear water.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
People scoop water out of the Chambal and drink it,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
something you wouldn't do in most north Indian rivers.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
So, in order to try to find out the answer to this,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
we got veterinarians from all over the world

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
working with Indian vets to try to figure out what was happening.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
I was there for a lot of the necropsies on the riverside.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
And we actually looked through

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
all their organs and tried to figure out what was going on.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
And it came down to something called gout,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
which, as a result of kidney breakdown

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
is actually uric acid crystals throughout the body,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
and worse in the joints,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
which made the gharial unable to swim.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
And it's a horribly painful death.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
Just downriver from the Chambal is the

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
filthy Yamuna river, the sacred Yamuna river.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
And I hate to be so ironic and sarcastic about it

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
but it's the truth. It's just one of the filthiest cesspools you can imagine.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:50.958
It flows down through Delhi, Mathura, Agra,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
and gets just about every bit of effluent you can imagine.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
So, it seemed that the toxin that was killing the gharial

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
was something in the food chain,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
something in the fish they were eating.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
And, you know, once a toxin is in the food chain

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
everything is affected, including us.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:10.958
Because these rivers are the lifeblood of people all along their course.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
In order to try to answer some of these questions,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
we again turn to technology,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
to biological technology, in this case,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.958
again, telemetry, putting radios on 10 gharial,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and actually following their movements. They're being watched

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
everyday as we speak, to try to find out

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
what this mysterious toxin is.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:32.958
The Chambal river is an absolutely incredible place.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
It's a place that's famous to a lot of you who know

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
about the bandits, the dacoits

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
who used to work up there. And there still are quite a few around.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
But Poolan Devi was one [of them]. Which actually Shekhar Kapur

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
made an incredible movie, "The Bandit Queen," which I urge you to see.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
You'll get to see the incredible [Chambal] landscape as well.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:54.958
But, again, heavy fishing pressures.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
This is one of the last repositories of the

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
Ganges river dolphin,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
various species of turtles,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
thousands of migratory birds,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
and fishing is causing problems like this.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:11.958
And now [these] new elements of human intolerance

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
for river creatures like the gharial

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
means that if they don't drown in the net,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
then they simply cut their beaks off.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
Animals like the Ganges river dolphin

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
which is just down to a few left,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
and it is also critically endangered.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
So, who is next? Us?

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Because we are all dependent on these water sources.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
So, we all know about the Narmada river,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
the tragedies of dams, the tragedies of huge projects

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
which displace people and wreck river systems

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
without providing livelihoods.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
And development just basically going berserk,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
for a double figure growth index, basically.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:51.958
So, we're not sure where this story is going to end,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
whether it's got a happy or sad ending.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
And climate change is certainly going

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
to turn all of our theories and predictions on their heads.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
We're still working hard at it.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
We've got a lot of a good team of people working up there.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
And the thing is, you know, the decision makers,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
the folks in power,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
they're up in their bungalows and so on in Delhi,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
in the city capitals. They are all supplied with plenty of water. It's cool.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
But out on the rivers there are still millions of people

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
who are in really bad shape.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
And it's a bleak future for them.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
So, we have our Ganges and Yamuna cleanup project.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
We've spent hundreds of millions of dollars on it,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
and nothing to show for it. Incredible.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
So, people talk about political will.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
During the die-off of the gharial we did galvanize a lot of action.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
Government cut through all the red tape,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
we got foreign vets on it. It was great.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
So, we can do it.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
But if you stroll down to the Yamuna

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
or to the Gomati in Lucknow,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
or to the Adyar river in Chennai,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
or the Mula-Mutha river in Pune,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:55.958
just see what we're capable of doing to a river. It's sad.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
But I think the final note really is

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
that we can do it.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
The corporates, the artists, the wildlife nuts,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
the good old everyday folks

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
can actually bring these rivers back.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
And the final word is

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
that there is a king cobra looking over our shoulders.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
And there is a gharial looking at us from the river.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
And these are powerful water totems.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:24.958
And they are going to disturb our dreams until we do the right thing.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
Namaste.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:32.958
(Applause)

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
Chris Anderson: Thanks, Rom. Thanks a lot.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
You know, most people are terrified of snakes.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
And there might be quite a few people here who would be

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
very glad to see the last king cobra bite the dust.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
Do you have those conversations with people?

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
How do you really get them to care?

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:53.958
Romulus Whitaker: I take the sort of humble approach,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:57.958
I guess you could say. I don't say that snakes are huggable exactly.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
It's not like the teddy bear.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:04.958
But I sort of -- there is an innocence in these animals.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
And when the average person looks at a cobra

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
going "Ssssss!" like that, they say, "My god,

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
look at that angry, dangerous creature."

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
I look at it as a creature who is totally frightened

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
of something so dangerous as a human being.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
And that is the truth. And that's what I try to get out.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:23.958
(Applause)

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
CA: Now, incredible footage you showed of the viper being killed.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
You were saying that that hasn't been filmed before.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
RW: Yes, this is actually the first time anyone of us knew about it, for one thing.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
As I said, it's just like a little snack for him, you know?

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
Usually they eat larger snakes like rat snakes,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
or even cobras.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
But this guy who we're following right now is in the deep jungle.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
Whereas other king cobras

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
very often come into the human interface,

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
you know, the plantations, to find big rat snakes and stuff.

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
This guy specializes in pit vipers.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
And the guy who is working there with them,

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
he's from Maharashtra, he said, "I think he's after the nusha."

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
(Laughter)

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
Now, the nusha means the high.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
Whenever he eats the pit viper he gets this little venom rush.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
(Laughter)

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
CA: Thanks Rom. Thank you.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958

title: How we rescued the "dancing" bears"
transcript: Hi. For those of you who haven't seen dancing bears, these are the dancing bears. In 1995, we started working on a two-year investigative research project to try and find out what was going on. Because the sloth bears in the wild were obviously getting depleted because of this. This is the Qalandar community. They are a marginalized Islamic community who live across India, and have been in India since the 13th century.We went about getting evidence of what was going on. And this is footage from a hidden camera in a button. And we went in, pretending to be buyers. And we found this right in this very state, in Karnataka. And the bear cubs were being harvested from across the country and being sold and traded. These were being sold for about 2,000 dollars each, and they are used for bear paw soup, and also being trained, later on, to become dancing bears like the one you just saw.Sadly, the family of Qalandars depended on this bear. The couple are barely 18 years old. They already have four children beside them. You can see them. And the economy of the family and their livelihood depended on those animals. So, we had to deal with it in a very practical and sustainable manner.Now, when we started working deeper and digging deeper, we found that it's an illegal act. These guys could go to jail for up to seven years if they were caught by authorities. And what they were doing to the bears was really appalling. It was unacceptable. The mother bears are usually killed. The cubs, which are taken, are separated. Their teeth are basically bashed out with a metal rod. And they use a red hot iron needle to make a hole through the muzzle. Now we had to start changing these people and converting them from using that for a livelihood, to getting something else.So, this is Bitu Qalandar, who was our first experiment. And we were so unsure that this would work. We weren't sure at all. And we managed to convince him. And we said, "Okay, here is some seed fund. Let's see if you can get something else." And we got the bear surrendered to — we set up a sanctuary. We have four sanctuaries in India. And now he sells cool drinks, he's by the highway. He has a telephone booth.And then it started, there was no turning back after that. This is Sadua who came and surrendered his bear. And now he runs a cattle fodder store and a grain store near Agra. Then there was no looking back at all for us. We gave cycle rickshaws. We set up carpet-weaving units, vocational training for the women. The women were just not allowed to come out of the community and work with mainstream society. So, we were able to address that.Education. The kids never went to school. They only had Islamic education, very little of it. And they were never allowed to go to school because they were an extra earning hand at home. So we managed to get education. So, we sponsor 600 children education programs today. We were able to ensure brighter futures for these people.Of course we also had to get the bears in. This is what happens to the bears when they come in. And this is what we turn them into. We have a veterinary facility in our rescue centers. So, basically in 2002 there were 1,200 dancing bears. We rescued over 550 dancing bears. We've been able to ensure better futures for the people and the bears.The big news that I want to announce today is that next month we will be bringing in the very last bear of India, into our rescue center. (Applause) And India will no longer have to witness this cruel barbaric practice which has been here for centuries. And the people can hold their heads up high. And the Qalandar people will rise above all this cruel barbaric past that they've lived all their lives. And the beautiful bears can of course live in the wild again. And there will be no more removing of these bears. And the children, both humans and bear cubs can live peacefully. Thank you. (Applause)

title: Kids, take charge
transcript: Contagious is a good word. Even in the times of H1N1, I like the word. Laughter is contagious. Passion is contagious. Inspiration is contagious. We've heard some remarkable stories from some remarkable speakers. But for me, what was contagious about all of them was that they were infected by something I call the "I Can" bug.So, the question is, why only them? In a country of a billion people and some, why so few? Is it luck? Is it chance? Can we all not systematically and consciously get infected? So, in the next eight minutes I would like to share with you my story. I got infected when I was 17, when, as a student of the design college, I encountered adults who actually believed in my ideas, challenged me and had lots of cups of chai with me. And I was struck by just how wonderful it felt, and how contagious that feeling was. I also realized I should have got infected when I was seven.So, when I started Riverside school 10 years ago it became a lab, a lab to prototype and refine a design process that could consciously infect the mind with the "I Can" bug. And I uncovered that if learning is embedded in real-world context, that if you blur the boundaries between school and life, then children go through a journey of "aware," where they can see the change, "enable," be changed, and then "empower," lead the change. And that directly increased student wellbeing. Children became more competent, and less helpless. But this was all common sense.So, I'd like to show you a little glimpse of what common practice looks like at Riverside. A little background: when my grade five was learning about child rights, they were made to roll incense sticks, agarbattis, for eight hours to experience what it means to be a child laborer. It transformed them. What you will see is their journey, and then their utter conviction that they could go out and change the world. (Music)That's them rolling. And in two hours, after their backs were broke, they were changed. And once that happened, they were out in the city convincing everybody that child labor just had to be abolished. And look at Ragav, that moment when his face changes because he's been able to understand that he has shifted that man's mindset. And that can't happen in a classroom. So, when Ragav experienced that he went from "teacher told me," to "I am doing it." And that's the "I Can" mindshift. And it is a process that can be energized and nurtured.But we had parents who said, "Okay, making our children good human beings is all very well, but what about math and science and English? Show us the grades." And we did. The data was conclusive. When children are empowered, not only do they do good, they do well, in fact very well, as you can see in this national benchmarking assessment taken by over 2,000 schools in India, Riverside children were outperforming the top 10 schools in India in math, English and science.So, it worked. It was now time to take it outside Riverside. So, on August 15th, Independence Day, 2007, the children of Riverside set out to infect Ahmedabad. Now it was not about Riverside school. It was about all children. So, we were shameless. We walked into the offices of the municipal corporation, the police, the press, businesses, and basically said, "When are you going to wake up and recognize the potential that resides in every child? When will you include the child in the city? Basically, open your hearts and your minds to the child."So, how did the city respond? Since 2007 every other month the city closes down the busiest streets for traffic and converts it into a playground for children and childhood. Here was a city telling its child, "You can." A glimpse of infection in Ahmedabad. Video: [Unclear] So, the busiest streets closed down. We have the traffic police and municipal corporation helping us. It gets taken over by children. They are skating. They are doing street plays. They are playing, all free, for all children. (Music)Atul Karwal: aProCh is an organization which has been doing things for kids earlier. And we plan to extend this to other parts of the city. (Music)Kiran Bir Sethi: And the city will give free time. And Ahmedabad got the first child-friendly zebra crossing in the world.Geet Sethi: When a city gives to the children, in the future the children will give back to the city. (Music)KBS: And because of that, Ahmedabad is known as India's first child-friendly city.So, you're getting the pattern. First 200 children at Riverside. Then 30,000 children in Ahmedabad, and growing. It was time now to infect India. So, on August 15th, again, Independence Day, 2009, empowered with the same process, we empowered 100,000 children to say, "I can." How? We designed a simple toolkit, converted it into eight languages, and reached 32,000 schools. We basically gave children a very simple challenge. We said, take one idea, anything that bothers you, choose one week, and change a billion lives.And they did. Stories of change poured in from all over India, from Nagaland in the east, to Jhunjhunu in the west, from Sikkim in the north, to Krishnagiri in the south. Children were designing solutions for a diverse range of problems. Right from loneliness to filling potholes in the street to alcoholism, and 32 children who stopped 16 child marriages in Rajasthan. I mean, it was incredible. Basically again reaffirming that when adults believe in children and say, "You can," then they will. Infection in India. This is in Rajasthan, a rural village.Child: Our parents are illiterate and we want to teach them how to read and write. KBS: First time, a rally and a street play in a rural school — unheard of — to tell their parents why literacy is important. Look at what their parents says.Man: This program is wonderful. We feel so nice that our children can teach us how to read and write.Woman: I am so happy that my students did this campaign. In the future, I will never doubt my students' abilities. See? They have done it.KBS: An inner city school in Hyderabad. Girl: 581. This house is 581 ...We have to start collecting from 555.KBS: Girls and boys in Hyderabad, going out, pretty difficult, but they did it.Woman: Even though they are so young, they have done such good work. First they have cleaned the society, then it will be Hyderabad, and soon India.Woman: It was a revelation for me. It doesn't strike me that they had so much inside them.Girl: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. For our auction we have some wonderful paintings for you, for a very good cause, the money you give us will be used to buy hearing aids. Are you ready, ladies and gentlemen? Audience: Yes! Girl: Are you ready? Audience: Yes! Girl: Are you ready? Audience: Yes!KBS: So, the charter of compassion starts right here. Street plays, auctions, petitions. I mean, they were changing lives. It was incredible. So, how can we still stay immune? How can we stay immune to that passion, that energy, that excitement? I know it's obvious, but I have to end with the most powerful symbol of change, Gandhiji. 70 years ago, it took one man to infect an entire nation with the power of "We can."So, today who is it going to take to spread the infection from 100,000 children to the 200 million children in India? Last I heard, the preamble still said, "We, the people of India," right? So, if not us, then who? If not now, then when? Like I said, contagious is a good word. Thank you. (Applause)

that could consciously infect the mind with the "I Can" bug.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
And I uncovered

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
that if learning is embedded in real-world context,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
that if you blur the boundaries between school and life,

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.958
then children go through a journey of "aware,"

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
where they can see the change,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
"enable," be changed,

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:45.958
and then "empower," lead the change.

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:48.958
And that directly increased student wellbeing.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
Children became more competent,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
and less helpless.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
But this was all common sense.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
So, I'd like to show you a little glimpse of what

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
common practice looks like at Riverside.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:03.958
A little background: when my grade five was learning about child rights,

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
they were made to roll incense sticks,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
agarbattis, for eight hours

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:11.958
to experience what it means to be a child laborer.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
It transformed them. What you will see is their journey,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and then their utter conviction

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
that they could go out and change the world.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
(Music)

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
That's them rolling.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
And in two hours, after their backs were broke,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
they were changed.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
And once that happened,

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
they were out in the city convincing everybody

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
that child labor just had to be abolished.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
And look at Ragav, that moment when his face changes

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
because he's been able to understand that he

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
has shifted that man's mindset.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
And that can't happen in a classroom.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:55.958
So, when Ragav experienced that

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
he went from "teacher told me,"

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
to "I am doing it." And that's the "I Can" mindshift.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:05.958
And it is a process that can be energized and nurtured.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
But we had parents who said,

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
"Okay, making our children good human beings is all very well,

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
but what about math and science and English?

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
Show us the grades."

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
And we did. The data was conclusive.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
When children are empowered,

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
not only do they do good,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
they do well, in fact very well,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
as you can see in this national benchmarking assessment

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
taken by over 2,000 schools in India,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
Riverside children were outperforming the top 10 schools in India

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
in math, English and science.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:37.958
So, it worked. It was now time to take it outside Riverside.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:41.958
So, on August 15th, Independence Day, 2007,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:46.958
the children of Riverside set out to infect Ahmedabad.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
Now it was not about Riverside school.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
It was about all children. So, we were shameless.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
We walked into the offices of the municipal corporation, the police,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
the press, businesses,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
and basically said, "When are you going to wake up

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
and recognize the potential that resides in every child?

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
When will you include the child in the city?

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
Basically, open your hearts and your minds to the child."

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
So, how did the city respond?

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
Since 2007 every other month

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:16.958
the city closes down the busiest streets for traffic

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:19.958
and converts it into a playground for children and childhood.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:23.958
Here was a city telling its child, "You can."

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
A glimpse of infection in Ahmedabad.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:29.958
Video: [Unclear]

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
So, the busiest streets closed down.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:37.958
We have the traffic police and municipal corporation helping us.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
It gets taken over by children.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
They are skating. They are doing street plays.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:48.958
They are playing, all free, for all children.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:58.958
(Music)

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
Atul Karwal: aProCh is an organization which has been doing things for kids earlier.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
And we plan to extend this to other parts of the city.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
(Music)

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
Kiran Bir Sethi: And the city will give free time.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:13.958
And Ahmedabad got the first child-friendly zebra crossing in the world.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
Geet Sethi: When a city gives to the children,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
in the future the children will give back to the city.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
(Music)

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
KBS: And because of that,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:31.958
Ahmedabad is known as India's first child-friendly city.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
So, you're getting the pattern. First 200 children at Riverside.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
Then 30,000 children in Ahmedabad, and growing.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:40.958
It was time now to infect India.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
So, on August 15th,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
again, Independence Day, 2009,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
empowered with the same process,

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:52.958
we empowered 100,000 children to say, "I can."

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
How? We designed a simple toolkit,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
converted it into eight languages,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
and reached 32,000 schools.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
We basically gave children a very simple challenge.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
We said, take one idea,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
anything that bothers you,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
choose one week,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
and change a billion lives.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
And they did. Stories of change

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
poured in from all over India,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
from Nagaland in the east,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
to Jhunjhunu in the west,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
from Sikkim in the north, to Krishnagiri in the south.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
Children were designing solutions for a diverse range of problems.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:28.958
Right from loneliness to filling potholes in the street

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
to alcoholism,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
and 32 children who stopped 16 child marriages

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
in Rajasthan.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
I mean, it was incredible.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
Basically again reaffirming that when adults believe in children

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
and say, "You can," then they will.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
Infection in India.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
This is in Rajasthan, a rural village.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Child: Our parents are illiterate and we want to teach them how to read and write.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
KBS: First time, a rally and a street play in a rural school --

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:03.958
unheard of -- to tell their parents why literacy is important.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:11.958
Look at what their parents says.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
Man: This program is wonderful.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:18.958
We feel so nice that our children can teach us how to read and write.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
Woman: I am so happy that my students did this campaign.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
In the future, I will never doubt my students' abilities.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
See? They have done it.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
KBS: An inner city school in Hyderabad.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
Girl: 581. This house is 581 ...

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
We have to start collecting from 555.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
KBS: Girls and boys in Hyderabad, going out,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
pretty difficult, but they did it.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.958
Woman: Even though they are so young, they have done such good work.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:52.958
First they have cleaned the society, then it will be Hyderabad, and soon India.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
Woman: It was a revelation for me. It doesn't strike me

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
that they had so much inside them.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
Girl: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
For our auction we have some wonderful paintings for you,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
for a very good cause,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
the money you give us will be used to buy hearing aids.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
Are you ready, ladies and gentlemen? Audience: Yes!

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
Girl: Are you ready? Audience: Yes!

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Girl: Are you ready? Audience: Yes!

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
KBS: So, the charter of compassion starts right here.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
Street plays, auctions, petitions.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
I mean, they were changing lives.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
It was incredible.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
So, how can we still stay immune?

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:34.958
How can we stay immune to that passion, that energy, that excitement?

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
I know it's obvious,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:40.958
but I have to end with the most powerful symbol of change, Gandhiji.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
70 years ago, it took one man

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
to infect an entire nation

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
with the power of "We can."

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
So, today who is it going to take

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
to spread the infection from 100,000 children

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
to the 200 million children in India?

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:59.958
Last I heard, the preamble still said, "We, the people of India," right?

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
So, if not us, then who?

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
If not now, then when?

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
Like I said, contagious is a good word.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
Thank you.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:21.958
(Applause)

title: Making maps to fight disaster, build economies
transcript: In 2008, Cyclone Nargis devastated Myanmar. Millions of people were in severe need of help. The U.N. wanted to rush people and supplies to the area. But there were no maps, no maps of roads, no maps showing hospitals, no way for help to reach the cyclone victims.When we look at a map of Los Angeles or London, it is hard to believe that as of 2005, only 15 percent of the world was mapped to a geo-codable level of detail. The U.N. ran headfirst into a problem that the majority of the world's populous faces: not having detailed maps.But help was coming. At Google, 40 volunteers used a new software to map 120,000 kilometers of roads, 3,000 hospitals, logistics and relief points. And it took them four days. The new software they used? Google Mapmaker.Google Mapmaker is a technology that empowers each of us to map what we know locally. People have used this software to map everything from roads to rivers, from schools to local businesses, and video stores to the corner store.Maps matter. Nobel Prize nominee Hernando De Soto recognized that the key to economic liftoff for most developing countries is to tap the vast amounts of uncapitalized land. For example, a trillion dollars of real estate remains uncapitalized in India alone.In the last year alone, thousands of users in 170 countries have mapped millions of pieces of information, and created a map of a level of detail never thought viable. And this was made possible by the power of passionate users everywhere.Let's look at some of the maps being created by users right now. So, as we speak, people are mapping the world in these 170 countries. You can see Bridget in Africa who just mapped a road in Senegal. And, closer to home, Chalua, an N.G. road in Bangalore.This is the result of computational geometry, gesture recognition, and machine learning. This is a victory of thousands of users, in hundreds of cities, one user, one edit at a time.This is an invitation to the 70 percent of our unmapped planet. Welcome to the new world. (Applause)

title: All things are Moleeds
transcript: I am going to be talking about secrets. Obviously the best way to divulge a secret is to tell someone to not say anything about it. (Laughter) Secrets. I'm using PowerPoint this year just because, you know, I'm into the TED thing. (Laughter) And when you use these things you don't have to go like that. You just press it. (Laughter) Oh, man. Um, yes. (Laughter) Yes. I'm sure! Just change it! (Laughter) Is Bill Gates here? Change it! Come on! What? (Laughter) Ah! Okay. That's not my slides, but it's okay. (Laughter)As you can see, these are all maps. And maps are important devices for transferring information, especially if you have human cognitive ability. We can see that all formulas are really maps. Now, as humans, we make maps of places that we seldom even go, which seems a little wasteful of time.This, of course, is a map of the moon. There're some very delightful names. Tranquilacalitis, [unclear]. My favorite is Frigoris. What are these people thinking? Frigoris? What the Frigoris you doing? Names are important. Frigoris? This is the Moon. People could live there one day. I'll meet you at Frigoris. No. I don't think so. (Laughter)There we see Mars, again with various names. And this is all done, by the way, by the International Astronomical Union. This is an actual group of people that sit around naming planetary objects. This is from their actual book. These are some of the names that they have chosen, ladies and gentlemen.I'll go through a little of them. Bolotnitsa. That, of course, is the Slavic swamp mermaid. (Laughter) Now I think the whole concept of a mermaid doesn't really blend into the swamp feel. (Laughter) "Oh look! Mermaid come out of swamp. Oh boy! It's time for Bolotnitsa!" (Laughter)Djabran Fluctus. If that don't flow off the tongue, what does? (Laughter) I mean kids are studying this stuff and they've got the word "fluctus" up there. That's wrong. (Laughter) One dyslexic kid and he could be ruining his life. (Laughter) "It fluctus up, Mama."Hikuleo Fluctus. That's a little more flowing. Hikuleo sounds like a kind of a Leonardo DiCaprio 17 syllable thing. And that's the Tonga underworld.And one of my favorites is the Itoki Fluctus, who is the Nicaraguan goddess of insects, stars, and planets. Now, if you're a goddess of stars and planets wouldn't you relegate insects to somebody else? (Laughter) "No, no, really, I'm so busy with the stars. Would you mind taking the insects? Thank you darling. Oh take the spiders too. I know they're not insects, but I don't care. Monkeys, chimps, just get rid of the hairy creatures." (Laughter)Now, we're going to be going to Mars one day. And when we do, it's going to be unfair for the people that are living there to have to live with these ridiculous names. So, you'll be on Mars, and you're at Hellespointica Depressio which has got to be a really "up" place. (Laughter)Yeah, I'm at the Depressio, and I want to get over to Amazonis so I plug it into the Mars map, and click the button and there's my directions. I go to Chrysokeras. (Laughter) Left to the Thymiamata. Then to Niliacus Lacus, which is not a bad name. Niliacus Lacus, try to get the practice, slick-a-tick-a-bacus. That's a cool name. I will say that. So, I hold back a little of my venom for these astronomical misnomers.And then of course Arnon to Thoth. And of course there will be advertisements. This is from their rule book, the International Astronomical Union. And you know they're international because they put it "en Francais" as well. L'Union Astronomique Internationale, for those of you who don't speak French. I thought I'd translate for you.From the rulebook: Nomenclature is a tool. The first consideration, make it clear, simple and unambiguous. And I think that Djabran Fluctus, that fits that mode. (Laughter) That's simple, the goddess of goats, very simple. Djabran Fluctus. "Now, Frank is this clear to you, Djabran Fluctus?" "Yeah, that's the goat goddess right? The Abacazanian? (Laughter) It's clear to me." "Listen, I'm going back to the swamp mermaid. Can you call me in a little while?" (Laughter)Also, from the actual document I highlighted a part I thought may be of interest. Anyone can suggest changing a name. So, I look to you, fellow member of the Earth community. We've got to change this stuff up fast. So, these are actual names of people that work there. I did some more investigation. These are more people working for this group. And, as you can see, they don't use their first names. (Laughter) These are people naming planets, and they won't use their first names. Something is askew here. (Laughter) Is it because his name is really Jupiter Blunck? (Laughter) Is that Ganymede Andromeda Burba? (Laughter) Is that Mars Ya Marov? I don't know. But it's investigative material, no doubt.There are some mapping people who do use their names. Witness please, Eugene Shoemaker, who, diligently, from a young boy decided he wanted to make maps of celestial bodies. Must have been a very interesting day in the Shoemaker house. "Mom, I want to make maps." "That's wonderful Eugene. You could make maps of Toronto." "No, I want to make maps of planets." "Yeah, go to your room." (Laughter)Martians, Venusians, Jovians. We have names for places where people don't exist. That seems a little silly to me. There are no Jovians.Getting back to my premise, I used stamps, by the way, because you don't have to pay anybody for the rights. (Laughter) (Applause) There is obviously Einstein, Niels Bohr, de Fermat's last theorem, and I'm not sure whether that's James Coburn or Richard Harris. (Laughter) It's definitely one of the two. I'm not really clear which one.But obviously the point is that numbers are maps. And within numbers, is there an underlying secret to the universe? and then they just merge into each other.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
So, the whole concept of branes in the universe,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
if the universe is shaped like a dodecahedron

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
this is a very good map of what could possibly be.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
And that is, of course, what we are here to talk about.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
What a coincidence!

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
October 9th, in France, Jean-Pierre Luminet

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
said that the universe is probably shaped like a dodecahedron,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
based on information that they got from this probe.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
This would be a normal wave pattern.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
But what they're seeing, way out there in the far reaches

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
of the microwave background,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
is this kind of odd undulation.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
It doesn't plug in to what they suspected a flat universe would be.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
So, you can kind of get an idea from this

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
extrapolating that back under this huge picture,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
so we get this idea of what the primal universe looked like.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
And judging from this, it looks a little like a cheeseburger.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
(Laughter)

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958

relate to the unfolding of the measured meter of matter, as I refer to it.

I reason, through some sort of reverse engineering,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:42.958
