00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
So, salamanders can do it.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Why can't we? Why can't humans regenerate?

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
Actually, we can regenerate.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:57.958
Your body has many organs

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
and every single organ in your body

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
has a cell population

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:06.958
that's ready to take over at the time of injury. It happens every day.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
As you age, as you get older.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:12.958
Your bones regenerate every 10 years.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
Your skin regenerates every two weeks.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
So, your body is constantly regenerating.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
The challenge occurs when there is an injury.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
At the time of injury or disease,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
the body's first reaction

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
is to seal itself off from the rest of the body.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
It basically wants to fight off infection,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
and seal itself, whether it's organs inside your body,

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
or your skin, the first reaction

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
is for scar tissue to move in,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:43.958
to seal itself off from the outside.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
So, how can we harness that power?

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
One of the ways that we do that

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:52.958
is actually by using smart biomaterials.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
How does this work? Well, on the left side here

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
you see a urethra which was injured.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:01.958
This is the channel that connects the bladder to the outside of the body.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
And you see that it is injured.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
We basically found out that you can use these smart biomaterials

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
that you can actually use as a bridge.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
If you build that bridge, and you close off

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
from the outside environment,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
then you can create that bridge, and cells

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
that regenerate in your body,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:24.958
can then cross that bridge, and take that path.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
That's exactly what you see here.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
It's actually a smart biomaterial

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
that we used, to actually treat this patient.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
This was an injured urethra on the left side.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
We used that biomaterial in the middle.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
And then, six months later on the right-hand side

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
you see this reengineered urethra.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
Turns out your body can regenerate,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
but only for small distances.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
The maximum efficient distance for regeneration

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
is only about one centimeter.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
So, we can use these smart biomaterials

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
but only for about one centimeter

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
to bridge those gaps.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
So, we do regenerate, but for limited distances.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
What do we do now,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
if you have injury for larger organs?

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
What do we do when we have injuries

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
for structures which are much larger

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
than one centimeter?

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
Then we can start to use cells.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
The strategy here, is if a patient comes in to us

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
with a diseased or injured organ,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
you can take a very small piece of tissue from that organ,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
less than half the size of a postage stamp,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
you can then tease that tissue apart,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
and look at its basic components,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
the patient's own cells,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
you take those cells out,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:39.958
grow and expand those cells outside the body in large quantities,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
and then we then use scaffold materials.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
To the naked eye they look like a piece of your blouse,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
or your shirt, but actually

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
these materials are fairly complex

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
and they are designed to degrade once inside the body.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
It disintegrates a few months later.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
It's acting only as a cell delivery vehicle.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
It's bringing the cells into the body. It's allowing

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
the cells to regenerate new tissue,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
and once the tissue is regenerated the scaffold goes away.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
And that's what we did for this piece of muscle.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
This is actually showing a piece of muscle and how we go through

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
the structures to actually engineer the muscle.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
We take the cells, we expand them,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
we place the cells on the scaffold,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
and we then place the scaffold back into the patient.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
But actually, before placing the scaffold into the patient,

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
we actually exercise it.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
We want to make sure that we condition

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
this muscle, so that it knows what to do

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
once we put it into the patient.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
That's what you're seeing here. You're seeing

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
this muscle bio-reactor

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:41.958
actually exercising the muscle back and forth.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:45.958
Okay. These are flat structures that we see here,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
the muscle.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
What about other structures?

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
This is actually an engineered blood vessel.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Very similar to what we just did, but a little bit more complex.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
Here we take a scaffold,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:01.958
and we basically -- scaffold can be like a piece of paper here.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
And we can then tubularize this scaffold.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:07.958
And what we do is we, to make a blood vessel, same strategy.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:11.958
A blood vessel is made up of two different cell types.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
We take muscle cells, we paste,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
or coat the outside with these muscle cells,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
very much like baking a layer cake, if you will.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
You place the muscle cells on the outside.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:27.958
You place the vascular blood vessel lining cells on the inside.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
You now have your fully seeded scaffold.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
You're going to place this in an oven-like device.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
It has the same conditions as a human body,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
37 degrees centigrade,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
95 percent oxygen.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:42.958
You then exercise it, as what you saw on that tape.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
And on the right you actually see a carotid artery that was engineered.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
This is actually the artery that goes from your neck to your brain.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
And this is an X-ray showing you

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
the patent, functional blood vessel.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
More complex structures

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
such as blood vessels, urethras, which I showed you,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
they're definitely more complex

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
because you're introducing two different cell types.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
But they are really acting mostly as conduits.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
You're allowing fluid or air to go through

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
at steady states.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
They are not nearly as complex as hollow organs.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
Hollow organs have a much higher degree of complexity,

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
because you're asking these organs to act on demand.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
So, the bladder is one such organ.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
Same strategy, we take a very small piece of the bladder,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
less than half the size of a postage stamp.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
We then tease the tissue apart

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
into its two individual cell components,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
muscle, and these bladder specialized cells.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
We grow the cells outside the body in large quantities.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
It takes about four weeks to grow these cells from the organ.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
We then take a scaffold that we shape like a bladder.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:45.958
We coat the inside with these bladder lining cells.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
We coat the outside with these muscle cells.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
We place it back into this oven-like device.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
From the time you take that piece of tissue, six to eight weeks later

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
you can put the organ right back into the patient.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
This actually shows the scaffold.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:04.958
The material is actually being coated with the cells.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
When we did the first clinical trial for these patients

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
we actually created the scaffold specifically for each patient.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
We brought patients in,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
six to eight weeks prior to their scheduled surgery, did X-rays,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
and we then composed a scaffold specifically for that patient's size

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
pelvic cavity.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
For the second phase of the trials

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
we just had different sizes, small, medium, large and extra-large.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
(Laughter)

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
It's true.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
And I'm sure everyone here wanted an extra-large. Right?

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
(Laughter)

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
So, bladders are definitely a little bit more complex

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
than the other structures.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
But there are other hollow organs that have added complexity to it.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
This is actually a heart valve, which we engineered.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
And the way you engineer this heart valve is the same strategy.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
We take the scaffold, we seed it with cells,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
and you can now see here, the valve leaflets opening and closing.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
We exercise these prior to implantation.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Same strategy.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
And then the most complex are the solid organs.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
For solid organs, they're more complex

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:08.958
because you're using a lot more cells per centimeter.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
This is actually a simple solid organ like the ear.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
It's now being seeded with cartilage.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
That's the oven-like device;

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
once it's coated it gets placed there.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:22.958
And then a few weeks later we can take out the cartilage scaffold.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
This is actually digits that we're engineering.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
These are being layered, one layer at a time,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
first the bone, we fill in the gaps with cartilage.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
We then start adding the muscle on top.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
And you start layering these solid structures.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
Again, fairly more complex organs,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
but by far, the most complex solid organs

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:44.958
are actually the vascularized, highly vascularized,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
a lot of blood vessel supply,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
organs such as the heart,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
the liver, the kidneys.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
This is actually an example -- several strategies

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
to engineer solid organs.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
This is actually one of the strategies. We use a printer.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:02.958
And instead of using ink, we use -- you just saw an inkjet cartridge --

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
we just use cells.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
This is actually your typical desktop printer.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
It's actually printing this two chamber heart,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
one layer at a time.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:15.958
You see the heart coming out there. It takes about 40 minutes to print,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
and about four to six hours later

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
you see the muscle cells contract.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:26.958
(Applause)

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
This technology was developed by Tao Ju, who worked at our institute.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
And this is actually still, of course, experimental,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
not for use in patients.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
Another strategy that we have followed

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
is actually to use decellularized organs.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
We actually take donor organs,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
organs that are discarded,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
and we then can use very mild detergents

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
to take all the cell elements out of these organs.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So, for example on the left panel,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
top panel, you see a liver.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
We actually take the donor liver,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
we use very mild detergents,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:01.958
and we, by using these mild detergents, we take all the cells

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
out of the liver.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
Two weeks later, we basically can lift this organ up,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
it feels like a liver,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
we can hold it like a liver,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
it looks like a liver, but it has no cells.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
All we are left with

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
is the skeleton, if you will, of the liver,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
all made up of collagen,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
a material that's in our bodies, that will not reject.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
We can use it from one patient to the next.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
We then take this vascular structure

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:30.958
and we can prove that we retain the blood vessel supply.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
You can see, actually that's a fluoroscopy.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
We're actually injecting contrast into the organ.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:39.958
Now you can see it start. We're injecting the contrast into the organ

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
into this decellularized liver.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
And you can see the vascular tree that remains intact.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
We then take the cells, the vascular cells,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
blood vessel cells, we perfuse the vascular tree

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
with the patient's own cells.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
We perfuse the outside of the liver

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
with the patient's own liver cells.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
And we can then create functional livers.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And that's actually what you're seeing.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:03.958
This is still experimental. But we are able to actually reproduce the functionality

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
of the liver structure, experimentally.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
For the kidney,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:12.958
as I talked to you about the first painting that you saw,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
the first slide I showed you,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
90 percent of the patients on the transplant wait list

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
are waiting for a kidney, 90 percent.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
So, another strategy we're following

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
is actually to create wafers

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:27.958
that we stack together, like an accordion, if you will.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
So, we stack these wafers together, using the kidney cells.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
And then you can see these miniature kidneys that we've engineered.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
They are actually making urine.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:39.958
Again, small structures, our challenge is how to make them larger,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
and that is something we're working on

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
right now at the institute.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
One of the things that I wanted to summarize for you then

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:50.958
is what is a strategy that we're going for in regenerative medicine.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
If at all possible,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
we really would like to use smart biomaterials

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
that we can just take off the shelf

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
and regenerate your organs.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
We are limited with distances right now,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
but our goal is actually to increase those distances over time.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
If we cannot use smart biomaterials,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
then we'd rather use your very own cells.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
Why? Because they will not reject.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
We can take cells from you,

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
create the structure, put it right back into you, they will not reject.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.958
And if possible, we'd rather use the cells from your very specific organ.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
If you present with a diseased wind pipe

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
we'd like to take cells from your windpipe.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
If you present with a diseased pancreas

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
we'd like to take cells from that organ.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
Why? Because we'd rather take those cells

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
which already know that those are the cell types you want.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
A windpipe cell already knows it's a windpipe cell.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
We don't need to teach it to become another cell type.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
So, we prefer organ-specific cells.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
And today we can obtain cells from most every organ in your body,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
except for several which we still need stem cells for,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:54.958
like heart, liver, nerve and pancreas.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
And for those we still need stem cells.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
If we cannot use stem cells from your body

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
then we'd like to use donor stem cells.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
And we prefer cells that will not reject

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
and will not form tumors.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
And we're working a lot with the stem cells that we

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
published on two years ago,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
stem cells from the amniotic fluid,

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
and the placenta, which have those properties.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
So, at this point, I do want to tell you that

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:24.958
some of the major challenges we have.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
You know, I just showed you this presentation, everything looks so good,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
everything works. Actually no,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
these technologies really are not that easy.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
Some of the work you saw today

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
was performed by over 700 researchers

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
at our institute across a 20-year time span.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
So, these are very tough technologies.

title: Your health depends on where you live
transcript: Can geographic information make you healthy? In 2001 I got hit by a train. My train was a heart attack. I found myself in a hospital in an intensive-care ward, recuperating from emergency surgery. And I suddenly realized something: that I was completely in the dark. I started asking my questions, "Well, why me?" "Why now?" "Why here?" "Could my doctor have warned me?"So, what I want to do here in the few minutes I have with you is really talk about what is the formula for life and good health. Genetics, lifestyle and environment. That's going to sort of contain our risks, and if we manage those risks we're going to live a good life and a good healthy life. Well, I understand the genetics and lifestyle part. And you know why I understand that? Because my physicians constantly ask me questions about this.Have you ever had to fill out those long, legal-size forms in your doctor's office? I mean, if you're lucky enough you get to do it more than once, right? (Laughter) Do it over and over again. And they ask you questions about your lifestyle and your family history, your medication history, your surgical history, your allergy history ... did I forget any history?But this part of the equation I didn't really get, and I don't think my physicians really get this part of the equation. What does that mean, my environment? Well, it can mean a lot of things. This is my life. These are my life places. We all have these. While I'm talking I'd like you to also be thinking about: How many places have you lived?Just think about that, you know, wander through your life thinking about this. And you realize that you spend it in a variety of different places. You spend it at rest and you spend it at work. And if you're like me, you're in an airplane a good portion of your time traveling some place. So, it's not really simple when somebody asks you, "Where do you live, where do you work, and where do you spend all your time? And where do you expose yourselves to risks that maybe perhaps you don't even see?" Well, when I have done this on myself, I always come to the conclusion that I spend about 75 percent of my time relatively in a small number of places. And I don't wander far from that place for a majority of my time, even though I'm an extensive global trekker.Now, I'm going to take you on a little journey here. I started off in Scranton, Pennsylvania. I don't know if anybody might hail from northeastern Pennsylvania, but this is where I spent my first 19 years with my little young lungs. You know, breathing high concentrations here of sulfur dioxide, carbon dioxide and methane gas, in unequal quantities — 19 years of this. And if you've been in that part of the country, this is what those piles of burning, smoldering coal waste look like.So then I decided to leave that part of the world, and I was going to go to the mid-west. OK, so I ended up in Louisville, Kentucky. Well, I decided to be neighbors to a place called Rubbertown. They manufacture plastics. They use large quantities chloroprene and benzene. Okay, I spent 25 years, in my middle-age lungs now, breathing various concentrations of that. And on a clear day it always looked like this, so you never saw it. It was insidious and it was really happening.Then I decided I had to get really smart, I would take this job in the West Coast. And I moved to Redlands California. Very nice, and there my older, senior lungs, as I like to call them, I filled with particulate matter, carbon dioxide and very high doses of ozone. Okay? Almost like the highest in the nation. Alright, this is what it looks like on a good day. If you've been there, you know what I'm talking about.So, what's wrong with this picture? Well, the picture is, there is a huge gap here. The one thing that never happens in my doctor's office: They never ask me about my place history. No doctor, can I remember, ever asking me, "Where have you lived?" They haven't asked me what kind of the quality of the drinking water that I put in my mouth or the food that I ingest into my stomach. They really don't do that. It's missing. Look at the kind of data that's available. This data's from all over the world — countries spend billions of dollars investing in this kind of research.Now, I've circled the places where I've been. Well, by design, if I wanted to have a heart attack I'd been in the right places. Right? So, how many people are in the white? How many people in the room have spent the majority of their life in the white space? Anybody? Boy you're lucky. How many have spent it in the red places? Oh, not so lucky. There are thousands of these kinds of maps that are displayed in atlases all over the world. They give us some sense of what's going to be our train wreck. But none of that's in my medical record. And it's not in yours either.So, here's my friend Paul. He's a colleague. He allowed his cell phone to be tracked every two hours, 24/7, 365 days out of the year for the last two years, everywhere he went. And you can see he's been to a few places around the United States. And this is where he has spent most of his time. If you really studied that you might have some clues as to what Paul likes to do. Anybody got any clues? Ski. Right. We can zoom in here, and we suddenly see that now we see where Paul has really spent a majority of his time. And all of those black dots are all of the toxic release inventories that are monitored by the EPA.Did you know that data existed? For every community in the United States, you could have your own personalized map of that. So, our cell phones can now build a place history. This is how Paul did it. He did it with his iPhone. This might be what we end up with.This is what the physician would have in front of him and her when we enter that exam room instead of just the pink slip that said I paid at the counter. Right? This could be my little assessment. And he looks at that and he says, "Whoa Bill, I suggest that maybe you not decide, just because you're out here in beautiful California, and it's warm every day, that you get out and run at six o'clock at night. I'd suggest that that's a bad idea Bill, because of this report."What I'd like to leave you for are two prescriptions. Okay, number one is, we must teach physicians about the value of geographical information. It's called geomedicine. There are about a half a dozen programs in the world right now that are focused on this. And they're in the early stages of development. These programs need to be supported, and we need to teach our future doctors of the world the importance of some of the information I've shared here with you today.The second thing we need to do is while we're spending billions and billions of dollars all over the world building an electronic health record, we make sure we put a place history inside that medical record. It not only will be important for the physician; it will be important for the researchers that now will have huge samples to draw upon. But it will also be useful for us. I could have made the decision, if I had this information, not to move to the ozone capital of the United States, couldn't I? I could make that decision. Or I could negotiate with my employer to make that decision in the best interest of myself and my company.With that, I would like to just say that Jack Lord said this almost 10 years ago. Just look at that for a minute. That was what the conclusion of the Dartmouth Atlas of Healthcare was about, was saying that we can explain the geographic variations that occur in disease, in illness, in wellness, and how our healthcare system actually operates. That was what he was talking about on that quote. And I would say he got it right almost a decade ago. So, I'd very much like to see us begin to really seize this as an opportunity to get this into our medical records. So with that, I'll leave you that in my particular view of view of health: Geography always matters. And I believe that geographic information can make both you and me very healthy. Thank you. (Applause)

title: Building a theater that remakes itself
transcript: I'm going to speak to you today about architectural agency. What I mean by that is that it's time for architecture to do things again, not just represent things. This is a construction helmet that I received two years ago at the groundbreaking of the largest project I, and my firm, have ever been involved in. I was thrilled to get it. I was thrilled to be the only person standing on the stage with a shiny silver helmet. I thought it represented the importance of the architect.I stayed thrilled until I got home, threw the helmet onto my bed, fell down onto my bed and realized inside there was an inscription. (Laughter) Now, I think that this is a great metaphor for the state of architecture and architects today. We are for decorative purposes only. (Laughter)Now, who do we have to blame? We can only blame ourselves. Over the last 50 years the design and construction industry has gotten much more complex and has gotten much more litigious. And we architects are cowards. So, as we have faced liability, we have stepped back and back, and unfortunately, where there is liability, guess what there is: power. So, eventually we have found ourselves in a totally marginalized position, way over here.Now, what did we do? We're cowards, but we're smart cowards. And so we redefined this marginalized position as the place of architecture. And we announced, "Hey, architecture, it's over here, in this autonomous language we're going to seed control of processes." And we were going to do something that was horrible for the profession. We actually created an artificial schism between creation and execution, as if you could actually create without knowing how to execute and as if you could actually execute without knowing how to create.Now, something else happened. And that's when we began to sell the world that architecture was created by individuals creating genius sketches. And that the incredible amount of effort to deliver those sketches for years and years and years is not only something to be derided, but we would merely write it off as merely execution. Now I'd argue that that is as absurd as stating that 30 minutes of copulation is the creative act, and nine months of gestation, and, God forbid, 24 hours of child labor is merely execution.So, what do we architects need to do? We need to stitch back creation and execution. And we need to start authoring processes again instead of authoring objects. Now, if we do this, I believe we can go back 50 years and start reinjecting agency, social engineering, back into architecture. Now, there are all kinds of things that we architects need to learn how to do, like managing contracts, learning how to write contracts, understanding procurement processes, understanding the time value of money and cost estimation.But I'm going to reduce this to the beginning of the process, into three very pedantic statements. The first is: Take core positions with your client. I know it's shocking, right, that architecture would actually say that.The second position is: Actually take positions. Take joint positions with your client. This is the moment in which you as the architect and your client can begin to inject vision and agency. But it has to be done together. And then only after this is done are you allowed to do this, begin to put forward architectural manifestations that manifest those positions. And both owner and architect alike are empowered to critique those manifestations based on the positions that you've taken.Now, I believe that one really amazing thing will happen if you do this. I'd like to call it the lost art of productively losing control. You do not know what the end result is. But I promise you, with enough brain power and enough passion and enough commitment, you will arrive at conclusions that will transcend convention, and will simply be something that you could not have initially or individually conceived of.Alright, now I'm going to reduce all of this to a series of simple dumb sketches. This is the modus operandi that we have today. We roll 120-foot Spartan, i.e. our vision, up to our clients' gates of Troy. And we don't understand why they won't let us in. Right? Well, how about instead of doing that, we roll up to the gates something they want.Now this is a little bit of a dangerous metaphor, because of course we all know that inside of the Trojan Horse were a bunch of people with spears. So, we can change the metaphor. Let's call the Trojan Horse the vessel by which you get through the gate, get through the constraints of a project. At which point, you and your client have the ability to start considering what you're going to put inside that vessel, the agency, the vision. And if you do that, you do that responsibly, I believe that instead of delivering Spartans, you can deliver maidens.And if I could summarize that all up into one single sketch it would be this. If we are so good at our craft shouldn't we be able to conceive of an architectural manifestation that slides seamlessly through the project's and the client's constraints? Now, with that in mind, I'm going to show a project that's very dear to many people in this room— well, maybe not dear, but certainly close to many people in this room. And that's a project that is just about to open next week, the new home for the Dallas Theater Center, the Dee and Charles Wyly Theatre.Now, I'm going to present it on the same terms: issue, position and architectural manifestation. Now, the first issue that we faced was that the Dallas Theater Center had a notoriety that was beyond what you would expect of some place outside of the triumvirate of New York, Chicago and Seattle. And this had to do with the ambitions of the leadership. But it also had to do with something rather unusual, and that was this horrible little building that they'd been performing in.Why was this horrible little building so important to their renown and their innovation? Because they could do whatever they wanted to to this building. When you're on Broadway, you cannot tear the proscenium down. This building, when an artistic director wanted to do a "Cherry Orchard" and wanted people and wanted people to come out of a well on the stage, they brought a backhoe in, and they simply dug the hole. Well, that's exciting. And you can start to get the best artistic directors, scenic designers and actors from around the country to come to perform here because you can do things you can't do elsewhere.So, the first position we took was, "Hey, we as architects had better not show up and do a pristine building that doesn't engender the same freedoms that this old dilapidated shed provided the company." The second issue is a nuance of the first. And that's that the company and the building was multiform. That meant that they were able to perform, as long as they had labor they were able to go between proscenium, thrust, flat floor, arena, traverse, you name it. All they needed was labor.Well, something happened. In fact something happened to all institutions around the world. It started to become hard to raise operational costs, operational budgets. So, they stopped having inexpensive labor. And eventually they had to freeze their organization into something called a bastardized thruscenium.So, the second position we took is that the freedoms that we provided, the ability to move between stage configurations, had better be able to be done without relying on operational costs. Alright? Affordably. The architectural manifestation was frankly just dumb. It was to take all the things that are known as front of house and back of house and redefine them as above house and below house.At first blush you think, "Hey it's crazy, what could you possibly gain?" We created what we like to call superfly. (Laughter) Now, superfly, the concept is you take all the freedoms you normally associate with the flytower, and you smear them across flytower and auditorium. Suddenly the artistic director can move between different stage and audience configurations. And because that flytower has the ability to pick up all the pristine elements, suddenly the rest of the environment can be provisional. And you can drill, cut, nail, screw paint and replace, with a minimum of cost.But there was a third advantage that we got by doing this move that was unexpected. And that was that it freed up the perimeter of the auditorium in a most unusual way. And that provided the artistic director suddenly the ability to define suspension of disbelief. So, the building affords artistic directors the freedom to conceive of almost any kind of activity underneath this floating object. But also to challenge the notion of suspension of disbelief such that in the last act of Macbeth, if he or she wants you to associate the parable that you're seeing with Dallas, with your real life, he or she can do so.Now, in order to do this we and the clients had to do something fairly remarkable. In fact it really was the clients who had to do it. They had to make a decision, based on the positions we took to redefine the budget being from two thirds capital-A architecture and one-third infrastructure, to actually the inverse, two-thirds infrastructure and one-third capital-A architecture. That's a lot for a client to commit to before you actually see the fruition of the concept. But based on the positions, they took the educated leap of faith to do so. And effectively we created what we like to call a theater machine.Now, that theater machine has ability to move between a whole series of configurations at the push of a button and a few stagehands in a short amount of time. But it also has the potential to not only provide multiform but multi-processional sequences. Meaning: The artistic director doesn't necessarily need to go through our lobby.One of the things that we learned when we visited various theaters is they hate us architects, because they say the first thing they have to do, the first five minutes of any show, is they have to get our architecture out of the mind of their patron. Well now there are potentials of this building to allow the artistic director to actually move into the building without using our architecture. So, in fact, there is the building, there is what we call the draw. You're going down into our lobby, go through the lobby with our own little dangly bits, whether you like them or not, up through the stair that leads you into the auditorium.But there is also the potential to allow people to move directly from the outside, in this case suggesting kind of Wagnerian entrance, into the interior of the auditorium. And here is the fruition of that in actuality. These are the two large pivoting doors that allow people to move directly from the outside, in or from the inside, out, performers or audience alike.Now, imagine what that could be. I have to say honestly this is not something yet the building can do because it takes too long. But imagine the freedoms if you could take this further, that in fact you could consider a Wagnerian entry, a first act in thrust, an intermission in Greek, a second act in arena, and you leave through our lobby with dangly bits. Now that, I would say, is architecture performing. It is taking the hand of the architect to actually remove the hand of the architect in favor of the hand of the artistic director.I'll go through the three basic configurations. This is the flat floor configuration. You notice that there is no proscenium, the balconies have been raised up, there are no seats, the floor in the auditorium is flat.The first configuration is easy to understand. The balconies come down, you see that the orchestra begins to have a rake that's frontal towards the end stage, and the seats come in.The third configuration is a little harder to understand. Here you see that the balconies actually have to move out of the way in order to bring a thrust into the space. And some of the seats need to actually change their direction, and change their rake, to allow that to happen.I'll do it again so you can see it. There you see it's the side balconies for the proscenium. And there it is in the thrust configuration.In order to do that, again, we needed a client who was willing to take educational risks. And they told us one important thing: "You shall not beta-test." Meaning, nothing that we do can we be the first ones to do it. But they were willing for us to apply technologies from other areas that already had failsafe mechanisms to this building.And the solution in terms of the balconies was to use something that we all know as a scoreboard lift. Now, if you were to take a scoreboard and drop it on dirt and whiskey, that would be bad. If you were not able to take the scoreboard out of the arena and be able to do the Ice Capades the next night, that would also be bad. And so this technology already had all the failsafe mechanisms and allowed the theater and our client to actually do this with confidence that they would be able to change over their configurations at will.The second technology that we applied was actually using things that you know from the stage side of an opera house. In this case what we're doing is we're taking the orchestra floor, lifting it up, spinning it, changing the rake, taking it back to flat floor, changing the rake again. In essence, you can begin to define rakes and viewing angles of people in the orchestra seating, at will.Here you see the chairs being spun around to go from proscenium or end stage to thrust configuration. The proscenium, also. As far as we know this is the first building in the world in which the proscenium can entirely fly out of the space. Here you see the various acoustic baffles as well as the flying mechanisms and catwalks over the auditorium. And ultimately, up in the flytower, the scene sets that allow the transformations to occur.As I said, all that was in service of creating a flexible yet affordable configuration. But we got this other benefit, and that was the ability of the perimeter to suddenly engage Dallas on the outside. Here you see the building in its current state with blinds closed. This is a trompe l'oeil. Actually this is not a curtain. These are vinyl blinds that are integrated into the windows themselves, again with failsafe mechanisms that can be lifted such that you can completely demystify, if you chose, the operations of the theater going on behind, rehearsals and so forth. But you also have the ability to allow the audience to see Dallas, to perform with Dallas as the backdrop of your performance.Now, if I'll take you through — this is an early concept sketch — take you through kind of a mixture of all these things together. Effectively you would have something like this. You would be allowed to bring objects or performers into the performing chamber: "Aida," their elephants, you can bring the elephants in. You would be able to expose the auditorium to Dallas or vice versa, Dallas to the auditorium. You'd be able to open portions in order to change the procession, allow people to come in and out for an intermission, or to enter for the beginning or the end of a performance.As I said, all the balconies can move, but they can also be disappeared completely. The proscenium can fly. You can bring large objects into the chamber itself. But most convincingly when we had to confront the idea of changing costs from architecture to infrastructure, is something that is represented by this. And again, this is not all the flexibilities of the building that is actually built, but at least suggests the ideas.This building has the ability, in short order, to go back to a flat floor organization such that they can rent it out. Now, if there is anyone here from American Airlines, please consider doing your Christmas party here. (Laughter) That allows the company to raise operational budgets without having to compete with other venues with much larger auditoriums. That's an enormous benefit.So, the theater company has the ability to do totally hermetic, light-controlled, sound-controlled, great acoustics, great intimacy Shakespeare, but can also do Beckett with the skyline of Dallas sitting behind it. Here it is in a flat floor configuration. The theater has been going through its kind of paces.Here it is in an end stage configuration. It's actually beautiful. There was a rock band. We stood outside trying to see if the acoustics worked, and you could see the guys doing this but you couldn't hear them. It was very unusual. Here it is in a thrust configuration. And last but not least, you see this already has the ability to create events in order to generate operational budgets to overcome the building in fact performing to allow the company to overcome their biggest problem.I'm going to show you a brief time lapse. As I said, this can be done with only two people, and with a minimum amount of time. This is the first time that actually the changeover was done and so there is literally thousands of people because everyone was excited and wanted to be a part of it. So, in a way try to disregard all the thousands of ants running around. And think of it being done with just a few people. Again, just a couple people are required. (Laughter) I promise. Et voila. (Applause)So, just in conclusion, a few shots. This is the AT&T Performing Arts Center's Dee and Charles Wyly Theater. There it is at night. And last but not least the entire AT&T Performing Arts Center. You can see the Winspear Opera House on the right and the Dee and Charles Wyly Theater on the left.And to remind you that here is an example in which architecture actually did something. But we got to that conclusion without understanding where we were going, what we knew were a series of issues that the company and the client was confronted with. And we took positions with them, and it was through those positions that we began to take architectural manifestations and we arrived at a conclusion that none of us, really none of us could ever have conceived of initially or individually. Thank you. (Applause)

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
that slides seamlessly through

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
the project's and the client's constraints?

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
Now, with that in mind, I'm going to show a project

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
that's very dear to many people in this room--

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.958
well, maybe not dear, but certainly close to many people in this room.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
And that's a project that is just about to open next week,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
the new home for the Dallas Theater Center,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
the Dee and Charles Wyly Theatre.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
Now, I'm going to present it on the same terms:

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
issue, position and architectural manifestation.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
Now, the first issue that we faced

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
was that the Dallas Theater Center

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
had a notoriety that was beyond what you would expect

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
of some place outside of the triumvirate

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:01.958
of New York, Chicago and Seattle.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
And this had to do with the ambitions of the leadership.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
But it also had to do with something rather unusual,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:10.958
and that was this horrible little building that they'd been performing in.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
Why was this horrible little building

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
so important to their renown and their innovation?

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
Because they could do whatever they wanted to to this building.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:24.958
When you're on Broadway, you cannot tear the proscenium down.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
This building, when an artistic director

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
wanted to do a "Cherry Orchard" and wanted people

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
and wanted people to come out of a well on the stage,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
they brought a backhoe in, and they simply dug the hole.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
Well, that's exciting.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
And you can start to get the best artistic directors,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
scenic designers and actors from around the country

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
to come to perform here

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
because you can do things you can't do elsewhere.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
So, the first position we took was,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
"Hey, we as architects had better not show up

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
and do a pristine building

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
that doesn't engender the same freedoms that this

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
old dilapidated shed provided the company."

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
The second issue is a nuance of the first.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
And that's that the company and the building was multiform.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
That meant that they were able to perform,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
as long as they had labor

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
they were able to go between proscenium, thrust, flat floor,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
arena, traverse, you name it.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
All they needed was labor.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
Well, something happened. In fact something happened to all institutions

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
around the world.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
It started to become hard to raise operational costs,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
operational budgets.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
So, they stopped having inexpensive labor.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
And eventually they had to freeze their organization

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
into something called a bastardized thruscenium.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
So, the second position we took is that the freedoms that we provided,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
the ability to move between stage configurations,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
had better be able to be done

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:42.958
without relying on operational costs. Alright? Affordably.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
The architectural manifestation

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
was frankly just dumb.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
It was to take all the things that are known as front of house and back of house

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
and redefine them as above house and below house.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
At first blush you think, "Hey it's crazy,

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
what could you possibly gain?"

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
We created what we like to call superfly.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:00.958
(Laughter)

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
Now, superfly, the concept is

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
you take all the freedoms you normally associate with the flytower,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
and you smear them across flytower and auditorium.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
Suddenly the artistic director

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
can move between different stage

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
and audience configurations.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And because that flytower has the ability to pick up

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
all the pristine elements, suddenly the rest of the environment

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
can be provisional. And you can drill, cut, nail, screw

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
paint and replace,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
with a minimum of cost.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
But there was a third advantage that we got by doing this move

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
that was unexpected.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
And that was that it freed up the perimeter of the auditorium

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
in a most unusual way.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
And that provided the artistic director suddenly

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
the ability to define suspension of disbelief.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
So, the building affords artistic directors the freedom

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
to conceive of almost any kind of activity

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
underneath this floating object.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
But also to challenge the notion of suspension of disbelief

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
such that in the last act of Macbeth,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
if he or she wants you to associate

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
the parable that you're seeing with Dallas, with your real life,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
he or she can do so.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Now, in order to do this we and the clients

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
had to do something fairly remarkable.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
In fact it really was the clients who had to do it.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
They had to make a decision, based on the positions we took

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
to redefine the budget being from two thirds capital-A architecture

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and one-third infrastructure,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
to actually the inverse,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
two-thirds infrastructure and one-third capital-A architecture.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
That's a lot for a client to commit to

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
before you actually see the fruition of the concept.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
But based on the positions,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
they took the educated leap of faith to do so.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
And effectively we created what we like to call

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
a theater machine.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
Now, that theater machine has ability

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
to move between a whole series of configurations

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
at the push of a button and a few stagehands

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
in a short amount of time.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
But it also has the potential

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
to not only provide multiform but multi-processional sequences.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
Meaning: The artistic director

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
doesn't necessarily need to go through our lobby.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
One of the things that we learned when we visited various theaters

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
is they hate us architects,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
because they say the first thing they have to do,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
the first five minutes of any show,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
is they have to get our architecture

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
out of the mind of their patron.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Well now there are potentials of this building

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
to allow the artistic director

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
to actually move into the building

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
without using our architecture.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
So, in fact, there is the building, there is what we call the draw.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
You're going down into our lobby,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:26.958
go through the lobby with our own little dangly bits, whether you like them or not,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
up through the stair that leads you into the auditorium.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
But there is also the potential

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
to allow people to move directly from the outside,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
in this case suggesting kind of Wagnerian entrance,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
into the interior of the auditorium.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
And here is the fruition of that in actuality.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
These are the two large pivoting doors

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
that allow people to move directly from the outside, in

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
or from the inside, out,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
performers or audience alike.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
Now, imagine what that could be. I have to say honestly

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
this is not something yet the building can do because it takes too long.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
But imagine the freedoms

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
if you could take this further, that in fact you could consider

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
a Wagnerian entry,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
a first act in thrust,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
an intermission in Greek, a second act in arena,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:10.958
and you leave through our lobby with dangly bits.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
Now that, I would say, is architecture performing.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
It is taking the hand of the architect

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
to actually remove the hand of the architect

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:20.958
in favor of the hand of the artistic director.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
I'll go through the three basic configurations.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
This is the flat floor configuration.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
You notice that there is no proscenium,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
the balconies have been raised up, there are no seats,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
the floor in the auditorium is flat.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
The first configuration is easy to understand.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
The balconies come down, you see that the orchestra

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
begins to have a rake that's frontal towards the end stage,

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
and the seats come in.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
The third configuration is a little harder to understand.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:48.958
Here you see that the balconies actually have to move out of the way

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
in order to bring a thrust into the space.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
And some of the seats need to actually change their direction,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
and change their rake, to allow that to happen.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
I'll do it again so you can see it.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:02.958
There you see it's the side balconies for the proscenium.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
And there it is in the thrust configuration.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
In order to do that,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
again, we needed a client who was willing to take educational risks.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
And they told us one important thing:

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
"You shall not beta-test."

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
Meaning, nothing that we do

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
can we be the first ones to do it.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
But they were willing for us to apply technologies

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:23.958
from other areas that already had failsafe mechanisms to this building.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
And the solution in terms of the balconies

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
was to use something that we all know as a scoreboard lift.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
Now, if you were to take a scoreboard

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
and drop it on dirt and whiskey,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
that would be bad.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
If you were not able to take the scoreboard out of the arena

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
and be able to do the Ice Capades the next night,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
that would also be bad.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:47.958
And so this technology already had all the failsafe mechanisms

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
and allowed the theater and our client

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
to actually do this with confidence

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
that they would be able to change over their configurations at will.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
The second technology that we applied

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.958
was actually using things that you know from

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
the stage side of an opera house.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
In this case what we're doing is we're taking

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:09.958
the orchestra floor, lifting it up, spinning it,

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
changing the rake, taking it back to flat floor,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
changing the rake again. In essence, you can begin to define

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
rakes and viewing angles

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
of people in the orchestra seating, at will.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
Here you see the chairs being spun around to go from proscenium or end stage

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
to thrust configuration.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:31.958
The proscenium, also. As far as we know this is the first building in the world

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
in which the proscenium can entirely fly out of the space.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
Here you see the various acoustic baffles as well as

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:41.958
the flying mechanisms and catwalks over the auditorium.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
And ultimately, up in the flytower,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.958
the scene sets that allow the transformations to occur.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:51.958
As I said, all that was in service of creating a flexible

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
yet affordable configuration.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
But we got this other benefit, and that was

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
the ability of the perimeter to suddenly engage

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
Dallas on the outside.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
Here you see the building in its current state

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
with blinds closed. This is a trompe l'oeil.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
Actually this is not a curtain. These are vinyl blinds

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
that are integrated into the windows themselves,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
again with failsafe mechanisms

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
that can be lifted such that you can completely demystify,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
if you chose, the operations of the theater

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
going on behind, rehearsals and so forth.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
But you also have the ability

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
to allow the audience to see Dallas,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
to perform with Dallas as the backdrop of your performance.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
Now, if I'll take you through --

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
this is an early concept sketch --

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
take you through kind of a mixture of all these things together.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
Effectively you would have something like this.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:42.958
You would be allowed to bring objects or performers into the performing chamber:

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
"Aida," their elephants, you can bring the elephants in.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:49.958
You would be able to expose the auditorium to Dallas

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
or vice versa, Dallas to the auditorium.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
You'd be able to open portions in order to

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
change the procession,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
allow people to come in and out for an intermission,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
or to enter for the beginning or the end of a performance.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
As I said, all the balconies can move,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
but they can also be disappeared completely.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
The proscenium can fly.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
You can bring large objects into the chamber itself.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
But most convincingly when we had to confront the idea

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
of changing costs from architecture to infrastructure,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
is something that is represented by this.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
And again, this is not all the flexibilities of the building that is actually built,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
but at least suggests the ideas.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
This building has the ability, in short order,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
to go back to a flat floor organization

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
such that they can rent it out.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
Now, if there is anyone here from American Airlines,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
please consider doing your Christmas party here.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:36.958
(Laughter)

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
That allows the company to raise operational budgets

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
without having to compete with other venues

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
with much larger auditoriums.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
That's an enormous benefit.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
So, the theater company has the ability

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
to do totally hermetic,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
light-controlled, sound-controlled, great acoustics,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
great intimacy Shakespeare,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
but can also do Beckett

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
with the skyline of Dallas sitting behind it.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
Here it is in a flat floor configuration.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
The theater has been going through its kind of paces.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
Here it is in an end stage configuration.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
It's actually beautiful. There was a rock band.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
We stood outside trying to see if the acoustics worked,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
and you could see the guys doing this but you couldn't hear them.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
It was very unusual.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
Here it is in a thrust configuration.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
And last but not least,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
you see this already has the ability to create events

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
in order to generate operational budgets

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:25.958
to overcome the building in fact performing

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
to allow the company to overcome their biggest problem.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:31.958
I'm going to show you a brief time lapse.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
As I said, this can be done with only two people,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
and with a minimum amount of time.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
This is the first time that actually the changeover was done

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
and so there is literally thousands of people because

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
everyone was excited and wanted to be a part of it.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:45.958
So, in a way try to disregard all the thousands of ants running around.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
And think of it being done with just a few people.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
Again, just a couple people are required.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:22.958
(Laughter)

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
I promise.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
Et voila.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:44.958
(Applause)

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:46.958
So, just in conclusion, a few shots.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
This is the AT&T Performing Arts Center's

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
Dee and Charles Wyly Theater.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:53.958
There it is at night.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:57.958
And last but not least the entire AT&T Performing Arts Center.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
You can see the Winspear Opera House on the right

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
and the Dee and Charles Wyly Theater on the left.

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:05.958
And to remind you that here is an example in which

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:07.958
architecture actually did something.
