00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
As a researcher, every once in a while

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
you encounter something

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
a little disconcerting.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
And this is something that changes your understanding of the world around you,

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:23.958
and teaches you that you're very wrong

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:27.958
about something that you really believed firmly in.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
And these are unfortunate moments,

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
because you go to sleep that night

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
dumber than when you woke up.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
So, that's really the goal of my talk,

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
is to A, communicate that moment to you

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
and B, have you leave this session

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
a little dumber than when you entered.

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.958
So, I hope I can really accomplish that.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:49.958
So, this incident that I'm going to describe

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
really began with some diarrhea.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
Now, we've known for a long time the cause of diarrhea.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
That's why there's a glass of water up there.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
For us, it's a problem, the people in this room.

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:03.958
For babies, it's deadly.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:07.958
They lack nutrients, and diarrhea dehydrates them.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
And so, as a result, there is a lot of death,

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
a lot of death.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
In India in 1960,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
there was a 24 percent child mortality rate,

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:20.958
lots of people didn't make it. This is incredibly unfortunate.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
One of the big reasons this happened was

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
because of diarrhea.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:27.958
Now, there was a big effort to solve this problem,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:31.958
and there was actually a big solution.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
This solution has been called, by some,

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
"potentially the most important medical

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.958
advance this century."

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
Now, the solution turned out to be simple.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:45.958
And what it was was oral rehydration salts.

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
Many of you have probably used this.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
It's brilliant. It's a way to get sodium

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
and glucose together so that when you add it to water

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
the child is able to absorb it even during situations of diarrhea.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:59.958
Remarkable impact on mortality.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
Massive solution to the problem.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
Flash forward: 1960, 24 percent child mortality

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
has dropped to 6.5 percent today.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
Still a big number, but a big drop.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
It looks like the technological problem is solved.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
But if you look, even today

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
there are about 400,000 diarrhea-related deaths

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:18.958
in India alone.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
What's going on here?

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
Well the easy answer is, we just haven't gotten those salts

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
to those people.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
That's actually not true.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
If you look in areas where these salts are completely available,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
the price is low or zero, these deaths still continue abated.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
Maybe there's a biological answer.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
Maybe these are the deaths that simple rehydration

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
alone doesn't solve. That's not true either.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:45.958
Many of these deaths were completely preventable,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
and this what I want to think of as the disconcerting thing,

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
what I want to call "the last mile" problem.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:54.958
See, we spent a lot of energy, in many domains --

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
technological, scientific, hard work,

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
creativity, human ingenuity --

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:02.958
to crack important social problems with technology solutions.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
That's been the discoveries of the last 2,000 years,

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
that's mankind moving forward.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
But in this case we cracked it,

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
but a big part of the problem still remains.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
Nine hundred and ninety-nine miles went well,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
the last mile's proving incredibly stubborn.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:20.958
Now, that's for oral rehydration therapy.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
Maybe this is something unique about diarrhea.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
Well, it turns out -- and this is where things get really disconcerting --

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
it's not unique to diarrhea.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
It's not even unique to poor people in India.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
Here's an example from a variety of contexts.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
I've put a bunch of examples up here.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
I'll start with insulin, diabetes

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
medication in the U.S.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
OK, the American population.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
On Medicaid -- if you're fairly poor you get Medicaid,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
or if you have health insurance -- insulin is pretty straightforward.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:48.958
You get it, either in pill form or you get it as an injection;

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
you have to take it every day to maintain your blood sugar levels.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
Massive technological advance:

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
took an incredibly deadly disease, made it solvable.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
Adherence rates. How many people are taking their insulin every day?

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:01.958
About on average, a typical person is taking it 75 percent of the time.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:06.958
As a result, 25,000 people a year go blind,

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
hundreds of thousands lose limbs, every year,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
for something that's solvable.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
Here I have a bunch of other examples,

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
all suffer from the last mile problem.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
It's not just medicine.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
Here's another example from technology:

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
agriculture. We think

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
there's a food problem, so we create new seeds.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
We think there's an income problem, so we create

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
new ways of farming that increase income.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
Well, look at some old ways, some ways that we'd already cracked.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Intercropping. Intercropping really increases income.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
Sometimes in rice we found incredible increases in yield

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
when you mix different varieties of rice side by side.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
Some people are doing that,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
many are not. What's going on?

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
This is the last mile.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
The last mile is, everywhere, problematic.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
Alright, what's the problem?

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
The problem is this little three-pound machine

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:54.958
that's behind your eyes and between your ears.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
This machine is really strange,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:05:00.958
and one of the consequences is that people are weird.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:04.958
They do lots of inconsistent things.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
(Applause)

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
They do lots of inconsistent things.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
And the inconsistencies

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
create, fundamentally, this last mile problem.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
See, when we were dealing with our biology, bacteria,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
the genes, the things inside here, the blood?

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
That's complex, but it's manageable.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
When we're dealing with people like this?

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
The mind is more complex.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
That's not as manageable, and that's what we're struggling with.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
Let me go back to diarrhea for a second.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
Here's a question that was asked in the National Sample Survey,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
which is a survey asked of many Indian women:

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
"Your child has diarrhea.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:43.958
Should you increase, maintain or decrease the number of fluids?"

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
Just so you don't embarrass yourselves, I'll give you the right answer:

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
It's increase.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:51.958
Now, diarrhea's interesting

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
because it's been around for thousands of years,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
ever since humankind really

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
lived side by side enough to have really polluted water.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
One Roman strategy that was very interesting

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
was that -- and it really gave them a comparative advantage --

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
they made sure their soldiers didn't drink

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
even remotely muddied waters.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
Because if some of your troops get diarrhea they're not that effective

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
on the battlefield.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
So, if you think of Roman comparative advantage part of it was the breast shields,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
the breastplates, but part of it was drinking the right water.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
So, here are these women. They've seen their parents

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
have struggled with diarrhea, they've struggled with diarrhea,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
they've seen lots of deaths. How do they answer this question?

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:30.958
In India, 35 to 50 percent say "Reduce."

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Think about what that means for a second.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
Thirty-five to 50 percent of women

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
forget oral rehydration therapy,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
they are increasing --

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
they are actually making their child

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
more likely to die through their actions.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
How is that possible?

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
Well, one possibility -- I think that's how most people respond to this --

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:53.958
is to say, "That's just stupid."

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
I don't think that's stupid.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
I think there is something very profoundly right in what these women are doing.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
And that is, you don't put water

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
into a leaky bucket.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:06.958
So, think of the mental model that goes behind reducing the intake.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
Just doesn't make sense.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
Now, the model is intuitively right.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
It just doesn't happen to be right about the world.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
But it makes a whole lot of sense at some deep level.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
And that, to me, is the fundamental challenge

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:26.958
of the last mile.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
This first challenge is what I refer to as the persuasion challenge.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
Convincing people to do something --

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
take oral rehydration therapy, intercrop, whatever it might be --

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
is not an act of information:

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
"Let's give them the data,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
and when they have data they'll do the right thing."

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
It's more complex than that.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
And if you want to understand how it's more complex

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:48.958
let me start with something kind of interesting.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
I'm going to give you a little math problem,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
and I want you to just yell out the answer as fast as possible.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
A bat and a ball together cost $1.10.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
The bat costs a dollar more than the ball.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
How much does the ball cost? Quick.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
So, somebody out there says, "Five."

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
A lot of you said, "Ten."

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Let's think about 10 for a second.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
If the ball costs 10, the bat costs...

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
this is easy, $1.10.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Yeah. So, together they would cost $1.20.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
So, here you all are, ostensibly educated people.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
Most of you look smart.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
The combination of that produces

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
something that is actually, you got this thing wrong.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
How is that possible? Let's go to something else.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
I know algebra can be complicated.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
So, let's dial this back. That's what? Fifth grade? Fourth grade?

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
Let's go back to kindergarten. OK?

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
There's a great show on American television that you have to watch.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
It's called "Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?"

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
I think we've learned the answer to that here.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
Let's move to kindergarten. Let's see if we can beat five-year-olds.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
Here's what I'm going to do: I'm going to put objects on the screen.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:57.958
I just want you to name the color of the object.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
That's all it is. OK?

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
I want you to do it fast, and say it out loud with me,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
and do it quickly. I'll make the first one easy for you.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
Ready? Black.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
Now the next ones I want you to do quickly and say it out loud.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
Ready? Go.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
Audience: Red. Green.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
Yellow. Blue. Red.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
(Laughter)

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:21.958
Sendhil Mullainathan: That's pretty good.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
Almost out of kindergarten.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
What is all this telling us?

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
You see, what's going on here, and in the bat and ball problem

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
is that you have some intuitive ways of interacting with the world,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
some models that you use to understand the world.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
These models, like the leaky bucket,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
work well in most situations.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
I suspect most of you --

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
I hope that's true for the rest of you --

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:45.958
actually do pretty well with addition and subtraction in the real world.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
I found a problem, a specific problem

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
that actually found an error with that.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
Diarrhea, and many last mile problems, are like that.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
They are situations where the mental model

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
doesn't match the reality.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
Same thing here:

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
You had an intuitive response to this that was very quick.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
You read "blue" and you wanted to say "blue," even though you knew your task was red.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
Now, I do this stuff because it's fun.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:09.958
But it's more profound than fun.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
I'll give you a good example of how it actually effects persuasion.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
BMW is a pretty safe car.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
And they are trying to figure out, "Safety is good.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
I want to advertise safety. How am I going to advertise safety?"

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
"I could give people numbers. We do well on crash tests."

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
But the truth of the matter is, you look at that car,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
it doesn't look like a Volvo,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
and it doesn't look like a Hummer.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
So, what I want you to think about for a few minutes

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
is: How would you convey safety of the BMW? Okay?

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
So now, while you're thinking about that let's move to a second task.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
The second task is fuel efficiency. Okay?

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
Here's another puzzle for all of you.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
One person walks into a car lot,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
and they're thinking about buying this Toyota Yaris.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
They are saying, "This is 35 miles per gallon. I'm going to do

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
the environmentally right thing, I'm going to buy the Prius,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
50 miles per gallon."

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
Another person walks into the lot,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
and they're about to buy a Hummer, nine miles per gallon,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
fully loaded, luxury.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:02.958
And they say, "You know what? Do I need turbo? Do I need this heavyweight car?"

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
I'm going to do something good for the environment.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
I'm going to take off some of that weight,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
and I'm going to buy a Hummer that's 11 miles per gallon."

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
Which one of these people has done more for the environment?

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
See, you have a mental model.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
Fifty versus 35, that's a big move. Eleven versus nine? Come on.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
Turns out, go home and do the math,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
the nine to 11 is a bigger change. That person has saved more gallons.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
Why? Because we don't care about miles per gallon, we care about

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
gallons per mile.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
Think about how powerful that is if you're trying to encourage fuel efficiency.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
Miles per gallon is the way we present things.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
If we want to encourage change of behavior,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
gallons per mile would have far more effectiveness.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
Researchers have found these type of anomalies.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
Okay, back to BMW. What should they do?

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
The problem BMW faces is this car looks safe.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:50.958
This car, which is my Mini, doesn't look that safe.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
Here was BMW's brilliant insight, which they embodied into an ad campaign.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
They showed a BMW driving down the street.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
There's a truck on the right. Boxes fall out of the truck.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:03.958
The car swerves to avoid it, and therefore doesn't get into an accident.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
BWM realizes safety, in people's minds, has two components.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
You can be safe because when you're hit, you survive,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
or you can be safe because you avoid accidents.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
Remarkably successful campaign, but notice the power of it.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
It harnesses something you already believe.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
Now, even if I persuaded you to do something,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:26.958
it's hard sometimes to actually get action as a result.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
You all probably intended to wake up,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
I don't know, 6:30, 7 a.m.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
This is a battle we all fight every day,

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
along with trying to get to the gym.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
Now, this is an example of that battle,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
and makes us realize intentions don't always translate into action,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
and so one of the fundamental challenges

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:48.958
is how we would actually do that. OK?

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
So, let me now talk about the last mile problem.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
So far, I've been pretty negative.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
I've been trying to show you the oddities of human behavior.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And I think maybe I'm being too negative.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
Maybe it's the diarrhea.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
Maybe the last mile problem really should be thought of

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
as the last mile opportunity.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
Let's go back to diabetes.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
This is a typical insulin injection.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
Now, carrying this thing around is complicated.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:17.958
You gotta carry the bottle, you gotta carry the syringe.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
It's also painful.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:23.958
Now, you may think to yourself, "Well, if my eyes depended on it,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
you know, I would obviously use it every day."

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
But the pain, the discomfort,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
you know, paying attention, remembering to put it in your purse

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
when you go on a long trip:

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:35.958
These are the day-to-day of life, and they do pose problems.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
Here is an innovation, a design innovation.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.958
This is a pen, it's called an insulin pen, preloaded.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:43.958
The needle is particularly sharp.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
You just gotta carry this thing around.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
It's much easier to use, much less painful.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:51.958
Anywhere between five and 10 percent increase in adherence,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
just as a result of this.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
That's what I'm talking about as a last mile opportunity.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
You see, we tend to think the problem is solved

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
when we solve the technology problem.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
But the human innovation, the human problem

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
still remains, and that's a great frontier that we have left.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
This isn't about the biology of people;

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:13.958
this is now about the brains, the psychology of people,

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
and innovation needs to continue all the way through

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
the last mile.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
Here's another example of this.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.958
This is from a company called Positive Energy.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
This is about energy efficiency.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
We're spending a lot of time on fuel cells right now.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
What this company does is they send a letter

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
to households that say, "Here's your energy use,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
here's your neighbor's energy use: You're doing well." Smiley face.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
"You're doing worse." Frown.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
And what they find is just this letter, nothing else,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
has a two to three percent reduction in electricity use.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
And you want to think about the social value of that

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
in terms of carbon offsets, reduced electricity,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
900 million dollars per year.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
Why? Because for free,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
this isn't a new technology, this is a letter --

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
we're getting a Big Bang in behavior.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:57.958
So, how do we tackle the last mile?

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
I think this tells us there is an opportunity.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
And I think to tackle it, we need to combine

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
psychology,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
marketing,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
art, we've seen that.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
But you know what we need to combine it with?

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
We need to combine this with the scientific method.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:16.958
See what's really puzzling and frustrating about the last mile, to me,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
is that the first 999 miles are all about science.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
No one would say, "Hey, I think this medicine works, go ahead and use it."

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
We have testing, we go to the lab, we try it again, we have refinement.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
But you know what we do on the last mile?

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
"Oh, this is a good idea. People will like this. Let's put it out there."

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
The amount of resources we put in are disparate.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
We put billions of dollars into fuel-efficient technologies.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
How much are we putting into

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
energy behavior change

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
in a credible, systematic, testing way?

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
Now, I think that we're on the verge of something big.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
We're on the verge of a whole new social science.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
It's a social science that recognizes --

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
much like science recognizes the complexity of the body,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
biology recognizes the complexity of the body -- we'll recognize

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
the complexity of the human mind.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
The careful testing, retesting, design,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
are going to open up vistas of understanding,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
complexities, difficult things.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
And those vistas will both create new science,

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
and fundamental change in the world as we see it, in the next hundred years.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
All right. Thank you very much.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
(Applause)

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
Chris Anderson: Sendhil, thank you so much.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
So, this whole area is so fascinating.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
I mean, it sometimes feels, listening to behavioral economists

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
that they are kind of putting into place

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
academically, what great marketers

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
have sort of intuitively known for a long time.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:36.958
How much is your field talking to great marketers

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
about their insights into human psychology?

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
Because they've seen it on the ground.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
Sendhil Mullainathan: Yeah, we spend a lot of time talking to marketers,

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
and I think 60 percent of it is exactly what you say,

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
there are insights to be gleaned there.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
Forty percent of it is about what marketing is.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:54.958
Marketing is selling an ad to a firm.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
So, in some sense, a lot of marketing is about

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
convincing a CEO, "This is a good ad campaign."

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
So, there is a little bit of slippage there.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:05.958
That's just a caveat. That's different from actually having an effective ad campaign.

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
And one of the new movements in marketing is: How do we actually

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
measure effectiveness? Are we effective?

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:13.958
CA: How you take your insights here

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
and actually get them integrated

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
into working business models on the ground,

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
in Indian villages, for example?

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
SM: So, the scientific method I alluded to is pretty important.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
We work closely with companies that have operational capacity,

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
or nonprofits that have operational capacity.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:30.958
And then we say, "Well, you want to get this behavior change.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
Let's come up with a few ideas, test them,

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
see which is working, go back, synthesize,

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
and try to come up with a thing that works,"

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
and then we're able to scale with partners.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
It's kind of the model that has worked in other contexts.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
If you have biological problems

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
we try and fix it, see if it works, and then work the scale.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.958
CA: Alright Sendhil, thanks so much for coming to TED. Thank you.

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:51.958
(Applause)

title: The big idea my brother inspired
transcript: When my brother called me in December of 1998, he said, "The news does not look good." This is him on the screen. He'd just been diagnosed with ALS, which is a disease that the average lifespan is three years. It paralyzes you. It starts by killing the motor neurons in your spinal cord. And you go from being a healthy, robust 29-year-old male to someone that cannot breathe, cannot move, cannot speak.This has actually been, to me, a gift, because we began a journey to learn a new way of thinking about life. And even though Steven passed away three years ago we had an amazing journey as a family. We did not even — I think adversity is not even the right word. We looked at this and we said, "We're going to do something with this in an incredibly positive way." And I want to talk today about one of the things that we decided to do, which was to think about a new way of approaching healthcare. Because, as we all know here today, it doesn't work very well. I want to talk about it in the context of a story.This is the story of my brother. But it's just a story. And I want to go beyond the story, and go to something more. "Given my status, what is the best outcome I can hope to achieve, and how do I get there?" is what we are here to do in medicine, is what everyone should do. And those questions all have variables to them. All of our statuses are different. All of our hopes and dreams, what we want to accomplish, is different, and our paths will be different, they are all stories.But it's a story until we convert it to data and so what we do, this concept we had, was to take Steven's status, "What is my status?" and go from this concept of walking, breathing, and then his hands, speak, and ultimately happiness and function. So, the first set of pathologies, they end up in the stick man on his icon, but the rest of them are really what's important here. Because Steven, despite the fact that he was paralyzed, as he was in that pool, he could not walk, he could not use his arms — that's why he had the little floaty things on them, did you see those? — he was happy. We were at the beach, he was raising his son, and he was productive.And we took this, and we converted it into data. But it's not a data point at that one moment in time. It is a data point of Steven in a context. Here he is in the pool. But here he is healthy, as a builder: taller, stronger, got all the women, amazing guy. Here he is walking down the aisle, but he can barely walk now, so it's impaired. And he could still hold his wife's hand, but he couldn't do buttons on his clothes, can't feed himself. And here he is, paralyzed completely, unable to breathe and move, over this time journey. These stories of his life, converted to data. He renovated my carriage house when he was completely paralyzed, and unable to speak, and unable to breathe, and he won an award for a historic restoration.So, here's Steven alone, sharing this story in the world. And this is the insight, the thing that we are excited about, because we have gone away from the community that we are, the fact that we really do love each other and want to care for each other. We need to give to others to be successful. So, Steven is sharing this story, but he is not alone. There are so many other people sharing their stories. Not stories in words, but stories in data and words. And we convert that information into this structure, this understanding, this ability to convert those stories into something that is computable, to which we can begin to change the way medicine is done and delivered.We did this for ALS. We can do this for depression, Parkinson's disease, HIV. These are not simple, they are not internet scalable; they require thought and processes to find the meaningful information about the disease. So, this is what it looks like when you go to the website. And I'm going to show you what Patients Like Me, the company that myself, my youngest brother and a good friend from MIT started.Here are the actual patients, there are 45,000 of them now, sharing their stories as data. Here is an M.S. patient. His name is Mike, and he is uniformly impaired on cognition, vision, walking, sensation. Those are things that are different for each M.S. patient. Each of them can have a different characteristic. You can see fibromyalgia, HIV, ALS, depression. Look at this HIV patient down here, Zinny. It's two years of this disease. All of the symptoms are not there. But he is working to keep his CD4 count high and his viral level low so he can make his life better.But you can aggregate this and you can discover things about treatments. Look at this, 2,000 people almost, on Copaxone. These are patients currently on drugs, sharing data. I love some of these, physical exercise, prayer. Anyone want to run a comparative effectiveness study on prayer against something? Let's look at prayer. What I love about this, just sort of interesting design problems. These are why people pray. Here is the schedule of how frequently they — it's a dose. So, anyone want to see the 32 patients that pray for 60 minutes a day, and see if they're doing better, they probably are. Here they are. It's an open network, everybody is sharing. We can see it all.Or, I want to look at anxiety, because people are praying for anxiety. And here is data on 15,000 people's current anxiety, right now. How they treat it, the drugs, the components of it, their side effects, all of it in a rich environment, and you can drill down and see the individuals. This amazing data allows us to drill down and see what this drug is for — 1,500 people on this drug, I think. Yes. I want to talk to the 58 patients down here who are taking four milligrams a day. And I want to talk to the ones of those that have been doing it for more than two years. So, you can see the duration. All open, all available. I'm going to log in.And this is my brother's profile. And this is a new version of our platform we're launching right now. This is the second generation. It's going to be in Flash. And you can see here, as this animates over, Steven's actual data against the background of all other patients, against this information. The blue band is the 50th percentile. Steven is the 75th percentile, that he has non-genetic ALS. You scroll down in this profile and you can see all of his prescription drugs, but more than that, in the new version, I can look at this interactively. Wait, poor spinal capacity.Doesn't this remind you of a great stock program? Wouldn't it be great if the technology we used to take care of ourselves was as good as the technology we use to make money? Detrol. In the side effects for his drug, integrated into that, the stem cell transplant that he had, the first in the world, shared openly for anyone who wants to see it.I love here — the cyberkinetics implant, which was, again, the only patient's data that was online and available. You can adjust the time scale. You can adjust the symptoms. You can look at the interaction between how I treat my ALS. So, you click down on the ALS tab there. I'm taking three drugs to manage it. Some of them are experimental. I can look at my constipation, how to manage it. I can see magnesium citrate, and the side effects from that drug all integrated in the time in which they're meaningful.But I want more. I don't want to just look at this cool device, I want to take this data and make something even better. I want my brother's center of the universe and his symptoms and his drugs, and all of the things that interact among those, the side effects, to be in this beautiful data galaxy that we can look at in any way we want to understand it, so that we can take this information and go beyond just this simple model of what a record is.I don't even know what a medical record is. I want to solve a problem. I want an application. So, can I take this data — rearrange yourself, put the symptoms in the left, the drugs across the top, tell me everything we know about Steven and everyone else, and what interacts. Years after he's had these drugs, I learned that everything he did to manage his excess saliva, including some positive side effects that came from other drugs, were making his constipation worse. And if anyone's ever had severe constipation, and you don't understand how much of an impact that has on your life — yes, that was a pun.You're trying to manage these, and this grid is available here, and we want to understand it. No one's ever had this kind of information. So, patients have this. We're for patients. This is all about patient health care, there was no doctors on our network. This is about the patients. So, how can we take this and bring them a tool that they can go back and they can engage the medical system? And we worked hard, and we thought about it and we said, "What's something we can use all the time, that we can use in the medical care system, that everyone will understand?"So, the patients print it out, because hospitals usually block us because they believe we are a social network. It's actually the most used feature on the website. Doctors actually love this sheet, and they're actually really engaged. So, we went from this story of Steven and his history to data, and then back to paper, where we went back and engaged the medical care system. And here's another paper. This is a journal, PNAS — I think it's the Proceedings of the National Academy of Science of the United States of America. You've seen multiple of these today, when everyone's bragging about the amazing things they've done. This is a report about a drug called lithium. Lithium, that is a drug used to treat bipolar disorder, that a group in Italy found slowed ALS down in 16 patients, and published it.Now, we'll skip the critiques of the paper. But the short story is: If you're a patient, you want to be on the blue line. You don't want to be on the red line, you want to be on the blue line. Because the blue line is a better line. The red line is way downhill, the blue line is a good line. So, you know we said — we looked at this, and what I love also is that people always accuse these Internet sites of promoting bad medicine and having people do things irresponsibly. So, this is what happened when PNAS published this. Ten percent of the people in our system took lithium. Ten percent of the patients started taking lithium based on 16 patients of data in a bad publication. And they call the Internet irresponsible. Here's the implication of what happens.There's this one guy, named Humberto, from Brazil, who unfortunately passed away nine months ago, who said, "Hey, listen. Can you help us answer this question? Because I don't want to wait for the next trial, it's going to be years. I want to know now. Can you help us?" So, we launched some tools, we let them track their blood levels. We let them share the data and exchange it. You know, a data network. And they said, you know, "Jamie, PLM, can you guys tell us whether this works or not?" And we went around and we talked to people, and they said, "You can't run a clinical trial like this. You know? You don't have the blinding, you don't have data, it doesn't follow the scientific method. It's never going to work. You can't do it."So, I said, "Okay well we can't do that. Then we can do something harder." (Laughter) I can't say whether lithium works in all ALS patients, but I can say whether it works in Humberto. I bought a Mac about two years ago, I converted over, and I was so excited about this new feature of the time machine that came in Leopard. And we said — because it's really cool, you can go back and you can look at the entire history of your computer, and find everything you've lost, and I loved it. And I said, "What if we built a time machine for patients, except instead of going backwards, we go forwards. Can we find out what's going to happen to you, so that you can maybe change it?"So, we did. We took all the patients like Humberto, That's the Apple background, we stole that because we didn't have time to build our own. This is a real app by the way. This is not just graphics. And you take those data, and we find the patients like him, and we bring their data together. And we bring their histories into it. And then we say, "Well how do we line them all up?" So, we line them all up so they go together around the meaningful points, integrated across everything we know about the patient. Full information, the entire course of their disease. And that's what is going to happen to Humberto, unless he does something. And he took lithium, and he went down the line. And it works almost every time.Now, the ones that it doesn't work are interesting. But almost all the time it works. It's actually scary. It's beautiful. So, we couldn't run a clinical trial, we couldn't figure it out. But we could see whether it was going to work for Humberto. And yeah, all the clinicians in the audience will talk about power and all the standard deviation. We'll do that later. But here is the answer of the mean of the patients that actually decided to take lithium. These are all the patients that started lithium. It's the Intent to Treat Curve. You can see here, the blue dots on the top, the light ones, those are the people in the study in PNAS that you wanted to be on. And the red ones are the ones, the pink ones on the bottom are the ones you didn't want to be. And the ones in the middle are all of our patients from the start of lithium at time zero, going forward, and then going backward.So, you can see we matched them perfectly, perfectly. Terrifyingly accurate matching. And going forward, you actually don't want to be a lithium patient this time. You're actually doing slightly worse — not significantly, but slightly worse. You don't want to be a lithium patient this time. But you know, a lot of people dropped out, the trial, there is too much drop out. Can we do the even harder thing? Can we go to the patients that actually decided to stay on lithium, because they were so convinced they were getting better?We asked our control algorithm, are those 69 patients — by the way, you'll notice that's four times the number of patients in the clinical trial — can we look at those patients and say, "Can we match them with our time machine to the other patients that are just like them, and what happens?" Even the ones that believed they were getting better matched the controls exactly. Exactly. Those little lines? That's the power.So, we — I can't tell you lithium doesn't work. I can't tell you that if you did it at a higher dose or if you run the study proper — I can tell you that for those 69 people that took lithium, they didn't do any better than the people that were just like them, just like me, and that we had the power to detect that at about a quarter of the strengths reported in the initial study. We did that one year ahead of the time when the first clinical trial funded by the NIH for millions of dollars failed for futility last week, and announced it.So, remember I told you about my brother's stem cell transplant. I never really knew whether it worked. And I put 100 million cells in his cisterna magna, in his lumbar cord, and filled out the IRBs and did all this work, and I never really knew. How did I not know? I mean, I didn't know what was going to happen to him. I actually asked Tim, who is the quant in our group — we actually searched for about a year to find someone who could do the sort of math and statistics and modeling in healthcare, couldn't find anybody. So, we went to the finance industry. And there are these guys who used to model the future of interest rates, and all that kind of stuff. And some of them were available. So, we hired one. (Laughter)We hired them, set them up, assisting at lab. I I.M. him things. That's the way I communicate with him, is like a little guy in a box. I I.M.ed Tim. I said, "Tim can you tell me whether my brother's stem cell transplant worked or not?" And he sent me this two days ago. It was that little outliers there. You see that guy that lived a long time? We have to go talk to him. Because I'd like to know what happened. Because something went different. But my brother didn't. My brother went straight down the line. It only works about 12 months.It's the first version of the time machine. First time we ever tried it. We'll try to get it better later but 12 months so far. And, you know, I look at this, and I get really emotional. You look at the patients, you can drill in all the controls, you can look at them, you can ask them. And I found a woman that had — we found her, she was odd because she had data after she died. And her husband had come in and entered her last functional scores, because he knew how much she cared. And I am thankful.I can't believe that these people, years after my brother had died, helped me answer the question about whether an operation I did, and spent millions of dollars on years ago, worked or not. I wished it had been there when I'd done it the first time, and I'm really excited that it's here now, because the lab that I founded has some data on a drug that might work, and I'd like to show it. I'd like to show it in real time, now, and I want to do that for all of the diseases that we can do that for. I've got to thank the 45,000 people that are doing this social experiment with us. There is an amazing journey we are going on to become human again, to be part of community again, to share of ourselves, to be vulnerable, and it's very exciting. So, thank you. (Applause)

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
When my brother called me in December of 1998,

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
he said, "The news does not look good."

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
This is him on the screen.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
He'd just been diagnosed with ALS,

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:24.958
which is a disease that the average lifespan is three years.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
It paralyzes you. It starts by killing

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
the motor neurons in your spinal cord.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
And you go from being a healthy,

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:34.958
robust 29-year-old male

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
to someone that cannot breathe,

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:39.958
cannot move, cannot speak.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:46.958
This has actually been, to me, a gift,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:49.958
because we began a journey

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
to learn a new way of thinking about life.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:56.958
And even though Steven passed away three years ago

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
we had an amazing journey as a family.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:01.958
We did not even --

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
I think adversity is not even the right word.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:06.958
We looked at this and we said, "We're going to do something with this

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
in an incredibly positive way."

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
And I want to talk today

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
about one of the things that we decided to do,

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:17.958
which was to think about a new way of approaching healthcare.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
Because, as we all know here today,

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
it doesn't work very well.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
I want to talk about it in the context of a story.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
This is the story of my brother.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
But it's just a story. And I want to go beyond the story,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
and go to something more.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
"Given my status, what is the best outcome

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.958
I can hope to achieve, and how do I get there?"

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
is what we are here to do in medicine, is what everyone should do.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
And those questions all have variables to them.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
All of our statuses are different.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
All of our hopes and dreams, what we want to accomplish,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:48.958
is different, and our paths will be different,

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
they are all stories.

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
But it's a story until we convert it to data

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
and so what we do, this concept we had,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.958
was to take Steven's status, "What is my status?"

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:02.958
and go from this concept of walking, breathing,

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
and then his hands, speak,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:09.958
and ultimately happiness and function.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
So, the first set of pathologies, they end up in the stick man

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
on his icon,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
but the rest of them are really what's important here.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
Because Steven, despite the fact that he was paralyzed,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
as he was in that pool, he could not walk,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
he could not use his arms -- that's why he had the little floaty things on them,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
did you see those? --

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
he was happy. We were at the beach,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
he was raising his son, and he was productive.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:35.958
And we took this, and we converted it into data.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
But it's not a data point at that one moment in time.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
It is a data point of Steven in a context.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
Here he is in the pool. But here he is healthy,

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:44.958
as a builder: taller, stronger,

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
got all the women, amazing guy.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
Here he is walking down the aisle,

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
but he can barely walk now, so it's impaired.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
And he could still hold his wife's hand, but he couldn't do buttons on his clothes,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
can't feed himself.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
And here he is, paralyzed completely,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
unable to breathe and move, over this time journey.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
These stories of his life, converted to data.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
He renovated my carriage house

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
when he was completely paralyzed, and unable to speak,

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:12.958
and unable to breathe, and he won an award for a historic restoration.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
So, here's Steven alone, sharing this story in the world.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
And this is the insight, the thing that we are

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
excited about,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
because we have gone away from the community that we are,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
the fact that we really do love each other and want to care for each other.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
We need to give to others to be successful.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
So, Steven is sharing this story,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
but he is not alone.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
There are so many other people sharing their stories.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
Not stories in words, but stories in data and words.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
And we convert that information into this structure,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
this understanding, this ability to convert

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
those stories into something that is computable,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
to which we can begin to change the way

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
medicine is done and delivered.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
We did this for ALS. We can do this for depression,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
Parkinson's disease, HIV.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
These are not simple, they are not internet scalable;

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
they require thought and processes

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
to find the meaningful information about the disease.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
So, this is what it looks like when you go to the website.

And I'm going to show you what Patients Like Me,

the company that myself, my youngest brother

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
I'm taking three drugs to manage it. Some of them are experimental.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
I can look at my constipation, how to manage it.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
I can see magnesium citrate, and the side effects

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
from that drug all integrated in the time

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
in which they're meaningful.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
But I want more.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
I don't want to just look at this cool device, I want to take this

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
data and make something even better.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
I want my brother's center of the universe and his symptoms

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
and his drugs,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
and all of the things that interact among those,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
the side effects, to be in this beautiful data galaxy

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
that we can look at in any way we want to understand it,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
so that we can take this information

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:48.958
and go beyond just this simple model

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
of what a record is.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
I don't even know what a medical record is.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
I want to solve a problem. I want an application.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
So, can I take this data -- rearrange yourself,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
put the symptoms in the left, the drugs across the top,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
tell me everything we know about Steven and everyone else,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and what interacts.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
Years after he's had these drugs,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
I learned that everything he did to manage his excess saliva,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
including some positive side effects that came from other drugs,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
were making his constipation worse.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
And if anyone's ever had severe constipation,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
and you don't understand how much of an impact that has on your life --

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
yes, that was a pun.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
You're trying to manage these,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
and this grid is available here,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
and we want to understand it.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
No one's ever had this kind of information.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
So, patients have this. We're for patients.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
This is all about patient health care, there was no doctors on our network.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
This is about the patients.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
So, how can we take this and bring them a tool

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
that they can go back and they can engage the medical system?

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
And we worked hard, and we thought about it and we said,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
"What's something we can use all the time,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
that we can use in the medical care system,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
that everyone will understand?"

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
So, the patients print it out,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
because hospitals usually block us

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
because they believe we are a social network.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
It's actually the most used feature on the website.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Doctors actually love this sheet, and they're actually really engaged.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
So, we went from this story of Steven

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
and his history to data, and then back to paper,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:11.958
where we went back and engaged the medical care system.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
And here's another paper.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
This is a journal, PNAS --

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
I think it's the Proceedings of the National Academy of Science

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
of the United States of America.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
You've seen multiple of these today, when everyone's bragging about

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
the amazing things they've done.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
This is a report about a drug called lithium.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:29.958
Lithium, that is a drug used to treat bipolar disorder,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
that a group in Italy found

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
slowed ALS down in 16 patients, and published it.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
Now, we'll skip the critiques of the paper.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
But the short story is: If you're a patient,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
you want to be on the blue line.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
You don't want to be on the red line, you want to be on the blue line.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
Because the blue line is a better line. The red line

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
is way downhill, the blue line is a good line.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
So, you know we said -- we looked at this, and what I love also

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
is that people always accuse these Internet sites

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
of promoting bad medicine and having people do things irresponsibly.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
So, this is what happened when PNAS published this.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Ten percent of the people in our system took lithium.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
Ten percent of the patients started taking lithium based on 16 patients of data

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
in a bad publication.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
And they call the Internet irresponsible.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
Here's the implication of what happens.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
There's this one guy, named Humberto, from Brazil,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
who unfortunately passed away nine months ago,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
who said, "Hey, listen. Can you help us answer this question?

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
Because I don't want to wait for the next trial, it's going to be years.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
I want to know now. Can you help us?"

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
So, we launched some tools, we let them track their blood levels.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
We let them share the data and exchange it.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
You know, a data network.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
And they said, you know, "Jamie, PLM,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
can you guys tell us whether this works or not?"

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
And we went around and we talked to people,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
and they said, "You can't run a clinical trial like this. You know?

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
You don't have the blinding, you don't have data,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
it doesn't follow the scientific method.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
It's never going to work. You can't do it."

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
So, I said, "Okay well we can't do that. Then we can do something harder."

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
(Laughter)

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
I can't say whether lithium works in all ALS patients,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
but I can say whether it works in Humberto.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
I bought a Mac about two years ago, I converted over,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
and I was so excited about this new feature of the time machine

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
that came in Leopard. And we said -- because it's really cool,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
you can go back and you can look at the entire history of your computer,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and find everything you've lost, and I loved it.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:10.958
And I said, "What if we built a time machine for patients,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
except instead of going backwards, we go forwards.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
Can we find out what's going to happen to you,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
so that you can maybe change it?"

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
So, we did. We took all the patients like Humberto,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
That's the Apple background, we stole that because we didn't have time

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
to build our own. This is a real app by the way.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
This is not just graphics.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
And you take those data, and we find the patients like him, and we bring

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
their data together. And we bring their histories into it.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
And then we say, "Well how do we line them all up?"

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
So, we line them all up so they go together

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
around the meaningful points,

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
integrated across everything we know about the patient.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
Full information, the entire course of their disease.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
And that's what is going to happen to Humberto,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
unless he does something.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
And he took lithium, and he went down the line.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
And it works almost every time.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
Now, the ones that it doesn't work are interesting.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
But almost all the time it works.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
It's actually scary. It's beautiful.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
So, we couldn't run a clinical trial, we couldn't figure it out.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
But we could see whether it was going to work for Humberto.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
And yeah, all the clinicians in the audience will talk about power

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
and all the standard deviation. We'll do that later.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:16.958
But here is the answer

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
of the mean of the patients that actually decided

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
to take lithium.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
These are all the patients that started lithium.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
It's the Intent to Treat Curve.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:28.958
You can see here, the blue dots on the top, the light ones,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
those are the people in the study in PNAS

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
that you wanted to be on. And the red ones are the ones,

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
the pink ones on the bottom are the ones you didn't want to be.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
And the ones in the middle are all of our patients

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
from the start of lithium at time zero,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:43.958
going forward, and then going backward.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
So, you can see we matched them perfectly, perfectly.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
Terrifyingly accurate matching.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:52.958
And going forward, you actually don't want to be a lithium patient this time.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
You're actually doing slightly worse -- not significantly,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
but slightly worse. You don't want to be a lithium patient this time.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
But you know, a lot of people dropped out,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
the trial, there is too much drop out.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
Can we do the even harder thing? Can we go to the patients

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
that actually decided to stay on lithium,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
because they were so convinced they were getting better?

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
We asked our control algorithm,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
are those 69 patients -- by the way, you'll notice

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
that's four times the number of patients in the clinical trial --

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
can we look at those patients and say,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
"Can we match them with our time machine

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
to the other patients that are just like them,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
and what happens?"

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Even the ones that believed they were getting better

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
matched the controls exactly. Exactly.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
Those little lines? That's the power.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
So, we -- I can't tell you lithium doesn't work. I can't tell you

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
that if you did it at a higher dose

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
or if you run the study proper -- I can tell you

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
that for those 69 people that took lithium,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
they didn't do any better than the people that were just like them,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
just like me,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
and that we had the power to detect that at about

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
a quarter of the strengths reported in the initial study.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
We did that one year ahead of the time

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
when the first clinical trial funded by the NIH

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
for millions of dollars failed for futility last week,

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
and announced it.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
So, remember I told you about my brother's stem cell transplant.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
I never really knew whether it worked.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
And I put 100 million cells in his cisterna magna,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
in his lumbar cord,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
and filled out the IRBs and did all this work,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.958
and I never really knew.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
How did I not know?

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
I mean, I didn't know what was going to happen to him.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
I actually asked Tim, who is the quant in our group --

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
we actually searched for about a year to find someone

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
who could do the sort of math and statistics and modeling

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
in healthcare, couldn't find anybody. So, we went to the finance industry.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
And there are these guys who used to model the future

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
of interest rates, and all that kind of stuff.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
And some of them were available. So, we hired one.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
(Laughter)

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
We hired them, set them up, assisting at lab.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
I I.M. him things. That's the way I communicate with him,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
is like a little guy in a box. I I.M.ed Tim. I said,

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
"Tim can you tell me whether my brother's stem cell transplant

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
worked or not?"

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
And he sent me this two days ago.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
It was that little outliers there. You see that guy that lived a long time?

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
We have to go talk to him. Because I'd like to know what happened.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
Because something went different.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
But my brother didn't. My brother went straight down the line.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
It only works about 12 months.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
It's the first version of the time machine.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
First time we ever tried it. We'll try to get it better later

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
but 12 months so far.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:24.958
And, you know, I look at this,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
and I get really emotional.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
You look at the patients, you can drill in all the controls,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
you can look at them, you can ask them.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:33.958
And I found a woman that had --

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
we found her, she was odd because she had data

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
after she died.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
And her husband had come in and entered her last functional scores,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
because he knew how much she cared.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
And I am thankful.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
I can't believe that these people,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
years after my brother had died,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
helped me answer the question about whether

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
an operation I did, and spent millions of dollars on

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
years ago, worked or not.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
I wished it had been there

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
when I'd done it the first time,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
and I'm really excited that it's here now,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:08.958
because the lab that I founded

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
has some data on a drug that might work,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:14.958
and I'd like to show it.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
I'd like to show it in real time, now,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:21.958
and I want to do that for all of the diseases that we can do that for.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
I've got to thank the 45,000 people

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
that are doing this social experiment with us.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
There is an amazing journey we are going on

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
to become human again,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
to be part of community again,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
to share of ourselves, to be vulnerable,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
and it's very exciting. So, thank you.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:45.958
(Applause)

title: A lab the size of a postage stamp
transcript: The problem I want to talk with you about is really the problem of: How does one supply health care in a world in which cost is everything? How do you do that? And the basic paradigm we want to suggest to you, I want to suggest to you, is one in which you say that in order to treat disease, you have to first know what you're treating, that's diagnostics, and then you have to do something.The program we're involved in is something we call "Diagnostics for All," or "zero-cost diagnostics." How do you provide medically relevant information at as close as possible to zero cost? How do you do it? Let me just give you two examples. The rigors of military medicine are not so dissimilar from the third world: poor resources, a rigorous environment — a series of problems — light weight and things of this kind. And also they're not so different from the home health care and diagnostic system world.So, the technology I want to talk about is for the third world, for the developing world, but it has, I think, much broader application, because information is so important in the health care system. So you see two examples here. One is a lab that is actually a fairly high-end laboratory in Africa. The second is basically an entrepreneur who is set up and doing who-knows-what at a table in a market. I don't know what kind of health care is delivered there. But it's not really what is probably most efficient.What is our approach? The way in which one typically approaches a problem of lowering cost, starting from the perspective of the United States, is to take our solution, and then try to cut cost out of it. No matter how you do that, you're not going to start with a $100,000 instrument and bring it down to no cost. It isn't going to work.So the approach we took was the other way around, to ask: What is the cheapest possible stuff that you could make a diagnostic system out of, and get useful information and add function? And what we've chosen is paper. What you see here is a prototypic device. It's about a centimeter on the side. It's about the size of a fingernail. The lines around the edges are a polymer. It's made of paper. And paper, of course, wicks fluid, as you know, paper, cloth — drop wine on the tablecloth, and the wine wicks all over everything. Put it on your shirt, it ruins the shirt. That's what a hydrophilic surface does.So in this device, the idea is that you drip the bottom end of it in a drop of, in this case, urine. The fluid wicks its way into those chambers at the top. The brown color indicates the amount of glucose in the urine, the blue color indicates the amount of protein in the urine. And the combination of those two is a first-order shot at a number of useful things that you want. So, this is an example of a device made from a simple piece of paper.Now, how simple can you make the production? Why do we choose paper? There's an example of the same thing on a finger, showing you basically what it looks like. One reason for using paper is that it's everywhere. We have made these kinds of devices using napkins and toilet paper and wraps, and all kinds of stuff.So the production capability is there. The second is, you can put lots and lots of tests in a very small place. I'll show you in a moment that the stack of paper there would probably hold something like 100,000 tests, something of that kind.And then finally, a point you don't think of so much in developed world medicine: it eliminates sharps. And what sharps means is needles, things that stick. If you've taken a sample of someone's blood and the someone might have hepatitis C, you don't want to make a mistake and stick it in you. You don't want to do that. So how do you dispose of that? It's a problem everywhere, and here, you simply burn it. So it's a sort of a practical approach to starting on things.Now, you say, "If paper is a good idea, other people have surely thought of it." And the answer is, of course, yes. Those half of you, roughly, who are women, at some point may have had a pregnancy test. And the most common of these is in a device that looks like the thing on the left. It's something called a lateral-flow immunoassay. In that particular test, urine, either containing a hormone called hCG, does or does not flow across a piece of paper. And there are two bars; one bar indicates that the test is working, and if the second bar shows up, you're pregnant.This is a terrific kind of test in a binary world, and the nice thing about pregnancy is either you are pregnant or you're not pregnant; you're not partially pregnant or thinking about being pregnant or something of that sort. So it works very well there, but it doesn't work very well when you need more quantitative information.There are also dipsticks, but if you look at the dipsticks, they're for another kind of urine analysis. There are an awful lot of colors and things like that. What do you actually do about that in a difficult circumstance? So the approach we started with is to ask: Is it really practical to make things of this sort? And that problem is now, in a purely engineering way, solved. And the procedure that we have is simply to start with paper. You run it through a new kind of printer called a wax printer. The wax printer does what looks like printing. It is printing. You put that on, you warm it a little bit, the wax prints through, so it absorbs into the paper, and you end up with the device you want.The printers cost 800 bucks now. We estimate that if you were to run them 24 hours a day, they'd make about 10 million tests a year. So it's a solved problem. That particular problem is solved. And there is an example of the kind of thing that you see. That's on a piece of 8 by 12 paper. That takes about two seconds to make. And so I regard that as done. There's a very important issue here, which is that because it's a printer, a color printer, it prints colors. That's what color printers do. I'll show you in a moment, that's actually quite useful.Now, the next question that you would like to ask is: What would you like to measure? What would you like to analyze? And the thing you'd most like to analyze, we're a fair distance from. It's what's called "fever of undiagnosed origin." Someone comes into the clinic, they have a fever, they feel bad. What do they have? Do they have TB? Do they have AIDS? Do they have a common cold? The triage problem. That's a hard problem for reasons I won't go through. There are an awful lot of things that you'd like to distinguish among. But then there are a series of things — AIDS, hepatitis, malaria, TB, others — and simpler ones, such as guidance of treatment.Now, even that's more complicated than you think. A friend of mine works in transcultural psychiatry, and he is interested in the question of why people do and don't take their meds. So Dapsone, or something like that, you have to take for a while.
