He has a wonderful story of talking to a villager in India and saying, "Have you taken your Dapsone?" "Yes." "Have you taken it every day?" "Yes." "Have you taken if for a month?" "Yes." What the guy actually meant was that he'd fed a 30-day dose of Dapsone to his dog that morning.(Laughter)And he was telling the truth, because in a different culture, the dog is a surrogate for you; "today," "this month," "since the rainy season" — there are lots of opportunities for misunderstanding.(Laughter)And so an issue here is to, in some cases, figure out how to deal with matters that seem uninteresting, like compliance.Now, take a look at what a typical test looks like. Prick a finger, you get some blood — about 50 microliters. That's about all you're going to get, because you can't use the usual sort of systems. You can't manipulate it very well; I'll show something about that in a moment. So you take the drop of blood, no further manipulations, you put it on a little device, the device filters out the blood cells, lets the serum go through, and you get a series of colors down in the bottom there. And the colors indicate "disease" or "normal." But even that's complicated, because to me, colors might indicate "normal," but after all, we're all suffering from probably an excess of education.What do you do about something which requires quantitative analysis? And so the solution that we and many other people are thinking about there, and at this point, there is a dramatic flourish, and out comes the universal solution to everything these days, which is a cell phone — in this particular case, a camera phone. They're everywhere — six billion a month in India. And the idea is that what one does is to take the device, you dip it, you develop the color, you take a picture, the picture goes to a central laboratory. You don't have to send out a doctor, you send out somebody who can just take the sample, and in the clinic either a doctor, or ideally, a computer in this case, does the analysis. Turns out to work actually quite well, particularly when your color printer has printed the color bars that indicate how things work.So my view of the health care worker of the future is not a doctor, but an 18-year-old, otherwise unemployed, who has two things: a backpack full of these tests and a lancet to occasionally take a blood sample, and an AK-47. And these are the things that get him through his day.(Laughter)There's another very interesting connection here, and that is, that what one wants to do is pass through useful information over what is generally a pretty awful telephone system. It turns out there's an enormous amount of information already available on that subject, which is the Mars Rover problem. How do you get back an accurate view of the color on Mars if you have a really terrible bandwidth to do it with? And the answer is not complicated, but it's one which I don't want to go through here, other than to say that the communication systems for doing this are really pretty well understood.Also, a fact which you may not know is that the compute capability of this thing is not so different from the compute capability of your desktop computer. This is a fantastic device which is only beginning to be tapped. I don't know whether the idea of one computer, one child makes any sense. Here's the computer of the future, because this screen is already there and they're ubiquitous.All right, let me show you just a little bit about advanced devices. And we'll start by posing a little problem. What you see here is another centimeter-sized device, and the different colors are different colors of dye. And you notice something which might strike you as a little bit interesting, which is, the yellow seems to disappear, get through the blue, and then get through the red. How does that happen? How do you make something flow through something? And, of course the answer is, "You don't." You make it flow under and over.But now the question is: How do you make it flow under and over in a piece of paper? The answer is that what you do — and the details are not terribly important here — is to make something more elaborate: You take several different layers of paper, each one containing its own little fluid system, and you separate them by pieces of, literally, double-sided carpet tape, the stuff you use to stick the carpets onto the floor. And the fluid will flow from one layer into the next. It distributes itself, flows through further holes, distributes itself.And what you see, at the lower right-hand side there, is a sample in which a single sample of blood has been put on the top, and it has gone through and distributed itself into these 16 holes on the bottom, in a piece of paper — basically, it looks like a chip, two pieces of paper thick. And in this particular case, we were just interested in the replicability of that. But that is, in principle, the way you solve the "fever of unexplained origin" problem, because each one of those spots then becomes a test for a particular set of markers of disease, and this will work in due course.Here is an example of a slightly more complicated device. There's the chip. You dip in a corner. The fluid goes into the center. It distributes itself out into these various wells or holes and turns color, all done with paper and carpet tape. So it's, I think, as low-cost as we're likely to be able to come up and make things.Now, I have two last little stories to tell you in finishing off this business. This is one: One of the things you occasionally need to do is separate blood cells from serum. And the question was, here we do it by taking a sample, we put it in a centrifuge, we spin it, and you get blood cells out. Terrific. What happens if you don't have electricity, a centrifuge, and whatever? And we thought for a while of how you might do this, and the way, in fact, you do it, is what's shown here. You get an eggbeater, which is everywhere, and you saw off a blade, and then you take tubing, and you stick it on that. You put the blood in, somebody sits there and spins it. It works really, really well.And we sat down, we did the physics of eggbeaters and self-aligning tubes and all the rest of that kind of thing, and sent it off to a journal. We were very proud of this, particularly the title, which was "Eggbeater as Centrifuge."(Laughter)And we sent it off, and by return mail, it came back. I called up the editor and I said, "What's going on? How is this possible?" The editor said, with enormous disdain, "I read this. And we're not going to publish it, because we only publish science."(Laughter)And it's an important issue, because it means that we have to, as a society, think about what we value. And if it's just papers and Phys. Rev. letters, we've got a problem.Here is another example of something which is — this is a little spectrophotometer. It measures the absorption of light in a sample. The neat thing about this is, you have a light source that flickers on and off at about 1,000 hertz, another light source that detects that light at 1,000 hertz, and so you can run this system in broad daylight. It performs about equivalently to a system that's on the order of 100,000 dollars. It costs 50 dollars. We can probably make it for 50 cents if we put our mind to it. Why doesn't somebody do it? The answer is: How do you make a profit in a capitalist system, doing that? Interesting problem.So, let me finish by saying that we've thought about this as a kind of engineering problem. And we've asked: What is the scientific unifying idea here? And we've decided we should think about this not so much in terms of cost, but in terms of simplicity. Simplicity is a neat word. You've got to think about what simplicity means. I know what it is, but I don't actually know what it means.So I actually was interested enough in this to put together several groups of people. The most recent involved a couple of people at MIT, one of them being an exceptionally bright kid who is one of the very few people I would think of who's an authentic genius. We all struggled for an entire day to think about simplicity. And I want to give you the answer of this deep scientific thought.[What is simplicity? "It's impossible to f..k it up"](Laughter)So, in a sense, you get what you pay for.Thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.658 --> 00:00:17.634
The problem I want to talk with you
about is really the problem of:

00:00:17.658 --> 00:00:24.464
How does one supply health care
in a world in which cost is everything?

00:00:24.972 --> 00:00:26.209
How do you do that?

00:00:27.157 --> 00:00:29.492
And the basic paradigm
we want to suggest to you,

00:00:29.516 --> 00:00:30.741
I want to suggest to you,

00:00:30.765 --> 00:00:34.437
is one in which you say
that in order to treat disease,

00:00:34.461 --> 00:00:37.833
you have to first know
what you're treating, that's diagnostics,

00:00:37.857 --> 00:00:39.504
and then you have to do something.

00:00:39.528 --> 00:00:43.844
The program we're involved in is something
we call "Diagnostics for All,"

00:00:43.868 --> 00:00:45.979
or "zero-cost diagnostics."

00:00:46.003 --> 00:00:49.417
How do you provide medically
relevant information

00:00:49.441 --> 00:00:52.065
at as close as possible to zero cost?

00:00:52.089 --> 00:00:53.319
How do you do it?

00:00:53.343 --> 00:00:55.134
Let me just give you two examples.

00:00:55.665 --> 00:01:01.531
The rigors of military medicine are not
so dissimilar from the third world:

00:01:01.555 --> 00:01:05.907
poor resources, a rigorous environment --
a series of problems --

00:01:05.931 --> 00:01:07.912
light weight and things of this kind.

00:01:07.936 --> 00:01:11.370
And also they're not so different
from the home health care

00:01:11.394 --> 00:01:13.799
and diagnostic system world.

00:01:13.823 --> 00:01:18.671
So, the technology I want to talk
about is for the third world,

00:01:18.695 --> 00:01:20.093
for the developing world,

00:01:20.117 --> 00:01:22.658
but it has, I think,
much broader application,

00:01:22.682 --> 00:01:26.145
because information is so important
in the health care system.

00:01:26.999 --> 00:01:28.793
So you see two examples here.

00:01:28.817 --> 00:01:34.566
One is a lab that is actually
a fairly high-end laboratory in Africa.

00:01:34.590 --> 00:01:38.894
The second is basically an entrepreneur
who is set up and doing who-knows-what

00:01:38.918 --> 00:01:40.365
at a table in a market.

00:01:40.389 --> 00:01:43.336
I don't know what kind
of health care is delivered there.

00:01:43.360 --> 00:01:47.212
But it's not really
what is probably most efficient.

00:01:48.299 --> 00:01:50.932
What is our approach?

00:01:51.400 --> 00:01:56.925
The way in which one typically
approaches a problem of lowering cost,

00:01:56.949 --> 00:01:59.812
starting from the perspective
of the United States,

00:01:59.836 --> 00:02:01.979
is to take our solution,

00:02:02.003 --> 00:02:04.158
and then try to cut cost out of it.

00:02:04.721 --> 00:02:06.134
No matter how you do that,

00:02:06.158 --> 00:02:08.664
you're not going to start
with a $100,000 instrument

00:02:08.688 --> 00:02:10.109
and bring it down to no cost.

00:02:10.133 --> 00:02:11.306
It isn't going to work.

00:02:11.330 --> 00:02:14.189
So the approach we took
was the other way around, to ask:

00:02:14.213 --> 00:02:16.678
What is the cheapest possible stuff

00:02:16.702 --> 00:02:19.638
that you could make
a diagnostic system out of,

00:02:19.662 --> 00:02:22.209
and get useful information
and add function?

00:02:22.233 --> 00:02:24.230
And what we've chosen is paper.

00:02:24.254 --> 00:02:27.278
What you see here is a prototypic device.

00:02:27.302 --> 00:02:29.134
It's about a centimeter on the side.

00:02:29.158 --> 00:02:31.135
It's about the size of a fingernail.

00:02:31.159 --> 00:02:34.762
The lines around the edges are a polymer.

00:02:34.786 --> 00:02:36.628
It's made of paper.

00:02:36.652 --> 00:02:41.337
And paper, of course, wicks fluid,
as you know, paper, cloth --

00:02:41.361 --> 00:02:43.237
drop wine on the tablecloth,

00:02:43.261 --> 00:02:45.998
and the wine wicks all over everything.

00:02:46.022 --> 00:02:48.061
Put it on your shirt, it ruins the shirt.

00:02:48.085 --> 00:02:50.824
That's what a hydrophilic surface does.

00:02:50.848 --> 00:02:54.471
So in this device, the idea
is that you drip the bottom end of it

00:02:54.495 --> 00:02:57.134
in a drop of, in this case, urine.

00:02:57.158 --> 00:03:00.906
The fluid wicks its way
into those chambers at the top.

00:03:00.930 --> 00:03:05.134
The brown color indicates
the amount of glucose in the urine,

00:03:05.158 --> 00:03:08.705
the blue color indicates the amount
of protein in the urine.

00:03:08.729 --> 00:03:11.765
And the combination of those two
is a first-order shot

00:03:11.789 --> 00:03:14.911
at a number of useful things
that you want.

00:03:14.935 --> 00:03:18.292
So, this is an example of a device
made from a simple piece of paper.

00:03:18.316 --> 00:03:20.576
Now, how simple can you make
the production?

00:03:21.158 --> 00:03:22.923
Why do we choose paper?

00:03:23.417 --> 00:03:26.327
There's an example
of the same thing on a finger,

00:03:26.351 --> 00:03:28.607
showing you basically what it looks like.

00:03:28.631 --> 00:03:31.059
One reason for using paper
is that it's everywhere.

00:03:31.083 --> 00:03:36.256
We have made these kinds of devices
using napkins and toilet paper

00:03:36.280 --> 00:03:38.510
and wraps, and all kinds of stuff.

00:03:38.534 --> 00:03:40.972
So the production capability is there.

00:03:40.996 --> 00:03:45.293
The second is, you can put lots and lots
of tests in a very small place.

00:03:45.317 --> 00:03:48.136
I'll show you in a moment
that the stack of paper there

00:03:48.160 --> 00:03:50.892
would probably hold
something like 100,000 tests,

00:03:50.916 --> 00:03:52.657
something of that kind.

00:03:52.681 --> 00:03:55.526
And then finally, a point
you don't think of so much

00:03:55.550 --> 00:03:58.134
in developed world medicine:

00:03:58.158 --> 00:03:59.837
it eliminates sharps.

00:03:59.861 --> 00:04:03.243
And what sharps means
is needles, things that stick.

00:04:03.267 --> 00:04:05.561
If you've taken a sample
of someone's blood

00:04:05.585 --> 00:04:08.082
and the someone might have hepatitis C,

00:04:08.106 --> 00:04:10.653
you don't want to make a mistake
and stick it in you.

00:04:10.677 --> 00:04:11.974
You don't want to do that.

00:04:11.998 --> 00:04:13.487
So how do you dispose of that?

00:04:13.511 --> 00:04:16.193
It's a problem everywhere,
and here, you simply burn it.

00:04:16.217 --> 00:04:19.717
So it's a sort of a practical approach
to starting on things.

00:04:21.375 --> 00:04:25.031
Now, you say, "If paper is a good idea,

00:04:25.055 --> 00:04:27.018
other people have surely thought of it."

00:04:27.042 --> 00:04:28.924
And the answer is, of course, yes.

00:04:28.948 --> 00:04:32.768
Those half of you, roughly, who are women,

00:04:32.792 --> 00:04:35.254
at some point may have had
a pregnancy test.

00:04:35.278 --> 00:04:39.262
And the most common of these
is in a device

00:04:39.286 --> 00:04:41.134
that looks like the thing on the left.

00:04:41.158 --> 00:04:43.650
It's something called
a lateral-flow immunoassay.

00:04:43.674 --> 00:04:45.134
In that particular test,

00:04:45.158 --> 00:04:48.773
urine, either containing
a hormone called hCG,

00:04:48.797 --> 00:04:52.134
does or does not flow
across a piece of paper.

00:04:52.158 --> 00:04:56.059
And there are two bars; one bar
indicates that the test is working,

00:04:56.083 --> 00:04:59.248
and if the second bar shows up,
you're pregnant.

00:04:59.272 --> 00:05:02.443
This is a terrific kind of test
in a binary world,

00:05:02.467 --> 00:05:05.382
and the nice thing about pregnancy
is either you are pregnant

00:05:05.406 --> 00:05:06.560
or you're not pregnant;

00:05:06.584 --> 00:05:09.565
you're not partially pregnant
or thinking about being pregnant

00:05:09.589 --> 00:05:10.873
or something of that sort.

00:05:10.897 --> 00:05:13.632
So it works very well there,
but it doesn't work very well

00:05:13.656 --> 00:05:15.742
when you need more
quantitative information.

00:05:15.766 --> 00:05:16.986
There are also dipsticks,

00:05:17.010 --> 00:05:18.756
but if you look at the dipsticks,

00:05:18.780 --> 00:05:20.993
they're for another kind
of urine analysis.

00:05:21.017 --> 00:05:23.894
There are an awful lot of colors
and things like that.

00:05:23.918 --> 00:05:27.211
What do you actually do about that
in a difficult circumstance?

00:05:28.330 --> 00:05:32.639
So the approach we started with is to ask:

00:05:32.663 --> 00:05:36.134
Is it really practical
to make things of this sort?

00:05:36.158 --> 00:05:40.445
And that problem is now,
in a purely engineering way, solved.

00:05:40.469 --> 00:05:44.018
And the procedure that we have
is simply to start with paper.

00:05:44.042 --> 00:05:47.588
You run it through a new kind
of printer called a wax printer.

00:05:47.612 --> 00:05:50.244
The wax printer does
what looks like printing.

00:05:50.268 --> 00:05:51.426
It is printing.

00:05:51.450 --> 00:05:53.490
You put that on, you warm it a little bit,

00:05:53.514 --> 00:05:56.557
the wax prints through,
so it absorbs into the paper,

00:05:56.581 --> 00:05:58.725
and you end up with the device you want.

00:05:58.749 --> 00:06:01.828
The printers cost 800 bucks now.

00:06:01.852 --> 00:06:05.740
We estimate that if you were
to run them 24 hours a day,

00:06:05.764 --> 00:06:07.872
they'd make about 10 million tests a year.

00:06:07.896 --> 00:06:11.120
So it's a solved problem.
That particular problem is solved.

00:06:11.144 --> 00:06:13.920
And there is an example
of the kind of thing that you see.

00:06:13.944 --> 00:06:15.783
That's on a piece of 8 by 12 paper.

00:06:15.807 --> 00:06:18.076
That takes about two seconds to make.

00:06:18.100 --> 00:06:20.742
And so I regard that as done.

00:06:20.766 --> 00:06:22.560
There's a very important issue here,

00:06:22.584 --> 00:06:27.002
which is that because it's a printer,
a color printer, it prints colors.

00:06:27.026 --> 00:06:28.550
That's what color printers do.

00:06:28.574 --> 00:06:31.340
I'll show you in a moment,
that's actually quite useful.

00:06:32.609 --> 00:06:35.134
Now, the next question
that you would like to ask is:

00:06:35.158 --> 00:06:38.349
What would you like to measure?
What would you like to analyze?

00:06:38.373 --> 00:06:43.134
And the thing you'd most like to analyze,
we're a fair distance from.

00:06:43.158 --> 00:06:47.134
It's what's called
"fever of undiagnosed origin."

00:06:47.158 --> 00:06:50.719
Someone comes into the clinic,
they have a fever, they feel bad.

00:06:50.743 --> 00:06:51.909
What do they have?

00:06:51.933 --> 00:06:55.335
Do they have TB? Do they have AIDS?
Do they have a common cold?

00:06:55.359 --> 00:06:56.573
The triage problem.

00:06:56.597 --> 00:06:59.253
That's a hard problem for reasons
I won't go through.

00:06:59.277 --> 00:07:02.819
There are an awful lot of things
that you'd like to distinguish among.

00:07:02.843 --> 00:07:05.045
But then there are a series of things --

00:07:05.069 --> 00:07:08.653
AIDS, hepatitis, malaria, TB, others --

00:07:08.677 --> 00:07:12.172
and simpler ones,
such as guidance of treatment.

00:07:12.196 --> 00:07:15.134
Now, even that's more
complicated than you think.

00:07:15.158 --> 00:07:19.373
A friend of mine works
in transcultural psychiatry,

00:07:19.397 --> 00:07:21.503
and he is interested in the question

00:07:21.527 --> 00:07:24.257
of why people do
and don't take their meds.

00:07:24.281 --> 00:07:27.856
So Dapsone, or something like that,
you have to take for a while.

00:07:27.880 --> 00:07:31.496
He has a wonderful story
of talking to a villager in India

00:07:31.520 --> 00:07:32.671
and saying,

00:07:32.695 --> 00:07:34.501
"Have you taken your Dapsone?" "Yes."

00:07:34.525 --> 00:07:36.391
"Have you taken it every day?" "Yes."

00:07:36.415 --> 00:07:38.369
"Have you taken if for a month?" "Yes."

00:07:38.393 --> 00:07:39.894
What the guy actually meant

00:07:39.918 --> 00:07:43.820
was that he'd fed a 30-day dose of Dapsone
to his dog that morning.

00:07:43.844 --> 00:07:44.969
(Laughter)

00:07:44.993 --> 00:07:48.749
And he was telling the truth,
because in a different culture,

00:07:48.773 --> 00:07:51.347
the dog is a surrogate for you;

00:07:51.371 --> 00:07:54.514
"today," "this month,"
"since the rainy season" --

00:07:54.538 --> 00:07:57.022
there are lots of opportunities
for misunderstanding.

00:07:57.046 --> 00:07:58.053
(Laughter)

00:07:58.077 --> 00:08:01.641
And so an issue here is to,
in some cases, figure out

00:08:01.665 --> 00:08:05.776
how to deal with matters
that seem uninteresting, like compliance.

00:08:07.118 --> 00:08:10.663
Now, take a look
at what a typical test looks like.

00:08:11.377 --> 00:08:15.134
Prick a finger, you get some blood --
about 50 microliters.

00:08:15.158 --> 00:08:16.989
That's about all you're going to get,

00:08:17.013 --> 00:08:20.989
because you can't use
the usual sort of systems.

00:08:21.543 --> 00:08:23.217
You can't manipulate it very well;

00:08:23.241 --> 00:08:25.357
I'll show something
about that in a moment.

00:08:25.381 --> 00:08:28.134
So you take the drop of blood,
no further manipulations,

00:08:28.158 --> 00:08:29.941
you put it on a little device,

00:08:29.965 --> 00:08:34.638
the device filters out the blood cells,
lets the serum go through,

00:08:34.662 --> 00:08:38.423
and you get a series of colors
down in the bottom there.

00:08:38.447 --> 00:08:42.606
And the colors indicate
"disease" or "normal."

00:08:42.630 --> 00:08:44.312
But even that's complicated,

00:08:44.336 --> 00:08:47.937
because to me, colors
might indicate "normal,"

00:08:47.961 --> 00:08:52.921
but after all, we're all suffering
from probably an excess of education.

00:08:52.945 --> 00:08:57.532
What do you do about something
which requires quantitative analysis?

00:08:57.556 --> 00:09:00.238
And so the solution
that we and many other people

00:09:00.262 --> 00:09:01.873
are thinking about there,

00:09:01.897 --> 00:09:04.486
and at this point,
there is a dramatic flourish,

00:09:04.510 --> 00:09:07.682
and out comes the universal solution
to everything these days,

00:09:07.706 --> 00:09:08.863
which is a cell phone --

00:09:08.887 --> 00:09:10.885
in this particular case, a camera phone.

00:09:10.909 --> 00:09:15.134
They're everywhere --
six billion a month in India.

00:09:15.158 --> 00:09:20.680
And the idea is that what one does
is to take the device,

00:09:20.704 --> 00:09:23.134
you dip it, you develop the color,

00:09:23.158 --> 00:09:26.383
you take a picture,
the picture goes to a central laboratory.

00:09:26.407 --> 00:09:28.134
You don't have to send out a doctor,

00:09:28.158 --> 00:09:30.899
you send out somebody
who can just take the sample,

00:09:30.923 --> 00:09:34.648
and in the clinic either a doctor,
or ideally, a computer in this case,

00:09:34.672 --> 00:09:35.836
does the analysis.

00:09:35.860 --> 00:09:37.711
Turns out to work actually quite well,

00:09:37.735 --> 00:09:40.827
particularly when your color printer
has printed the color bars

00:09:40.851 --> 00:09:42.672
that indicate how things work.

00:09:42.696 --> 00:09:45.720
So my view of the health care
worker of the future

00:09:45.744 --> 00:09:48.311
is not a doctor, but an 18-year-old,

00:09:48.335 --> 00:09:51.087
otherwise unemployed, who has two things:

00:09:51.111 --> 00:09:53.194
a backpack full
of these tests and a lancet

00:09:53.218 --> 00:09:55.134
to occasionally take a blood sample,

00:09:55.158 --> 00:09:56.717
and an AK-47.

00:09:56.741 --> 00:09:59.337
And these are the things
that get him through his day.

00:09:59.361 --> 00:10:00.909
(Laughter)

00:10:02.070 --> 00:10:04.405
There's another very
interesting connection here,

00:10:04.429 --> 00:10:09.969
and that is, that what one wants to do
is pass through useful information

00:10:09.993 --> 00:10:13.524
over what is generally
a pretty awful telephone system.

00:10:13.548 --> 00:10:16.134
It turns out there's an enormous
amount of information

00:10:16.158 --> 00:10:19.537
already available on that subject,
which is the Mars Rover problem.

00:10:19.561 --> 00:10:23.428
How do you get back an accurate view
of the color on Mars

00:10:23.452 --> 00:10:27.238
if you have a really terrible
bandwidth to do it with?

00:10:27.262 --> 00:10:29.134
And the answer is not complicated,

00:10:29.158 --> 00:10:31.699
but it's one which I don't want
to go through here,

00:10:31.723 --> 00:10:34.767
other than to say that the communication
systems for doing this

00:10:34.791 --> 00:10:36.492
are really pretty well understood.

00:10:36.516 --> 00:10:39.253
Also, a fact which you may not know

00:10:39.277 --> 00:10:43.011
is that the compute capability
of this thing is not so different

00:10:43.035 --> 00:10:45.874
from the compute capability
of your desktop computer.

00:10:45.898 --> 00:10:49.559
This is a fantastic device
which is only beginning to be tapped.

00:10:49.583 --> 00:10:53.029
I don't know whether the idea
of one computer, one child

00:10:53.053 --> 00:10:54.204
makes any sense.

00:10:54.228 --> 00:10:56.134
Here's the computer of the future,

00:10:56.158 --> 00:10:59.359
because this screen is already there
and they're ubiquitous.

00:11:00.809 --> 00:11:04.046
All right, let me show you just
a little bit about advanced devices.

00:11:04.070 --> 00:11:06.224
And we'll start by posing
a little problem.

00:11:06.248 --> 00:11:09.645
What you see here
is another centimeter-sized device,

00:11:09.669 --> 00:11:13.652
and the different colors
are different colors of dye.

00:11:13.676 --> 00:11:14.854
And you notice something

00:11:14.878 --> 00:11:17.577
which might strike you
as a little bit interesting,

00:11:17.601 --> 00:11:20.458
which is, the yellow seems to disappear,

00:11:20.482 --> 00:11:22.971
get through the blue,
and then get through the red.

00:11:22.995 --> 00:11:24.148
How does that happen?

00:11:24.172 --> 00:11:26.747
How do you make something
flow through something?

00:11:26.771 --> 00:11:28.966
And, of course the answer is, "You don't."

00:11:28.990 --> 00:11:30.733
You make it flow under and over.

00:11:30.757 --> 00:11:31.918
But now the question is:

00:11:31.942 --> 00:11:35.484
How do you make it flow
under and over in a piece of paper?

00:11:35.508 --> 00:11:38.454
The answer is that what you do --

00:11:38.478 --> 00:11:41.134
and the details are not
terribly important here --

00:11:41.158 --> 00:11:43.049
is to make something more elaborate:

00:11:43.073 --> 00:11:45.150
You take several different
layers of paper,

00:11:45.174 --> 00:11:48.245
each one containing
its own little fluid system,

00:11:48.269 --> 00:11:52.858
and you separate them by pieces of,
literally, double-sided carpet tape,

00:11:52.882 --> 00:11:55.768
the stuff you use to stick
the carpets onto the floor.

00:11:55.792 --> 00:11:59.018
And the fluid will flow
from one layer into the next.

00:11:59.042 --> 00:12:02.134
It distributes itself,
flows through further holes,

00:12:02.158 --> 00:12:03.747
distributes itself.

00:12:03.771 --> 00:12:07.012
And what you see,
at the lower right-hand side there,

00:12:07.036 --> 00:12:12.335
is a sample in which a single sample
of blood has been put on the top,

00:12:12.359 --> 00:12:14.869
and it has gone through
and distributed itself

00:12:14.893 --> 00:12:18.239
into these 16 holes on the bottom,

00:12:18.263 --> 00:12:20.967
in a piece of paper --
basically, it looks like a chip,

00:12:20.991 --> 00:12:22.729
two pieces of paper thick.

00:12:22.753 --> 00:12:24.236
And in this particular case,

00:12:24.260 --> 00:12:27.024
we were just interested
in the replicability of that.

00:12:27.048 --> 00:12:29.352
But that is, in principle,
the way you solve

00:12:29.376 --> 00:12:31.532
the "fever of unexplained origin" problem,

00:12:31.556 --> 00:12:34.312
because each one of those spots
then becomes a test

00:12:34.336 --> 00:12:37.935
for a particular set
of markers of disease,

00:12:37.959 --> 00:12:40.225
and this will work in due course.

00:12:40.249 --> 00:12:43.565
Here is an example of a slightly
more complicated device.

00:12:43.589 --> 00:12:44.771
There's the chip.

00:12:44.795 --> 00:12:46.011
You dip in a corner.

00:12:46.035 --> 00:12:47.582
The fluid goes into the center.

00:12:47.606 --> 00:12:51.389
It distributes itself out
into these various wells or holes

00:12:51.413 --> 00:12:52.649
and turns color,

00:12:52.673 --> 00:12:55.366
all done with paper and carpet tape.

00:12:55.390 --> 00:12:57.547
So it's, I think, as low-cost

00:12:57.571 --> 00:13:00.398
as we're likely to be able
to come up and make things.

00:13:01.390 --> 00:13:04.686
Now, I have two last
little stories to tell you

00:13:04.710 --> 00:13:07.320
in finishing off this business.

00:13:07.344 --> 00:13:08.509
This is one:

00:13:08.533 --> 00:13:10.974
One of the things
you occasionally need to do

00:13:10.998 --> 00:13:13.645
is separate blood cells from serum.

00:13:14.832 --> 00:13:16.517
And the question was,

00:13:16.541 --> 00:13:18.642
here we do it by taking a sample,

00:13:18.666 --> 00:13:22.528
we put it in a centrifuge, we spin it,

00:13:22.552 --> 00:13:25.019
and you get blood cells out.

00:13:25.043 --> 00:13:26.202
Terrific.

00:13:26.226 --> 00:13:29.673
What happens if you don't have
electricity, a centrifuge, and whatever?

00:13:29.697 --> 00:13:32.213
And we thought for a while
of how you might do this,

00:13:32.237 --> 00:13:34.874
and the way, in fact, you do it,
is what's shown here.

00:13:34.898 --> 00:13:39.505
You get an eggbeater, which is everywhere,
and you saw off a blade,

00:13:39.529 --> 00:13:42.012
and then you take tubing,
and you stick it on that.

00:13:42.036 --> 00:13:44.776
You put the blood in,
somebody sits there and spins it.

00:13:44.800 --> 00:13:46.919
It works really, really well.

00:13:46.943 --> 00:13:49.357
And we sat down,
we did the physics of eggbeaters

00:13:49.381 --> 00:13:52.458
and self-aligning tubes
and all the rest of that kind of thing,

00:13:52.482 --> 00:13:53.944
and sent it off to a journal.

00:13:53.968 --> 00:13:55.290
We were very proud of this,

00:13:55.314 --> 00:13:58.176
particularly the title,
which was "Eggbeater as Centrifuge."

00:13:58.200 --> 00:13:59.274
(Laughter)

00:13:59.298 --> 00:14:00.449
And we sent it off,

00:14:00.473 --> 00:14:02.380
and by return mail, it came back.

00:14:02.404 --> 00:14:04.134
I called up the editor and I said,

00:14:04.158 --> 00:14:06.280
"What's going on? How is this possible?"

00:14:06.304 --> 00:14:09.438
The editor said, with enormous disdain,

00:14:09.462 --> 00:14:10.905
"I read this.

00:14:10.929 --> 00:14:14.685
And we're not going to publish it,
because we only publish science."

00:14:14.709 --> 00:14:16.122
(Laughter)

00:14:16.146 --> 00:14:17.615
And it's an important issue,

00:14:17.639 --> 00:14:21.037
because it means
that we have to, as a society,

00:14:21.061 --> 00:14:23.038
think about what we value.

00:14:23.062 --> 00:14:25.846
And if it's just papers
and Phys. Rev. letters,

00:14:25.870 --> 00:14:27.113
we've got a problem.

00:14:27.776 --> 00:14:31.006
Here is another example
of something which is --

00:14:31.030 --> 00:14:33.071
this is a little spectrophotometer.

00:14:33.095 --> 00:14:36.385
It measures the absorption
of light in a sample.

00:14:36.409 --> 00:14:37.888
The neat thing about this is,

00:14:37.912 --> 00:14:41.603
you have a light source that flickers
on and off at about 1,000 hertz,

00:14:41.627 --> 00:14:45.296
another light source
that detects that light at 1,000 hertz,

00:14:45.320 --> 00:14:48.134
and so you can run this system
in broad daylight.

00:14:48.158 --> 00:14:50.227
It performs about equivalently

00:14:50.251 --> 00:14:54.820
to a system that's on the order
of 100,000 dollars.

00:14:54.844 --> 00:14:56.005
It costs 50 dollars.

00:14:56.029 --> 00:15:00.134
We can probably make it for 50 cents
if we put our mind to it.

00:15:00.158 --> 00:15:02.031
Why doesn't somebody do it?

00:15:02.055 --> 00:15:03.206
The answer is:

00:15:03.230 --> 00:15:06.500
How do you make a profit
in a capitalist system, doing that?

00:15:06.524 --> 00:15:07.816
Interesting problem.

00:15:09.273 --> 00:15:14.226
So, let me finish by saying
that we've thought about this

00:15:14.250 --> 00:15:16.452
as a kind of engineering problem.

00:15:16.476 --> 00:15:20.858
And we've asked: What
is the scientific unifying idea here?

00:15:20.882 --> 00:15:23.006
And we've decided
we should think about this

00:15:23.030 --> 00:15:26.134
not so much in terms of cost,
but in terms of simplicity.

00:15:26.158 --> 00:15:27.736
Simplicity is a neat word.

00:15:27.760 --> 00:15:30.134
You've got to think
about what simplicity means.

00:15:30.713 --> 00:15:31.869
I know what it is,

00:15:31.893 --> 00:15:34.070
but I don't actually know what it means.

00:15:34.094 --> 00:15:36.191
So I actually was interested
enough in this

00:15:36.215 --> 00:15:39.968
to put together several groups of people.

00:15:40.602 --> 00:15:43.134
The most recent involved
a couple of people at MIT,

00:15:43.158 --> 00:15:45.278
one of them being
an exceptionally bright kid

00:15:45.302 --> 00:15:48.012
who is one of the very
few people I would think of

00:15:48.036 --> 00:15:49.425
who's an authentic genius.

00:15:49.449 --> 00:15:53.499
We all struggled for an entire day
to think about simplicity.

00:15:53.523 --> 00:15:57.705
And I want to give you the answer
of this deep scientific thought.

00:15:57.729 --> 00:15:59.062
[What is simplicity?

00:15:59.086 --> 00:16:00.673
"It's impossible to f..k it up"]

00:16:00.697 --> 00:16:01.746
(Laughter)

00:16:01.770 --> 00:16:04.220
So, in a sense, you get what you pay for.

00:16:04.244 --> 00:16:05.753
Thank you very much.

00:16:05.777 --> 00:16:07.862
(Applause)

title: A new strategy in the war on cancer
transcript: I'm a cancer doctor, and I walked out of my office and walked by the pharmacy in the hospital three or four years ago, and this was the cover of Fortune magazine sitting in the window of the pharmacy.And so, as a cancer doctor, you look at this, and you get a little bit downhearted. But when you start to read the article by Cliff, who himself is a cancer survivor, who was saved by a clinical trial where his parents drove him from New York City to upstate New York to get an experimental therapy for — at the time — Hodgkin's disease, which saved his life, he makes remarkable points here. And the point of the article was that we have gotten reductionist in our view of biology, in our view of cancer. For the last 50 years, we have focused on treating the individual gene in understanding cancer, not in controlling cancer.So, this is an astounding table. And this is something that sobers us in our field everyday in that, obviously, we've made remarkable impacts on cardiovascular disease, but look at cancer. The death rate in cancer in over 50 years hasn't changed. We've made small wins in diseases like chronic myelogenous leukemia, where we have a pill that can put 100 percent of people in remission, but in general, we haven't made an impact at all in the war on cancer.So, what I'm going to tell you today, is a little bit of why I think that's the case, and then go out of my comfort zone and tell you where I think it's going, where a new approach — that we hope to push forward in terms of treating cancer. Because this is wrong.So, what is cancer, first of all? Well, if one has a mass or an abnormal blood value, you go to a doctor, they stick a needle in. They way we make the diagnosis today is by pattern recognition: Does it look normal? Does it look abnormal?So, that pathologist is just like looking at this plastic bottle. This is a normal cell. This is a cancer cell. That is the state-of-the-art today in diagnosing cancer. There's no molecular test, there's no sequencing of genes that was referred to yesterday, there's no fancy looking at the chromosomes. This is the state-of-the-art and how we do it.You know, I know very well, as a cancer doctor, I can't treat advanced cancer. So, as an aside, I firmly believe in the field of trying to identify cancer early. It is the only way you can start to fight cancer, is by catching it early. We can prevent most cancers. You know, the previous talk alluded to preventing heart disease. We could do the same in cancer. I co-founded a company called Navigenics, where, if you spit into a tube — and we can look look at 35 or 40 genetic markers for disease, all of which are delayable in many of the cancers — you start to identify what you could get, and then we can start to work to prevent them. Because the problem is, when you have advanced cancer, we can't do that much today about it, as the statistics allude to.So, the thing about cancer is that it's a disease of the aged. Why is it a disease of the aged? Because evolution doesn't care about us after we've had our children. See, evolution protected us during our childbearing years and then, after age 35 or 40 or 45, it said "It doesn't matter anymore, because they've had their progeny." So if you look at cancers, it is very rare — extremely rare — to have cancer in a child, on the order of thousands of cases a year. As one gets older? Very, very common.Why is it hard to treat? Because it's heterogeneous, and that's the perfect substrate for evolution within the cancer. It starts to select out for those bad, aggressive cells, what we call clonal selection. But, if we start to understand that cancer isn't just a molecular defect, it's something more, then we'll get to new ways of treating it, as I'll show you.So, one of the fundamental problems we have in cancer is that, right now, we describe it by a number of adjectives, symptoms: "I'm tired, I'm bloated, I have pain, etc." You then have some anatomic descriptions, you get that CT scan: "There's a three centimeter mass in the liver." You then have some body part descriptions: "It's in the liver, in the breast, in the prostate." And that's about it. So, our dictionary for describing cancer is very, very poor. It's basically symptoms. It's manifestations of a disease.What's exciting is that over the last two or three years, the government has spent 400 million dollars, and they've allocated another billion dollars, to what we call the Cancer Genome Atlas Project. So, it is the idea of sequencing all of the genes in the cancer, and giving us a new lexicon, a new dictionary to describe it. You know, in the mid-1850's in France, they started to describe cancer by body part. That hasn't changed in over 150 years. It is absolutely archaic that we call cancer by prostate, by breast, by muscle. It makes no sense, if you think about it.So, obviously, the technology is here today, and, over the next several years, that will change. You will no longer go to a breast cancer clinic. You will go to a HER2 amplified clinic, or an EGFR activated clinic, and they will go to some of the pathogenic lesions that were involved in causing this individual cancer. So, hopefully, we will go from being the art of medicine more to the science of medicine, and be able to do what they do in infectious disease, which is look at that organism, that bacteria, and then say, "This antibiotic makes sense, because you have a particular bacteria that will respond to it." When one is exposed to H1N1, you take Tamiflu, and you can remarkably decrease the severity of symptoms and prevent many of the manifestations of the disease. Why? Because we know what you have, and we know how to treat it — although we can't make vaccine in this country, but that's a different story.The Cancer Genome Atlas is coming out now. The first cancer was done, which was brain cancer. In the next month, the end of December, you'll see ovarian cancer, and then lung cancer will come several months after. There's also a field of proteomics that I'll talk about in a few minutes, which I think is going to be the next level in terms of understanding and classifying disease. But remember, I'm not pushing genomics, proteomics, to be a reductionist. I'm doing it so we can identify what we're up against. And there's a very important distinction there that we'll get to.In health care today, we spend most of the dollars — in terms of treating disease — most of the dollars in the last two years of a person's life. We spend very little, if any, dollars in terms of identifying what we're up against. If you could start to move that, to identify what you're up against, you're going to do things a hell of a lot better. If we could even take it one step further and prevent disease, we can take it enormously the other direction, and obviously, that's where we need to go, going forward.So, this is the website of the National Cancer Institute. And I'm here to tell you, it's wrong. So, the website of the National Cancer Institute says that cancer is a genetic disease. The website says, "If you look, there's an individual mutation, and maybe a second, and maybe a third, and that is cancer." But, as a cancer doc, this is what I see. This isn't a genetic disease. So, there you see, it's a liver with colon cancer in it, and you see into the microscope a lymph node where cancer has invaded. You see a CT scan where cancer is in the liver. Cancer is an interaction of a cell that no longer is under growth control with the environment. It's not in the abstract; it's the interaction with the environment. It's what we call a system.The goal of me as a cancer doctor is not to understand cancer. And I think that's been the fundamental problem over the last five decades, is that we have strived to understand cancer. The goal is to control cancer. And that is a very different optimization scheme, a very different strategy for all of us.I got up at the American Association of Cancer Research, one of the big cancer research meetings, with 20,000 people there, and I said, "We've made a mistake. We've all made a mistake, myself included, by focusing down, by being a reductionist. We need to take a step back." And, believe it or not, there were hisses in the audience. People got upset, but this is the only way we're going to go forward.You know, I was very fortunate to meet Danny Hillis a few years ago. We were pushed together, and neither one of us really wanted to meet the other. I said, "Do I really want to meet a guy from Disney, who designed computers?" And he was saying: Does he really want to meet another doctor? But people prevailed on us, and we got together, and it's been transformative in what I do, absolutely transformative. We have designed, and we have worked on the modeling — and much of these ideas came from Danny and from his team — the modeling of cancer in the body as complex system. And I'll show you some data there where I really think it can make a difference and a new way to approach it.The key is, when you look at these variables and you look at this data, you have to understand the data inputs. You know, if I measured your temperature over 30 days, and I asked, "What was the average temperature?" and it came back at 98.7, I would say, "Great." But if during one of those days your temperature spiked to 102 for six hours, and you took Tylenol and got better, etc., I would totally miss it. So, one of the problems, the fundamental problems in medicine is that you and I, and all of us, we go to our doctor once a year. We have discrete data elements; we don't have a time function on them.Earlier it was referred to this direct life device. You know, I've been using it for two and a half months. It's a staggering device, not because it tells me how many kilocalories I do every day, but because it looks, over 24 hours, what I've done in a day. And I didn't realize that for three hours I'm sitting at my desk, and I'm not moving at all. And a lot of the functions in the data that we have as input systems here are really different than we understand them, because we're not measuring them dynamically.And so, if you think of cancer as a system, there's an input and an output and a state in the middle. So, the states, are equivalent classes of history, and the cancer patient, the input, is the environment, the diet, the treatment, the genetic mutations. The output are our symptoms: Do we have pain? Is the cancer growing? Do we feel bloated, etc.? Most of that state is hidden. So what we do in our field is we change and input, we give aggressive chemotherapy, and we say, "Did that output get better? Did that pain improve, etc.?"And so, the problem is that it's not just one system, it's multiple systems on multiple scales. It's a system of systems. And so, when you start to look at emergent systems, you can look at a neuron under a microscope. A neuron under the microscope is very elegant with little things sticking out and little things over here, but when you start to put them together in a complex system, and you start to see that it becomes a brain, and that brain can create intelligence, what we're talking about in the body, and cancer is starting to model it like a complex system. Well, the bad news is that these robust — and robust is a key word — emergent systems are very hard to understand in detail. The good news is you can manipulate them. You can try to control them without that fundamental understanding of every component.One of the most fundamental clinical trials in cancer came out in February in the New England Journal of Medicine, where they took women who were pre-menopausal with breast cancer. So, about the worst kind of breast cancer you can get. They had gotten their chemotherapy, and then they randomized them, where half got placebo, and half got a drug called Zoledronic acid that builds bone. It's used to treat osteoporosis, and they got that twice a year. They looked and, in these 1,800 women, given twice a year a drug that builds bone, you reduce the recurrence of cancer by 35 percent. Reduce occurrence of cancer by a drug that doesn't even touch the cancer. So the notion, you change the soil, the seed doesn't grow as well. You change that system, and you could have a marked effect on the cancer.Nobody has ever shown — and this will be shocking — nobody has ever shown that most chemotherapy actually touches a cancer cell. It's never been shown. There's all these elegant work in the tissue culture dishes, that if you give this cancer drug, you can do this effect to the cell, but the doses in those dishes are nowhere near the doses that happen in the body.If I give a woman with breast cancer a drug called Taxol every three weeks, which is the standard, about 40 percent of women with metastatic cancer have a great response to that drug. And a response is 50 percent shrinkage. Well, remember that's not even an order of magnitude, but that's a different story. They then recur, I give them that same drug every week. Another 30 percent will respond. They then recur, I give them that same drug over 96 hours by continuous infusion, another 20 or 30 percent will respond. So, you can't tell me it's working by the same mechanism in all three size. It's not. We have no idea the mechanism. So the idea that chemotherapy may just be disrupting that complex system, just like building bone disrupted that system and reduced recurrence, chemotherapy may work by that same exact way. The wild thing about that trial also, was that it reduced new primaries, so new cancers, by 30 percent also.So, the problem is, yours and mine, all of our systems are changing. They're dynamic. I mean, this is a scary slide, not to take an aside, but it looks at obesity in the world. And I'm sorry if you can't read the numbers, they're kind of small. But, if you start to look at it, that red, that dark color there, more than 75 percent of the population of those countries are obese. Look a decade ago, look two decades ago: markedly different. So, our systems today are dramatically different than our systems a decade or two ago. So the diseases we have today, which reflect patterns in the system over the last several decades, are going to change dramatically over the next decade or so based on things like this.So, this picture, although it is beautiful, is a 40-gigabyte picture of the whole proteome. So this is a drop of blood that has gone through a superconducting magnet, and we're able to get resolution where we can start to see all of the proteins in the body. We can start to see that system. Each of the red dots are where a protein has actually been identified. The power of these magnets, the power of what we can do here, is that we can see an individual neutron with this technology. So, again, this is stuff we're doing with Danny Hillis and a group called Applied Proteomics, where we can start to see individual neutron differences, and we can start to look at that system like we never have before. So, instead of a reductionist view, we're taking a step back.So this is a woman, 46 years old, who had recurrent lung cancer. It was in her brain, in her lungs, in her liver. She had gotten Carboplatin Taxol, Carboplatin Taxotere, Gemcitabine, Navelbine: Every drug we have she had gotten, and that disease continued to grow. She had three kids under the age of 12, and this is her CT scan. And so what this is, is we're taking a cross-section of her body here, and you can see in the middle there is her heart, and to the side of her heart on the left there is this large tumor that will invade and will kill her, untreated, in a matter of weeks. She goes on a pill a day that targets a pathway, and again, I'm not sure if this pathway was in the system, in the cancer, but it targeted a pathway, and a month later, pow, that cancer's gone. Six months later it's still gone. That cancer recurred, and she passed away three years later from lung cancer, but she got three years from a drug whose symptoms predominately were acne. That's about it.So, the problem is that the clinical trial was done, and we were a part of it, and in the fundamental clinical trial — the pivotal clinical trial we call the Phase Three, we refused to use a placebo. Would you want your mother, your brother, your sister to get a placebo if they had advanced lung cancer and had weeks to live? And the answer, obviously, is not. So, it was done on this group of patients. Ten percent of people in the trial had this dramatic response that was shown here, and the drug went to the FDA, and the FDA said, "Without a placebo, how do I know patients actually benefited from the drug?" So the morning the FDA was going to meet, this was the editorial in the Wall Street Journal. (Laughter) And so, what do you know, that drug was approved.The amazing thing is another company did the right scientific trial, where they gave half placebo and half the drug. And we learned something important there. What's interesting is they did it in South America and Canada, where it's "more ethical to give placebos." They had to give it also in the U.S. to get approval, so I think there were three U.S. patients in upstate New York who were part of the trial. But they did that, and what they found is that 70 percent of the non-responders lived much longer and did better than people who got placebo. So it challenged everything we knew in cancer, is that you don't need to get a response. You don't need to shrink the disease. If we slow the disease, we may have more of a benefit on patient survival, patient outcome, how they feel, than if we shrink the disease.The problem is that, if I'm this doc, and I get your CT scan today and you've got a two centimeter mass in your liver, and you come back to me in three months and it's three centimeters, did that drug help you or not? How do I know? Would it have been 10 centimeters, or am I giving you a drug with no benefit and significant cost? So, it's a fundamental problem. And, again, that's where these new technologies can come in.And so, the goal obviously is that you go into your doctor's office — well, the ultimate goal is that you prevent disease, right? The ultimate goal is that you prevent any of these things from happening. That is the most effective, cost-effective, best way we can do things today. But if one is unfortunate to get a disease, you'll go into your doctor's office, he or she will take a drop of blood, and we will start to know how to treat your disease. The way we've approached it is the field of proteomics, again, this looking at the system. It's taking a big picture.The problem with technologies like this is that if one looks at proteins in the body, there are 11 orders of magnitude difference between the high-abundant and the low-abundant proteins. So, there's no technology in the world that can span 11 orders of magnitude. And so, a lot of what has been done with people like Danny Hillis and others is to try to bring in engineering principles, try to bring the software. We can start to look at different components along this spectrum.And so, earlier was talked about cross-discipline, about collaboration. And I think one of the exciting things that is starting to happen now is that people from those fields are coming in. Yesterday, the National Cancer Institute announced a new program called the Physical Sciences and Oncology, where physicists, mathematicians, are brought in to think about cancer, people who never approached it before. Danny and I got 16 million dollars, they announced yesterday, to try to attach this problem. A whole new approach, instead of giving high doses of chemotherapy by different mechanisms, to try to bring technology to get a picture of what's actually happening in the body.So, just for two seconds, how these technologies work — because I think it's important to understand it. What happens is every protein in your body is charged, so the proteins are sprayed in, the magnet spins them around, and then there's a detector at the end. When it hit that detector is dependent on the mass and the charge. And so we can accurately — if the magnet is big enough, and your resolution is high enough — you can actually detect all of the proteins in the body and start to get an understanding of the individual system.And so, as a cancer doctor, instead of having paper in my chart, in your chart, and it being this thick, this is what data flow is starting to look like in our offices, where that drop of blood is creating gigabytes of data. Electronic data elements are describing every aspect of the disease. And certainly the goal is we can start to learn from every encounter and actually move forward, instead of just having encounter and encounter, without fundamental learning.So, to conclude, we need to get away from reductionist thinking. We need to start to think differently and radically. And so, I implore everyone here: Think differently. Come up with new ideas. Tell them to me or anyone else in our field, because over the last 59 years, nothing has changed. We need a radically different approach.You know, Andy Grove stepped down as chairman of the board at Intel — and Andy was one of my mentors, tough individual. When Andy stepped down, he said, "No technology will win. Technology itself will win." And I'm a firm believer, in the field of medicine and especially cancer, that it's going to be a broad platform of technologies that will help us move forward and hopefully help patients in the near-term.Thank you very much.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I'm a cancer doctor, and I walked out of my office

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:18.958
and walked by the pharmacy in the hospital three or four years ago,

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
and this was the cover of Fortune magazine

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:23.958
sitting in the window of the pharmacy.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:25.958
And so, as a cancer doctor, you look at this,

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
and you get a little bit downhearted.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
But when you start to read the article by Cliff,

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
who himself is a cancer survivor,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
who was saved by a clinical trial

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:38.958
where his parents drove him from New York City to upstate New York

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
to get an experimental therapy for --

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:43.958
at the time -- Hodgkin's disease, which saved his life,

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.958
he makes remarkable points here.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:49.958
And the point of the article was that we have gotten

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
reductionist in our view of biology,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
in our view of cancer.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:57.958
For the last 50 years, we have focused on treating

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
the individual gene

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
in understanding cancer, not in controlling cancer.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
So, this is an astounding table.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
And this is something that sobers us in our field everyday

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
in that, obviously, we've made remarkable impacts

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:12.958
on cardiovascular disease,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
but look at cancer. The death rate in cancer

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
in over 50 years hasn't changed.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:22.958
We've made small wins in diseases like chronic myelogenous leukemia,

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
where we have a pill that can put 100 percent of people in remission,

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:31.958
but in general, we haven't made an impact at all in the war on cancer.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
So, what I'm going to tell you today,

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.958
is a little bit of why I think that's the case,

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
and then go out of my comfort zone

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
and tell you where I think it's going,

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:45.958
where a new approach -- that we hope to push forward

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:49.958
in terms of treating cancer.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
Because this is wrong.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
So, what is cancer, first of all?

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:59.958
Well, if one has a mass or an abnormal blood value, you go to a doctor,

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
they stick a needle in.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:05.958
They way we make the diagnosis today is by pattern recognition:

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:09.958
Does it look normal? Does it look abnormal?

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
So, that pathologist is just like looking at this plastic bottle.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
This is a normal cell. This is a cancer cell.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:20.958
That is the state-of-the-art today in diagnosing cancer.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
There's no molecular test,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.958
there's no sequencing of genes that was referred to yesterday,

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:29.958
there's no fancy looking at the chromosomes.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
This is the state-of-the-art and how we do it.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:38.958
You know, I know very well, as a cancer doctor, I can't treat advanced cancer.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:45.958
So, as an aside, I firmly believe in the field of trying to identify cancer early.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:50.958
It is the only way you can start to fight cancer, is by catching it early.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
We can prevent most cancers.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
You know, the previous talk alluded to preventing heart disease.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
We could do the same in cancer.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
I co-founded a company called Navigenics,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
where, if you spit into a tube --

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:08.958
and we can look look at 35 or 40 genetic markers for disease,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
all of which are delayable in many of the cancers --

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:14.958
you start to identify what you could get,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
and then we can start to work to prevent them.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
Because the problem is, when you have advanced cancer,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:24.958
we can't do that much today about it, as the statistics allude to.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:28.958
So, the thing about cancer is that it's a disease of the aged.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
Why is it a disease of the aged?

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
Because evolution doesn't care about us after we've had our children.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
See, evolution protected us during our childbearing years

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:42.958
and then, after age 35 or 40 or 45,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:46.958
it said "It doesn't matter anymore, because they've had their progeny."

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:51.958
So if you look at cancers, it is very rare -- extremely rare --

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:56.958
to have cancer in a child, on the order of thousands of cases a year.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:00.958
As one gets older? Very, very common.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
Why is it hard to treat?

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
Because it's heterogeneous,

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:09.958
and that's the perfect substrate for evolution within the cancer.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:13.958
It starts to select out for those bad, aggressive cells,

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:17.958
what we call clonal selection.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
But, if we start to understand

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:25.958
that cancer isn't just a molecular defect, it's something more,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:29.958
then we'll get to new ways of treating it, as I'll show you.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
So, one of the fundamental problems we have in cancer

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:35.958
is that, right now, we describe it by a number of adjectives, symptoms:

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
"I'm tired, I'm bloated, I have pain, etc."

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
You then have some anatomic descriptions,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:44.958
you get that CT scan: "There's a three centimeter mass in the liver."

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
You then have some body part descriptions:

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
"It's in the liver, in the breast, in the prostate."

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
And that's about it.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:56.958
So, our dictionary for describing cancer is very, very poor.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
It's basically symptoms.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
It's manifestations of a disease.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
What's exciting is that over the last two or three years,

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
the government has spent 400 million dollars,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
and they've allocated another billion dollars,

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
to what we call the Cancer Genome Atlas Project.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:15.958
So, it is the idea of sequencing all of the genes in the cancer,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:20.958
and giving us a new lexicon, a new dictionary to describe it.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
You know, in the mid-1850's in France,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
they started to describe cancer by body part.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958
That hasn't changed in over 150 years.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
It is absolutely archaic that we call cancer

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.958
by prostate, by breast, by muscle.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
It makes no sense, if you think about it.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
So, obviously, the technology is here today,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
and, over the next several years, that will change.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
You will no longer go to a breast cancer clinic.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:54.958
You will go to a HER2 amplified clinic, or an EGFR activated clinic,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
and they will go to some of the pathogenic lesions

00:05:56.958 --> 00:06:00.958
that were involved in causing this individual cancer.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
So, hopefully, we will go from being the art of medicine

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
more to the science of medicine,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
and be able to do what they do in infectious disease,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
which is look at that organism, that bacteria,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
and then say, "This antibiotic makes sense,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:18.958
because you have a particular bacteria that will respond to it."

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.958
When one is exposed to H1N1, you take Tamiflu,

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
and you can remarkably decrease the severity of symptoms

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
and prevent many of the manifestations of the disease.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:33.958
Why? Because we know what you have, and we know how to treat it --

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:37.958
although we can't make vaccine in this country, but that's a different story.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
The Cancer Genome Atlas is coming out now.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:44.958
The first cancer was done, which was brain cancer.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:48.958
In the next month, the end of December, you'll see ovarian cancer,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:52.958
and then lung cancer will come several months after.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
There's also a field of proteomics that I'll talk about in a few minutes,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
which I think is going to be the next level

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:02.958
in terms of understanding and classifying disease.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
But remember, I'm not pushing genomics,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
proteomics, to be a reductionist.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
I'm doing it so we can identify what we're up against.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:14.958
And there's a very important distinction there that we'll get to.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
In health care today, we spend most of the dollars --

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
in terms of treating disease --

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
most of the dollars in the last two years of a person's life.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:29.958
We spend very little, if any, dollars in terms of identifying what we're up against.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:33.958
If you could start to move that, to identify what you're up against,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
you're going to do things a hell of a lot better.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:40.958
If we could even take it one step further and prevent disease,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
we can take it enormously the other direction,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:47.958
and obviously, that's where we need to go, going forward.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
So, this is the website of the National Cancer Institute.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And I'm here to tell you, it's wrong.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
So, the website of the National Cancer Institute

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:59.958
says that cancer is a genetic disease.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:03.958
The website says, "If you look, there's an individual mutation,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and maybe a second, and maybe a third,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
and that is cancer."

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:11.958
But, as a cancer doc, this is what I see.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
This isn't a genetic disease.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
So, there you see, it's a liver with colon cancer in it,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
and you see into the microscope a lymph node

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
where cancer has invaded.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.958
You see a CT scan where cancer is in the liver.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
Cancer is an interaction of a cell

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:32.958
that no longer is under growth control with the environment.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:36.958
It's not in the abstract; it's the interaction with the environment.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
It's what we call a system.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:43.958
The goal of me as a cancer doctor is not to understand cancer.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
And I think that's been the fundamental problem over the last five decades,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
is that we have strived to understand cancer.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
The goal is to control cancer.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
And that is a very different optimization scheme,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
a very different strategy for all of us.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
I got up at the American Association of Cancer Research,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.958
one of the big cancer research meetings, with 20,000 people there,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
and I said, "We've made a mistake.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
We've all made a mistake, myself included,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
by focusing down, by being a reductionist.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
We need to take a step back."

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
And, believe it or not, there were hisses in the audience.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
People got upset, but this is the only way we're going to go forward.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:23.958
You know, I was very fortunate to meet Danny Hillis a few years ago.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:27.958
We were pushed together, and neither one of us really wanted to meet the other.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:31.958
I said, "Do I really want to meet a guy from Disney, who designed computers?"

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
And he was saying: Does he really want to meet another doctor?

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
But people prevailed on us, and we got together,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:41.958
and it's been transformative in what I do, absolutely transformative.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
We have designed, and we have worked on the modeling --

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:49.958
and much of these ideas came from Danny and from his team --

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
the modeling of cancer in the body as complex system.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
And I'll show you some data there

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
where I really think it can make a difference and a new way to approach it.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:02.958
The key is, when you look at these variables and you look at this data,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:06.958
you have to understand the data inputs.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:10.958
You know, if I measured your temperature over 30 days,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
and I asked, "What was the average temperature?"

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
and it came back at 98.7, I would say, "Great."

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
But if during one of those days

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
your temperature spiked to 102 for six hours,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
and you took Tylenol and got better, etc.,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
I would totally miss it.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
So, one of the problems, the fundamental problems in medicine

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
is that you and I, and all of us,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
we go to our doctor once a year.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
We have discrete data elements; we don't have a time function on them.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
Earlier it was referred to this direct life device.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
You know, I've been using it for two and a half months.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
It's a staggering device, not because it tells me

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
how many kilocalories I do every day,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:51.958
but because it looks, over 24 hours, what I've done in a day.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
And I didn't realize that for three hours I'm sitting at my desk,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
and I'm not moving at all.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:01.958
And a lot of the functions in the data that we have as input systems here

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
are really different than we understand them,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
because we're not measuring them dynamically.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:11.958
And so, if you think of cancer as a system,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:15.958
there's an input and an output and a state in the middle.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
So, the states, are equivalent classes of history,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
and the cancer patient, the input, is the environment,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:25.958
the diet, the treatment, the genetic mutations.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
The output are our symptoms:

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:32.958
Do we have pain? Is the cancer growing? Do we feel bloated, etc.?

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:36.958
Most of that state is hidden.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
So what we do in our field is we change and input,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
we give aggressive chemotherapy,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:46.958
and we say, "Did that output get better? Did that pain improve, etc.?"

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:50.958
And so, the problem is that it's not just one system,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
it's multiple systems on multiple scales.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
It's a system of systems.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
And so, when you start to look at emergent systems,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
you can look at a neuron under a microscope.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
A neuron under the microscope is very elegant

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
with little things sticking out and little things over here,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:10.958
but when you start to put them together in a complex system,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
and you start to see that it becomes a brain,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
and that brain can create intelligence,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
what we're talking about in the body,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
and cancer is starting to model it like a complex system.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
Well, the bad news is that these robust --

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
and robust is a key word --

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:29.958
emergent systems are very hard to understand in detail.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
The good news is you can manipulate them.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
You can try to control them

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
without that fundamental understanding of every component.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
One of the most fundamental clinical trials in cancer

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
came out in February in the New England Journal of Medicine,

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:47.958
where they took women who were pre-menopausal with breast cancer.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
So, about the worst kind of breast cancer you can get.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
They had gotten their chemotherapy,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
and then they randomized them,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
where half got placebo,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:00.958
and half got a drug called Zoledronic acid that builds bone.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
It's used to treat osteoporosis,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
and they got that twice a year.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
They looked and, in these 1,800 women,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
given twice a year a drug that builds bone,

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:16.958
you reduce the recurrence of cancer by 35 percent.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
Reduce occurrence of cancer by a drug

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
that doesn't even touch the cancer.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:26.958
So the notion, you change the soil, the seed doesn't grow as well.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
You change that system,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
and you could have a marked effect on the cancer.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
Nobody has ever shown -- and this will be shocking --

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
nobody has ever shown that most chemotherapy

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
actually touches a cancer cell.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
It's never been shown.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
There's all these elegant work in the tissue culture dishes,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
that if you give this cancer drug, you can do this effect to the cell,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
but the doses in those dishes are nowhere near

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:54.958
the doses that happen in the body.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
If I give a woman with breast cancer a drug called Taxol

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
every three weeks, which is the standard,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
about 40 percent of women with metastatic cancer

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
have a great response to that drug.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
And a response is 50 percent shrinkage.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
Well, remember that's not even an order of magnitude,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
but that's a different story.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
They then recur, I give them that same drug every week.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
Another 30 percent will respond.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
They then recur, I give them that same drug

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.958
over 96 hours by continuous infusion,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
another 20 or 30 percent will respond.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:29.958
So, you can't tell me it's working by the same mechanism in all three size.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
It's not. We have no idea the mechanism.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
So the idea that chemotherapy may just be disrupting

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
that complex system,

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:43.958
just like building bone disrupted that system and reduced recurrence,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
chemotherapy may work by that same exact way.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
The wild thing about that trial also,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:56.958
was that it reduced new primaries, so new cancers, by 30 percent also.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:03.958
So, the problem is, yours and mine, all of our systems are changing.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
They're dynamic.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
I mean, this is a scary slide, not to take an aside,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
but it looks at obesity in the world.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
And I'm sorry if you can't read the numbers, they're kind of small.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
But, if you start to look at it, that red, that dark color there,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
more than 75 percent of the population

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
of those countries are obese.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:27.958
Look a decade ago, look two decades ago: markedly different.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
So, our systems today are dramatically different

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:34.958
than our systems a decade or two ago.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
So the diseases we have today,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
which reflect patterns in the system over the last several decades,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:45.958
are going to change dramatically over the next decade or so

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
based on things like this.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:58.958
So, this picture, although it is beautiful, is a 40-gigabyte picture

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
of the whole proteome.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:04.958
So this is a drop of blood that has gone through a superconducting magnet,

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
and we're able to get resolution

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
where we can start to see all of the proteins in the body.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
We can start to see that system.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
