without proper drinking water in the world,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
twice that number,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
more than two billion people

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
without sanitation and so on,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
and the consequent illnesses

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
of mothers and children,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
still, child mortality of more than

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
10 million people every year,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
children dying before they are five years old:

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
The cause of this is, to a large extent,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
grand corruption.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
Now, why did the World Bank

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
not let me do this work?

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
I found out afterwards,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
after I left, under a big fight, the World Bank.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
The reason was that the members of the World Bank

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
thought that foreign bribery was okay,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
including Germany.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
In Germany, foreign bribery was allowed.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
It was even tax-deductible.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
No wonder that most of the most important

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
international operators in Germany,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
but also in France and the UK

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
and Scandinavia, everywhere, systematically bribed.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
Not all of them, but most of them.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
And this is the phenomenon

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
which I call failing governance,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
because when I then came to Germany

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
and started this little NGO

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:48.958
here in Berlin, at the Villa Borsig,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
we were told, "You cannot stop

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
our German exporters from bribing,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
because we will lose our contracts.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
We will lose to the French,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
we will lose to the Swedes, we'll lose to the Japanese."

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
And therefore, there was a indeed a prisoner's dilemma,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
which made it very difficult

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
for an individual company,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
an individual exporting country

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
to say, "We are not going to

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
continue this deadly, disastrous

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.958
habit of large companies to bribe."

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
So this is what I mean

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
with a failing governance structure,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
because even the powerful government,

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
which we have in Germany, comparatively,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
was not able to say,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
"We will not allow our companies to bribe abroad."

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
They needed help,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and the large companies themselves

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
have this dilemma.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
Many of them didn't want to bribe.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Many of the German companies, for instance,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
believe that they are really

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
producing a high-quality product

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
at a good price, so they are very competitive.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
They are not as good at bribing

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
as many of their international competitors are,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
but they were not allowed

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
to show their strengths,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
because the world was eaten up

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
by grand corruption.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:10.958
And this is why I'm telling you this:

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:14.958
Civil society rose to the occasion.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
We had this small NGO,

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
Transparency International.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
They began to think of

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
an escape route from this prisoner's dilemma,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:27.958
and we developed concepts

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
of collective action,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
basically trying to bring various competitors

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
together around the table,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
explaining to all of them

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
how much it would be in their interests

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
if they simultaneously would stop bribing,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
and to make a long story short,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
we managed to eventually

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
get Germany to sign

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
together with the other OECD countries

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
and a few other exporters.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
In 1997, a convention,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
under the auspices of the OECD,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
which obliged everybody

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
to change their laws

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
and criminalize foreign bribery.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:05.958
(Applause)

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
Well, thank you. I mean, it's interesting,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
in doing this,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
we had to sit together with the companies.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
We had here in Berlin, at the Aspen Institute on the Wannsee,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
we had sessions with about

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
20 captains of industry,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
and we discussed with them

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
what to do about international bribery.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
In the first session -- we had three sessions

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
over the course of two years.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
And President von Weizsäcker, by the way,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
chaired one of the sessions, the first one,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
to take the fear away

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
from the entrepreneurs,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
who were not used to deal

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
with non-governmental organizations.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
And in the first session, they all said,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
"This is not bribery, what we are doing." This is customary there.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
This is what these other cultures demand.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
They even applaud it.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
In fact, [unclear]

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
still says this today.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
And so there are still a lot of people

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
who are not convinced that you have to stop bribing.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
But in the second session,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
they admitted already that they would never do this,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
what they are doing in these other countries,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
here in Germany, or in the U.K., and so on.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
Cabinet ministers would admit this.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
And in the final session, at the Aspen Institute,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
we had them all sign an open letter

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
to the Kohl government, at the time,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
requesting that they

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
participate in the OECD convention.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And this is, in my opinion,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
an example of soft power,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
because we were able to convince them

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
that they had to go with us.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
We had a longer-term time perspective.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
We had a broader,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
geographically much wider,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
constituency we were trying to defend.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
And that's why the law has changed.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
That's why Siemens is now in the trouble they are in

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
and that's why MIN is in the trouble they are in.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
In some other countries, the OECD convention

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
is not yet properly enforced.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
And, again, civil societies

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
breathing down the neck of the establishment.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
In London, for instance,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
where the BAE got away

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
with a huge corruption case,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
which the Serious Fraud Office tried to prosecute,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
100 million British pounds,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
every year for ten years,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
to one particular official of one particular friendly country,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
who then bought for

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:24.958
44 billion pounds of military equipment.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
This case, they are not prosecuting in the UK.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
Why? Because they consider this

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
as contrary to the security interest

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
of the people of Great Britain.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Civil society is pushing, civil society

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
is trying to get a solution to this problem,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
also in the U.K.,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
and also in Japan, which is not properly enforcing,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
and so on.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
In Germany, we are pushing

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
the ratification of the UN convention,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
which is a subsequent convention.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
We are, Germany, is not ratifying.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
Why? Because it would make it necessary

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
to criminalize the corruption

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
of deputies.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
In Germany, we have a system where

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
you are not allowed to bribe a civil servant,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
but you are allowed to bribe a deputy.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
This is, under German law, allowed,

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
and the members of our parliament don't want to change this,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
and this is why they can't sign

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
the U.N. convention against foreign bribery --

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
one of they very, very few countries

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
which is preaching honesty and good governance everywhere in the world,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
but not able to ratify the convention,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
which we managed to get on the books

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
with about 160 countries all over the world.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
I see my time is ticking.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
Let me just try to

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
draw some conclusions from what has happened.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.958
I believe that what we managed to achieve

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
in fighting corruption,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
one can also achieve

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
in other areas of failing governance.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
By now, the United Nations

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
is totally on our side.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:57.958
The World Bank has turned from Saulus to Paulus; under Wolfensohn,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
they became, I would say, the strongest

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
anti-corruption agency in the world.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
Most of the large companies

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
are now totally convinced

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
that they have to put in place

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
very strong policies

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
against bribery and so on.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
And this is possible because civil society

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
joined the companies

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
and joined the government

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
in the analysis of the problem,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
in the development of remedies,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
in the implementation of reforms,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
and then later, in the monitoring of reforms.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
Of course, if civil society organizations

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
want to play that role,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:38.958
they have to grow into this responsibility.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
Not all civil society organizations are good.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
The Ku Klux Klan is an NGO.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
So, we must be aware

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
that civil society

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
has to shape up itself.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
They have to have a much more

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
transparent financial governance.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
They have to have a much more participatory governance

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
in many civil society organizations.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
We also need much more competence of civil society leaders.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
This is why we have set up the governance school

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
and the Center for Civil Society here in Berlin,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
because we believe most of our educational

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
and research institutions in Germany

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
and continental Europe in general,

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
do not focus enough, yet,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
on empowering civil society

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
and training the leadership of civil society.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
But what I'm saying from my very practical experience:

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
If civil society does it right

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
and joins the other actors --

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
in particular, governments,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
governments and their international institutions,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
but also large international actors,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
in particular those which have committed themselves

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
to corporate social responsibility --

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
then in this magical triangle

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
between civil society,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
government and private sector,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
there is a tremendous chance

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:56.958
for all of us to create a better world.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
Thank you.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
(Applause)

title: Teach every child about food
transcript: Sadly, in the next 18 minutes when I do our chat, four Americans that are alive will be dead through the food that they eat.My name's Jamie Oliver. I'm 34 years old. I'm from Essex in England and for the last seven years I've worked fairly tirelessly to save lives in my own way. I'm not a doctor; I'm a chef, I don't have expensive equipment or medicine. I use information, education.I profoundly believe that the power of food has a primal place in our homes that binds us to the best bits of life. We have an awful, awful reality right now. America, you're at the top of your game. This is one of the most unhealthy countries in the world.Can I please just see a raise of hands for how many of you have children in this room today? Put your hands up. You can continue to put your hands up, aunties and uncles as well. Most of you. OK. We, the adults of the last four generations, have blessed our children with the destiny of a shorter lifespan than their own parents. Your child will live a life ten years younger than you because of the landscape of food that we've built around them. Two-thirds of this room, today, in America, are statistically overweight or obese. You lot, you're all right, but we'll get you eventually, don't worry.(Laughter)The statistics of bad health are clear, very clear. We spend our lives being paranoid about death, murder, homicide, you name it; it's on the front page of every paper, CNN. Look at homicide at the bottom, for God's sake. Right?(Laughter)(Applause)Every single one of those in the red is a diet-related disease. Any doctor, any specialist will tell you that. Fact: diet-related disease is the biggest killer in the United States, right now, here today. This is a global problem. It's a catastrophe. It's sweeping the world. England is right behind you, as usual.(Laughter)I know they were close, but not that close. We need a revolution. Mexico, Australia, Germany, India, China, all have massive problems of obesity and bad health. Think about smoking. It costs way less than obesity now. Obesity costs you Americans 10 percent of your health-care bills, 150 billion dollars a year. In 10 years, it's set to double: 300 billion dollars a year. Let's be honest, guys, you haven't got that cash.(Laughter)I came here to start a food revolution that I so profoundly believe in. We need it. The time is now. We're in a tipping-point moment. I've been doing this for seven years. I've been trying in America for seven years. Now is the time when it's ripe — ripe for the picking. I went to the eye of the storm. I went to West Virginia, the most unhealthy state in America. Or it was last year. We've got a new one this year, but we'll work on that next season.(Laughter)Huntington, West Virginia. Beautiful town. I wanted to put heart and soul and people, your public, around the statistics that we've become so used to. I want to introduce you to some of the people that I care about: your public, your children. I want to show a picture of my friend Brittany. She's 16 years old. She's got six years to live because of the food that she's eaten. She's the third generation of Americans that hasn't grown up within a food environment where they've been taught to cook at home or in school, or her mom, or her mom's mom. She has six years to live. She's eating her liver to death.Stacy, the Edwards family. This is a normal family, guys. Stacy does her best, but she's third-generation as well; she was never taught to cook at home or at school. The family's obese. Justin here, 12 years old, he's 350 pounds. He gets bullied, for God's sake. The daughter there, Katie, she's four years old. She's obese before she even gets to primary school. Marissa, she's all right, she's one of your lot. But you know what? Her father, who was obese, died in her arms, And then the second most important man in her life, her uncle, died of obesity, and now her step-dad is obese. You see, the thing is, obesity and diet-related disease doesn't just hurt the people that have it; it's all of their friends, families, brothers, sisters.Pastor Steve: an inspirational man, one of my early allies in Huntington, West Virginia. He's at the sharp knife-edge of this problem. He has to bury the people, OK? And he's fed up with it. He's fed up with burying his friends, his family, his community. Come winter, three times as many people die. He's sick of it. This is preventable disease. Waste of life. By the way, this is what they get buried in. We're not geared up to do this. Can't even get them out the door, and I'm being serious. Can't even get them there. Forklift.OK, I see it as a triangle, OK? This is our landscape of food. I need you to understand it. You've probably heard all this before. Over the last 30 years, what's happened that's ripped the heart out of this country? Let's be frank and honest. Well, modern-day life.Let's start with the Main Street. Fast food has taken over the whole country; we know that. The big brands are some of the most important powers, powerful powers, in this country.(Sighs)Supermarkets as well. Big companies. Big companies. Thirty years ago, most of the food was largely local and largely fresh. Now it's largely processed and full of all sorts of additives, extra ingredients, and you know the rest of the story. Portion size is obviously a massive, massive problem. Labeling is a massive problem. The labeling in this country is a disgrace. The industry wants to self-police themselves. What, in this kind of climate? They don't deserve it. How can you say something is low-fat when it's full of so much sugar?Home. The biggest problem with the home is that used to be the heart of passing on food culture, what made our society. That is not happening anymore. And you know, as we go to work and as life changes, and as life always evolves, we kind of have to look at it holistically — step back for a moment, and re-address the balance. It hasn't happened for 30 years, OK? I want to show you a situation that is very normal right now; the Edwards family.(Video) Jamie Oliver: Let's have a talk. This stuff goes through you and your family's body every week. And I need you to know that this is going to kill your children early. How are you feeling?Stacy: Just feeling really sad and depressed right now. But, you know, I want my kids to succeed in life and this isn't going to get them there. But I'm killing them.JO: Yes you are. You are. But we can stop that. Normal. Let's get on schools, something that I'm fairly much a specialist in. OK, school. What is school? Who invented it? What's the purpose of school? School was always invented to arm us with the tools to make us creative, do wonderful things, make us earn a living, etc., etc. You know, it's been kind of in this sort of tight box for a long, long time, OK? But we haven't really evolved it to deal with the health catastrophes of America, OK? School food is something that most kids — 31 million a day, actually — have twice a day, more than often, breakfast and lunch, 180 days of the year. So you could say that school food is quite important, really, judging the circumstances.(Laughter)Before I crack into my rant, which I'm sure you're waiting for —(Laughter)I need to say one thing, and it's so important in, hopefully, the magic that happens and unfolds in the next three months. The lunch ladies, the lunch cooks of America — I offer myself as their ambassador. I'm not slagging them off. They're doing the best they can do. They're doing their best. But they're doing what they're told, and what they're being told to do is wrong. The system is highly run by accountants; there's not enough, or any, food-knowledgeable people in the business. There's a problem: If you're not a food expert, and you've got tight budgets and it's getting tighter, then you can't be creative, you can't duck and dive and write different things around things. If you're an accountant, and a box-ticker, the only thing you can do in these circumstances is buy cheaper shit.Now, the reality is, the food that your kids get every day is fast food, it's highly processed, there's not enough fresh food in there at all. You know, the amount of additives, E numbers, ingredients you wouldn't believe — there's not enough veggies at all. French fries are considered a vegetable. Pizza for breakfast. They don't even get crockery. Knives and forks? No, they're too dangerous. They have scissors in the classroom, but knives and forks? No. And the way I look at it is: If you don't have knives and forks in your school, you're purely endorsing, from a state level, fast food, because it's handheld. And yes, by the way, it is fast food: It's sloppy Joes, it's burgers, it's wieners, it's pizzas, it's all of that stuff.(Sighs)Ten percent of what we spend on health care, as I said earlier, is on obesity, and it's going to double. We're not teaching our kids. There's no statutory right to teach kids about food, elementary or secondary school, OK? We don't teach kids about food, right? And this is a little clip from an elementary school, which is very common in England.(Video) Who knows what this is?Child: Potatoes.Jamie Oliver: Potato? So, you think these are potatoes? Do you know what that is? Do you know what that is?Child: Broccoli?JO: What about this? Our good old friend.Child: Celery.JO: No. What do you think this is?Child: Onion. JO: Onion? No.JO: Immediately you get a really clear sense of "Do the kids know anything about where food comes from?" Who knows what that is? Child: Uh, pear?JO: What do you think this is? Child: I don't know.JO: If the kids don't know what stuff is, then they will never eat it.(Laughter)JO: Normal. England and America, England and America. Guess what fixed that. Two one-hour sessions. We've got to start teaching our kids about food in schools, period.(Applause)I want to tell you about something that kind of epitomizes the trouble that we're in, guys, OK? I want to talk about something so basic as milk. Every kid has the right to milk at school. Your kids will be having milk at school, breakfast and lunch, right? They'll be having two bottles, OK? And most kids do. But milk ain't good enough anymore. Don't get me wrong, I support milk — but someone at the milk board probably paid a lot of money for some geezer to work out that if you put loads of flavorings, colorings and sugar in milk, more kids will drink it. Yeah.Obviously now that's going to catch on the apple board is going to work out that if they make toffee apples they'll eat more as well. Do you know what I mean? For me, there isn't any need to flavor the milk. Okay? There's sugar in everything. I know the ins and outs of those ingredients. It's in everything. Even the milk hasn't escaped the kind of modern-day problems. There's our milk. There's our carton. In that is nearly as much sugar as one of your favorite cans of fizzy pop, and they are having two a day. So, let me just show you. We've got one kid, here — having, you know, eight tablespoons of sugar a day. You know, there's your week. There's your month. And I've taken the liberty of putting in just the five years of elementary school sugar, just from milk. Now, I don't know about you guys, but judging the circumstances, right, any judge in the whole world, would look at the statistics and the evidence, and they would find any government of old guilty of child abuse. That's my belief.(Applause)(Applause ends)Now, if I came up here, and I wish I could come up here today and hang a cure for AIDS or cancer, you'd be fighting and scrambling to get to me. This, all this bad news, is preventable. That's the good news. It's very, very preventable. So, let's just think about, we got a problem here, we need to reboot. Okay so, in my world, what do we need to do? Here is the thing, right, it cannot just come from one source. To reboot and make real tangible change, real change, so that I could look you in the white of the eyes and say, "In 10 years' time, the history of your children's lives, happiness — and let's not forget, you're clever if you eat well, you know you're going to live longer — all of that stuff, it will look different. OK?"So, supermarkets. Where else do you shop so religiously? Week in, week out. How much money do you spend, in your life, in a supermarket? Love them. They just sell us what we want. All right. They owe us to put a food ambassador in every major supermarket. They need to help us shop. They need to show us how to cook quick, tasty, seasonal meals for people that are busy. This is not expensive. It is done in some, and it needs to be done across the board in America soon, and quick. The big brands, you know, the food brands, need to put food education at the heart of their businesses. I know, easier said than done. It's the future. It's the only way.Fast food. With the fast-food industry you know, it's very competitive. I've had loads of secret papers and dealings with fast food restaurants. I know how they do it. I mean, basically they've weaned us on to these hits of sugar, salt and fat, and x, y, and z, and everyone loves them, right? So, these guys are going to be part of the solution. But we need to get the government to work with all of the fast food purveyors and the restaurant industry, and over a five, six, seven year period wean of us off the extreme amounts of fat, sugar and all the other non-food ingredients.Now, also, back to the sort of big brands: labeling, I said earlier, is an absolute farce and has got to be sorted. OK, school. Obviously, in schools, we owe it to them to make sure those 180 days of the year, from that little precious age of four, until 18, 20, 24, whatever, they need to be cooked proper, fresh food from local growers on site, OK? There needs to be a new standard of fresh, proper food for your children, yeah?(Applause)Under the circumstances, it's profoundly important that every single American child leaves school knowing how to cook 10 recipes that will save their life. Life skills.(Applause)That means that they can be students, young parents, and be able to sort of duck and dive around the basics of cooking, no matter what recession hits them next time. If you can cook, recession money doesn't matter. If you can cook, time doesn't matter. The workplace, we haven't really talked about it. You know, it's now time for corporate responsibility to really look at what they feed or make available to their staff. The staff are the moms and dads of America's children. Marissa, her father died in her hand, I think she'd be quite happy if corporate America could start feeding their staff properly. Definitely they shouldn't be left out. Let's go back to the home.Now, look, if we do all this stuff, and we can, it's so achievable. You can care and be commercial. Absolutely. But the home needs to start passing on cooking again, for sure. For sure, pass it on as a philosophy. And for me, it's quite romantic, but it's about if one person teaches three people how to cook something, and they teach three of their mates, that only has to repeat itself 25 times, and that's the whole population of America. Romantic, yes, but most importantly, it's about trying to get people to realize that every one of your individual efforts makes a difference. We've got to put back what's been lost. Huntington's Kitchen. Huntington, where I made this program, we've got this prime-time program that hopefully will inspire people to really get on this change. I truly believe that change will happen. Huntington's Kitchen. I work with a community. I worked in the schools. I found local sustainable funding to get every single school in the area from the junk, onto the fresh food: six-and-a-half grand per school.(Applause)That's all it takes, six-and-a-half grand per school. The Kitchen is 25 grand a month. Okay? This can do 5,000 people a year, which is 10 percent of their population, and it's people on people. You know, it's local cooks teaching local people. It's free cooking lessons, guys, in the Main Street. This is real, tangible change, real, tangible change. Around America, if we just look back now, there is plenty of wonderful things going on. There is plenty of beautiful things going on. There are angels around America doing great things in schools — farm-to-school set-ups, garden set-ups, education — there are amazing people doing this already. The problem is they all want to roll out what they're doing to the next school, but there's no cash. We need to recognize the experts and the angels quickly, identify them, and allow them to easily find the resource to keep rolling out what they're already doing, and doing well. Businesses of America need to support Mrs. Obama to do the things that she wants to do.(Applause)And look, I know it's weird having an English person standing here before you talking about all this. All I can say is: I care. I'm a father, and I love this country. And I believe truly, actually, that if change can be made in this country, beautiful things will happen around the world. If America does it, other people will follow. It's incredibly important.(Audience) Yeah!(Applause)When I was in Huntington, trying to get a few things to work when they weren't, I thought "If I had a magic wand, what would I do?" And I thought, "You know what? I'd just love to be put in front of some of the most amazing movers and shakers in America." And a month later, TED phoned me up and gave me this award. I'm here. So, my wish. Dyslexic, so I'm a bit slow. My wish is for you to help a strong, sustainable movement to educate every child about food, to inspire families to cook again, and to empower people everywhere to fight obesity.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause continues)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.898 --> 00:00:14.874
Sadly,

00:00:14.898 --> 00:00:18.161
in the next 18 minutes when I do our chat,

00:00:18.185 --> 00:00:20.874
four Americans that are alive

00:00:20.898 --> 00:00:23.946
will be dead through
the food that they eat.

00:00:26.589 --> 00:00:27.964
My name's Jamie Oliver.

00:00:27.988 --> 00:00:29.121
I'm 34 years old.

00:00:29.739 --> 00:00:31.874
I'm from Essex in England

00:00:31.898 --> 00:00:34.874
and for the last seven years

00:00:34.898 --> 00:00:40.256
I've worked fairly tirelessly
to save lives in my own way.

00:00:41.082 --> 00:00:42.874
I'm not a doctor;

00:00:42.898 --> 00:00:44.075
I'm a chef,

00:00:44.099 --> 00:00:46.621
I don't have expensive equipment

00:00:46.645 --> 00:00:47.715
or medicine.

00:00:47.739 --> 00:00:49.984
I use information, education.

00:00:51.223 --> 00:00:54.200
I profoundly believe
that the power of food

00:00:54.224 --> 00:00:57.399
has a primal place in our homes

00:00:57.423 --> 00:01:01.874
that binds us to the best bits of life.

00:01:03.818 --> 00:01:09.188
We have an awful, awful reality right now.

00:01:10.477 --> 00:01:13.453
America, you're at the top of your game.

00:01:13.898 --> 00:01:16.885
This is one of the most unhealthy
countries in the world.

00:01:17.588 --> 00:01:20.234
Can I please just see a raise of hands

00:01:20.258 --> 00:01:22.837
for how many of you have
children in this room today?

00:01:22.861 --> 00:01:23.961
Put your hands up.

00:01:24.286 --> 00:01:27.671
You can continue to put your hands up,
aunties and uncles as well.

00:01:28.230 --> 00:01:30.207
Most of you. OK.

00:01:30.231 --> 00:01:33.208
We, the adults of the last
four generations,

00:01:33.232 --> 00:01:36.097
have blessed our children with the destiny

00:01:36.121 --> 00:01:40.453
of a shorter lifespan
than their own parents.

00:01:41.977 --> 00:01:46.874
Your child will live a life
ten years younger than you

00:01:46.898 --> 00:01:49.874
because of the landscape of food
that we've built around them.

00:01:51.293 --> 00:01:52.778
Two-thirds of this room,

00:01:52.802 --> 00:01:55.778
today, in America, are statistically
overweight or obese.

00:01:56.132 --> 00:01:57.379
You lot, you're all right,

00:01:57.403 --> 00:01:59.418
but we'll get you eventually, don't worry.

00:01:59.442 --> 00:02:00.874
(Laughter)

00:02:00.898 --> 00:02:03.874
The statistics of bad health are clear,

00:02:03.898 --> 00:02:05.089
very clear.

00:02:05.707 --> 00:02:09.331
We spend our lives being paranoid
about death, murder, homicide,

00:02:09.355 --> 00:02:12.874
you name it; it's on the front page
of every paper, CNN.

00:02:12.898 --> 00:02:15.391
Look at homicide
at the bottom, for God's sake.

00:02:16.296 --> 00:02:17.327
Right?

00:02:17.351 --> 00:02:18.874
(Laughter)

00:02:18.898 --> 00:02:23.874
(Applause)

00:02:23.898 --> 00:02:28.214
Every single one of those in the red
is a diet-related disease.

00:02:28.238 --> 00:02:30.826
Any doctor, any specialist
will tell you that.

00:02:30.850 --> 00:02:34.137
Fact: diet-related disease
is the biggest killer

00:02:34.161 --> 00:02:37.312
in the United States,
right now, here today.

00:02:40.003 --> 00:02:41.460
This is a global problem.

00:02:42.468 --> 00:02:43.620
It's a catastrophe.

00:02:43.644 --> 00:02:45.112
It's sweeping the world.

00:02:45.136 --> 00:02:47.349
England is right behind you, as usual.

00:02:48.111 --> 00:02:52.318
(Laughter)

00:02:52.342 --> 00:02:54.365
I know they were close,
but not that close.

00:02:55.064 --> 00:02:56.412
We need a revolution.

00:02:56.436 --> 00:02:58.715
Mexico, Australia, Germany,

00:02:58.739 --> 00:02:59.967
India, China,

00:02:59.991 --> 00:03:03.102
all have massive problems
of obesity and bad health.

00:03:04.683 --> 00:03:05.874
Think about smoking.

00:03:06.992 --> 00:03:08.874
It costs way less than obesity now.

00:03:09.635 --> 00:03:14.545
Obesity costs you Americans
10 percent of your health-care bills,

00:03:14.569 --> 00:03:17.290
150 billion dollars a year.

00:03:18.972 --> 00:03:20.874
In 10 years, it's set to double:

00:03:20.898 --> 00:03:22.391
300 billion dollars a year.

00:03:22.415 --> 00:03:24.791
Let's be honest, guys,
you haven't got that cash.

00:03:24.815 --> 00:03:27.931
(Laughter)

00:03:28.723 --> 00:03:35.114
I came here to start a food revolution
that I so profoundly believe in.

00:03:35.138 --> 00:03:37.393
We need it. The time is now.

00:03:37.417 --> 00:03:39.144
We're in a tipping-point moment.

00:03:39.168 --> 00:03:40.953
I've been doing this for seven years.

00:03:40.977 --> 00:03:43.140
I've been trying in America
for seven years.

00:03:43.164 --> 00:03:47.048
Now is the time when it's ripe --
ripe for the picking.

00:03:47.072 --> 00:03:48.874
I went to the eye of the storm.

00:03:48.898 --> 00:03:51.827
I went to West Virginia,
the most unhealthy state in America.

00:03:51.851 --> 00:03:52.890
Or it was last year.

00:03:52.914 --> 00:03:56.153
We've got a new one this year,
but we'll work on that next season.

00:03:56.177 --> 00:03:58.060
(Laughter)

00:03:58.084 --> 00:04:00.107
Huntington, West Virginia. Beautiful town.

00:04:00.131 --> 00:04:03.628
I wanted to put heart and soul and people,

00:04:03.652 --> 00:04:05.407
your public,

00:04:05.431 --> 00:04:08.922
around the statistics
that we've become so used to.

00:04:09.302 --> 00:04:12.302
I want to introduce you
to some of the people that I care about:

00:04:12.326 --> 00:04:13.946
your public, your children.

00:04:13.970 --> 00:04:16.519
I want to show a picture
of my friend Brittany.

00:04:16.543 --> 00:04:18.216
She's 16 years old.

00:04:18.826 --> 00:04:22.316
She's got six years to live

00:04:22.340 --> 00:04:24.874
because of the food that she's eaten.

00:04:25.182 --> 00:04:27.286
She's the third generation of Americans

00:04:27.310 --> 00:04:29.501
that hasn't grown up
within a food environment

00:04:29.525 --> 00:04:32.114
where they've been taught
to cook at home or in school,

00:04:32.138 --> 00:04:34.145
or her mom, or her mom's mom.

00:04:34.169 --> 00:04:36.351
She has six years to live.

00:04:37.485 --> 00:04:39.659
She's eating her liver to death.

00:04:40.358 --> 00:04:41.794
Stacy, the Edwards family.

00:04:42.311 --> 00:04:44.159
This is a normal family, guys.

00:04:44.898 --> 00:04:47.724
Stacy does her best,
but she's third-generation as well;

00:04:47.748 --> 00:04:50.097
she was never taught to cook
at home or at school.

00:04:50.121 --> 00:04:51.256
The family's obese.

00:04:51.280 --> 00:04:54.001
Justin here, 12 years old,
he's 350 pounds.

00:04:54.025 --> 00:04:55.693
He gets bullied, for God's sake.

00:04:55.717 --> 00:04:58.184
The daughter there, Katie,
she's four years old.

00:04:58.208 --> 00:05:00.716
She's obese before she even gets
to primary school.

00:05:01.232 --> 00:05:03.874
Marissa, she's all right,
she's one of your lot.

00:05:04.180 --> 00:05:05.203
But you know what?

00:05:05.227 --> 00:05:08.585
Her father, who was obese,
died in her arms,

00:05:08.609 --> 00:05:11.013
And then the second
most important man in her life,

00:05:11.037 --> 00:05:13.561
her uncle, died of obesity,

00:05:13.585 --> 00:05:15.490
and now her step-dad is obese.

00:05:16.675 --> 00:05:18.451
You see, the thing is,

00:05:18.475 --> 00:05:20.874
obesity and diet-related disease

00:05:20.898 --> 00:05:22.898
doesn't just hurt the people that have it;

00:05:22.922 --> 00:05:25.547
it's all of their friends, families,
brothers, sisters.

00:05:27.111 --> 00:05:28.874
Pastor Steve:

00:05:28.898 --> 00:05:30.335
an inspirational man,

00:05:30.359 --> 00:05:32.873
one of my early allies
in Huntington, West Virginia.

00:05:33.229 --> 00:05:36.681
He's at the sharp knife-edge
of this problem.

00:05:37.173 --> 00:05:39.157
He has to bury the people, OK?

00:05:39.530 --> 00:05:40.710
And he's fed up with it.

00:05:40.734 --> 00:05:43.776
He's fed up with burying his friends,
his family, his community.

00:05:44.085 --> 00:05:47.033
Come winter, three times
as many people die.

00:05:47.414 --> 00:05:48.469
He's sick of it.

00:05:48.898 --> 00:05:51.564
This is preventable disease.
Waste of life.

00:05:51.898 --> 00:05:53.977
By the way, this is
what they get buried in.

00:05:55.223 --> 00:05:56.906
We're not geared up to do this.

00:05:58.001 --> 00:06:00.629
Can't even get them out the door,
and I'm being serious.

00:06:00.653 --> 00:06:02.374
Can't even get them there. Forklift.

00:06:03.430 --> 00:06:05.522
OK, I see it as a triangle, OK?

00:06:05.546 --> 00:06:07.078
This is our landscape of food.

00:06:07.102 --> 00:06:08.459
I need you to understand it.

00:06:08.483 --> 00:06:10.547
You've probably heard all this before.

00:06:10.571 --> 00:06:11.857
Over the last 30 years,

00:06:11.881 --> 00:06:14.714
what's happened that's ripped
the heart out of this country?

00:06:14.738 --> 00:06:15.979
Let's be frank and honest.

00:06:17.422 --> 00:06:19.622
Well, modern-day life.

00:06:19.646 --> 00:06:21.271
Let's start with the Main Street.

00:06:22.025 --> 00:06:24.709
Fast food has taken over
the whole country; we know that.

00:06:24.733 --> 00:06:27.537
The big brands are
some of the most important powers,

00:06:27.561 --> 00:06:29.401
powerful powers, in this country.

00:06:30.011 --> 00:06:31.012
(Sighs)

00:06:31.036 --> 00:06:32.335
Supermarkets as well.

00:06:32.778 --> 00:06:34.754
Big companies. Big companies.

00:06:35.169 --> 00:06:38.129
Thirty years ago, most of the food

00:06:38.153 --> 00:06:40.874
was largely local and largely fresh.

00:06:40.898 --> 00:06:44.257
Now it's largely processed
and full of all sorts of additives,

00:06:44.281 --> 00:06:46.972
extra ingredients,
and you know the rest of the story.

00:06:46.996 --> 00:06:49.874
Portion size is obviously
a massive, massive problem.

00:06:51.575 --> 00:06:53.414
Labeling is a massive problem.

00:06:54.231 --> 00:06:56.398
The labeling in this country
is a disgrace.

00:06:57.388 --> 00:07:01.843
The industry wants
to self-police themselves.

00:07:02.898 --> 00:07:05.453
What, in this kind of climate?
They don't deserve it.

00:07:05.477 --> 00:07:08.743
How can you say something is low-fat
when it's full of so much sugar?

00:07:09.969 --> 00:07:10.989
Home.

00:07:13.171 --> 00:07:14.746
The biggest problem with the home

00:07:14.770 --> 00:07:19.874
is that used to be the heart
of passing on food culture,

00:07:19.898 --> 00:07:22.322
what made our society.

00:07:22.346 --> 00:07:23.779
That is not happening anymore.

00:07:23.803 --> 00:07:26.684
And you know, as we go
to work and as life changes,

00:07:26.708 --> 00:07:28.685
and as life always evolves,

00:07:28.709 --> 00:07:30.822
we kind of have
to look at it holistically --

00:07:30.846 --> 00:07:33.234
step back for a moment,
and re-address the balance.

00:07:33.258 --> 00:07:35.321
It hasn't happened for 30 years, OK?

00:07:36.302 --> 00:07:39.660
I want to show you a situation

00:07:39.684 --> 00:07:42.925
that is very normal right now;
the Edwards family.

00:07:43.540 --> 00:07:45.516
(Video) Jamie Oliver: Let's have a talk.

00:07:46.370 --> 00:07:50.403
This stuff goes through you
and your family's body every week.

00:07:50.427 --> 00:07:52.336
And I need you to know

00:07:52.360 --> 00:07:55.930
that this is going to kill
your children early.

00:07:56.508 --> 00:07:57.898
How are you feeling?

00:07:58.597 --> 00:08:01.874
Stacy: Just feeling really sad
and depressed right now.

00:08:02.588 --> 00:08:05.701
But, you know, I want
my kids to succeed in life

00:08:05.725 --> 00:08:07.874
and this isn't going to get them there.

00:08:08.707 --> 00:08:10.203
But I'm killing them.

00:08:11.613 --> 00:08:14.589
JO: Yes you are. You are.

00:08:14.613 --> 00:08:15.825
But we can stop that.

00:08:19.715 --> 00:08:20.789
Normal.

00:08:21.964 --> 00:08:23.798
Let's get on schools,

00:08:23.822 --> 00:08:26.874
something that I'm fairly much
a specialist in.

00:08:26.898 --> 00:08:28.435
OK, school.

00:08:28.898 --> 00:08:31.874
What is school? Who invented it?
What's the purpose of school?

00:08:31.898 --> 00:08:34.730
School was always invented
to arm us with the tools

00:08:34.754 --> 00:08:37.573
to make us creative, do wonderful things,

00:08:37.597 --> 00:08:40.054
make us earn a living, etc., etc.

00:08:40.078 --> 00:08:44.236
You know, it's been kind of in this sort
of tight box for a long, long time, OK?

00:08:44.898 --> 00:08:46.874
But we haven't really evolved it

00:08:46.898 --> 00:08:50.228
to deal with the health
catastrophes of America, OK?

00:08:50.252 --> 00:08:53.339
School food is something

00:08:53.363 --> 00:08:56.021
that most kids --
31 million a day, actually --

00:08:56.045 --> 00:09:00.706
have twice a day, more than often,
breakfast and lunch,

00:09:00.730 --> 00:09:02.459
180 days of the year.

00:09:02.483 --> 00:09:05.658
So you could say that school
food is quite important, really,

00:09:05.682 --> 00:09:07.268
judging the circumstances.

00:09:07.292 --> 00:09:11.308
(Laughter)

00:09:12.357 --> 00:09:14.874
Before I crack into my rant,

00:09:14.898 --> 00:09:16.924
which I'm sure you're waiting for --

00:09:16.948 --> 00:09:19.995
(Laughter)

00:09:20.019 --> 00:09:22.385
I need to say one thing,
and it's so important

00:09:22.409 --> 00:09:25.116
in, hopefully, the magic
that happens and unfolds

00:09:25.140 --> 00:09:26.353
in the next three months.

00:09:26.898 --> 00:09:30.187
The lunch ladies,
the lunch cooks of America --

00:09:30.211 --> 00:09:33.586
I offer myself as their ambassador.

00:09:33.610 --> 00:09:35.096
I'm not slagging them off.

00:09:35.120 --> 00:09:37.120
They're doing the best they can do.

00:09:39.786 --> 00:09:41.198
They're doing their best.

00:09:41.898 --> 00:09:43.730
But they're doing what they're told,

00:09:43.754 --> 00:09:46.015
and what they're being
told to do is wrong.

00:09:46.334 --> 00:09:49.571
The system is highly run by accountants;

00:09:49.595 --> 00:09:53.672
there's not enough, or any,
food-knowledgeable people in the business.

00:09:53.696 --> 00:09:54.727
There's a problem:

00:09:54.751 --> 00:09:57.874
If you're not a food expert,
and you've got tight budgets

00:09:57.898 --> 00:10:00.608
and it's getting tighter,
then you can't be creative,

00:10:00.632 --> 00:10:03.771
you can't duck and dive
and write different things around things.

00:10:03.795 --> 00:10:05.802
If you're an accountant, and a box-ticker,

00:10:05.826 --> 00:10:08.072
the only thing you can do
in these circumstances

00:10:08.096 --> 00:10:09.124
is buy cheaper shit.

00:10:09.148 --> 00:10:10.478
Now, the reality is,

00:10:10.502 --> 00:10:14.113
the food that your kids get
every day is fast food,

00:10:14.137 --> 00:10:15.446
it's highly processed,

00:10:15.470 --> 00:10:17.710
there's not enough
fresh food in there at all.

00:10:17.734 --> 00:10:19.915
You know, the amount
of additives, E numbers,

00:10:19.939 --> 00:10:21.645
ingredients you wouldn't believe --

00:10:21.669 --> 00:10:23.380
there's not enough veggies at all.

00:10:23.404 --> 00:10:25.328
French fries are considered a vegetable.

00:10:25.352 --> 00:10:27.874
Pizza for breakfast.
They don't even get crockery.

00:10:27.898 --> 00:10:30.230
Knives and forks?
No, they're too dangerous.

00:10:31.055 --> 00:10:32.795
They have scissors in the classroom,

00:10:32.819 --> 00:10:34.200
but knives and forks? No.

00:10:34.224 --> 00:10:35.620
And the way I look at it is:

00:10:35.644 --> 00:10:38.033
If you don't have knives
and forks in your school,

00:10:38.057 --> 00:10:39.596
you're purely endorsing,

00:10:39.620 --> 00:10:42.692
from a state level, fast food,
because it's handheld.

00:10:42.716 --> 00:10:44.501
And yes, by the way, it is fast food:

00:10:44.525 --> 00:10:46.115
It's sloppy Joes, it's burgers,

00:10:46.139 --> 00:10:48.915
it's wieners, it's pizzas,
it's all of that stuff.

00:10:50.163 --> 00:10:51.602
(Sighs)

00:10:52.350 --> 00:10:55.327
Ten percent of what we spend
on health care, as I said earlier,

00:10:55.351 --> 00:10:57.786
is on obesity, and it's going to double.

00:10:59.048 --> 00:11:00.478
We're not teaching our kids.

00:11:00.502 --> 00:11:03.207
There's no statutory right
to teach kids about food,

00:11:03.231 --> 00:11:05.024
elementary or secondary school, OK?

00:11:05.048 --> 00:11:07.366
We don't teach kids about food, right?

00:11:07.390 --> 00:11:09.819
And this is a little clip
from an elementary school,

00:11:09.843 --> 00:11:11.422
which is very common in England.

00:11:13.898 --> 00:11:15.427
(Video) Who knows what this is?

00:11:15.451 --> 00:11:16.522
Child: Potatoes.

00:11:16.546 --> 00:11:19.134
Jamie Oliver: Potato?
So, you think these are potatoes?

00:11:19.158 --> 00:11:20.379
Do you know what that is?

00:11:20.692 --> 00:11:21.896
Do you know what that is?

00:11:21.920 --> 00:11:22.935
Child: Broccoli?

00:11:22.959 --> 00:11:25.415
JO: What about this? Our good old friend.

00:11:25.439 --> 00:11:26.599
Child: Celery.

00:11:26.623 --> 00:11:28.567
JO: No. What do you think this is?

00:11:28.591 --> 00:11:30.075
Child: Onion.
JO: Onion? No.

00:11:30.099 --> 00:11:32.505
JO: Immediately you
get a really clear sense

00:11:32.529 --> 00:11:35.749
of "Do the kids know anything
about where food comes from?"

00:11:35.773 --> 00:11:37.750
Who knows what that is? Child: Uh, pear?

00:11:37.774 --> 00:11:40.202
JO: What do you think this is?
Child: I don't know.

00:11:40.226 --> 00:11:42.210
JO: If the kids don't know what stuff is,

00:11:42.234 --> 00:11:43.633
then they will never eat it.

00:11:45.821 --> 00:11:47.078
(Laughter)

00:11:47.102 --> 00:11:49.874
JO: Normal. England and America,

00:11:49.898 --> 00:11:51.436
England and America.

00:11:51.460 --> 00:11:53.603
Guess what fixed that.

00:11:54.065 --> 00:11:55.538
Two one-hour sessions.

00:11:57.109 --> 00:12:00.498
We've got to start teaching our kids
about food in schools, period.

00:12:01.334 --> 00:12:06.874
(Applause)

00:12:06.898 --> 00:12:10.919
I want to tell you about something

00:12:10.943 --> 00:12:15.281
that kind of epitomizes the trouble
that we're in, guys, OK?

00:12:15.305 --> 00:12:17.876
I want to talk about something
so basic as milk.

00:12:18.540 --> 00:12:20.541
Every kid has the right to milk at school.

00:12:20.565 --> 00:12:24.161
Your kids will be having milk
at school, breakfast and lunch, right?

00:12:24.185 --> 00:12:25.983
They'll be having two bottles, OK?

00:12:26.007 --> 00:12:27.500
And most kids do.

00:12:27.524 --> 00:12:30.309
But milk ain't good enough anymore.

00:12:30.333 --> 00:12:32.874
Don't get me wrong, I support milk --

00:12:32.898 --> 00:12:35.014
but someone at the milk board

00:12:35.038 --> 00:12:37.708
probably paid a lot of money
for some geezer to work out

00:12:37.732 --> 00:12:39.473
that if you put loads of flavorings,

00:12:39.497 --> 00:12:40.920
colorings and sugar in milk,

00:12:40.944 --> 00:12:42.362
more kids will drink it.

00:12:43.603 --> 00:12:44.603
Yeah.

00:12:45.119 --> 00:12:47.072
Obviously now that's going to catch on

00:12:47.096 --> 00:12:48.882
the apple board is going to work out

00:12:48.906 --> 00:12:51.683
that if they make toffee apples
they'll eat more as well.

00:12:51.707 --> 00:12:53.120
Do you know what I mean?

00:12:53.144 --> 00:12:56.191
For me, there isn't any need
to flavor the milk.

00:12:56.215 --> 00:12:58.238
Okay? There's sugar in everything.

00:12:58.262 --> 00:13:00.411
I know the ins and outs
of those ingredients.

00:13:00.435 --> 00:13:01.461
It's in everything.

00:13:01.485 --> 00:13:05.063
Even the milk hasn't escaped
the kind of modern-day problems.

00:13:05.087 --> 00:13:06.874
There's our milk. There's our carton.

00:13:06.898 --> 00:13:11.147
In that is nearly as much sugar
as one of your favorite cans of fizzy pop,

00:13:11.171 --> 00:13:12.607
and they are having two a day.

00:13:12.631 --> 00:13:14.186
So, let me just show you.

00:13:14.210 --> 00:13:17.292
We've got one kid, here --

00:13:18.985 --> 00:13:22.797
having, you know,
eight tablespoons of sugar a day.

00:13:23.517 --> 00:13:25.643
You know, there's your week.

00:13:26.398 --> 00:13:28.254
There's your month.

00:13:29.476 --> 00:13:31.671
And I've taken the liberty of putting in

00:13:31.695 --> 00:13:34.695
just the five years
of elementary school sugar,

00:13:38.351 --> 00:13:39.549
just from milk.

00:13:42.898 --> 00:13:44.718
Now, I don't know about you guys,

00:13:44.742 --> 00:13:47.559
but judging the circumstances, right,

00:13:47.583 --> 00:13:49.874
any judge in the whole world,

00:13:49.898 --> 00:13:52.362
would look at the statistics
and the evidence,

00:13:52.386 --> 00:13:55.671
and they would find any government
of old guilty of child abuse.

00:13:56.226 --> 00:13:57.330
That's my belief.

00:13:57.354 --> 00:14:00.354
(Applause)

00:14:04.245 --> 00:14:05.874
(Applause ends)

00:14:05.898 --> 00:14:09.190
Now, if I came up here, and I wish
I could come up here today

00:14:09.214 --> 00:14:11.875
and hang a cure for AIDS or cancer,

00:14:11.899 --> 00:14:14.349
you'd be fighting
and scrambling to get to me.

00:14:15.382 --> 00:14:18.358
This, all this bad news, is preventable.

00:14:18.898 --> 00:14:20.409
That's the good news.

00:14:20.433 --> 00:14:22.409
It's very, very preventable.

00:14:23.178 --> 00:14:25.874
So, let's just think about,
we got a problem here,

00:14:25.898 --> 00:14:27.016
we need to reboot.

00:14:28.231 --> 00:14:30.874
Okay so, in my world,
what do we need to do?

00:14:30.898 --> 00:14:32.613
Here is the thing, right,

00:14:32.637 --> 00:14:34.874
it cannot just come from one source.

00:14:34.898 --> 00:14:38.305
To reboot and make real tangible change,

00:14:38.329 --> 00:14:41.273
real change, so that I could look you
in the white of the eyes

00:14:41.297 --> 00:14:42.874
and say, "In 10 years' time,

00:14:42.898 --> 00:14:44.874
the history of your children's lives,

00:14:44.898 --> 00:14:47.946
happiness -- and let's not forget,
you're clever if you eat well,

00:14:47.970 --> 00:14:49.828
you know you're going to live longer --

00:14:49.852 --> 00:14:52.785
all of that stuff,
it will look different. OK?"

00:14:53.504 --> 00:14:55.210
So, supermarkets.

00:14:55.234 --> 00:14:57.154
Where else do you shop so religiously?

00:14:57.178 --> 00:14:58.366
Week in, week out.

00:14:58.390 --> 00:15:01.469
How much money do you spend,
in your life, in a supermarket?

00:15:01.493 --> 00:15:02.501
Love them.

00:15:02.525 --> 00:15:04.581
They just sell us what we want. All right.

00:15:04.605 --> 00:15:09.064
They owe us to put a food ambassador
in every major supermarket.

00:15:09.580 --> 00:15:11.160
They need to help us shop.

00:15:11.184 --> 00:15:14.874
They need to show us how to cook
quick, tasty, seasonal meals

00:15:14.898 --> 00:15:16.763
for people that are busy.

00:15:16.787 --> 00:15:18.756
This is not expensive.

00:15:18.780 --> 00:15:21.661
It is done in some, and it needs
to be done across the board

00:15:21.685 --> 00:15:23.390
in America soon, and quick.

00:15:23.762 --> 00:15:26.739
The big brands, you know, the food brands,

00:15:26.763 --> 00:15:30.488
need to put food education
at the heart of their businesses.

00:15:30.512 --> 00:15:32.392
I know, easier said than done.

00:15:32.416 --> 00:15:34.627
It's the future. It's the only way.

00:15:34.651 --> 00:15:36.272
Fast food.

00:15:36.296 --> 00:15:39.056
With the fast-food industry

00:15:39.080 --> 00:15:40.874
you know, it's very competitive.

00:15:40.898 --> 00:15:42.993
I've had loads
of secret papers and dealings

00:15:43.017 --> 00:15:44.735
with fast food restaurants.

00:15:44.759 --> 00:15:46.576
I know how they do it.

00:15:46.600 --> 00:15:48.873
I mean, basically they've weaned us on

00:15:48.897 --> 00:15:51.676
to these hits of sugar,
salt and fat, and x, y, and z,

00:15:51.700 --> 00:15:53.677
and everyone loves them, right?

00:15:53.701 --> 00:15:56.897
So, these guys are going
to be part of the solution.

00:15:56.921 --> 00:15:58.874
But we need to get the government to work

00:15:58.898 --> 00:16:01.946
with all of the fast food purveyors
and the restaurant industry,

00:16:01.970 --> 00:16:04.019
and over a five, six, seven year period

00:16:04.043 --> 00:16:06.362
wean of us off the extreme amounts

00:16:06.386 --> 00:16:09.874
of fat, sugar and all the other
non-food ingredients.

00:16:09.898 --> 00:16:12.180
Now, also, back to the sort of big brands:

00:16:12.204 --> 00:16:15.386
labeling, I said earlier,
is an absolute farce

00:16:15.410 --> 00:16:16.821
and has got to be sorted.

00:16:18.201 --> 00:16:19.526
OK, school.

00:16:20.428 --> 00:16:22.874
Obviously, in schools, we owe it to them

00:16:22.898 --> 00:16:24.874
to make sure those 180 days of the year,

00:16:24.898 --> 00:16:26.874
from that little precious age of four,

00:16:26.898 --> 00:16:28.874
until 18, 20, 24, whatever,

00:16:28.898 --> 00:16:33.749
they need to be cooked proper, fresh food

00:16:33.773 --> 00:16:35.874
from local growers on site, OK?

00:16:35.898 --> 00:16:38.424
There needs to be a new
standard of fresh, proper food

00:16:38.448 --> 00:16:39.874
for your children, yeah?

00:16:39.898 --> 00:16:44.327
(Applause)

00:16:44.351 --> 00:16:47.787
Under the circumstances,
it's profoundly important

00:16:47.811 --> 00:16:50.380
that every single
American child leaves school

00:16:50.404 --> 00:16:52.381
knowing how to cook 10 recipes

00:16:52.405 --> 00:16:53.754
that will save their life.

00:16:54.898 --> 00:16:55.977
Life skills.

00:16:56.001 --> 00:16:58.198
(Applause)

00:16:58.222 --> 00:17:01.260
That means that they can be
students, young parents,

00:17:01.284 --> 00:17:05.523
and be able to sort of duck and dive
around the basics of cooking,

00:17:05.547 --> 00:17:07.650
no matter what recession hits
them next time.

00:17:07.674 --> 00:17:10.056
If you can cook,
recession money doesn't matter.

00:17:10.080 --> 00:17:12.551
If you can cook, time doesn't matter.

00:17:14.093 --> 00:17:16.538
The workplace, we haven't
really talked about it.

00:17:16.562 --> 00:17:20.124
You know, it's now time
for corporate responsibility

00:17:20.148 --> 00:17:24.172
to really look at what they feed
or make available to their staff.

00:17:24.196 --> 00:17:27.506
The staff are the moms and dads
of America's children.

00:17:27.530 --> 00:17:29.689
Marissa, her father died in her hand,

00:17:29.713 --> 00:17:31.690
I think she'd be quite happy

00:17:31.714 --> 00:17:34.874
if corporate America could start
feeding their staff properly.

00:17:34.898 --> 00:17:36.874
Definitely they shouldn't be left out.

00:17:36.898 --> 00:17:38.464
Let's go back to the home.

00:17:38.488 --> 00:17:40.728
Now, look, if we do
all this stuff, and we can,

00:17:40.752 --> 00:17:41.825
it's so achievable.

00:17:41.849 --> 00:17:43.591
You can care and be commercial.

00:17:43.615 --> 00:17:44.638
Absolutely.

00:17:44.662 --> 00:17:49.657
But the home needs to start passing on
cooking again, for sure.

00:17:49.681 --> 00:17:51.657
For sure, pass it on as a philosophy.

00:17:52.171 --> 00:17:53.815
And for me, it's quite romantic,

00:17:53.839 --> 00:17:56.232
but it's about if one person
teaches three people

00:17:56.256 --> 00:17:57.874
how to cook something,

00:17:57.898 --> 00:17:59.638
and they teach three of their mates,

00:17:59.662 --> 00:18:01.986
that only has to repeat itself 25 times,

00:18:02.010 --> 00:18:04.265
and that's the whole
population of America.

00:18:04.289 --> 00:18:08.589
Romantic, yes, but most importantly,

00:18:08.613 --> 00:18:11.304
it's about trying to get people to realize

00:18:11.328 --> 00:18:14.312
that every one of your individual efforts
makes a difference.

00:18:14.336 --> 00:18:16.536
We've got to put back what's been lost.

00:18:17.030 --> 00:18:18.252
Huntington's Kitchen.

00:18:18.893 --> 00:18:21.164
Huntington, where I made this program,

00:18:21.188 --> 00:18:22.775
we've got this prime-time program

00:18:22.799 --> 00:18:25.987
that hopefully will inspire people
to really get on this change.

00:18:26.011 --> 00:18:28.042
I truly believe that change will happen.

00:18:28.066 --> 00:18:30.233
Huntington's Kitchen.
I work with a community.

00:18:30.257 --> 00:18:31.738
I worked in the schools.

00:18:31.762 --> 00:18:34.027
I found local sustainable funding

00:18:34.051 --> 00:18:38.337
to get every single school in the area
from the junk, onto the fresh food:

00:18:38.361 --> 00:18:40.230
six-and-a-half grand per school.

00:18:40.898 --> 00:18:42.104
(Applause)

00:18:42.128 --> 00:18:44.624
That's all it takes,
six-and-a-half grand per school.

00:18:44.648 --> 00:18:47.051
The Kitchen is 25 grand a month. Okay?

00:18:47.075 --> 00:18:49.950
This can do 5,000 people a year,

00:18:49.974 --> 00:18:52.092
which is 10 percent of their population,

00:18:52.116 --> 00:18:53.497
and it's people on people.

00:18:53.521 --> 00:18:55.822
You know, it's local cooks
teaching local people.

00:18:55.846 --> 00:18:59.432
It's free cooking lessons,
guys, in the Main Street.

00:19:00.238 --> 00:19:03.585
This is real, tangible change,
real, tangible change.

00:19:04.382 --> 00:19:07.404
Around America, if we just look back now,

00:19:07.428 --> 00:19:09.831
there is plenty of wonderful
things going on.

00:19:10.532 --> 00:19:12.641
There is plenty of beautiful
things going on.

00:19:12.665 --> 00:19:15.874
There are angels
around America doing great things

00:19:15.898 --> 00:19:18.795
in schools -- farm-to-school set-ups,

00:19:18.819 --> 00:19:21.430
garden set-ups, education --

00:19:21.454 --> 00:19:23.551
there are amazing people
doing this already.

00:19:23.575 --> 00:19:25.504
The problem is they all want to roll out

00:19:25.528 --> 00:19:27.663
what they're doing to the next school,

00:19:27.687 --> 00:19:29.035
but there's no cash.

00:19:29.955 --> 00:19:33.655
We need to recognize the experts
and the angels quickly,

00:19:33.679 --> 00:19:36.874
identify them, and allow them
to easily find the resource

00:19:36.898 --> 00:19:39.138
to keep rolling out
what they're already doing,

00:19:39.162 --> 00:19:40.162
and doing well.

00:19:40.746 --> 00:19:43.018
Businesses of America need to support

00:19:43.042 --> 00:19:45.874
Mrs. Obama to do the things
that she wants to do.

00:19:45.898 --> 00:19:52.297
(Applause)

00:19:52.321 --> 00:19:54.267
And look, I know it's weird

00:19:54.291 --> 00:19:56.874
having an English person
standing here before you

00:19:56.898 --> 00:19:58.339
talking about all this.

00:19:58.363 --> 00:19:59.711
All I can say is: I care.

00:20:00.267 --> 00:20:01.689
I'm a father,

00:20:01.713 --> 00:20:03.054
and I love this country.

00:20:03.898 --> 00:20:06.500
And I believe truly, actually,

00:20:06.524 --> 00:20:09.373
that if change can be made
in this country,

00:20:09.397 --> 00:20:11.580
beautiful things will happen
around the world.

00:20:11.604 --> 00:20:13.739
If America does it,
other people will follow.

00:20:13.763 --> 00:20:15.159
It's incredibly important.

00:20:15.535 --> 00:20:16.603
(Audience) Yeah!

00:20:16.627 --> 00:20:22.258
(Applause)

00:20:22.282 --> 00:20:23.560
When I was in Huntington,

00:20:23.584 --> 00:20:26.208
trying to get a few things to work
when they weren't,

00:20:26.232 --> 00:20:31.543
I thought "If I had a magic wand,
what would I do?"

00:20:31.567 --> 00:20:33.124
And I thought, "You know what?

00:20:33.148 --> 00:20:36.431
I'd just love to be put in front
of some of the most amazing

00:20:36.455 --> 00:20:38.219
movers and shakers in America."

00:20:39.139 --> 00:20:42.226
And a month later, TED phoned me up
and gave me this award.

00:20:43.691 --> 00:20:44.746
I'm here.

00:20:47.413 --> 00:20:48.595
So, my wish.

00:20:53.633 --> 00:20:55.395
Dyslexic, so I'm a bit slow.

00:21:00.898 --> 00:21:02.874
My wish

00:21:02.898 --> 00:21:07.029
is for you to help a strong,
sustainable movement

00:21:07.053 --> 00:21:10.727
to educate every child

00:21:10.751 --> 00:21:13.139
about food,

00:21:13.163 --> 00:21:16.678
to inspire families to cook again,

00:21:16.702 --> 00:21:19.363
and to empower people everywhere

00:21:19.387 --> 00:21:20.910
to fight obesity.

00:21:21.898 --> 00:21:25.002
