The other grade is: Are we deploying this zero-emission technology, have we deployed it in all the developed countries and are in the process of getting it elsewhere? That's super important. That's a key element of making that report card.Backing up from there, what should the 2020 report card look like? Well, again, it should have the two elements. We should go through these efficiency measures to start getting reductions: The less we emit, the less that sum will be of CO2, and therefore, the less the temperature. But in some ways, the grade we get there, doing things that don't get us all the way to the big reductions, is only equally, or maybe even slightly less, important than the other, which is the piece of innovation on these breakthroughs.These breakthroughs, we need to move those at full speed, and we can measure that in terms of companies, pilot projects, regulatory things that have been changed. There's a lot of great books that have been written about this. The Al Gore book, "Our Choice," and the David MacKay book, "Sustainable Energy Without the Hot Air." They really go through it and create a framework that this can be discussed broadly, because we need broad backing for this. There's a lot that has to come together.So this is a wish. It's a very concrete wish that we invent this technology. If you gave me only one wish for the next 50 years — I could pick who's president, I could pick a vaccine, which is something I love, or I could pick that this thing that's half the cost with no CO2 gets invented — this is the wish I would pick. This is the one with the greatest impact. If we don't get this wish, the division between the people who think short term and long term will be terrible, between the US and China, between poor countries and rich, and most of all, the lives of those two billion will be far worse.So what do we have to do? What am I appealing to you to step forward and drive? We need to go for more research funding. When countries get together in places like Copenhagen, they shouldn't just discuss the CO2. They should discuss this innovation agenda. You'd be stunned at the ridiculously low levels of spending on these innovative approaches. We do need the market incentives — CO2 tax, cap and trade — something that gets that price signal out there. We need to get the message out. We need to have this dialogue be a more rational, more understandable dialogue, including the steps that the government takes. This is an important wish, but it is one I think we can achieve.Thank you.(Applause) (Applause ends)Thank you.Chris Anderson: Thank you. Thank you.(Applause)CA: Thank you. So to understand more about TerraPower. I mean, first of all, can you give a sense of what scale of investment this is?Bill Gates: To actually do the software, buy the supercomputer, hire all the great scientists, which we've done, that's only tens of millions. And even once we test our materials out in a Russian reactor to make sure our materials work properly, then you'll only be up in the hundreds of millions. The tough thing is building the pilot reactor — finding the several billion, finding the regulator, the location that will actually build the first one of these. Once you get the first one built, if it works as advertised, then it's just clear as day, because the economics, the energy density, are so different than nuclear as we know it.CA: So to understand it right, this involves building deep into the ground, almost like a vertical column of nuclear fuel, of this spent uranium, and then the process starts at the top and kind of works down?BG: That's right. Today, you're always refueling the reactor, so you have lots of people and lots of controls that can go wrong, where you're opening it up and moving things in and out — that's not good. So if you have very —(Laughter)very cheap fuel that you can put 60 years in — just think of it as a log — put it down and not have those same complexities. And it just sits there and burns for the 60 years, and then it's done.CA: It's a nuclear power plant that is its own waste disposal solution.BG: Yeah; what happens with the waste, you can let it sit there — there's a lot less waste under this approach — then you can actually take that and put it into another one and burn that. And we start out, actually, by taking the waste that exists today that's sitting in these cooling pools or dry-casking by reactors — that's our fuel to begin with. So the thing that's been a problem from those reactors is actually what gets fed into ours, and you're reducing the volume of the waste quite dramatically as you're going through this process.CA: You're talking to different people around the world about the possibilities. Where is there most interest in actually doing something with this?BG: Well, we haven't picked a particular place, and there's all these interesting disclosure rules about anything that's called "nuclear." So we've got a lot of interest. People from the company have been in Russia, India, China. I've been back seeing the secretary of energy here, talking about how this fits into the energy agenda. So I'm optimistic. The French and Japanese have done some work. This is a variant on something that has been done. It's an important advance, but it's like a fast reactor, and a lot of countries have built them, so anybody who's done a fast reactor is a candidate to be where the first one gets built.CA: So, in your mind, timescale and likelihood of actually taking something like this live?BG: Well, we need — for one of these high-scale, electro-generation things that's very cheap, we have 20 years to invent and then 20 years to deploy. That's sort of the deadline that the environmental models have shown us that we have to meet. And TerraPower — if things go well, which is wishing for a lot — could easily meet that. And there are, fortunately now, dozens of companies — we need it to be hundreds — who, likewise, if their science goes well, if the funding for their pilot plants goes well, that they can compete for this. And it's best if multiple succeed, because then you could use a mix of these things. We certainly need one to succeed.CA: In terms of big-scale possible game changers, is this the biggest that you're aware of out there?BG: An energy breakthrough is the most important thing. It would have been, even without the environmental constraint, but the environmental constraint just makes it so much greater. In the nuclear space, there are other innovators. You know, we don't know their work as well as we know this one, but the modular people, that's a different approach. There's a liquid-type reactor, which seems a little hard, but maybe they say that about us. And so, there are different ones, but the beauty of this is a molecule of uranium has a million times as much energy as a molecule of, say, coal. And so, if you can deal with the negatives, which are essentially the radiation, the footprint and cost, the potential, in terms of effect on land and various things, is almost in a class of its own.CA: If this doesn't work, then what? Do we have to start taking emergency measures to try and keep the temperature of the earth stable?BG: If you get into that situation, it's like if you've been overeating, and you're about to have a heart attack. Then where do you go? You may need heart surgery or something. There is a line of research on what's called geoengineering, which are various techniques that would delay the heating to buy us 20 or 30 years to get our act together. Now, that's just an insurance policy; you hope you don't need to do that. Some people say you shouldn't even work on the insurance policy because it might make you lazy, that you'll keep eating because you know heart surgery will be there to save you. I'm not sure that's wise, given the importance of the problem, but there's now the geoengineering discussion about: Should that be in the back pocket in case things happen faster, or this innovation goes a lot slower than we expect?CA: Climate skeptics: If you had a sentence or two to say to them, how might you persuade them that they're wrong?BG: Well, unfortunately, the skeptics come in different camps. The ones who make scientific arguments are very few. Are they saying there's negative feedback effects that have to do with clouds that offset things? There are very, very few things that they can even say there's a chance in a million of those things. The main problem we have here — it's kind of like with AIDS: you make the mistake now, and you pay for it a lot later.And so, when you have all sorts of urgent problems, the idea of taking pain now that has to do with a gain later, and a somewhat uncertain pain thing. In fact, the IPCC report — that's not necessarily the worst case, and there are people in the rich world who look at IPCC and say, "OK, that isn't that big of a deal." The fact is it's that uncertain part that should move us towards this. But my dream here is that, if you can make it economic, and meet the CO2 constraints, then the skeptics say, "OK, I don't care that it doesn't put out CO2, I kind of wish it did put out CO2. But I guess I'll accept it, because it's cheaper than what's come before."(Applause)CA: So that would be your response to the Bjørn Lomborg argument, basically if you spend all this energy trying to solve the CO2 problem, it's going to take away all your other goals of trying to rid the world of poverty and malaria and so forth, it's a stupid waste of the Earth's resources to put money towards that when there are better things we can do.BG: Well, the actual spending on the R&D piece — say the US should spend 10 billion a year more than it is right now — it's not that dramatic. It shouldn't take away from other things. The thing you get into big money on, and reasonable people can disagree, is when you have something that's non-economic and you're trying to fund that — that, to me, mostly is a waste. Unless you're very close, and you're just funding the learning curve and it's going to get very cheap, I believe we should try more things that have a potential to be far less expensive. If the trade-off you get into is, "Let's make energy super expensive," then the rich can afford that. I mean, all of us here could pay five times as much for our energy and not change our lifestyle. The disaster is for that two billion.And even Lomborg has changed. His shtick now is, "Why isn't the R&D getting more discussed?" He's still, because of his earlier stuff, still associated with the skeptic camp, but he's realized that's a pretty lonely camp, and so, he's making the R&D point. And so there is a thread of something that I think is appropriate. The R&D piece — it's crazy how little it's funded.CA: Well, Bill, I suspect I speak on behalf of most people here to say I really hope your wish comes true. Thank you so much.BG: Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.712 --> 00:00:16.346
I'm going to talk today
about energy and climate.

00:00:17.061 --> 00:00:18.839
And that might seem a bit surprising,

00:00:18.863 --> 00:00:22.012
because my full-time work
at the foundation

00:00:22.036 --> 00:00:24.071
is mostly about vaccines and seeds,

00:00:24.095 --> 00:00:27.663
about the things that we need
to invent and deliver

00:00:27.687 --> 00:00:31.194
to help the poorest two billion
live better lives.

00:00:32.439 --> 00:00:36.934
But energy and climate
are extremely important to these people;

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:41.229
in fact, more important
than to anyone else on the planet.

00:00:41.751 --> 00:00:47.462
The climate getting worse means
that many years, their crops won't grow:

00:00:47.486 --> 00:00:50.517
there will be too much rain,
not enough rain;

00:00:50.541 --> 00:00:56.478
things will change in ways their fragile
environment simply can't support.

00:00:56.502 --> 00:01:00.131
And that leads to starvation, it leads
to uncertainty, it leads to unrest.

00:01:00.830 --> 00:01:03.964
So, the climate changes
will be terrible for them.

00:01:04.791 --> 00:01:07.934
Also, the price of energy
is very important to them.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.236
In fact, if you could pick just one thing

00:01:10.260 --> 00:01:14.992
to lower the price of to reduce poverty,
by far you would pick energy.

00:01:15.660 --> 00:01:18.573
Now, the price of energy
has come down over time.

00:01:19.041 --> 00:01:25.347
Really advanced civilization
is based on advances in energy.

00:01:25.736 --> 00:01:29.307
The coal revolution fueled
the Industrial Revolution,

00:01:29.331 --> 00:01:33.392
and, even in the 1900s,
we've seen a very rapid decline

00:01:33.416 --> 00:01:34.934
in the price of electricity,

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:38.340
and that's why we have
refrigerators, air-conditioning;

00:01:38.364 --> 00:01:41.676
we can make modern materials
and do so many things.

00:01:42.184 --> 00:01:48.337
And so, we're in a wonderful situation
with electricity in the rich world.

00:01:49.242 --> 00:01:52.121
But as we make it cheaper --
and let's say,

00:01:52.145 --> 00:01:54.854
let's go for making it twice as cheap --

00:01:56.314 --> 00:01:57.934
we need to meet a new constraint,

00:01:58.735 --> 00:02:02.677
and that constraint has to do with CO2.

00:02:02.701 --> 00:02:05.770
CO2 is warming the planet,

00:02:05.794 --> 00:02:10.934
and the equation on CO2
is actually a very straightforward one.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:14.897
If you sum up the CO2 that gets emitted,

00:02:15.564 --> 00:02:17.934
that leads to a temperature increase,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:21.934
and that temperature increase
leads to some very negative effects:

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:25.871
the effects on the weather;
perhaps worse, the indirect effects,

00:02:25.895 --> 00:02:30.588
in that the natural ecosystems
can't adjust to these rapid changes,

00:02:30.612 --> 00:02:32.855
and so you get ecosystem collapses.

00:02:33.358 --> 00:02:38.753
Now, the exact amount of how you map
from a certain increase of CO2

00:02:38.777 --> 00:02:42.067
to what temperature will be,
and where the positive feedbacks are --

00:02:42.091 --> 00:02:44.811
there's some uncertainty there,
but not very much.

00:02:45.224 --> 00:02:48.524
And there's certainly uncertainty
about how bad those effects will be,

00:02:48.548 --> 00:02:50.284
but they will be extremely bad.

00:02:51.159 --> 00:02:53.461
I asked the top scientists
on this several times:

00:02:53.485 --> 00:02:56.009
Do we really have to get
down to near zero?

00:02:56.033 --> 00:02:59.066
Can't we just cut it in half or a quarter?

00:02:59.090 --> 00:03:02.934
And the answer is,
until we get near to zero,

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.934
the temperature will continue to rise.

00:03:05.416 --> 00:03:07.186
And so that's a big challenge.

00:03:07.210 --> 00:03:09.436
It's very different than saying,

00:03:09.460 --> 00:03:12.796
"We're a twelve-foot-high truck
trying to get under a ten-foot bridge,

00:03:12.820 --> 00:03:15.203
and we can just sort of squeeze under."

00:03:15.567 --> 00:03:18.550
This is something that has to get to zero.

00:03:19.526 --> 00:03:22.795
Now, we put out a lot
of carbon dioxide every year --

00:03:22.819 --> 00:03:24.922
over 26 billion tons.

00:03:25.540 --> 00:03:28.704
For each American, it's about 20 tons.

00:03:29.136 --> 00:03:31.934
For people in poor countries,
it's less than one ton.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:35.618
It's an average of about five tons
for everyone on the planet.

00:03:36.100 --> 00:03:40.933
And somehow, we have to make changes
that will bring that down to zero.

00:03:41.575 --> 00:03:43.719
It's been constantly going up.

00:03:43.743 --> 00:03:48.348
It's only various economic changes
that have even flattened it at all,

00:03:48.372 --> 00:03:51.829
so we have to go
from rapidly rising to falling,

00:03:51.853 --> 00:03:53.935
and falling all the way to zero.

00:03:53.959 --> 00:03:57.934
This equation has four factors,
a little bit of multiplication.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:01.722
So you've got a thing on the left,
CO2, that you want to get to zero,

00:04:01.746 --> 00:04:05.136
and that's going to be based
on the number of people,

00:04:05.160 --> 00:04:08.550
the services each person
is using on average,

00:04:08.574 --> 00:04:11.443
the energy, on average, for each service,

00:04:11.467 --> 00:04:15.299
and the CO2 being put out
per unit of energy.

00:04:15.690 --> 00:04:17.643
So let's look at each one of these,

00:04:17.667 --> 00:04:20.537
and see how we can get this down to zero.

00:04:21.196 --> 00:04:24.748
Probably, one of these numbers is going
to have to get pretty near to zero.

00:04:24.772 --> 00:04:25.954
(Laughter)

00:04:25.978 --> 00:04:27.952
That's back from high school algebra.

00:04:27.976 --> 00:04:29.296
But let's take a look.

00:04:29.656 --> 00:04:31.508
First, we've got population.

00:04:32.152 --> 00:04:34.934
The world today has 6.8 billion people.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.161
That's headed up to about nine billion.

00:04:37.185 --> 00:04:41.246
Now, if we do a really great job
on new vaccines,

00:04:41.270 --> 00:04:43.727
health care, reproductive health services,

00:04:43.751 --> 00:04:46.852
we could lower that by,
perhaps, 10 or 15 percent.

00:04:46.876 --> 00:04:50.667
But there, we see
an increase of about 1.3.

00:04:51.383 --> 00:04:53.976
The second factor is the services we use.

00:04:54.413 --> 00:04:56.178
This encompasses everything:

00:04:56.202 --> 00:05:00.375
the food we eat, clothing, TV, heating.

00:05:00.735 --> 00:05:02.372
These are very good things.

00:05:02.887 --> 00:05:06.594
Getting rid of poverty means
providing these services

00:05:06.618 --> 00:05:08.623
to almost everyone on the planet.

00:05:08.647 --> 00:05:11.934
And it's a great thing
for this number to go up.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.197
In the rich world, perhaps
the top one billion,

00:05:14.221 --> 00:05:16.606
we probably could cut back and use less,

00:05:16.630 --> 00:05:20.746
but every year, this number,
on average, is going to go up,

00:05:20.770 --> 00:05:23.934
and so, overall,
that will more than double

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.397
the services delivered per person.

00:05:27.096 --> 00:05:29.199
Here we have a very basic service:

00:05:29.223 --> 00:05:32.635
Do you have lighting in your house
to be able to read your homework?

00:05:32.659 --> 00:05:34.178
And, in fact, these kids don't,

00:05:34.202 --> 00:05:36.520
so they're going out and reading
their schoolwork

00:05:36.544 --> 00:05:37.938
under the street lamps.

00:05:39.236 --> 00:05:42.934
Now, efficiency, "E,"
the energy for each service --

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.935
here, finally we have some good news.

00:05:44.959 --> 00:05:46.821
We have something that's not going up.

00:05:46.845 --> 00:05:49.934
Through various inventions
and new ways of doing lighting,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:55.389
through different types of cars,
different ways of building buildings --

00:05:55.413 --> 00:05:57.048
there are a lot of services

00:05:57.072 --> 00:06:00.412
where you can bring the energy
for that service down

00:06:00.436 --> 00:06:01.934
quite substantially.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:05.453
Some individual services
even bring it down by 90 percent.

00:06:05.477 --> 00:06:08.823
There are other services,
like how we make fertilizer,

00:06:08.847 --> 00:06:10.489
or how we do air transport,

00:06:10.513 --> 00:06:13.430
where the rooms for improvement
are far, far less.

00:06:13.854 --> 00:06:18.152
And so overall, if we're optimistic,
we may get a reduction

00:06:18.176 --> 00:06:23.045
of a factor of three to even,
perhaps, a factor of six.

00:06:23.566 --> 00:06:25.934
But for these first three factors now,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:31.018
we've gone from 26 billion
to, at best, maybe 13 billion tons,

00:06:31.042 --> 00:06:32.503
and that just won't cut it.

00:06:32.957 --> 00:06:36.755
So let's look at this fourth factor --
this is going to be a key one --

00:06:36.779 --> 00:06:42.668
and this is the amount of CO2
put out per each unit of energy.

00:06:43.132 --> 00:06:46.657
So the question is:
Can you actually get that to zero?

00:06:46.681 --> 00:06:49.587
If you burn coal, no.

00:06:49.611 --> 00:06:51.086
If you burn natural gas, no.

00:06:51.110 --> 00:06:54.213
Almost every way
we make electricity today,

00:06:54.237 --> 00:06:59.789
except for the emerging renewables
and nuclear, puts out CO2.

00:07:00.249 --> 00:07:03.502
And so, what we're going to have
to do at a global scale,

00:07:03.526 --> 00:07:05.381
is create a new system.

00:07:05.831 --> 00:07:07.696
So we need energy miracles.

00:07:08.484 --> 00:07:12.777
Now, when I use the term "miracle,"
I don't mean something that's impossible.

00:07:12.801 --> 00:07:15.221
The microprocessor is a miracle.

00:07:15.245 --> 00:07:17.230
The personal computer is a miracle.

00:07:17.254 --> 00:07:19.721
The Internet and its services
are a miracle.

00:07:19.745 --> 00:07:24.360
So the people here have participated
in the creation of many miracles.

00:07:24.815 --> 00:07:26.792
Usually, we don't have a deadline

00:07:26.816 --> 00:07:29.294
where you have to get the miracle
by a certain date.

00:07:29.318 --> 00:07:33.299
Usually, you just kind of stand by,
and some come along, some don't.

00:07:33.323 --> 00:07:37.422
This is a case where we actually
have to drive at full speed

00:07:37.446 --> 00:07:41.437
and get a miracle
in a pretty tight timeline.

00:07:42.447 --> 00:07:45.392
Now, I thought, "How could
I really capture this?

00:07:45.416 --> 00:07:47.639
Is there some kind
of natural illustration,

00:07:47.663 --> 00:07:51.533
some demonstration that would grab
people's imagination here?"

00:07:52.200 --> 00:07:55.934
I thought back to a year ago
when I brought mosquitoes,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.588
and somehow people enjoyed that.

00:07:58.612 --> 00:08:00.219
(Laughter)

00:08:00.243 --> 00:08:04.289
It really got them involved
in the idea of, you know,

00:08:04.313 --> 00:08:06.365
there are people who live with mosquitoes.

00:08:06.389 --> 00:08:10.003
With energy, all I could
come up with is this.

00:08:10.799 --> 00:08:13.933
I decided that releasing fireflies

00:08:13.957 --> 00:08:17.590
would be my contribution
to the environment here this year.

00:08:18.074 --> 00:08:20.934
So here we have some natural fireflies.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.567
I'm told they don't bite; in fact,
they might not even leave that jar.

00:08:24.591 --> 00:08:26.163
(Laughter)

00:08:27.791 --> 00:08:31.929
Now, there's all sorts of gimmicky
solutions like that one,

00:08:31.953 --> 00:08:33.854
but they don't really add up to much.

00:08:33.878 --> 00:08:37.901
We need solutions, either one or several,

00:08:37.925 --> 00:08:43.436
that have unbelievable scale
and unbelievable reliability.

00:08:43.966 --> 00:08:47.434
And although there's many directions
that people are seeking,

00:08:47.458 --> 00:08:51.079
I really only see five
that can achieve the big numbers.

00:08:51.559 --> 00:08:55.846
I've left out tide,
geothermal, fusion, biofuels.

00:08:55.870 --> 00:08:57.847
Those may make some contribution,

00:08:57.871 --> 00:09:00.720
and if they can do better
than I expect, so much the better.

00:09:00.744 --> 00:09:04.666
But my key point here
is that we're going to have to work on

00:09:04.690 --> 00:09:06.416
each of these five,

00:09:06.440 --> 00:09:10.237
and we can't give up any of them
because they look daunting,

00:09:10.261 --> 00:09:13.122
because they all have
significant challenges.

00:09:13.759 --> 00:09:16.379
Let's look first at burning fossil fuels,

00:09:16.403 --> 00:09:19.244
either burning coal
or burning natural gas.

00:09:19.719 --> 00:09:23.805
What you need to do there seems
like it might be simple, but it's not.

00:09:23.829 --> 00:09:26.262
And that's to take all the CO2,

00:09:26.286 --> 00:09:28.934
after you've burned it,
going out the flue,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:32.103
pressurize it, create a liquid,
put it somewhere,

00:09:32.127 --> 00:09:33.557
and hope it stays there.

00:09:34.150 --> 00:09:35.772
Now, we have some pilot things

00:09:35.796 --> 00:09:38.135
that do this at the 60 to 80
percent level.

00:09:38.159 --> 00:09:42.558
But getting up to that full percentage --
that will be very tricky.

00:09:42.582 --> 00:09:48.154
And agreeing on where these CO2
quantities should be put will be hard,

00:09:48.178 --> 00:09:50.840
but the toughest one here
is this long-term issue:

00:09:50.864 --> 00:09:52.404
Who's going to be sure?

00:09:52.428 --> 00:09:54.026
Who's going to guarantee

00:09:54.050 --> 00:09:57.119
something that is literally
billions of times larger

00:09:57.143 --> 00:10:01.289
than any type of waste you think of
in terms of nuclear or other things?

00:10:01.313 --> 00:10:03.793
This is a lot of volume.

00:10:04.392 --> 00:10:05.598
So that's a tough one.

00:10:06.225 --> 00:10:07.560
Next would be nuclear.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.934
It also has three big problems:

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.934
cost, particularly in highly
regulated countries, is high;

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:19.612
the issue of safety, really feeling good
about nothing could go wrong,

00:10:19.636 --> 00:10:22.640
that, even though you have
these human operators,

00:10:22.664 --> 00:10:25.013
the fuel doesn't get used for weapons.

00:10:25.414 --> 00:10:27.369
And then what do you do with the waste?

00:10:27.393 --> 00:10:30.797
Although it's not very large,
there are a lot of concerns about that.

00:10:30.821 --> 00:10:32.486
People need to feel good about it.

00:10:32.510 --> 00:10:36.934
So three very tough problems
that might be solvable,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.541
and so, should be worked on.

00:10:39.147 --> 00:10:41.838
The last three of the five,
I've grouped together.

00:10:41.862 --> 00:10:45.277
These are what people often refer to
as the renewable sources.

00:10:45.799 --> 00:10:49.822
And they actually -- although it's great
they don't require fuel --

00:10:49.846 --> 00:10:51.822
they have some disadvantages.

00:10:52.275 --> 00:10:58.117
One is that the density of energy
gathered in these technologies

00:10:58.141 --> 00:11:00.204
is dramatically less than a power plant.

00:11:00.228 --> 00:11:01.910
This is energy farming,

00:11:01.934 --> 00:11:06.055
so you're talking about many square miles,
thousands of times more area

00:11:06.079 --> 00:11:08.583
than you think of
as a normal energy plant.

00:11:09.456 --> 00:11:12.044
Also, these are intermittent sources.

00:11:12.068 --> 00:11:15.483
The sun doesn't shine all day,
it doesn't shine every day,

00:11:15.507 --> 00:11:17.934
and likewise, the wind
doesn't blow all the time.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.347
And so, if you depend on these sources,

00:11:20.371 --> 00:11:22.721
you have to have some way
of getting the energy

00:11:22.745 --> 00:11:25.720
during those time periods
that it's not available.

00:11:26.116 --> 00:11:28.741
So we've got big cost challenges here.

00:11:29.196 --> 00:11:31.094
We have transmission challenges;

00:11:31.118 --> 00:11:34.682
for example, say this energy source
is outside your country,

00:11:34.706 --> 00:11:36.799
you not only need the technology,

00:11:36.823 --> 00:11:41.196
but you have to deal with the risk
of the energy coming from elsewhere.

00:11:41.220 --> 00:11:43.129
And, finally, this storage problem.

00:11:43.758 --> 00:11:45.259
To dimensionalize this,

00:11:45.283 --> 00:11:48.836
I went through and looked
at all the types of batteries made --

00:11:48.860 --> 00:11:53.372
for cars, for computers, for phones,
for flashlights, for everything --

00:11:53.396 --> 00:11:57.890
and compared that to the amount
of electrical energy the world uses.

00:11:58.342 --> 00:12:01.935
What I found is that all
the batteries we make now

00:12:01.959 --> 00:12:05.186
could store less than 10 minutes
of all the energy.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:09.326
And so, in fact, we need
a big breakthrough here,

00:12:09.350 --> 00:12:13.218
something that's going to be
a factor of 100 better

00:12:13.242 --> 00:12:15.075
than the approaches we have now.

00:12:15.099 --> 00:12:18.864
It's not impossible,
but it's not a very easy thing.

00:12:19.292 --> 00:12:22.934
Now, this shows up when you try
to get the intermittent source

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:27.110
to be above, say, 20 to 30 percent
of what you're using.

00:12:27.134 --> 00:12:29.728
If you're counting on it for 100 percent,

00:12:29.752 --> 00:12:33.411
you need an incredible miracle battery.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:38.575
Now, how are we going to go forward
on this -- what's the right approach?

00:12:38.599 --> 00:12:42.178
Is it a Manhattan Project?
What's the thing that can get us there?

00:12:42.202 --> 00:12:47.013
Well, we need lots of companies
working on this -- hundreds.

00:12:47.037 --> 00:12:50.616
In each of these five paths,
we need at least a hundred people.

00:12:50.640 --> 00:12:53.350
A lot of them, you'll look at
and say, "They're crazy."

00:12:53.374 --> 00:12:54.555
That's good.

00:12:54.579 --> 00:12:57.509
And, I think, here in the TED group,

00:12:57.533 --> 00:13:00.744
we have many people
who are already pursuing this.

00:13:01.514 --> 00:13:04.934
Bill Gross has several companies,
including one called eSolar

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.740
that has some great
solar thermal technologies.

00:13:07.764 --> 00:13:11.214
Vinod Khosla is investing
in dozens of companies

00:13:11.238 --> 00:13:15.165
that are doing great things
and have interesting possibilities,

00:13:15.189 --> 00:13:17.338
and I'm trying to help back that.

00:13:17.362 --> 00:13:20.934
Nathan Myhrvold and I
actually are backing a company

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.730
that, perhaps surprisingly,
is actually taking the nuclear approach.

00:13:24.754 --> 00:13:28.692
There are some innovations
in nuclear: modular, liquid.

00:13:29.356 --> 00:13:33.129
Innovation really stopped
in this industry quite some ago,

00:13:33.153 --> 00:13:36.248
so the idea that there's some
good ideas laying around

00:13:36.272 --> 00:13:37.997
is not all that surprising.

00:13:38.487 --> 00:13:44.277
The idea of TerraPower is that,
instead of burning a part of uranium --

00:13:44.301 --> 00:13:47.420
the one percent, which is the U235 --

00:13:47.444 --> 00:13:51.160
we decided, "Let's burn
the 99 percent, the U238."

00:13:51.696 --> 00:13:54.049
It is kind of a crazy idea.

00:13:54.073 --> 00:13:57.216
In fact, people had talked
about it for a long time,

00:13:57.240 --> 00:14:01.401
but they could never simulate properly
whether it would work or not,

00:14:01.425 --> 00:14:04.290
and so it's through the advent
of modern supercomputers

00:14:04.314 --> 00:14:06.445
that now you can simulate
and see that, yes,

00:14:06.469 --> 00:14:11.677
with the right materials approach,
this looks like it would work.

00:14:12.151 --> 00:14:14.934
And because you're burning
that 99 percent,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:19.341
you have greatly improved cost profile.

00:14:19.365 --> 00:14:23.575
You actually burn up the waste,
and you can actually use as fuel

00:14:23.599 --> 00:14:26.624
all the leftover waste
from today's reactors.

00:14:26.648 --> 00:14:30.439
So instead of worrying about them,
you just take that, it's a great thing.

00:14:30.786 --> 00:14:35.281
It breeds this uranium as it goes along,
so it's kind of like a candle.

00:14:35.305 --> 00:14:39.037
You see it's a log there, often
referred to as a traveling wave reactor.

00:14:39.458 --> 00:14:43.377
In terms of fuel,
this really solves the problem.

00:14:43.401 --> 00:14:46.302
I've got a picture here
of a place in Kentucky.

00:14:46.326 --> 00:14:48.526
This is the leftover, the 99 percent,

00:14:48.550 --> 00:14:50.780
where they've taken out
the part they burn now,

00:14:50.804 --> 00:14:52.374
so it's called depleted uranium.

00:14:52.398 --> 00:14:55.245
That would power the US
for hundreds of years.

00:14:55.269 --> 00:14:58.804
And simply by filtering seawater
in an inexpensive process,

00:14:58.828 --> 00:15:02.637
you'd have enough fuel for the entire
lifetime of the rest of the planet.

00:15:03.012 --> 00:15:07.073
So, you know, it's got lots
of challenges ahead,

00:15:07.097 --> 00:15:12.492
but it is an example of the many
hundreds and hundreds of ideas

00:15:12.516 --> 00:15:14.375
that we need to move forward.

00:15:15.365 --> 00:15:18.063
So let's think: How should
we measure ourselves?

00:15:18.087 --> 00:15:20.934
What should our report card look like?

00:15:21.314 --> 00:15:23.838
Well, let's go out to where
we really need to get,

00:15:23.862 --> 00:15:26.005
and then look at the intermediate.

00:15:26.029 --> 00:15:31.051
For 2050, you've heard many people
talk about this 80 percent reduction.

00:15:31.800 --> 00:15:34.852
That really is very important,
that we get there.

00:15:34.876 --> 00:15:39.297
And that 20 percent will be used up
by things going on in poor countries --

00:15:39.321 --> 00:15:44.715
still some agriculture; hopefully,
we will have cleaned up forestry, cement.

00:15:44.739 --> 00:15:47.728
So, to get to that 80 percent,

00:15:47.752 --> 00:15:52.257
the developed countries,
including countries like China,

00:15:52.281 --> 00:15:56.680
will have had to switch
their electricity generation altogether.

00:15:57.083 --> 00:16:02.934
The other grade is: Are we deploying
this zero-emission technology,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.355
have we deployed it
in all the developed countries

00:16:05.379 --> 00:16:08.166
and are in the process
of getting it elsewhere?

00:16:08.190 --> 00:16:09.934
That's super important.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.297
That's a key element
of making that report card.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:18.263
Backing up from there, what should
the 2020 report card look like?

00:16:18.713 --> 00:16:21.031
Well, again, it should have
the two elements.

00:16:21.055 --> 00:16:25.194
We should go through these efficiency
measures to start getting reductions:

00:16:25.218 --> 00:16:28.482
The less we emit,
the less that sum will be of CO2,

00:16:28.506 --> 00:16:30.578
and therefore, the less the temperature.

00:16:30.602 --> 00:16:33.531
But in some ways, the grade we get there,

00:16:33.555 --> 00:16:37.799
doing things that don't get us
all the way to the big reductions,

00:16:37.823 --> 00:16:41.667
is only equally, or maybe even slightly
less, important than the other,

00:16:41.691 --> 00:16:45.447
which is the piece of innovation
on these breakthroughs.

00:16:45.471 --> 00:16:48.709
These breakthroughs,
we need to move those at full speed,

00:16:48.733 --> 00:16:51.158
and we can measure that
in terms of companies,

00:16:51.182 --> 00:16:54.076
pilot projects, regulatory things
that have been changed.

00:16:54.556 --> 00:16:57.530
There's a lot of great books
that have been written about this.

00:16:57.554 --> 00:16:59.934
The Al Gore book, "Our Choice,"

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:03.538
and the David MacKay book,
"Sustainable Energy Without the Hot Air."

00:17:03.562 --> 00:17:06.738
They really go through it
and create a framework

00:17:06.762 --> 00:17:08.595
that this can be discussed broadly,

00:17:08.619 --> 00:17:10.576
because we need broad backing for this.

00:17:10.944 --> 00:17:13.171
There's a lot that has to come together.

00:17:13.195 --> 00:17:14.677
So this is a wish.

00:17:14.701 --> 00:17:18.878
It's a very concrete wish
that we invent this technology.

00:17:19.330 --> 00:17:22.419
If you gave me only one wish
for the next 50 years --

00:17:22.443 --> 00:17:24.420
I could pick who's president,

00:17:24.444 --> 00:17:27.206
I could pick a vaccine,
which is something I love,

00:17:27.230 --> 00:17:29.287
or I could pick that this thing

00:17:29.311 --> 00:17:32.772
that's half the cost with no CO2
gets invented --

00:17:32.796 --> 00:17:34.703
this is the wish I would pick.

00:17:34.727 --> 00:17:36.812
This is the one with the greatest impact.

00:17:36.836 --> 00:17:38.481
If we don't get this wish,

00:17:38.505 --> 00:17:41.943
the division between the people
who think short term and long term

00:17:41.967 --> 00:17:43.125
will be terrible,

00:17:43.149 --> 00:17:46.093
between the US and China,
between poor countries and rich,

00:17:46.117 --> 00:17:47.311
and most of all,

00:17:47.335 --> 00:17:50.399
the lives of those two billion
will be far worse.

00:17:51.116 --> 00:17:52.934
So what do we have to do?

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:57.782
What am I appealing to you
to step forward and drive?

00:17:58.147 --> 00:18:00.728
We need to go for more research funding.

00:18:01.148 --> 00:18:03.773
When countries get together
in places like Copenhagen,

00:18:03.797 --> 00:18:06.216
they shouldn't just discuss the CO2.

00:18:06.240 --> 00:18:08.607
They should discuss
this innovation agenda.

00:18:08.631 --> 00:18:12.934
You'd be stunned at the ridiculously
low levels of spending

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.673
on these innovative approaches.

00:18:15.141 --> 00:18:18.934
We do need the market incentives --
CO2 tax, cap and trade --

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.482
something that gets
that price signal out there.

00:18:21.839 --> 00:18:23.437
We need to get the message out.

00:18:23.461 --> 00:18:25.865
We need to have this dialogue
be a more rational,

00:18:25.889 --> 00:18:27.479
more understandable dialogue,

00:18:27.503 --> 00:18:30.034
including the steps
that the government takes.

00:18:30.058 --> 00:18:33.708
This is an important wish,
but it is one I think we can achieve.

00:18:34.374 --> 00:18:35.527
Thank you.

00:18:35.551 --> 00:18:42.551
(Applause)

00:18:44.933 --> 00:18:46.934
(Applause ends)

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:48.174
Thank you.

00:18:49.261 --> 00:18:51.106
Chris Anderson: Thank you. Thank you.

00:18:51.130 --> 00:18:56.191
(Applause)

00:18:56.215 --> 00:18:57.713
CA: Thank you.

00:18:57.737 --> 00:19:01.799
So to understand more about TerraPower.

00:19:02.357 --> 00:19:06.351
I mean, first of all, can you give a sense
of what scale of investment this is?

00:19:06.856 --> 00:19:11.190
Bill Gates: To actually do the software,
buy the supercomputer,

00:19:11.214 --> 00:19:13.543
hire all the great scientists,
which we've done,

00:19:13.567 --> 00:19:15.824
that's only tens of millions.

00:19:15.848 --> 00:19:19.796
And even once we test our materials out
in a Russian reactor

00:19:19.820 --> 00:19:22.995
to make sure our materials work properly,

00:19:23.019 --> 00:19:25.536
then you'll only be up
in the hundreds of millions.

00:19:25.560 --> 00:19:27.918
The tough thing
is building the pilot reactor --

00:19:27.942 --> 00:19:32.746
finding the several billion,
finding the regulator, the location

00:19:32.770 --> 00:19:35.029
that will actually build
the first one of these.

00:19:35.053 --> 00:19:39.215
Once you get the first one built,
if it works as advertised,

00:19:39.239 --> 00:19:40.589
then it's just clear as day,

00:19:40.613 --> 00:19:43.809
because the economics,
the energy density, are so different

00:19:43.833 --> 00:19:45.247
than nuclear as we know it.

00:19:45.271 --> 00:19:46.733
CA: So to understand it right,

00:19:46.757 --> 00:19:49.039
this involves building
deep into the ground,

00:19:49.063 --> 00:19:54.623
almost like a vertical column
of nuclear fuel, of this spent uranium,

00:19:54.647 --> 00:19:57.787
and then the process starts
at the top and kind of works down?

00:19:57.811 --> 00:19:58.988
BG: That's right.

00:19:59.012 --> 00:20:01.071
Today, you're always
refueling the reactor,

00:20:01.095 --> 00:20:04.287
so you have lots of people and lots
of controls that can go wrong,

00:20:04.311 --> 00:20:07.050
where you're opening it up
and moving things in and out --

00:20:07.074 --> 00:20:09.231
that's not good.

00:20:09.255 --> 00:20:10.428
So if you have very --

00:20:10.452 --> 00:20:11.541
(Laughter)

00:20:11.565 --> 00:20:14.312
very cheap fuel
that you can put 60 years in --

00:20:14.336 --> 00:20:15.890
just think of it as a log --

00:20:15.914 --> 00:20:19.452
put it down and not have
those same complexities.

00:20:19.476 --> 00:20:24.381
And it just sits there and burns
for the 60 years, and then it's done.

00:20:24.405 --> 00:20:28.343
CA: It's a nuclear power plant
that is its own waste disposal solution.

00:20:28.367 --> 00:20:30.261
BG: Yeah; what happens with the waste,

00:20:30.285 --> 00:20:35.665
you can let it sit there -- there's a lot
less waste under this approach --

00:20:35.689 --> 00:20:37.325
then you can actually take that

00:20:37.349 --> 00:20:39.934
and put it into another one and burn that.

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:44.164
And we start out, actually,
by taking the waste that exists today

00:20:44.188 --> 00:20:48.420
that's sitting in these cooling pools
or dry-casking by reactors --

00:20:48.444 --> 00:20:50.596
that's our fuel to begin with.

00:20:50.620 --> 00:20:53.227
So the thing that's been a problem
from those reactors

00:20:53.251 --> 00:20:55.178
is actually what gets fed into ours,

00:20:55.202 --> 00:20:58.189
and you're reducing the volume
of the waste quite dramatically

00:20:58.213 --> 00:21:00.190
as you're going through this process.

00:21:00.214 --> 00:21:02.789
CA: You're talking
to different people around the world

00:21:02.813 --> 00:21:04.102
about the possibilities.

00:21:04.126 --> 00:21:07.534
Where is there most interest
in actually doing something with this?

00:21:07.558 --> 00:21:11.713
BG: Well, we haven't picked
a particular place,

00:21:11.737 --> 00:21:15.197
and there's all these interesting
disclosure rules

00:21:15.221 --> 00:21:17.697
about anything that's called "nuclear."

00:21:17.721 --> 00:21:20.650
So we've got a lot of interest.

00:21:20.674 --> 00:21:23.749
People from the company
have been in Russia, India, China.

00:21:23.773 --> 00:21:26.387
I've been back seeing
the secretary of energy here,

00:21:26.411 --> 00:21:29.743
talking about how this fits
into the energy agenda.

00:21:29.767 --> 00:21:31.343
So I'm optimistic.

00:21:31.367 --> 00:21:33.544
The French and Japanese
have done some work.

00:21:33.568 --> 00:21:37.228
This is a variant on something
that has been done.

00:21:37.252 --> 00:21:40.934
It's an important advance,
but it's like a fast reactor,

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:42.934
and a lot of countries have built them,

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:45.532
so anybody who's done
a fast reactor is a candidate

00:21:45.556 --> 00:21:47.934
to be where the first one gets built.

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:51.400
CA: So, in your mind,

00:21:51.424 --> 00:21:56.182
timescale and likelihood of actually
taking something like this live?

00:21:56.206 --> 00:22:02.293
BG: Well, we need -- for one of these
high-scale, electro-generation things

00:22:02.317 --> 00:22:03.475
that's very cheap,

00:22:03.499 --> 00:22:07.177
we have 20 years to invent
and then 20 years to deploy.

00:22:07.201 --> 00:22:08.957
That's sort of the deadline

00:22:08.981 --> 00:22:14.239
that the environmental models
have shown us that we have to meet.

00:22:14.263 --> 00:22:19.675
And TerraPower -- if things go well,
which is wishing for a lot --

00:22:19.699 --> 00:22:21.342
could easily meet that.

00:22:21.366 --> 00:22:24.638
And there are, fortunately
now, dozens of companies --

00:22:24.662 --> 00:22:26.013
we need it to be hundreds --

00:22:26.037 --> 00:22:28.254
who, likewise, if their science goes well,

00:22:28.278 --> 00:22:31.173
if the funding for their pilot
plants goes well,

00:22:31.197 --> 00:22:33.223
that they can compete for this.

00:22:33.247 --> 00:22:35.221
And it's best if multiple succeed,

00:22:35.245 --> 00:22:37.934
because then you could use
a mix of these things.

00:22:37.958 --> 00:22:40.039
We certainly need one to succeed.

00:22:40.063 --> 00:22:43.022
CA: In terms of big-scale
possible game changers,

00:22:43.046 --> 00:22:45.780
is this the biggest
that you're aware of out there?

00:22:45.804 --> 00:22:50.153
BG: An energy breakthrough
is the most important thing.

00:22:50.177 --> 00:22:53.160
It would have been, even
without the environmental constraint,

00:22:53.184 --> 00:22:57.047
but the environmental constraint
just makes it so much greater.

00:22:57.071 --> 00:23:00.395
In the nuclear space,
there are other innovators.

00:23:00.419 --> 00:23:03.409
You know, we don't know their work
as well as we know this one,

00:23:03.433 --> 00:23:06.690
but the modular people,
that's a different approach.

00:23:06.714 --> 00:23:10.319
There's a liquid-type reactor,
which seems a little hard,

00:23:10.343 --> 00:23:12.579
but maybe they say that about us.

00:23:12.603 --> 00:23:14.934
And so, there are different ones,

00:23:14.958 --> 00:23:17.934
but the beauty of this
is a molecule of uranium

00:23:17.958 --> 00:23:22.048
has a million times as much energy
as a molecule of, say, coal.

00:23:22.660 --> 00:23:25.676
And so, if you can
deal with the negatives,

00:23:25.700 --> 00:23:29.552
which are essentially the radiation,
the footprint and cost,

00:23:29.576 --> 00:23:33.567
the potential, in terms of effect
on land and various things,

00:23:33.591 --> 00:23:36.934
is almost in a class of its own.

00:23:37.997 --> 00:23:41.636
CA: If this doesn't work, then what?

00:23:41.660 --> 00:23:44.934
Do we have to start taking
emergency measures

00:23:44.958 --> 00:23:48.056
to try and keep the temperature
of the earth stable?

00:23:48.080 --> 00:23:49.934
BG: If you get into that situation,

00:23:49.958 --> 00:23:54.934
it's like if you've been overeating,
and you're about to have a heart attack.

00:23:54.958 --> 00:23:57.483
Then where do you go?

00:23:57.507 --> 00:23:59.440
You may need heart surgery or something.

00:23:59.464 --> 00:24:03.334
There is a line of research
on what's called geoengineering,

00:24:03.358 --> 00:24:06.335
which are various techniques
that would delay the heating

00:24:06.359 --> 00:24:09.645
to buy us 20 or 30 years
to get our act together.

00:24:09.669 --> 00:24:13.277
Now, that's just an insurance policy;
you hope you don't need to do that.

00:24:13.301 --> 00:24:16.343
Some people say you shouldn't even
work on the insurance policy

00:24:16.367 --> 00:24:17.888
because it might make you lazy,

00:24:17.912 --> 00:24:21.778
that you'll keep eating because you know
heart surgery will be there to save you.

00:24:21.802 --> 00:24:24.919
I'm not sure that's wise,
given the importance of the problem,

00:24:24.943 --> 00:24:28.044
but there's now
the geoengineering discussion

00:24:28.068 --> 00:24:32.275
about: Should that be in the back
pocket in case things happen faster,

00:24:32.299 --> 00:24:35.786
or this innovation goes
a lot slower than we expect?

00:24:37.507 --> 00:24:39.308
CA: Climate skeptics:

00:24:39.332 --> 00:24:42.838
If you had a sentence or two
to say to them,

00:24:42.862 --> 00:24:46.471
how might you persuade them
that they're wrong?

00:24:47.603 --> 00:24:50.654
BG: Well, unfortunately,
the skeptics come in different camps.

00:24:50.678 --> 00:24:55.119
The ones who make scientific
arguments are very few.

00:24:55.143 --> 00:24:58.132
Are they saying there's negative
feedback effects

00:24:58.156 --> 00:25:00.358
that have to do with clouds
that offset things?

00:25:00.382 --> 00:25:03.690
There are very, very few things
that they can even say

00:25:03.714 --> 00:25:06.361
there's a chance
in a million of those things.

00:25:06.385 --> 00:25:09.589
The main problem we have here --
it's kind of like with AIDS:

00:25:09.613 --> 00:25:13.416
you make the mistake now,
and you pay for it a lot later.

00:25:13.440 --> 00:25:16.695
And so, when you have
all sorts of urgent problems,

00:25:16.719 --> 00:25:20.780
the idea of taking pain now
that has to do with a gain later,

00:25:20.804 --> 00:25:23.090
and a somewhat uncertain pain thing.

00:25:23.114 --> 00:25:29.202
In fact, the IPCC report --
that's not necessarily the worst case,

00:25:29.226 --> 00:25:33.301
and there are people in the rich world
who look at IPCC and say,

00:25:33.325 --> 00:25:35.109
"OK, that isn't that big of a deal."

00:25:35.133 --> 00:25:39.282
The fact is it's that uncertain part
that should move us towards this.

00:25:39.306 --> 00:25:40.938
But my dream here is that,

00:25:40.962 --> 00:25:44.622
if you can make it economic,
and meet the CO2 constraints,

00:25:44.646 --> 00:25:45.805
then the skeptics say,

00:25:45.829 --> 00:25:48.109
"OK, I don't care
that it doesn't put out CO2,

00:25:48.133 --> 00:25:49.813
I kind of wish it did put out CO2.

00:25:49.837 --> 00:25:51.193
But I guess I'll accept it,

00:25:51.217 --> 00:25:53.934
because it's cheaper
than what's come before."

00:25:53.958 --> 00:25:58.789
(Applause)

00:25:58.813 --> 00:26:01.993
CA: So that would be your response
to the Bjørn Lomborg argument,

00:26:02.017 --> 00:26:06.473
basically if you spend all this energy
trying to solve the CO2 problem,

00:26:06.497 --> 00:26:08.591
it's going to take away
all your other goals

00:26:08.615 --> 00:26:11.608
of trying to rid the world
of poverty and malaria and so forth,

00:26:11.632 --> 00:26:13.865
it's a stupid waste
of the Earth's resources

00:26:13.889 --> 00:26:15.162
to put money towards that

00:26:15.186 --> 00:26:17.104
when there are better things we can do.

00:26:17.128 --> 00:26:20.519
BG: Well, the actual
spending on the R&D piece --

00:26:20.543 --> 00:26:24.039
say the US should spend 10 billion a year
more than it is right now --

00:26:24.063 --> 00:26:25.934
it's not that dramatic.

00:26:25.958 --> 00:26:27.934
It shouldn't take away from other things.

00:26:27.958 --> 00:26:31.378
The thing you get into big money on,
and reasonable people can disagree,

00:26:31.402 --> 00:26:33.568
is when you have something
that's non-economic

00:26:33.592 --> 00:26:35.211
and you're trying to fund that --

00:26:35.235 --> 00:26:37.163
that, to me, mostly is a waste.

00:26:37.187 --> 00:26:38.734
Unless you're very close,

00:26:38.758 --> 00:26:42.402
and you're just funding the learning curve
and it's going to get very cheap,

00:26:42.426 --> 00:26:45.224
I believe we should try more things

00:26:45.248 --> 00:26:47.934
that have a potential
to be far less expensive.

00:26:47.958 --> 00:26:53.150
If the trade-off you get into is,
"Let's make energy super expensive,"

00:26:53.174 --> 00:26:55.196
then the rich can afford that.

00:26:55.220 --> 00:26:58.349
I mean, all of us here could pay
five times as much for our energy

00:26:58.373 --> 00:26:59.764
and not change our lifestyle.

00:26:59.788 --> 00:27:02.052
The disaster is for that two billion.

00:27:02.076 --> 00:27:04.383
And even Lomborg has changed.

00:27:04.407 --> 00:27:08.934
His shtick now is, "Why isn't the R&D
getting more discussed?"

00:27:08.958 --> 00:27:11.471
He's still, because of his earlier stuff,

00:27:11.495 --> 00:27:13.395
still associated with the skeptic camp,

00:27:13.419 --> 00:27:16.192
but he's realized
that's a pretty lonely camp,

00:27:16.216 --> 00:27:19.474
and so, he's making the R&D point.

00:27:19.498 --> 00:27:23.934
And so there is a thread of something
that I think is appropriate.

00:27:23.958 --> 00:27:26.934
The R&D piece --
it's crazy how little it's funded.

00:27:27.514 --> 00:27:30.801
CA: Well, Bill, I suspect I speak
on behalf of most people here

00:27:30.825 --> 00:27:32.893
to say I really hope your wish comes true.

00:27:32.917 --> 00:27:34.089
Thank you so much.

00:27:34.113 --> 00:27:35.264
BG: Thank you.

00:27:35.288 --> 00:27:40.680
(Applause)

title: Technology's epic story
transcript: I want to talk about my investigations into what technology means in our lives — not just our immediate life, but in the cosmic sense, in the kind of long history of the world and our place in the world. What is this stuff? What is the significance? And so, I want to kind of go through my little story of what I found out.One of the first things I started to investigate was the history of the name of technology. In the United States, there is a State of the Union address given by every president since 1790. And each one of those is kind of summing up the most important things for the United States at that time. If you search for the word "technology," it was not used until 1952. So, technology was sort of absent from everybody's thinking until 1952, which happened to be the year of my birth. And obviously, technology had existed before then, but we weren't aware of it. And so it was sort of an awakening of this force in our life.I actually did research to find out the first use of the word "technology." It was in 1829, and it was invented by a guy who was starting a curriculum — a course, bringing together all the kinds of arts and crafts, and industry — and he called it "Technology." And that's the very first use of the word.So what is this stuff that we're all consumed by and bothered by? Alan Kay calls it, "Technology is anything that was invented after you were born."(Laughter)Which is sort of the idea we normally have about what technology is: it's all that new stuff. It's not roads, or penicillin, or factory tires; it's the new stuff. My friend Danny Hillis says kind of a similar one, he says, "Technology is anything that doesn't work yet."(Laughter)Which is, again, a sense that it's all new.But we know that it's just not new. It actually goes way back, and what I want to suggest is, it goes a long way back. So, another way to think about technology, what it means, is to imagine a world without technology. If we were to eliminate every single bit of technology in the world today — and I mean everything, from blades to scrapers to cloth — we, as a species, would not live very long. We would die by the billions, and very quickly: the wolves would get us, we would be defenseless, we would be unable to grow enough food or find enough food.Even the hunter-gatherers used some elementary tools. So, they had minimal technology, but they had some technology. And if we study those hunter-gatherer tribes and the Neanderthal, which are very similar to early man, we find out a very curious thing about this world without technology, and this is a kind of a curve of their average age.There are no Neanderthal fossils that are older than 40 years old that we've ever found, and the average age of most of these hunter-gatherer tribes is 20 to 30. There are very few young infants, because they die — high mortality rate — and there's very few old people. So the profile is sort of for your average San Francisco neighborhood: a lot of young people. And if you go there, you say, "Hey, everybody's really healthy." Well, that's because they're all young.Same thing with the hunter-gatherer tribes and early man: you didn't live beyond the age of 30. So it was a world without grandparents. And grandparents are very important, because they are the transmitter of cultural evolution and information. Imagine a world where basically everybody was 20 to 30 years old. How much learning can you do? You can't do very much learning in your own life, it's so short, and there's nobody to pass on what you do learn. So that's one aspect.It was a very short life. But at the same time, anthropologists know that most hunter-gatherer tribes of the world, with that very little technology, actually did not spend a very long time gathering the food they needed: three to six hours a day. Some anthropologists call that the original affluent society, because they had bankers' hours, basically. So it was possible to get enough food. But when the scarcity came, when the highs and lows and the droughts came, then people went into starvation. And that's why they didn't live very long.So what technology brought, through the very simple tools like these stone tools here — even something as small as this — the early bands of humans were actually able to eliminate to extinction about 250 megafauna animals in North America when they first arrived 10,000 years ago. So, long before the industrial age, we've been affecting the planet on a global scale with just a small amount of technology.The other thing that the early man invented was fire. And fire was used to clear out, and again, affected the ecology of grass and whole continents, and was used in cooking. It enabled us to actually eat all kinds of things. It was, in a certain sense, in a McLuhan sense, an external stomach, in the sense that it was cooking food that we could not eat otherwise. And if we didn't have fire, we actually could not live. Our bodies have adapted to these new diets. Our bodies have changed in the last 10,000 years.So, with that little bit of technology, humans went from a small band of 10,000 or so — the same number as Neanderthals everywhere — and we suddenly exploded. With the invention of language around 50,000 years ago, the number of humans exploded, and very quickly became the dominant species on the planet. And they migrated into the rest of the world at two kilometers per year until, within several tens of thousands of years, we occupied every single watershed on the planet and became the most dominant species, with a very small amount of technology.And even at that time, with the introduction of agriculture, 8,000, 10,000 years ago, we started to see climate change. So climate change is not a new thing; what's new is just the degree of it. Even during the agricultural age, there was climate change. So already, small amounts of technology were transforming the world. And what this means, and where I'm going, is that technology has become the most powerful force in the world. All the things we see today that are changing our lives, we can always trace back to the introduction of some new technology.So it's a force, that is the most powerful force that has been unleashed on this planet, and in such a degree, that I think it's become who we are. In fact, our humanity and everything that we think about ourselves, is something we've invented. So we've invented ourselves. Of all the animals that we've domesticated, the most important animal has been us.So humanity is our greatest invention, but of course, we're not done yet. We're still inventing, and this is what technology is allowing us to do; it's continually to reinvent ourselves. It's a very, very strong force. I call this entire thing — us humans as our technology, everything that we've made, gadgets in our lives — we call that the technium. That's this world. My working definition of technology is: anything useful that a human mind makes. It's not just hammers and gadgets, like laptops. But it's also law. And, of course, cities are ways to make things more useful to us. While this is something that comes from our mind, it also has its roots deeply into the cosmos.It goes back. The origins and roots of technology go back to the Big Bang, in this way, in that they are part of this self-organizing thread that starts at the Big Bang and goes through galaxies and stars, into life, into us. And the three major phases of the early universe was energy, when the dominant force was energy; then the dominant force, as it cooled, became matter; and then, with the invention of life four billion years ago, the dominant force in our neighborhood became information. That's what life is: an information process that was restructuring and making new order.So, energy and matter, Einstein showed were equivalent, and now new sciences of quantum computing show that entropy and information and matter and energy are all interrelated. So it's one long continuum. You put energy into the right kind of system, and out comes wasted heat, entropy, and extropy, which is order. It's the increased order.Where does this order come from? Its roots go way back. We actually don't know. But we do know that the self-organization trend throughout the universe is long, and it began with things like galaxies; they maintained their order for billions of years. Stars are basically nuclear fission machines that self-organize and self-sustain themselves for billions of years: order against the extropy of the world. And flowers and plants are the same thing, extended, and technology is basically an extension of life.One trend that we notice in all those things is that the amount of energy per gram per second that flows through this is actually increasing. The amount of energy is increasing through this little sequence. And the amount of energy per gram per second that flows through life is actually greater than a star — because of the star's long lifespan, the energy density in life is actually higher than a star. And the energy density that we see in the greatest amount anywhere in the universe is actually in a PC chip. There is more energy flowing through, per gram per second, than anything that we have any other experience with.And so, what I would suggest is that if you want to see where technology is going, we continue that trajectory, and we say, "Well, it's going to become more energy-dense, that's where it's going." And so what I've done is, I've taken the same kinds of things and looked at other aspects of evolutionary life and say, "What are the general trends in evolutionary life?" And there are things moving towards greater complexity, moving towards greater diversity, moving towards greater specialization, sentience, ubiquity, and most important, evolvability. Those very same things are also present in technology. That's where technology is going.In fact, technology is accelerating all the aspects of life. And we can see that happening; just as there's diversity in life, there's more diversity in things we make. Things in life start off being general cells, and they become specialized: you have tissue cells, muscle, brain cells. The same thing happens with, say, a hammer, which is general at first and becomes more specific. So I would like to say that while there are six kingdoms of life, we can think of technology basically as a seventh kingdom of life. It's a branching off from the human form.But technology has its own agenda, like anything, like life itself. For instance, right now, three-quarters of the energy that we use is actually used to feed the technium itself. In transportation, it's not to move us; it's to move the stuff we make or buy. I use the word "want." Technology wants. This is a robot that wants to plug itself in to get more power. Your cat wants more food. A bacterium, which has no consciousness at all, wants to move towards light. It has an urge, and technology has an urge.At the same time, it wants to give us things, and what it gives us is basically progress. You can take all kinds of curves, and they're all pointing up. There's really no dispute about progress, if we discount the cost of that. And that's the thing that bothers most people, is that progress is really real, but we wonder and question: What are the environmental costs of it?I did a survey of the number of species of artifacts in my house, and there's 6,000. Other people have come up with 10,000. When King Henry of England died, he had 18,000 things in his house, but that was the entire wealth of England, so ...(Laughter)And with that entire wealth of England, King Henry could not buy any antibiotics, he could not buy refrigeration, he could not buy a trip of a thousand miles, whereas this rickshaw wallah in India could save up and buy antibiotics and he could buy refrigeration. He could buy things that King Henry, in all his wealth, could never buy. That's what progress is about.So, technology is selfish; technology is generous. That conflict, that tension, will be with us forever: sometimes it wants to do what it wants to do, and sometimes it's going to do things for us. We have confusion about what we should think about a new technology. Right now the default position when a new technology comes along, is people talk about the precautionary principle, which is very common in Europe, which says, basically, "Don't do anything. When you meet a new technology, stop, until it can be proven that it does no harm." I think that really leads nowhere.But a better way is what I call the proactionary principle, which is, you engage with technology. You try it out. You obviously do what the precautionary principle suggests, you try to anticipate it, but after anticipating it, you constantly asses it, not just once, but eternally. And when it diverts from what you want, we prioritize risk, we evaluate not just the new stuff, but the old stuff. We fix it; but most importantly, we relocate it. And what I mean by that is, we find a new job for it.Nuclear energy, fission, is a really bad idea for bombs. But it may be a pretty good idea relocated into sustainable nuclear energy for electricity, instead of burning coal. When we have a bad idea, the response to a bad idea is not no ideas, it's not to stop thinking. The response to a bad idea — like, say, a tungsten lightbulb — is a better idea. So, better ideas is really always the response to technology we don't like; it's basically better technology. And actually, in a certain sense, technology is a kind of a method for generating better ideas, if you can think about it that way.So, maybe spraying DDT on crops is a really bad idea. But DDT sprayed on local homes — there's nothing better to eliminate malaria, besides insect DDT-impregnated mosquito nets. But that's a really good idea; that's a good job for technology.So our job as humans is to parent our mind children, to find them good friends, to find them a good job. And so, every technology is sort of a creative force looking for the right job. That's actually my son, right here.(Laughter)There are no bad technologies, just as there are no bad children. We don't say children are neutral; children are positive. We just have to find them the right place.And so, what technology gives us over the long term — over this sort of extended evolution from the beginning of time, through the invention of the plants and animals, and the evolution of life, the evolution of brains — what that is constantly giving us is increasing differences: It's increasing diversity, it's increasing options, it's increasing choices, opportunities, possibilities and freedoms. That's what we get from technology all the time. That's why people leave villages and go into cities — because they are always gravitating towards increased choices and possibilities. And we are aware of the price; we pay a price for that, but we're aware of it, and generally, we will pay the price for increased freedoms, choices and opportunities.Even technology wants clean water. Is technology diametrically opposed to nature? Because technology is an extension of life, it's in parallel and aligned with the same things that life wants. So that I think technology loves biology, if we allow it to. Great movement starting billions of years ago is moving through us and it continues to go, and our choice, so to speak, in technology, is really to align ourselves with this force much greater than ourselves.So, technology is more than just the stuff in your pocket; it's more than just gadgets, it's more than just things that people invent. It's actually part of a very long story — a great story — that began billions of years ago. It's moving through us, this self-organization, and we're extending and accelerating it, and we can be part of it by aligning the technology that we make with it. And I really appreciate your attention today.Thank you.(Applause)
