a course, bringing together all the kinds
of arts and crafts, and industry --

00:01:29.983 --> 00:01:31.944
and he called it "Technology."

00:01:31.968 --> 00:01:34.451
And that's the very first use of the word.

00:01:34.475 --> 00:01:36.641
So what is this stuff

00:01:36.665 --> 00:01:40.465
that we're all consumed by
and bothered by?

00:01:41.976 --> 00:01:44.898
Alan Kay calls it, "Technology
is anything that was invented

00:01:44.922 --> 00:01:46.151
after you were born."

00:01:46.175 --> 00:01:47.183
(Laughter)

00:01:47.207 --> 00:01:51.642
Which is sort of the idea we normally
have about what technology is:

00:01:51.666 --> 00:01:53.309
it's all that new stuff.

00:01:53.333 --> 00:01:55.536
It's not roads, or penicillin,

00:01:55.560 --> 00:01:59.323
or factory tires; it's the new stuff.

00:01:59.347 --> 00:02:01.870
My friend Danny Hillis
says kind of a similar one,

00:02:01.894 --> 00:02:04.573
he says, "Technology is anything
that doesn't work yet."

00:02:04.597 --> 00:02:05.612
(Laughter)

00:02:05.636 --> 00:02:07.676
Which is, again,
a sense that it's all new.

00:02:07.700 --> 00:02:09.408
But we know that it's just not new.

00:02:09.432 --> 00:02:10.718
It actually goes way back,

00:02:10.742 --> 00:02:14.843
and what I want to suggest is,
it goes a long way back.

00:02:14.867 --> 00:02:17.635
So, another way to think
about technology, what it means,

00:02:17.659 --> 00:02:19.683
is to imagine a world without technology.

00:02:19.707 --> 00:02:23.368
If we were to eliminate every single bit
of technology in the world today --

00:02:23.392 --> 00:02:28.309
and I mean everything,
from blades to scrapers to cloth --

00:02:28.333 --> 00:02:31.068
we, as a species,
would not live very long.

00:02:31.092 --> 00:02:34.069
We would die by the billions,
and very quickly:

00:02:34.093 --> 00:02:37.398
the wolves would get us,
we would be defenseless,

00:02:37.422 --> 00:02:40.615
we would be unable to grow
enough food or find enough food.

00:02:40.639 --> 00:02:44.075
Even the hunter-gatherers
used some elementary tools.

00:02:44.099 --> 00:02:46.431
So, they had minimal technology,

00:02:46.455 --> 00:02:48.137
but they had some technology.

00:02:48.161 --> 00:02:51.294
And if we study
those hunter-gatherer tribes

00:02:51.318 --> 00:02:54.970
and the Neanderthal,
which are very similar to early man,

00:02:54.994 --> 00:02:58.281
we find out a very curious thing
about this world without technology,

00:02:58.305 --> 00:03:01.134
and this is a kind of a curve
of their average age.

00:03:01.158 --> 00:03:05.613
There are no Neanderthal fossils
that are older than 40 years old

00:03:05.637 --> 00:03:07.248
that we've ever found,

00:03:07.272 --> 00:03:11.502
and the average age of most of these
hunter-gatherer tribes is 20 to 30.

00:03:11.526 --> 00:03:16.427
There are very few young infants,
because they die -- high mortality rate --

00:03:16.451 --> 00:03:17.999
and there's very few old people.

00:03:18.023 --> 00:03:21.603
So the profile is sort of for your average
San Francisco neighborhood:

00:03:21.627 --> 00:03:23.032
a lot of young people.

00:03:23.056 --> 00:03:26.120
And if you go there, you say,
"Hey, everybody's really healthy."

00:03:26.144 --> 00:03:28.048
Well, that's because they're all young.

00:03:28.072 --> 00:03:30.803
Same thing with the hunter-gatherer
tribes and early man:

00:03:30.827 --> 00:03:32.622
you didn't live beyond the age of 30.

00:03:32.646 --> 00:03:34.623
So it was a world without grandparents.

00:03:34.647 --> 00:03:36.680
And grandparents are very important,

00:03:36.704 --> 00:03:40.343
because they are the transmitter
of cultural evolution and information.

00:03:40.367 --> 00:03:43.503
Imagine a world where basically
everybody was 20 to 30 years old.

00:03:43.527 --> 00:03:45.171
How much learning can you do?

00:03:45.195 --> 00:03:47.530
You can't do very much
learning in your own life,

00:03:47.554 --> 00:03:48.852
it's so short,

00:03:48.876 --> 00:03:51.230
and there's nobody to pass on
what you do learn.

00:03:51.254 --> 00:03:54.201
So that's one aspect.

00:03:54.225 --> 00:03:55.541
It was a very short life.

00:03:55.565 --> 00:03:58.357
But at the same time, anthropologists know

00:03:58.381 --> 00:04:00.961
that most hunter-gatherer
tribes of the world,

00:04:00.985 --> 00:04:02.647
with that very little technology,

00:04:02.671 --> 00:04:06.157
actually did not spend a very long time
gathering the food they needed:

00:04:06.181 --> 00:04:07.764
three to six hours a day.

00:04:07.788 --> 00:04:11.809
Some anthropologists call that
the original affluent society,

00:04:11.833 --> 00:04:14.199
because they had
bankers' hours, basically.

00:04:14.223 --> 00:04:16.857
So it was possible to get enough food.

00:04:16.881 --> 00:04:19.382
But when the scarcity came,

00:04:19.406 --> 00:04:21.689
when the highs and lows
and the droughts came,

00:04:21.713 --> 00:04:24.246
then people went into starvation.

00:04:24.270 --> 00:04:26.318
And that's why they didn't live very long.

00:04:26.342 --> 00:04:28.757
So what technology brought,

00:04:28.781 --> 00:04:32.230
through the very simple tools
like these stone tools here --

00:04:33.381 --> 00:04:35.194
even something as small as this --

00:04:35.218 --> 00:04:40.623
the early bands of humans were actually
able to eliminate to extinction

00:04:40.647 --> 00:04:45.739
about 250 megafauna animals
in North America

00:04:45.763 --> 00:04:47.952
when they first arrived 10,000 years ago.

00:04:47.976 --> 00:04:50.617
So, long before the industrial age,

00:04:50.641 --> 00:04:53.309
we've been affecting
the planet on a global scale

00:04:53.333 --> 00:04:55.464
with just a small amount of technology.

00:04:55.488 --> 00:04:58.784
The other thing that the early man
invented was fire.

00:04:58.808 --> 00:05:00.933
And fire was used to clear out, and again,

00:05:00.957 --> 00:05:04.605
affected the ecology of grass
and whole continents,

00:05:04.629 --> 00:05:07.027
and was used in cooking.

00:05:07.051 --> 00:05:09.506
It enabled us to actually
eat all kinds of things.

00:05:09.530 --> 00:05:11.784
It was, in a certain sense,
in a McLuhan sense,

00:05:11.808 --> 00:05:13.916
an external stomach,

00:05:13.940 --> 00:05:17.435
in the sense that it was cooking food
that we could not eat otherwise.

00:05:17.459 --> 00:05:20.203
And if we didn't have fire,
we actually could not live.

00:05:20.227 --> 00:05:23.369
Our bodies have adapted
to these new diets.

00:05:23.393 --> 00:05:26.188
Our bodies have changed
in the last 10,000 years.

00:05:26.212 --> 00:05:29.268
So, with that little bit of technology,

00:05:29.292 --> 00:05:31.568
humans went from a small band
of 10,000 or so --

00:05:31.592 --> 00:05:33.741
the same number
as Neanderthals everywhere --

00:05:33.765 --> 00:05:35.003
and we suddenly exploded.

00:05:35.027 --> 00:05:37.628
With the invention of language
around 50,000 years ago,

00:05:37.652 --> 00:05:39.145
the number of humans exploded,

00:05:39.169 --> 00:05:42.293
and very quickly became
the dominant species on the planet.

00:05:42.317 --> 00:05:44.759
And they migrated
into the rest of the world

00:05:44.783 --> 00:05:46.223
at two kilometers per year

00:05:46.247 --> 00:05:49.224
until, within several tens
of thousands of years,

00:05:49.248 --> 00:05:51.523
we occupied every single
watershed on the planet

00:05:51.547 --> 00:05:53.365
and became the most dominant species,

00:05:53.389 --> 00:05:55.752
with a very small amount of technology.

00:05:55.776 --> 00:05:58.856
And even at that time,
with the introduction of agriculture,

00:05:58.880 --> 00:06:00.590
8,000, 10,000 years ago,

00:06:00.614 --> 00:06:02.309
we started to see climate change.

00:06:02.333 --> 00:06:05.917
So climate change is not a new thing;
what's new is just the degree of it.

00:06:05.941 --> 00:06:09.016
Even during the agricultural age,
there was climate change.

00:06:09.040 --> 00:06:12.776
So already, small amounts of technology
were transforming the world.

00:06:12.800 --> 00:06:15.461
And what this means, and where I'm going,

00:06:15.485 --> 00:06:19.309
is that technology has become
the most powerful force in the world.

00:06:19.333 --> 00:06:22.260
All the things we see today
that are changing our lives,

00:06:22.284 --> 00:06:23.471
we can always trace back

00:06:23.495 --> 00:06:25.560
to the introduction
of some new technology.

00:06:25.584 --> 00:06:26.889
So it's a force,

00:06:26.913 --> 00:06:30.984
that is the most powerful force
that has been unleashed on this planet,

00:06:31.008 --> 00:06:32.817
and in such a degree,

00:06:32.841 --> 00:06:39.062
that I think it's become who we are.

00:06:39.086 --> 00:06:42.341
In fact, our humanity and everything
that we think about ourselves,

00:06:42.365 --> 00:06:43.833
is something we've invented.

00:06:43.857 --> 00:06:45.264
So we've invented ourselves.

00:06:45.288 --> 00:06:47.406
Of all the animals
that we've domesticated,

00:06:47.430 --> 00:06:49.545
the most important animal has been us.

00:06:50.791 --> 00:06:54.309
So humanity is our greatest invention,

00:06:54.333 --> 00:06:56.309
but of course, we're not done yet.

00:06:56.333 --> 00:06:57.495
We're still inventing,

00:06:57.519 --> 00:06:59.857
and this is what technology
is allowing us to do;

00:06:59.881 --> 00:07:01.917
it's continually to reinvent ourselves.

00:07:01.941 --> 00:07:04.364
It's a very, very strong force.

00:07:04.388 --> 00:07:07.523
I call this entire thing --
us humans as our technology,

00:07:07.547 --> 00:07:10.309
everything that we've made,
gadgets in our lives --

00:07:10.333 --> 00:07:11.596
we call that the technium.

00:07:11.620 --> 00:07:12.780
That's this world.

00:07:12.804 --> 00:07:14.709
My working definition of technology is:

00:07:14.733 --> 00:07:17.106
anything useful that a human mind makes.

00:07:17.130 --> 00:07:19.788
It's not just hammers
and gadgets, like laptops.

00:07:19.812 --> 00:07:21.233
But it's also law.

00:07:21.257 --> 00:07:26.400
And, of course, cities are ways
to make things more useful to us.

00:07:26.424 --> 00:07:28.889
While this is something
that comes from our mind,

00:07:28.913 --> 00:07:33.206
it also has its roots
deeply into the cosmos.

00:07:33.230 --> 00:07:34.393
It goes back.

00:07:34.417 --> 00:07:37.280
The origins and roots of technology
go back to the Big Bang,

00:07:37.304 --> 00:07:41.792
in this way, in that they are part
of this self-organizing thread

00:07:41.816 --> 00:07:46.371
that starts at the Big Bang
and goes through galaxies and stars,

00:07:46.395 --> 00:07:47.953
into life, into us.

00:07:47.977 --> 00:07:50.605
And the three major phases
of the early universe

00:07:50.629 --> 00:07:52.851
was energy, when the dominant
force was energy;

00:07:52.875 --> 00:07:55.915
then the dominant force,
as it cooled, became matter;

00:07:55.939 --> 00:07:59.309
and then, with the invention
of life four billion years ago,

00:07:59.333 --> 00:08:02.119
the dominant force in our neighborhood
became information.

00:08:02.143 --> 00:08:03.327
That's what life is:

00:08:03.351 --> 00:08:05.511
an information process
that was restructuring

00:08:05.535 --> 00:08:06.757
and making new order.

00:08:06.781 --> 00:08:10.398
So, energy and matter,
Einstein showed were equivalent,

00:08:10.422 --> 00:08:16.042
and now new sciences of quantum computing
show that entropy and information

00:08:16.066 --> 00:08:17.516
and matter and energy

00:08:17.540 --> 00:08:18.704
are all interrelated.

00:08:18.728 --> 00:08:20.265
So it's one long continuum.

00:08:21.162 --> 00:08:24.357
You put energy
into the right kind of system,

00:08:24.381 --> 00:08:27.455
and out comes wasted heat, entropy,

00:08:27.479 --> 00:08:30.309
and extropy, which is order.

00:08:30.333 --> 00:08:31.663
It's the increased order.

00:08:31.687 --> 00:08:33.240
Where does this order come from?

00:08:33.264 --> 00:08:34.535
Its roots go way back.

00:08:34.559 --> 00:08:35.892
We actually don't know.

00:08:35.916 --> 00:08:37.128
But we do know

00:08:37.152 --> 00:08:41.447
that the self-organization trend
throughout the universe is long,

00:08:41.471 --> 00:08:43.694
and it began with things like galaxies;

00:08:43.718 --> 00:08:46.212
they maintained their order
for billions of years.

00:08:46.236 --> 00:08:50.086
Stars are basically
nuclear fission machines

00:08:50.110 --> 00:08:53.409
that self-organize and self-sustain
themselves for billions of years:

00:08:53.433 --> 00:08:55.564
order against the extropy of the world.

00:08:55.588 --> 00:09:00.498
And flowers and plants
are the same thing, extended,

00:09:00.522 --> 00:09:05.269
and technology is basically
an extension of life.

00:09:06.181 --> 00:09:09.159
One trend that we notice
in all those things

00:09:09.183 --> 00:09:11.755
is that the amount of energy
per gram per second

00:09:11.779 --> 00:09:13.062
that flows through this

00:09:13.086 --> 00:09:14.377
is actually increasing.

00:09:14.401 --> 00:09:18.980
The amount of energy is increasing
through this little sequence.

00:09:19.004 --> 00:09:22.981
And the amount of energy per gram
per second that flows through life

00:09:23.005 --> 00:09:24.982
is actually greater than a star --

00:09:25.006 --> 00:09:28.309
because of the star's long lifespan,

00:09:28.333 --> 00:09:31.522
the energy density in life
is actually higher than a star.

00:09:31.546 --> 00:09:34.405
And the energy density
that we see in the greatest amount

00:09:34.429 --> 00:09:35.635
anywhere in the universe

00:09:35.659 --> 00:09:36.992
is actually in a PC chip.

00:09:37.016 --> 00:09:40.166
There is more energy flowing
through, per gram per second,

00:09:40.190 --> 00:09:43.308
than anything that we have
any other experience with.

00:09:43.332 --> 00:09:44.961
And so, what I would suggest

00:09:44.985 --> 00:09:47.926
is that if you want to see
where technology is going,

00:09:47.950 --> 00:09:49.582
we continue that trajectory,

00:09:49.606 --> 00:09:52.459
and we say, "Well, it's going
to become more energy-dense,

00:09:52.483 --> 00:09:53.700
that's where it's going."

00:09:53.724 --> 00:09:56.692
And so what I've done is,
I've taken the same kinds of things

00:09:56.716 --> 00:09:59.982
and looked at other aspects
of evolutionary life and say,

00:10:00.006 --> 00:10:02.612
"What are the general trends
in evolutionary life?"

00:10:02.636 --> 00:10:05.358
And there are things moving
towards greater complexity,

00:10:05.382 --> 00:10:09.309
moving towards greater diversity,
moving towards greater specialization,

00:10:09.333 --> 00:10:13.575
sentience, ubiquity,
and most important, evolvability.

00:10:13.599 --> 00:10:17.122
Those very same things
are also present in technology.

00:10:17.146 --> 00:10:18.995
That's where technology is going.

00:10:19.019 --> 00:10:23.462
In fact, technology
is accelerating all the aspects of life.

00:10:24.333 --> 00:10:25.831
And we can see that happening;

00:10:25.855 --> 00:10:30.006
just as there's diversity in life,
there's more diversity in things we make.

00:10:30.030 --> 00:10:32.180
Things in life start off
being general cells,

00:10:32.204 --> 00:10:33.585
and they become specialized:

00:10:33.609 --> 00:10:35.746
you have tissue cells,
muscle, brain cells.

00:10:35.770 --> 00:10:37.800
The same thing happens
with, say, a hammer,

00:10:37.824 --> 00:10:40.309
which is general at first
and becomes more specific.

00:10:40.333 --> 00:10:43.429
So I would like to say
that while there are six kingdoms of life,

00:10:43.453 --> 00:10:47.034
we can think of technology
basically as a seventh kingdom of life.

00:10:47.058 --> 00:10:49.389
It's a branching off from the human form.

00:10:49.413 --> 00:10:53.309
But technology has its own agenda,
like anything, like life itself.

00:10:53.333 --> 00:10:56.475
For instance, right now,
three-quarters of the energy that we use

00:10:56.499 --> 00:10:58.631
is actually used to feed
the technium itself.

00:10:58.655 --> 00:11:00.547
In transportation, it's not to move us;

00:11:00.571 --> 00:11:02.440
it's to move the stuff we make or buy.

00:11:02.464 --> 00:11:04.441
I use the word "want." Technology wants.

00:11:04.465 --> 00:11:07.467
This is a robot that wants to plug
itself in to get more power.

00:11:07.491 --> 00:11:10.070
Your cat wants more food.

00:11:10.094 --> 00:11:12.657
A bacterium, which has
no consciousness at all,

00:11:12.681 --> 00:11:14.309
wants to move towards light.

00:11:14.333 --> 00:11:17.021
It has an urge,
and technology has an urge.

00:11:17.045 --> 00:11:19.189
At the same time,
it wants to give us things,

00:11:19.213 --> 00:11:21.767
and what it gives us
is basically progress.

00:11:21.791 --> 00:11:24.863
You can take all kinds of curves,
and they're all pointing up.

00:11:24.887 --> 00:11:27.309
There's really no dispute about progress,

00:11:27.333 --> 00:11:30.309
if we discount the cost of that.

00:11:30.333 --> 00:11:32.524
And that's the thing
that bothers most people,

00:11:32.548 --> 00:11:36.412
is that progress is really real,
but we wonder and question:

00:11:36.436 --> 00:11:38.309
What are the environmental costs of it?

00:11:38.333 --> 00:11:42.160
I did a survey of the number
of species of artifacts in my house,

00:11:42.184 --> 00:11:43.342
and there's 6,000.

00:11:43.366 --> 00:11:45.435
Other people have come up with 10,000.

00:11:45.459 --> 00:11:47.899
When King Henry of England died,

00:11:47.923 --> 00:11:49.977
he had 18,000 things in his house,

00:11:50.001 --> 00:11:53.478
but that was the entire
wealth of England, so ...

00:11:53.502 --> 00:11:54.712
(Laughter)

00:11:54.736 --> 00:11:57.242
And with that entire wealth of England,

00:11:57.266 --> 00:12:00.192
King Henry could not buy any antibiotics,

00:12:00.216 --> 00:12:01.766
he could not buy refrigeration,

00:12:01.790 --> 00:12:03.923
he could not buy
a trip of a thousand miles,

00:12:03.947 --> 00:12:08.411
whereas this rickshaw wallah in India
could save up and buy antibiotics

00:12:08.435 --> 00:12:10.178
and he could buy refrigeration.

00:12:10.202 --> 00:12:13.673
He could buy things that King Henry,
in all his wealth, could never buy.

00:12:13.697 --> 00:12:15.364
That's what progress is about.

00:12:15.388 --> 00:12:18.309
So, technology is selfish;
technology is generous.

00:12:18.333 --> 00:12:21.529
That conflict, that tension,
will be with us forever:

00:12:21.553 --> 00:12:23.751
sometimes it wants to do
what it wants to do,

00:12:23.775 --> 00:12:25.895
and sometimes it's going
to do things for us.

00:12:25.919 --> 00:12:27.986
We have confusion
about what we should think

00:12:28.010 --> 00:12:29.309
about a new technology.

00:12:29.333 --> 00:12:33.163
Right now the default position
when a new technology comes along,

00:12:33.187 --> 00:12:35.512
is people talk about
the precautionary principle,

00:12:35.536 --> 00:12:37.422
which is very common in Europe,

00:12:37.446 --> 00:12:39.493
which says, basically, "Don't do anything.

00:12:39.517 --> 00:12:42.131
When you meet a new technology, stop,

00:12:42.155 --> 00:12:44.684
until it can be proven
that it does no harm."

00:12:44.708 --> 00:12:46.953
I think that really leads nowhere.

00:12:46.977 --> 00:12:49.978
But a better way is
what I call the proactionary principle,

00:12:50.002 --> 00:12:52.408
which is, you engage with technology.

00:12:52.432 --> 00:12:53.810
You try it out.

00:12:53.834 --> 00:12:58.050
You obviously do what the precautionary
principle suggests,

00:12:58.074 --> 00:12:59.319
you try to anticipate it,

00:12:59.343 --> 00:13:00.770
but after anticipating it,

00:13:00.794 --> 00:13:02.309
you constantly asses it,

00:13:02.333 --> 00:13:03.896
not just once, but eternally.

00:13:03.920 --> 00:13:07.097
And when it diverts from what you want,

00:13:07.121 --> 00:13:10.282
we prioritize risk,
we evaluate not just the new stuff,

00:13:10.306 --> 00:13:11.465
but the old stuff.

00:13:11.489 --> 00:13:13.359
We fix it; but most importantly,

00:13:13.383 --> 00:13:14.540
we relocate it.

00:13:14.564 --> 00:13:16.388
And what I mean by that is,

00:13:16.412 --> 00:13:18.120
we find a new job for it.

00:13:18.144 --> 00:13:22.154
Nuclear energy, fission,
is a really bad idea for bombs.

00:13:22.178 --> 00:13:27.573
But it may be a pretty good idea
relocated into sustainable nuclear energy

00:13:27.597 --> 00:13:29.915
for electricity, instead of burning coal.

00:13:29.939 --> 00:13:31.654
When we have a bad idea,

00:13:31.678 --> 00:13:33.242
the response to a bad idea

00:13:33.266 --> 00:13:36.586
is not no ideas,
it's not to stop thinking.

00:13:36.610 --> 00:13:38.763
The response to a bad idea --

00:13:38.787 --> 00:13:40.915
like, say, a tungsten lightbulb --

00:13:40.939 --> 00:13:43.178
is a better idea.

00:13:43.671 --> 00:13:47.151
So, better ideas
is really always the response

00:13:47.175 --> 00:13:48.540
to technology we don't like;

00:13:48.564 --> 00:13:50.651
it's basically better technology.

00:13:51.157 --> 00:13:54.977
And actually, in a certain sense,
technology is a kind of a method

00:13:55.001 --> 00:13:56.556
for generating better ideas,

00:13:56.580 --> 00:13:58.309
if you can think about it that way.

00:13:58.333 --> 00:14:01.428
So, maybe spraying DDT
on crops is a really bad idea.

00:14:01.452 --> 00:14:04.309
But DDT sprayed on local homes --

00:14:04.333 --> 00:14:07.309
there's nothing better
to eliminate malaria,

00:14:07.333 --> 00:14:11.071
besides insect DDT-impregnated
mosquito nets.

00:14:11.095 --> 00:14:14.426
But that's a really good idea;
that's a good job for technology.

00:14:14.450 --> 00:14:18.309
So our job as humans
is to parent our mind children,

00:14:18.333 --> 00:14:19.777
to find them good friends,

00:14:19.801 --> 00:14:21.193
to find them a good job.

00:14:21.217 --> 00:14:24.025
And so, every technology
is sort of a creative force

00:14:24.049 --> 00:14:26.069
looking for the right job.

00:14:26.093 --> 00:14:28.184
That's actually my son, right here.

00:14:28.208 --> 00:14:29.531
(Laughter)

00:14:29.555 --> 00:14:32.047
There are no bad technologies,

00:14:32.071 --> 00:14:33.767
just as there are no bad children.

00:14:33.791 --> 00:14:36.673
We don't say children are neutral;
children are positive.

00:14:36.697 --> 00:14:39.024
We just have to find them the right place.

00:14:39.048 --> 00:14:43.002
And so, what technology gives us
over the long term --

00:14:43.026 --> 00:14:46.667
over this sort of extended evolution
from the beginning of time,

00:14:46.691 --> 00:14:50.309
through the invention
of the plants and animals,

00:14:50.333 --> 00:14:53.309
and the evolution of life,
the evolution of brains --

00:14:53.333 --> 00:14:57.244
what that is constantly giving us
is increasing differences:

00:14:57.268 --> 00:14:59.723
It's increasing diversity,
it's increasing options,

00:14:59.747 --> 00:15:03.725
it's increasing choices, opportunities,
possibilities and freedoms.

00:15:03.749 --> 00:15:06.673
That's what we get
from technology all the time.

00:15:06.697 --> 00:15:09.513
That's why people leave villages
and go into cities --

00:15:09.537 --> 00:15:13.186
because they are always gravitating
towards increased choices

00:15:13.210 --> 00:15:14.447
and possibilities.

00:15:14.471 --> 00:15:17.100
And we are aware of the price;

00:15:17.124 --> 00:15:19.363
we pay a price for that,
but we're aware of it,

00:15:19.387 --> 00:15:22.342
and generally, we will pay the price
for increased freedoms,

00:15:22.366 --> 00:15:23.754
choices and opportunities.

00:15:24.263 --> 00:15:26.971
Even technology wants clean water.

00:15:26.995 --> 00:15:31.176
Is technology diametrically
opposed to nature?

00:15:31.200 --> 00:15:34.058
Because technology
is an extension of life,

00:15:34.082 --> 00:15:36.925
it's in parallel and aligned
with the same things

00:15:36.949 --> 00:15:38.252
that life wants.

00:15:38.832 --> 00:15:41.007
So that I think technology loves biology,

00:15:41.031 --> 00:15:42.582
if we allow it to.

00:15:43.189 --> 00:15:47.309
Great movement
starting billions of years ago

00:15:47.333 --> 00:15:49.637
is moving through us
and it continues to go,

00:15:49.661 --> 00:15:53.074
and our choice, so to speak,
in technology,

00:15:53.098 --> 00:15:55.169
is really to align ourselves
with this force

00:15:55.193 --> 00:15:56.577
much greater than ourselves.

00:15:56.601 --> 00:15:59.409
So, technology is more
than just the stuff in your pocket;

00:15:59.433 --> 00:16:00.824
it's more than just gadgets,

00:16:00.848 --> 00:16:03.313
it's more than just things
that people invent.

00:16:03.337 --> 00:16:06.724
It's actually part of a very long
story -- a great story --

00:16:06.748 --> 00:16:08.381
that began billions of years ago.

00:16:08.405 --> 00:16:10.712
It's moving through us,
this self-organization,

00:16:10.736 --> 00:16:12.713
and we're extending and accelerating it,

00:16:12.737 --> 00:16:16.501
and we can be part of it by aligning
the technology that we make with it.

00:16:16.525 --> 00:16:19.363
And I really appreciate
your attention today.

00:16:19.387 --> 00:16:20.546
Thank you.

00:16:20.570 --> 00:16:24.156
(Applause)

title: Four ways to fix a broken legal system
transcript: I've always been interested in the relationship of formal structures and human behavior. If you build a wide road out to the outskirts of town, people will move there. Well, law is also a powerful driver of human behavior. And what I'd like to discuss today is the need to overhaul and simplify the law to release the energy and passion of Americans, so that we can begin to address the challenges of our society.You might have noticed that law has grown progressively denser in your lives over the last decade or two. If you run a business, it's hard to do much of anything without calling your general counsel. Indeed, there is this phenomenon now where the general counsels are becoming the CEOs. It's a little bit like the Invasion Of The Body Snatchers. You need a lawyer to run the company, because there's so much law. But it's not just business that's affected by this, it's actually pressed down into the daily activities of ordinary people.A couple of years ago I was hiking near Cody, Wyoming. It was in a grizzly bear preserve, although no one told me that before we went. And our guide was a local science teacher. She was wholly unconcerned about the bears, but she was terrified of lawyers. The stories started pouring out. She'd just been involved in an episode where a parent had threatened to sue the school because she lowered the grade of the student by 10 percent when he turned the paper in late. The principal didn't want to stand up to the parent because he didn't want to get dragged into some legal proceedings. So, she had to go to meeting after meeting, same arguments made over and over again. After 30 days of sleepless nights, she finally capitulated and raised the grade. She said, "Life's too short, I just can't keep going with this."About the same time, she was going to take two students to a leadership conference in Laramie, which is a couple of hours away, and she was going to drive them in her car, but the school said, "No, you can't drive them in the car for liability reasons. You have to go in a school bus." So, they provided a bus that held 60 people and drove the three of them back and forth several hours to Laramie.Her husband is also a science teacher, and he takes his biology class on a hike in the nearby national park. But he was told he couldn't go on the hike this year because one of the students in the class was disabled, so the other 25 students didn't get to go on the hike either. At the end of this day I could have filled a book just with stories about law from this one teacher.Now, we've been taught to believe that law is the foundation of freedom. But somehow or another, in the last couple of decades, the land of the free has become a legal minefield. It's really changed our lives in ways that are sort of imperceptible; and yet, when you pull back, you see it all the time. It's changed the way we talk. I was talking to a pediatrician friend in North Carolina. He said, "Well you know, I don't deal with patients the same way anymore. You wouldn't want to say something off-the-cuff that might be used against you." This is a doctor, whose life is caring for people. My own law firm has a list of questions that I'm not allowed to ask when interviewing candidates, such as the sinister question, bulging with hidden motives and innuendo, "Where are you from?" (Laughter)Now for 20 years, tort reformers have been sounding the alarm that lawsuits are out of control. And we read every once in while about these crazy lawsuits, like the guy in the District of Columbia who sued his dry cleaners for 54 million dollars because they lost his pair of pants. The case went on for two years; I think he's still appealing the case.But the reality is, these crazy cases are relatively rare. They don't usually win. And the total of direct tort cost in this country is about two percent, which is twice as much as in other countries but, as taxes go, hardly crippling. But the direct costs are really only the tip of the iceberg.What's happened here, again, almost without our knowing, is our culture has changed. People no longer feel free to act on their best judgment. So, what do we do about it? We certainly don't want to give up the rights, when people do something wrong, to seek redress in the courts. We need regulation to make sure people don't pollute and such. We lack even a vocabulary to deal with this problem, and that's because we have the wrong frame of reference.We've been trained to think that the way to look at every dispute, every issue, is a matter of kind of individual rights. And so we peer through a legal microscope, and look at everything. Is it possible that there are extenuating circumstances that explain why Johnny turned his paper in late in Cody, Wyoming? Is it possible that the doctor might have done something differently when the sick person gets sicker? And of course the hindsight bias is perfect. There's always a different scenario that you can sketch out where it's possible that something could have been done differently.And yet, we've been trained to squint into this legal microscope, hoping that we can judge any dispute against the standard of a perfect society, where everyone will agree what's fair, and where accidents will be extinct, risk will be no more. Of course, this is Utopia; it's a formula for paralysis, not freedom. It's not the basis of the rule of law, it's not the basis of a free society. So, now I have the first of four propositions I'm going to leave with you about how you simplify the law: You've got to judge law mainly by its effect on the broader society, not individual disputes. Absolutely vital.So, let's pull back from the anecdotes for a second and look at our society from high above. Is it working? What does the macro-data show us? Well, the healthcare system has been transformed: a culture pervaded with defensiveness, universal distrust of the system of justice, universal practice of defensive medicine. It's very hard to measure because there are mixed motives. Doctors can make more on ordering tests sometimes, and also they no longer even know what's right or wrong. But reliable estimates range between 60 billion and 200 billion dollars per year. That's enough to provide care to all the people in America who don't have it.The trial lawyers say, "Well, this legal fear makes doctors practice better medicine." Well that's been studied too, by the Institute of Medicine and others. Turns out that's not the case. The fear has chilled professional interaction so thousands of tragic errors occur because doctors are afraid to speak up: "Are you sure that's the right dosage?" Because they're not sure, and they don't want to take legal responsibility.Let's go to schools. As we saw with the teacher in Cody, Wyoming, she seems to be affected by the law. Well it turns out the schools are literally drowning in law. You could have a separate section of a law library around each of the following legal concepts: due process, special education, no child left behind, zero tolerance, work rules ... it goes on. We did a study of all the rules that affect one school in New York. The Board of Ed. had no idea. Tens of thousands of discreet rules, 60 steps to suspend a student from school: It's a formula for paralysis. What's the effect of that? One is a decline in order.Again, studies have shown it's directly attributable to the rise of due process. Public agenda did a survey for us a couple of years ago where they found that 43 percent of the high school teachers in America say that they spend at least half of their time maintaining order in the classroom. That means those students are getting half the learning they're supposed to, because if one child is disrupting the class no one can learn. And what happens when the teacher tries to assert order? They're threatened with a legal claim. We also surveyed that. Seventy-eight percent of the middle and high school teachers in America have been threatened by their students with violating their rights, with lawsuits by their students. They are threatening, their students. It's not that they usually sue, it's not that they would win, but it's an indication of the corrosion of authority.And how has this system of law worked for government? It doesn't seem to be working very well does it? Neither in Sacramento nor in Washington. The other day at the State of the Union speech, President Obama said, and I think we could all agree with this goal, "From the first railroads to the interstate highway system, our nation has always been the first to compete. There is no reason Europe or China should have the fastest trains." Well, actually there is a reason: Environmental review has evolved into a process of no pebble left unturned for any major project taking the better part of a decade, then followed by years of litigation by anybody who doesn't like the project.Then, just staying above the Earth for one more second, people are acting like idiots, (Laughter) all across the country. (Applause) Idiots. A couple of years ago, Broward County, Florida, banned running at recess. (Laughter) That means all the boys are going to be ADD. I mean it's just absolutely a formula for failure.My favorite, though, are all the warning labels. "Caution: Contents are hot," on billions of coffee cups. Archeologists will dig us up in a thousand years and they won't know about defensive medicine and stuff, but they'll see all these labels, "Contents are extremely hot." They'll think it was some kind of aphrodisiac. That's the only explanation. Because why would you have to tell people that something was actually hot? My favorite warning was one on a five-inch fishing lure. I grew up in the South and whiled away the summers fishing. Five-inch fishing lure, it's a big fishing lure, with a three pronged hook in the back, and outside it said, "Harmful if swallowed." (Laughter)So, none of these people are doing what they think is right. And why not? They don't trust the law. Why don't they trust the law? Because it gives us the worst of both worlds: It's random — anybody can sue for almost anything and take it to a jury, not even an effort at consistency — and it's also too detailed. In the areas that are regulated, there are so many rules no human could possibly know it. Well how do you fix it? We could spend 10,000 lifetimes trying to prune this legal jungle. But the challenge here is not one of just amending the law, because the hurdle for success is trust.People — for law to be the platform for freedom, people have to trust it. So, that's my second proposition: Trust is an essential condition to a free society. Life is complicated enough without legal fear. But law is different than other kinds of uncertainties, because it carries with it the power of state. And so the state can come in. It actually changes the way people think. It's like having a little lawyer on your shoulders all day long, whispering in your ear, "Could that go wrong? Might that go wrong?" It drives people from the smart part of the brain — that dark, deep well of the subconscious, where instincts and experience, and all the other factors of creativity and good judgment are — it drives us to the thin veneer of conscious logic.Pretty soon the doctor's saying, "Well, I doubt if that headache could be a tumor, but who would protect me if it were? So maybe I'll just order the MRI." Then you've wasted 200 billion dollars in unnecessary tests. If you make people self-conscious about their judgments, studies show you will make them make worse judgments. If you tell the pianist to think about how she's hitting the notes when she's playing the piece, she can't play the piece. Self-consciousness is the enemy of accomplishment. Edison stated it best. He said, "Hell, we ain't got no rules around here, we're trying to accomplish something." (Laughter)So, how do you restore trust? Tweaking the law's clearly not good enough, and tort reform, which is a great idea, lowers your cost if you're a businessperson, but it's like a Band-Aid on this gaping wound of distrust. States with extensive tort reform still suffer all these pathologies. So, what's needed is not just to limit claims, but actually create a dry ground of freedom. It turns out that freedom actually has a formal structure. And it is this: Law sets boundaries, and on one side of those boundaries are all the things you can't do or must do — you can't steal, you've got to pay your taxes — but those same boundaries are supposed to define and protect a dry ground of freedom.Isaiah Berlin put it this way: "Law sets frontiers, not artificially drawn, within which men shall be inviolable." We've forgotten that second part. Those dikes have burst. People wade through law all day long. So, what's needed now is to rebuild these boundaries. And it's especially important to rebuild them for lawsuits. Because what people can sue for establishes the boundaries for everybody else's freedom. If someone brings a lawsuit over, "A kid fell off the seesaw," it doesn't matter what happens in the lawsuit, all the seesaws will disappear. Because no one will want to take the risk of a lawsuit. And that's what's happened. There are no seesaws, jungle gyms, merry-go-rounds, climbing ropes, nothing that would interest a kid over the age of four, because there's no risk associated with it.So, how do we rebuild it? Life is too complex for... (Applause) Life is too complex for a software program. All these choices involve value judgments and social norms, not objective facts. And so here is the fourth proposition. This is what we have, the philosophy we have to change to. And there are two essential elements of it: We have to simplify the law. We have to migrate from all this complexity towards general principles and goals. The constitution is only 16 pages long. Worked pretty well for 200 years.Law has to be simple enough so that people can internalize it in their daily choices. If they can't internalize it, they won't trust it. And how do you make it simple? Because life is complex, and here is the hardest and biggest change: We have to restore the authority to judges and officials to interpret and apply the law. (Applause) We have to rehumanize the law. To make law simple so that you feel free, the people in charge have to be free to use their judgment to interpret and apply the law in accord with reasonable social norms. As you're going down, and walking down the sidewalk during the day, you have to think that if there is a dispute, there's somebody in society who sees it as their job to affirmatively protect you if you're acting reasonably. That person doesn't exist today.This is the hardest hurdle. It's actually not very hard. Ninety-eight percent of cases, this is a piece of cake. Maybe you've got a claim in small claims court for your lost pair of pants for $100, but not in a court of general jurisdiction for millions of dollars. Case dismissed without prejudice or refiling in small claims court. Takes five minutes. That's it, it's not that hard.But it's a hard hurdle because we got into this legal quicksand because we woke up in the 1960s to all these really bad values: racism, gender discrimination, pollution — they were bad values. And we wanted to create a legal system where no one could have bad values anymore. The problem is, we created a system where we eliminated the right to have good values. It doesn't mean that people in authority can do whatever they want. They're still bounded by legal goals and principles: The teacher is accountable to the principal, the judge is accountable to an appellate court, the president is accountable to voters. But the accountability's up the line judging the decision against the effect on everybody, not just on the disgruntled person. You can't run a society by the lowest common denominator. (Applause)So, what's needed is a basic shift in philosophy. We can pull the plug on a lot of this stuff if we shift our philosophy. We've been taught that authority is the enemy of freedom. It's not true. Authority, in fact, is essential to freedom. Law is a human institution; responsibility is a human institution. If teachers don't have authority to run the classroom, to maintain order, everybody's learning suffers. If the judge doesn't have the authority to toss out unreasonable claims, then all of us go through the day looking over our shoulders. If the environmental agency can't decide that the power lines are good for the environment, then there's no way to bring the power from the wind farms to the city. A free society requires red lights and green lights, otherwise it soon descends into gridlock. That's what's happened to America. Look around.What the world needs now is to restore the authority to make common choices. It's the only way to get our freedom back, and it's the only way to release the energy and passion needed so that we can meet the challenges of our time. Thank you. (Applause)
