00:00:12.402 --> 00:00:14.848
I think I'll start out
and just talk a little bit

00:00:14.872 --> 00:00:16.363
about what exactly autism is.

00:00:16.387 --> 00:00:19.022
Autism is a very big continuum

00:00:19.046 --> 00:00:22.220
that goes from very severe --
the child remains nonverbal --

00:00:22.244 --> 00:00:24.934
all the way up to brilliant
scientists and engineers.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.935
And I actually feel at home here,

00:00:26.959 --> 00:00:29.505
because there's a lot
of autism genetics here.

00:00:29.529 --> 00:00:30.561
(Laughter)

00:00:30.585 --> 00:00:31.743
You wouldn't have any --

00:00:31.767 --> 00:00:34.736
(Applause)

00:00:34.760 --> 00:00:36.796
It's a continuum of traits.

00:00:36.820 --> 00:00:42.477
When does a nerd turn into Asperger,
which is just mild autism?

00:00:42.501 --> 00:00:47.659
I mean, Einstein and Mozart and Tesla
would all be probably diagnosed

00:00:47.683 --> 00:00:49.575
as autistic spectrum today.

00:00:49.599 --> 00:00:52.890
And one of the things
that is really going to concern me

00:00:52.914 --> 00:00:55.149
is getting these kids to be the ones

00:00:55.173 --> 00:00:57.995
that are going to invent
the next energy things

00:00:58.019 --> 00:01:00.269
that Bill Gates talked about this morning.

00:01:00.756 --> 00:01:04.669
OK, now, if you want
to understand autism: animals.

00:01:04.693 --> 00:01:07.583
I want to talk to you now
about different ways of thinking.

00:01:07.607 --> 00:01:10.457
You have to get away from verbal language.

00:01:10.481 --> 00:01:14.082
I think in pictures.
I don't think in language.

00:01:14.780 --> 00:01:20.050
Now, the thing about the autistic mind
is it attends to details.

00:01:20.074 --> 00:01:23.129
This is a test where you either
have to pick out the big letters

00:01:23.153 --> 00:01:24.376
or the little letters,

00:01:24.400 --> 00:01:28.293
and the autistic mind picks out
the little letters more quickly.

00:01:28.645 --> 00:01:32.396
And the thing is, the normal brain
ignores the details.

00:01:32.420 --> 00:01:35.430
Well, if you're building a bridge,
details are pretty important

00:01:35.454 --> 00:01:37.852
because it'll fall down
if you ignore the details.

00:01:37.876 --> 00:01:40.743
And one of my big concerns
with a lot of policy things today

00:01:40.767 --> 00:01:42.445
is things are getting too abstract.

00:01:42.469 --> 00:01:45.696
People are getting away
from doing hands-on stuff.

00:01:45.720 --> 00:01:47.880
I'm really concerned
that a lot of the schools

00:01:47.904 --> 00:01:51.872
have taken out the hands-on classes,
because art, and classes like that --

00:01:51.896 --> 00:01:54.209
those are the classes where I excelled.

00:01:54.233 --> 00:01:56.387
In my work with cattle,

00:01:56.411 --> 00:01:59.389
I noticed a lot of little things
that most people don't notice

00:01:59.413 --> 00:02:00.701
would make the cattle balk.

00:02:00.725 --> 00:02:04.272
For example, this flag waving
right in front of the veterinary facility.

00:02:04.296 --> 00:02:07.623
This feed yard was going to tear down
their whole veterinary facility;

00:02:07.647 --> 00:02:09.561
all they needed to do was move the flag.

00:02:09.585 --> 00:02:11.653
Rapid movement, contrast.

00:02:11.677 --> 00:02:14.711
In the early '70s when I started,
I got right down in the chutes

00:02:14.735 --> 00:02:16.234
to see what cattle were seeing.

00:02:16.258 --> 00:02:17.720
People thought that was crazy.

00:02:17.744 --> 00:02:21.026
A coat on a fence would make them balk,
shadows would make them balk,

00:02:21.050 --> 00:02:24.114
a hose on the floor --
people weren't noticing these things.

00:02:24.138 --> 00:02:25.654
A chain hanging down ...

00:02:25.678 --> 00:02:27.934
And that's shown
very, very nicely in the movie.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:31.413
In fact, I loved the movie,
how they duplicated all my projects.

00:02:31.437 --> 00:02:32.778
That's the geek side.

00:02:32.802 --> 00:02:35.222
My drawings got to star in the movie, too.

00:02:35.246 --> 00:02:37.356
And, actually, it's called
"Temple Grandin,"

00:02:37.380 --> 00:02:38.704
not "Thinking in Pictures."

00:02:38.728 --> 00:02:40.293
So what is thinking in pictures?

00:02:40.317 --> 00:02:42.996
It's literally movies in your head.

00:02:43.020 --> 00:02:45.902
My mind works like Google for images.

00:02:45.926 --> 00:02:48.970
When I was a young kid,
I didn't know my thinking was different.

00:02:48.994 --> 00:02:50.913
I thought everybody thought in pictures.

00:02:50.937 --> 00:02:53.192
Then when I did my book,
"Thinking in Pictures,"

00:02:53.216 --> 00:02:55.628
I started interviewing people
about how they think.

00:02:55.652 --> 00:02:58.807
And I was shocked to find out
that my thinking was quite different.

00:02:58.831 --> 00:03:01.007
Like if I say, "Think
about a church steeple,"

00:03:01.031 --> 00:03:03.544
most people get this sort
of generalized generic one.

00:03:03.568 --> 00:03:05.480
Now, maybe that's not true in this room,

00:03:05.504 --> 00:03:08.770
but it's going to be true
in a lot of different places.

00:03:08.794 --> 00:03:11.297
I see only specific pictures.

00:03:11.321 --> 00:03:15.130
They flash up into my memory,
just like Google for pictures.

00:03:15.154 --> 00:03:17.697
And in the movie,
they've got a great scene in there,

00:03:17.721 --> 00:03:21.521
where the word "shoe" is said,
and a whole bunch of '50s and '60s shoes

00:03:21.545 --> 00:03:23.211
pop into my imagination.

00:03:23.606 --> 00:03:26.117
OK, there's my childhood church;
that's specific.

00:03:26.505 --> 00:03:28.373
There's some more, Fort Collins.

00:03:28.397 --> 00:03:30.444
OK, how about famous ones?

00:03:30.468 --> 00:03:33.145
And they just kind of come up,
kind of like this.

00:03:33.169 --> 00:03:36.080
Just really quickly,
like Google for pictures.

00:03:36.104 --> 00:03:37.663
And they come up one at a time,

00:03:37.687 --> 00:03:40.638
and then I think, "OK, well,
maybe we can have it snow,

00:03:40.662 --> 00:03:42.286
or we can have a thunderstorm,"

00:03:42.310 --> 00:03:44.934
and I can hold it there
and turn them into videos.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:48.171
Now, visual thinking
was a tremendous asset

00:03:48.195 --> 00:03:50.997
in my work designing
cattle-handling facilities.

00:03:51.497 --> 00:03:54.697
And I've worked really hard
on improving how cattle are treated

00:03:54.721 --> 00:03:55.873
at the slaughter plant.

00:03:55.897 --> 00:03:58.393
I'm not going to go
into any gucky slaughter slides.

00:03:58.417 --> 00:04:01.305
I've got that stuff up on YouTube,
if you want to look at it.

00:04:01.329 --> 00:04:02.370
(Laughter)

00:04:02.394 --> 00:04:05.287
But one of the things
that I was able to do in my design work

00:04:05.311 --> 00:04:07.934
is I could test-run a piece
of equipment in my mind,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.390
just like a virtual reality
computer system.

00:04:11.406 --> 00:04:15.047
And this is an aerial view
of a recreation of one of my projects

00:04:15.071 --> 00:04:16.433
that was used in the movie.

00:04:16.457 --> 00:04:18.468
That was like just so super cool.

00:04:18.492 --> 00:04:21.970
And there were a lot of, kind of,
Asperger types and autism types

00:04:21.994 --> 00:04:23.942
working out there on the movie set, too.

00:04:23.966 --> 00:04:25.142
(Laughter)

00:04:25.166 --> 00:04:27.957
But one of the things
that really worries me is:

00:04:27.981 --> 00:04:30.985
Where's the younger version
of those kids going today?

00:04:31.518 --> 00:04:33.973
They're not ending up in Silicon Valley,

00:04:33.997 --> 00:04:35.237
where they belong.

00:04:35.261 --> 00:04:37.081
(Laughter)

00:04:37.105 --> 00:04:42.013
(Applause)

00:04:42.037 --> 00:04:45.618
One of the things I learned very early on
because I wasn't that social,

00:04:45.642 --> 00:04:49.053
is I had to sell my work, and not myself.

00:04:49.404 --> 00:04:52.364
And the way I sold livestock jobs
is I showed off my drawings,

00:04:52.388 --> 00:04:54.120
I showed off pictures of things.

00:04:54.144 --> 00:04:56.383
Another thing that helped me
as a little kid

00:04:56.407 --> 00:04:58.636
is, boy, in the '50s,
you were taught manners.

00:04:58.660 --> 00:05:01.699
You were taught you can't pull
the merchandise off the shelves

00:05:01.723 --> 00:05:03.357
in the store and throw it around.

00:05:03.381 --> 00:05:05.533
When kids get to be
in third or fourth grade,

00:05:05.557 --> 00:05:08.385
you might see that this kid's going
to be a visual thinker,

00:05:08.409 --> 00:05:09.674
drawing in perspective.

00:05:09.698 --> 00:05:10.896
Now, I want to emphasize

00:05:10.920 --> 00:05:13.843
that not every autistic kid
is going to be a visual thinker.

00:05:14.410 --> 00:05:18.388
Now, I had this brain scan
done several years ago,

00:05:18.412 --> 00:05:22.345
and I used to joke around about having
a gigantic Internet trunk line

00:05:22.369 --> 00:05:24.296
going deep into my visual cortex.

00:05:24.320 --> 00:05:26.195
This is tensor imaging.

00:05:26.219 --> 00:05:30.071
And my great big Internet trunk line
is twice as big as the control's.

00:05:30.095 --> 00:05:31.699
The red lines there are me,

00:05:31.723 --> 00:05:35.632
and the blue lines are the sex
and age-matched control.

00:05:36.548 --> 00:05:38.570
And there I got a gigantic one,

00:05:38.594 --> 00:05:42.602
and the control over there, the blue one,
has got a really small one.

00:05:43.799 --> 00:05:45.934
And some of the research now is showing

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:49.989
that people on the spectrum actually
think with the primary visual cortex.

00:05:50.013 --> 00:05:53.054
Now, the thing is, the visual thinker
is just one kind of mind.

00:05:53.078 --> 00:05:56.663
You see, the autistic mind
tends to be a specialist mind --

00:05:56.687 --> 00:05:59.300
good at one thing, bad at something else.

00:05:59.800 --> 00:06:01.554
And where I was bad was algebra.

00:06:01.578 --> 00:06:03.868
And I was never allowed
to take geometry or trig.

00:06:03.892 --> 00:06:05.055
Gigantic mistake.

00:06:05.079 --> 00:06:07.514
I'm finding a lot of kids
who need to skip algebra,

00:06:07.538 --> 00:06:09.187
go right to geometry and trig.

00:06:09.545 --> 00:06:12.145
Now, another kind of mind
is the pattern thinker.

00:06:12.169 --> 00:06:13.408
More abstract.

00:06:13.432 --> 00:06:15.995
These are your engineers,
your computer programmers.

00:06:16.019 --> 00:06:17.413
This is pattern thinking.

00:06:17.437 --> 00:06:20.322
That praying mantis is made
from a single sheet of paper --

00:06:20.346 --> 00:06:21.763
no scotch tape, no cuts.

00:06:21.787 --> 00:06:25.322
And there in the background
is the pattern for folding it.

00:06:25.346 --> 00:06:26.991
Here are the types of thinking:

00:06:27.429 --> 00:06:29.981
photo-realistic visual thinkers, like me;

00:06:30.554 --> 00:06:33.934
pattern thinkers, music and math minds.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.546
Some of these oftentimes
have problems with reading.

00:06:36.570 --> 00:06:41.051
You also will see these kind of problems
with kids that are dyslexic.

00:06:41.075 --> 00:06:43.099
You'll see these different kinds of minds.

00:06:43.123 --> 00:06:46.697
And then there's a verbal mind,
they know every fact about everything.

00:06:46.721 --> 00:06:48.687
Now, another thing is the sensory issues.

00:06:48.711 --> 00:06:52.003
I was really concerned about having
to wear this gadget on my face.

00:06:52.390 --> 00:06:54.544
And I came in half an hour beforehand

00:06:54.568 --> 00:06:57.551
so I could have it put on
and kind of get used to it,

00:06:57.575 --> 00:07:00.313
and they got it bent
so it's not hitting my chin.

00:07:00.337 --> 00:07:01.489
But sensory is an issue.

00:07:01.513 --> 00:07:03.662
Some kids are bothered
by fluorescent lights;

00:07:03.686 --> 00:07:05.843
others have problems
with sound sensitivity.

00:07:06.195 --> 00:07:08.368
You know, it's going to be variable.

00:07:09.350 --> 00:07:12.770
Now, visual thinking gave me
a whole lot of insight

00:07:12.794 --> 00:07:15.054
into the animal mind.

00:07:15.078 --> 00:07:18.511
Because think about it:
an animal is a sensory-based thinker,

00:07:18.535 --> 00:07:24.732
not verbal -- thinks in pictures,
thinks in sounds, thinks in smells.

00:07:24.756 --> 00:07:28.100
Think about how much information
there is on the local fire hydrant.

00:07:28.124 --> 00:07:29.486
He knows who's been there --

00:07:29.510 --> 00:07:30.541
(Laughter)

00:07:30.565 --> 00:07:31.722
When they were there.

00:07:31.746 --> 00:07:34.641
Are they friend or foe?
Is there anybody he can go mate with?

00:07:34.665 --> 00:07:37.547
There's a ton of information
on that fire hydrant.

00:07:37.571 --> 00:07:40.357
It's all very detailed information.

00:07:40.694 --> 00:07:44.933
And looking at these kind of details
gave me a lot of insight into animals.

00:07:45.386 --> 00:07:48.934
Now, the animal mind, and also my mind,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:53.527
puts sensory-based information
into categories.

00:07:53.551 --> 00:07:55.254
Man on a horse,

00:07:55.278 --> 00:07:56.833
and a man on the ground --

00:07:56.857 --> 00:07:59.642
that is viewed as two
totally different things.

00:07:59.666 --> 00:08:02.165
You could have a horse
that's been abused by a rider.

00:08:02.189 --> 00:08:04.459
They'll be absolutely fine
with the veterinarian

00:08:04.483 --> 00:08:06.934
and with the horseshoer,
but you can't ride him.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:10.133
You have another horse,
where maybe the horseshoer beat him up,

00:08:10.157 --> 00:08:14.152
and he'll be terrible for anything
on the ground with the veterinarian,

00:08:14.176 --> 00:08:16.191
but a person can ride him.

00:08:16.215 --> 00:08:17.522
Cattle are the same way.

00:08:17.546 --> 00:08:21.471
Man on a horse, a man on foot --
they're two different things.

00:08:21.495 --> 00:08:23.451
You see, it's a different picture.

00:08:23.475 --> 00:08:26.596
See, I want you to think
about just how specific this is.

00:08:26.620 --> 00:08:30.007
Now, this ability to put
information into categories,

00:08:30.031 --> 00:08:33.383
I find a lot of people
are not very good at this.

00:08:33.407 --> 00:08:35.575
When I'm out troubleshooting equipment

00:08:35.599 --> 00:08:37.427
or problems with something in a plant,

00:08:37.451 --> 00:08:39.456
they don't seem to be able to figure out:

00:08:39.480 --> 00:08:41.180
"Do I have a training-people issue?

00:08:41.204 --> 00:08:43.639
Or do I have something wrong
with the equipment?"

00:08:43.663 --> 00:08:47.357
In other words, categorize
equipment problem from a people problem.

00:08:47.381 --> 00:08:50.477
I find a lot of people
have difficulty doing that.

00:08:50.501 --> 00:08:53.065
Now, let's say I figure out
it's an equipment problem.

00:08:53.089 --> 00:08:55.865
Is it a minor problem,
with something simple I can fix?

00:08:55.889 --> 00:08:58.204
Or is the whole design
of the system wrong?

00:08:58.228 --> 00:09:00.934
People have a hard time figuring that out.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.054
Let's just look at something
like, you know,

00:09:03.078 --> 00:09:05.324
solving problems with making
airlines safer.

00:09:05.348 --> 00:09:06.934
Yeah, I'm a million-mile flier.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.784
I do lots and lots of flying,

00:09:08.808 --> 00:09:12.040
and if I was at the FAA,

00:09:12.064 --> 00:09:15.586
what would I be doing a lot
of direct observation of?

00:09:16.155 --> 00:09:18.459
It would be their airplane tails.

00:09:18.483 --> 00:09:21.033
You know, five fatal wrecks
in the last 20 years,

00:09:21.057 --> 00:09:22.832
the tail either came off,

00:09:22.856 --> 00:09:26.290
or steering stuff inside the tail
broke in some way.

00:09:26.705 --> 00:09:28.758
It's tails, pure and simple.

00:09:28.782 --> 00:09:31.315
And when the pilots walk
around the plane, guess what?

00:09:31.339 --> 00:09:33.390
They can't see that stuff inside the tail.

00:09:33.414 --> 00:09:34.851
Now as I think about that,

00:09:34.875 --> 00:09:38.334
I'm pulling up all of that
specific information.

00:09:38.358 --> 00:09:39.531
It's specific.

00:09:39.555 --> 00:09:41.050
See, my thinking's bottom-up.

00:09:41.074 --> 00:09:44.771
I take all the little pieces and I put
the pieces together like a puzzle.

00:09:44.795 --> 00:09:48.562
Now, here is a horse that was deathly
afraid of black cowboy hats.

00:09:48.586 --> 00:09:51.146
He'd been abused by somebody
with a black cowboy hat.

00:09:51.170 --> 00:09:54.059
White cowboy hats,
that was absolutely fine.

00:09:54.554 --> 00:09:57.104
Now, the thing is,
the world is going to need

00:09:57.128 --> 00:10:01.217
all of the different kinds of minds
to work together.

00:10:01.241 --> 00:10:04.432
We've got to work on developing
all these different kinds of minds.

00:10:04.456 --> 00:10:06.998
And one of the things
that is driving me really crazy

00:10:07.022 --> 00:10:09.369
as I travel around
and I do autism meetings,

00:10:09.393 --> 00:10:12.534
is I'm seeing a lot of smart,
geeky, nerdy kids,

00:10:12.558 --> 00:10:14.733
and they just aren't very social,

00:10:14.757 --> 00:10:17.848
and nobody's working
on developing their interest

00:10:17.872 --> 00:10:19.247
in something like science.

00:10:19.624 --> 00:10:22.311
And this brings up the whole thing
of my science teacher.

00:10:22.335 --> 00:10:25.443
My science teacher is shown
absolutely beautifully in the movie.

00:10:25.467 --> 00:10:27.953
I was a goofball student
when I was in high school.

00:10:27.977 --> 00:10:30.005
I just didn't care at all about studying,

00:10:30.029 --> 00:10:33.258
until I had Mr. Carlock's science class.

00:10:33.282 --> 00:10:35.654
He was now Dr. Carlock in the movie.

00:10:36.055 --> 00:10:41.934
And he got me challenged
to figure out an optical illusion room.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.673
This brings up the whole thing
of you've got to show kids

00:10:44.697 --> 00:10:45.854
interesting stuff.

00:10:46.272 --> 00:10:49.585
You know, one of the things
that I think maybe TED ought to do

00:10:49.609 --> 00:10:52.924
is tell all the schools about all
the great lectures that are on TED,

00:10:52.948 --> 00:10:55.435
and there's all kinds
of great stuff on the Internet

00:10:55.459 --> 00:10:56.831
to get these kids turned on.

00:10:56.855 --> 00:10:59.341
Because I'm seeing a lot
of these geeky, nerdy kids,

00:10:59.365 --> 00:11:02.549
and the teachers out in the Midwest
and other parts of the country

00:11:02.573 --> 00:11:04.511
when you get away from these tech areas,

00:11:04.535 --> 00:11:06.547
they don't know what to do
with these kids.

00:11:06.571 --> 00:11:08.592
And they're not going down the right path.

00:11:08.616 --> 00:11:10.398
The thing is, you can make a mind

00:11:10.422 --> 00:11:13.147
to be more of a thinking
and cognitive mind,

00:11:13.171 --> 00:11:15.646
or your mind can be wired
to be more social.

00:11:15.670 --> 00:11:18.301
And what some of the research
now has shown in autism

00:11:18.325 --> 00:11:21.795
is there may by extra wiring back here
in the really brilliant mind,

00:11:21.819 --> 00:11:23.732
and we lose a few social circuits here.

00:11:23.756 --> 00:11:26.707
It's kind of a trade-off
between thinking and social.

00:11:26.731 --> 00:11:29.323
And then you can get to the point
where it's so severe,

00:11:29.347 --> 00:11:32.203
you're going to have a person
that's going to be non-verbal.

00:11:32.227 --> 00:11:33.934
In the normal human mind,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:37.580
language covers up the visual thinking
we share with animals.

00:11:37.604 --> 00:11:40.295
This is the work of Dr. Bruce Miller.

00:11:41.454 --> 00:11:45.186
He studied Alzheimer's patients
that had frontal temporal lobe dementia.

00:11:45.210 --> 00:11:48.233
And the dementia ate out
the language parts of the brain.

00:11:48.257 --> 00:11:50.528
And then this artwork came out of somebody

00:11:50.552 --> 00:11:52.520
who used to install stereos in cars.

00:11:53.525 --> 00:11:57.191
Now, Van Gogh doesn't know
anything about physics,

00:11:57.215 --> 00:12:00.536
but I think it's very interesting
that there was some work done

00:12:00.560 --> 00:12:03.283
to show that this eddy pattern
in this painting

00:12:03.307 --> 00:12:06.455
followed a statistical model
of turbulence,

00:12:06.479 --> 00:12:08.498
which brings up the whole interesting idea

00:12:08.522 --> 00:12:12.260
of maybe some of this mathematical
patterns is in our own head.

00:12:12.284 --> 00:12:13.837
And the Wolfram stuff --

00:12:13.861 --> 00:12:18.427
I was taking notes and writing down
all the search words I could use,

00:12:18.451 --> 00:12:21.778
because I think that's going to go on
in my autism lectures.

00:12:21.802 --> 00:12:24.229
We've got to show
these kids interesting stuff.

00:12:24.253 --> 00:12:26.520
And they've taken out the auto-shop class

00:12:26.544 --> 00:12:28.644
and the drafting class and the art class.

00:12:28.668 --> 00:12:30.934
I mean, art was my best subject in school.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.817
We've got to think about all
these different kinds of minds,

00:12:33.841 --> 00:12:36.621
and we've got to absolutely
work with these kind of minds,

00:12:36.645 --> 00:12:38.933
because we absolutely are going to need

00:12:38.957 --> 00:12:41.478
these kinds of people in the future.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.737
And let's talk about jobs.

00:12:44.222 --> 00:12:46.415
OK, my science teacher got me studying,

00:12:46.439 --> 00:12:48.853
because I was a goofball
that didn't want to study.

00:12:48.877 --> 00:12:51.222
But you know what?
I was getting work experience.

00:12:51.246 --> 00:12:54.710
I'm seeing too many of these smart kids
who haven't learned basic things,

00:12:54.734 --> 00:12:58.182
like how to be on time -- I was taught
that when I was eight years old.

00:12:58.206 --> 00:13:00.761
How to have table manners
at granny's Sunday party.

00:13:00.785 --> 00:13:02.970
I was taught that
when I was very, very young.

00:13:03.444 --> 00:13:08.421
And when I was 13, I had a job
at a dressmaker's shop sewing clothes.

00:13:08.445 --> 00:13:11.033
I did internships in college,

00:13:11.057 --> 00:13:14.260
I was building things,

00:13:14.284 --> 00:13:17.301
and I also had to learn
how to do assignments.

00:13:17.325 --> 00:13:20.915
You know, all I wanted to do was draw
pictures of horses when I was little.

00:13:20.939 --> 00:13:23.767
My mother said, "Well let's do
a picture of something else."

00:13:23.791 --> 00:13:25.955
They've got to learn
how to do something else.

00:13:25.979 --> 00:13:27.823
Let's say the kid is fixated on Legos.

00:13:27.847 --> 00:13:30.544
Let's get him working
on building different things.

00:13:30.568 --> 00:13:34.164
The thing about the autistic mind
is it tends to be fixated.

00:13:34.188 --> 00:13:38.066
Like if the kid loves race cars,
let's use race cars for math.

00:13:38.090 --> 00:13:41.530
Let's figure out how long it takes
a race car to go a certain distance.

00:13:41.554 --> 00:13:44.667
In other words, use that fixation

00:13:44.691 --> 00:13:48.547
in order to motivate that kid,
that's one of the things we need to do.

00:13:48.571 --> 00:13:51.659
I really get fed up when the teachers,

00:13:51.683 --> 00:13:54.485
especially when you get away
from this part of the country,

00:13:54.509 --> 00:13:56.889
they don't know what to do
with these smart kids.

00:13:56.913 --> 00:13:58.076
It just drives me crazy.

00:13:58.100 --> 00:14:00.342
What can visual thinkers
do when they grow up?

00:14:00.366 --> 00:14:03.315
They can do graphic design,
all kinds of stuff with computers,

00:14:03.339 --> 00:14:06.722
photography, industrial design.

00:14:08.341 --> 00:14:12.273
The pattern thinkers -- they're the ones
that are going to be your mathematicians,

00:14:12.297 --> 00:14:14.804
your software engineers,
your computer programmers,

00:14:14.828 --> 00:14:16.791
all of those kinds of jobs.

00:14:16.815 --> 00:14:20.387
And then you've got the word minds;
they make great journalists,

00:14:20.411 --> 00:14:22.934
and they also make really,
really good stage actors.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.350
Because the thing about being autistic is,

00:14:25.374 --> 00:14:28.205
I had to learn social skills
like being in a play.

00:14:28.229 --> 00:14:30.602
You just kind of ...
you just have to learn it.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.934
And we need to be working
with these students.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.066
And this brings up mentors.

00:14:36.090 --> 00:14:39.190
You know, my science teacher
was not an accredited teacher.

00:14:39.214 --> 00:14:40.934
He was a NASA space scientist.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.362
Some states now are getting it to where,
if you have a degree in biology

00:14:44.386 --> 00:14:45.657
or in chemistry,

00:14:45.681 --> 00:14:48.518
you can come into the school
and teach biology or chemistry.

00:14:48.542 --> 00:14:50.068
We need to be doing that.

00:14:50.498 --> 00:14:52.288
Because what I'm observing is,

00:14:52.312 --> 00:14:54.361
the good teachers,
for a lot of these kids,

00:14:54.385 --> 00:14:56.033
are out in the community colleges.

00:14:56.057 --> 00:14:58.593
But we need to be getting
some of these good teachers

00:14:58.617 --> 00:14:59.768
into the high schools.

00:14:59.792 --> 00:15:03.348
Another thing that can be very,
very, very successful is:

00:15:03.372 --> 00:15:05.480
there's a lot of people
that may have retired

00:15:05.504 --> 00:15:07.326
from working in the software industry,

00:15:07.350 --> 00:15:08.738
and they can teach your kid.

00:15:08.762 --> 00:15:11.571
And it doesn't matter
if what they teach them is old,

00:15:11.595 --> 00:15:14.322
because what you're doing
is you're lighting the spark.

00:15:14.346 --> 00:15:16.810
You're getting that kid turned on.

00:15:16.834 --> 00:15:20.249
And you get him turned on,
then you'll learn all the new stuff.

00:15:20.273 --> 00:15:22.537
Mentors are just essential.

00:15:22.561 --> 00:15:26.294
I cannot emphasize enough
what my science teacher did for me.

00:15:26.902 --> 00:15:29.934
And we've got to mentor them, hire them.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.766
And if you bring them in
for internships in your companies,

00:15:32.790 --> 00:15:35.263
the thing about the autism,
Asperger-y kind of mind,

00:15:35.287 --> 00:15:37.255
you've got to give them a specific task.

00:15:37.279 --> 00:15:39.121
Don't just say, "Design new software."

00:15:39.145 --> 00:15:41.412
You've got to tell them
something more specific:

00:15:41.436 --> 00:15:43.333
"We're designing software for a phone

00:15:43.357 --> 00:15:45.157
and it has to do some specific thing,

00:15:45.181 --> 00:15:46.934
and it can only use so much memory."

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.385
That's the kind of specificity you need.

00:15:49.409 --> 00:15:51.268
Well, that's the end of my talk.

00:15:51.292 --> 00:15:53.535
And I just want to thank
everybody for coming.

00:15:53.559 --> 00:15:54.934
It was great to be here.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:16:01.958
(Applause)

00:16:06.484 --> 00:16:08.675
(Applause ends)

00:16:08.699 --> 00:16:10.524
Oh -- you have a question for me? OK.

00:16:10.548 --> 00:16:12.945
(Applause)

00:16:12.969 --> 00:16:14.997
Chris Anderson:
Thank you so much for that.

00:16:15.021 --> 00:16:17.347
You know, you once wrote --
I like this quote:

00:16:17.371 --> 00:16:21.932
"If by some magic, autism had been
eradicated from the face of the Earth,

00:16:21.956 --> 00:16:24.933
then men would still be socializing
in front of a wood fire

00:16:24.957 --> 00:16:26.298
at the entrance to a cave."

00:16:26.322 --> 00:16:27.350
(Laughter)

00:16:27.374 --> 00:16:30.610
Temple Grandin: Because who do you think
made the first stone spear?

00:16:30.634 --> 00:16:31.792
It was the Asperger guy,

00:16:31.816 --> 00:16:34.369
and if you were to get rid
of all the autism genetics,

00:16:34.393 --> 00:16:38.058
there'd be no more Silicon Valley,
and the energy crisis would not be solved.

00:16:38.082 --> 00:16:39.423
(Applause)

00:16:39.447 --> 00:16:41.677
CA: I want to ask you
a couple other questions,

00:16:41.701 --> 00:16:45.465
and if any of these feel inappropriate,
it's OK just to say, "Next question."

00:16:45.489 --> 00:16:49.103
But if there is someone here
who has an autistic child,

00:16:49.127 --> 00:16:53.868
or knows an autistic child and feels
kind of cut off from them,

00:16:54.491 --> 00:16:56.338
what advice would you give them?

00:16:56.362 --> 00:16:58.691
TG: Well, first of all,
we've got to look at age.

00:16:58.715 --> 00:17:02.664
If you have a two, three or four-year-old,
no speech, no social interaction,

00:17:02.688 --> 00:17:04.977
I can't emphasize enough: Don't wait.

00:17:05.001 --> 00:17:08.131
You need at least 20 hours a week
of one-to-one teaching.

00:17:08.310 --> 00:17:10.803
The thing is, autism comes
in different degrees.

00:17:10.827 --> 00:17:14.334
About half of the people on the spectrum
are not going to learn to talk,

00:17:14.358 --> 00:17:16.459
and they won't be working
in Silicon Valley.

00:17:16.483 --> 00:17:18.933
That would not be a reasonable
thing for them to do.

00:17:18.957 --> 00:17:22.034
But then you get these smart,
geeky kids with a touch of autism,

00:17:22.058 --> 00:17:24.538
and that's where you've got
to get them turned on

00:17:24.562 --> 00:17:26.051
with doing interesting things.

00:17:26.075 --> 00:17:29.090
I got social interaction
through shared interests --

00:17:29.114 --> 00:17:33.071
I rode horses with other kids,
I made model rockets with other kids,

00:17:33.095 --> 00:17:35.073
did electronics lab with other kids.

00:17:35.097 --> 00:17:39.348
And in the '60s, it was gluing mirrors
onto a rubber membrane on a speaker

00:17:39.372 --> 00:17:40.553
to make a light show.

00:17:40.577 --> 00:17:42.799
That was, like,
we considered that super cool.

00:17:42.823 --> 00:17:43.829

what they're most passionate about,

"My kids" or "My lover."

TG: I'm passionate
about that the things I do

00:18:07.799 --> 00:18:09.836
are going to make
the world a better place.

of an autistic child say,

because of your book

or one of your lectures,"

that makes me happy.

I worked with in the '80s;

I developed a really simple
scoring system for slaughter plants,

00:18:40.630 --> 00:18:43.379
We need a lot more of that,
and a lot less abstract stuff.

00:18:43.403 --> 00:18:44.554
CA: Totally.

that really astonished me

about was server farms.

TG: Well, the reason why I got really
excited when I read about that,

00:19:02.377 --> 00:19:04.033
it contains knowledge.

00:19:04.057 --> 00:19:05.715
It's libraries.

00:19:05.739 --> 00:19:09.258
And to me, knowledge is something
that is extremely valuable.

00:19:09.282 --> 00:19:12.398

now, our library got flooded.

00:19:12.422 --> 00:19:14.473
This is before the Internet
got really big.

00:19:14.497 --> 00:19:17.178
And I was really upset
about all the books being wrecked,

00:19:17.202 --> 00:19:19.178
because it was knowledge being destroyed.

And server farms, or data centers,

it's an absolute delight
to have you at TED.

Thank you so much.

TG: Well, thank you so much. Thank you.

title: How brains learn to see
transcript: If you are a blind child in India, you will very likely have to contend with at least two big pieces of bad news. The first bad news is that the chances of getting treatment are extremely slim to none, and that's because most of the blindness alleviation programs in the country are focused on adults, and there are very, very few hospitals that are actually equipped to treat children. In fact, if you were to be treated, you might well end up being treated by a person who has no medical credentials as this case from Rajasthan illustrates. This is a three-year-old orphan girl who had cataracts. So, her caretakers took her to the village medicine man, and instead of suggesting to the caretakers that the girl be taken to a hospital, the person decided to burn her abdomen with red-hot iron bars to drive out the demons. The second piece of bad news will be delivered to you by neuroscientists, who will tell you that if you are older than four or five years of age, that even if you have your eye corrected, the chances of your brain learning how to see are very, very slim — again, slim or none.So when I heard these two things, it troubled me deeply, both because of personal reasons and scientific reasons. So let me first start with the personal reason. It'll sound corny, but it's sincere. That's my son, Darius. As a new father, I have a qualitatively different sense of just how delicate babies are, what our obligations are towards them and how much love we can feel towards a child. I would move heaven and earth in order to get treatment for Darius, and for me to be told that there might be other Dariuses who are not getting treatment, that's just viscerally wrong. So that's the personal reason.Scientific reason is that this notion from neuroscience of critical periods — that if the brain is older than four or five years of age, it loses its ability to learn — that doesn't sit well with me, because I don't think that idea has been tested adequately. The birth of the idea is from David Hubel and Torsten Wiesel's work, two researchers who were at Harvard, and they got the Nobel Prize in 1981 for their studies of visual physiology, which are remarkably beautiful studies, but I believe some of their work has been extrapolated into the human domain prematurely. So, they did their work with kittens, with different kinds of deprivation regiments, and those studies, which date back to the '60s, are now being applied to human children.So I felt that I needed to do two things. One: provide care to children who are currently being deprived of treatment. That's the humanitarian mission. And the scientific mission would be to test the limits of visual plasticity. And these two missions, as you can tell, thread together perfectly. One adds to the other; in fact, one would be impossible without the other. So, to implement these twin missions, a few years ago, I launched Project Prakash. Prakash, as many of you know, is the Sanskrit word for light, and the idea is that in bringing light into the lives of children, we also have a chance of shedding light on some of the deepest mysteries of neuroscience. And the logo — even though it looks extremely Irish, it's actually derived from the Indian symbol of Diya, an earthen lamp. The Prakash, the overall effort has three components: outreach, to identify children in need of care; medical treatment; and in subsequent study. And I want to show you a short video clip that illustrates the first two components of this work.This is an outreach station conducted at a school for the blind.(Text: Most of the children are profoundly and permanently blind ...)Pawan Sinha: So, because this is a school for the blind, many children have permanent conditions. That's a case of microphthalmos, which is malformed eyes, and that's a permanent condition; it cannot be treated. That's an extreme of micropthalmos called enophthalmos. But, every so often, we come across children who show some residual vision, and that is a very good sign that the condition might actually be treatable. So, after that screening, we bring the children to the hospital. That's the hospital we're working with in Delhi, the Schroff Charity Eye Hospital. It has a very well-equipped pediatric ophthalmic center, which was made possible in part by a gift from the Ronald McDonald charity. So, eating burgers actually helps.(Text: Such examinations allow us to improve eye-health in many children, and ... ... help us find children who can participate in Project Prakash.)PS: So, as I zoom in to the eyes of this child, you will see the cause of his blindness. The whites that you see in the middle of his pupils are congenital cataracts, so opacities of the lens. In our eyes, the lens is clear, but in this child, the lens has become opaque, and therefore he can't see the world. So, the child is given treatment. You'll see shots of the eye. Here's the eye with the opaque lens, the opaque lens extracted and an acrylic lens inserted. And here's the same child three weeks post-operation, with the right eye open.(Applause)Thank you.So, even from that little clip, you can begin to get the sense that recovery is possible, and we have now provided treatment to over 200 children, and the story repeats itself. After treatment, the child gains significant functionality. In fact, the story holds true even if you have a person who got sight after several years of deprivation. We did a paper a few years ago about this woman that you see on the right, SRD, and she got her sight late in life, and her vision is remarkable at this age. I should add a tragic postscript to this — she died two years ago in a bus accident. So, hers is just a truly inspiring story — unknown, but inspiring story. So when we started finding these results, as you might imagine, it created quite a bit of stir in the scientific and the popular press. Here's an article in Nature that profiled this work, and another one in Time. So, we were fairly convinced — we are convinced — that recovery is feasible, despite extended visual deprivation.The next obvious question to ask: What is the process of recovery? So, the way we study that is, let's say we find a child who has light sensitivity. The child is provided treatment, and I want to stress that the treatment is completely unconditional; there is no quid pro quo. We treat many more children then we actually work with. Every child who needs treatment is treated. After treatment, about every week, we run the child on a battery of simple visual tests in order to see how their visual skills are coming on line. And we try to do this for as long as possible. This arc of development gives us unprecedented and extremely valuable information about how the scaffolding of vision gets set up. What might be the causal connections between the early developing skills and the later developing ones?And we've used this general approach to study many different visual proficiencies, but I want to highlight one particular one, and that is image parsing into objects. So, any image of the kind that you see on the left, be it a real image or a synthetic image, it's made up of little regions that you see in the middle column, regions of different colors, different luminances. The brain has this complex task of putting together, integrating, subsets of these regions into something that's more meaningful, into what we would consider to be objects, as you see on the right. And nobody knows how this integration happens, and that's the question we asked with Project Prakash.So, here's what happens very soon after the onset of sight. Here's a person who had gained sight just a couple of weeks ago, and you see Ethan Myers, a graduate student from MIT, running the experiment with him. His visual-motor coordination is quite poor, but you get a general sense of what are the regions that he's trying to trace out. If you show him real world images, if you show others like him real world images, they are unable to recognize most of the objects because the world to them is over-fragmented; it's made up of a collage, a patchwork, of regions of different colors and luminances. And that's what's indicated in the green outlines. When you ask them, "Even if you can't name the objects, just point to where the objects are," these are the regions that they point to. So the world is this complex patchwork of regions. Even the shadow on the ball becomes its own object. Interestingly enough, you give them a few months, and this is what happens.Doctor: How many are these?Patient: These are two things.Doctor: What are their shapes?Patient: Their shapes ... This one is a circle, and this is a square.PS: A very dramatic transformation has come about. And the question is: What underlies this transformation? It's a profound question, and what's even more amazing is how simple the answer is. The answer lies in motion and that's what I want to show you in the next clip.Doctor: What shape do you see here?Patient: I can't make it out.Doctor: Now?Patient: Triangle.Doctor: How many things are these? Now, how many things are these?Patient: Two.Doctor: What are these things?Patient: A square and a circle.PS: And we see this pattern over and over again. The one thing the visual system needs in order to begin parsing the world is dynamic information. So the inference we are deriving from this, and several such experiments, is that dynamic information processing, or motion processing, serves as the bedrock for building the rest of the complexity of visual processing; it leads to visual integration and eventually to recognition.This simple idea has far reaching implications. And let me just quickly mention two, one, drawing from the domain of engineering, and one from the clinic. So, from the perspective of engineering, we can ask: Goven that we know that motion is so important for the human visual system, can we use this as a recipe for constructing machine-based vision systems that can learn on their own, that don't need to be programmed by a human programmer? And that's what we're trying to do.I'm at MIT, at MIT you need to apply whatever basic knowledge you gain. So we are creating Dylan, which is a computational system with an ambitious goal of taking in visual inputs of the same kind that a human child would receive, and autonomously discovering: What are the objects in this visual input? So, don't worry about the internals of Dylan. Here, I'm just going to talk about how we test Dylan. The way we test Dylan is by giving it inputs, as I said, of the same kind that a baby, or a child in Project Prakash would get. But for a long time we couldn't quite figure out: Wow can we get these kinds of video inputs? So, I thought, could we have Darius serve as our babycam carrier, and that way get the inputs that we feed into Dylan? So that's what we did. (Laughter) I had to have long conversations with my wife. (Laughter) In fact, Pam, if you're watching this, please forgive me.So, we modified the optics of the camera in order to mimic the baby's visual acuity. As some of you might know, babyies are born pretty much legally blind. Their acuity — our acuity is 20/20; babies' acuity is like 20/800, so they are looking at the world in a very, very blurry fashion. Here's what a baby-cam video looks like.(Laughter) (Applause)Thankfully, there isn't any audio to go with this. What's amazing is that working with such highly degraded input, the baby, very quickly, is able to discover meaning in such input. But then two or three days afterward, babies begin to pay attention to their mother's or their father's face. How does that happen? We want Dylan to be able to do that, and using this mantra of motion, Dylan actually can do that. So, given that kind of video input, with just about six or seven minutes worth of video, Dylan can begin to extract patterns that include faces. So, it's an important demonstration of the power of motion.The clinical implication, it comes from the domain of autism. Visual integration has been associated with autism by several researchers. When we saw that, we asked: Could the impairment in visual integration be the manifestation of something underneath, of dynamic information processing deficiencies in autism? Because, if that hypothesis were to be true, it would have massive repercussions in our understanding of what's causing the many different aspects of the autism phenotype.What you're going to see are video clips of two children — one neurotypical, one with autism, playing Pong. So, while the child is playing Pong, we are tracking where they're looking. In red are the eye movement traces. This is the neurotypical child, and what you see is that the child is able to make cues of the dynamic information to predict where the ball is going to go. Even before the ball gets to a place, the child is already looking there. Contrast this with a child with autism playing the same game. Instead of anticipating, the child always follows where the ball has been. The efficiency of the use of dynamic information seems to be significantly compromised in autism. So we are pursuing this line of work and hopefully we'll have more results to report soon.Looking ahead, if you think of this disk as representing all of the children we've treated so far, this is the magnitude of the problem. The red dots are the children we have not treated. So, there are many, many more children who need to be treated, and in order to expand the scope of the project, we are planning on launching The Prakash Center for Children, which will have a dedicated pediatric hospital, a school for the children we are treating and also a cutting-edge research facility. The Prakash Center will integrate health care, education and research in a way that truly creates the whole to be greater than the sum of the parts.So, to summarize: Prakash, in its five years of existence, it's had an impact in multiple areas, ranging from basic neuroscience plasticity and learning in the brain, to clinically relevant hypotheses like in autism, the development of autonomous machine vision systems, education of the undergraduate and graduate students, and most importantly in the alleviation of childhood blindness. And for my students and I, it's been just a phenomenal experience because we have gotten to do interesting research, while at the same time helping the many children that we have worked with.Thank you very much.(Applause)
