00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
... help us find children who can participate in Project Prakash.)

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
PS: So, as I zoom in to the eyes of this child,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
you will see the cause of his blindness.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
The whites that you see in the middle of his pupils

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
are congenital cataracts,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
so opacities of the lens.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
In our eyes, the lens is clear,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
but in this child, the lens has become opaque,

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
and therefore he can't see the world.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
So, the child is given treatment. You'll see shots of the eye.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
Here's the eye with the opaque lens,

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
the opaque lens extracted

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
and an acrylic lens inserted.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
And here's the same child

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
three weeks post-operation,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
with the right eye open.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:42.958
(Applause)

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
Thank you.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
So, even from that little clip, you can begin to get the sense

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
that recovery is possible,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
and we have now

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
provided treatment to over 200 children,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
and the story repeats itself.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
After treatment, the child

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
gains significant functionality.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
In fact, the story holds true

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
even if you have a person who got sight

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
after several years of deprivation.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
We did a paper a few years ago

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:14.958
about this woman that you see on the right, SRD,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
and she got her sight late in life,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:20.958
and her vision is remarkable at this age.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
I should add a tragic postscript to this --

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
she died two years ago

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
in a bus accident.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:31.958
So, hers is just a truly inspiring story --

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
unknown, but inspiring story.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
So when we started finding these results,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
as you might imagine, it created quite a bit of stir

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
in the scientific and the popular press.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Here's an article in Nature

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
that profiled this work,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
and another one in Time.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
So, we were fairly convinced -- we are convinced --

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
that recovery is feasible,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
despite extended visual deprivation.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
The next obvious question to ask:

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
What is the process of recovery?

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
So, the way we study that is,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
let's say we find a child who has light sensitivity.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
The child is provided treatment,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
and I want to stress that the treatment

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
is completely unconditional;

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
there is no quid pro quo.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
We treat many more children then we actually work with.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
Every child who needs treatment is treated.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
After treatment, about every week,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
we run the child

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
on a battery of simple visual tests

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
in order to see how their visual skills

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
are coming on line.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
And we try to do this for as long as possible.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
This arc of development

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
gives us unprecedented

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and extremely valuable information

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
about how the scaffolding of vision

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
gets set up.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
What might be the causal connections

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
between the early developing skills

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
and the later developing ones?

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
And we've used this general approach to study

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
many different visual proficiencies,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:58.958
but I want to highlight one particular one,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
and that is image parsing into objects.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
So, any image of the kind that you see on the left,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
be it a real image or a synthetic image,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
it's made up of little regions

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
that you see in the middle column,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
regions of different colors, different luminances.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
The brain has this complex task

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
of putting together, integrating,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
subsets of these regions

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
into something that's more meaningful,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
into what we would consider to be objects,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
as you see on the right.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
And nobody knows how this integration happens,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
and that's the question we asked with Project Prakash.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
So, here's what happens

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
very soon after the onset of sight.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
Here's a person who had gained sight just a couple of weeks ago,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
and you see Ethan Myers, a graduate student from MIT,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
running the experiment with him.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
His visual-motor coordination is quite poor,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
but you get a general sense

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
of what are the regions that he's trying to trace out.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
If you show him real world images,

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
if you show others like him real world images,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
they are unable to recognize most of the objects

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
because the world to them is over-fragmented;

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
it's made up of a collage, a patchwork,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
of regions of different colors and luminances.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
And that's what's indicated in the green outlines.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
When you ask them,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
"Even if you can't name the objects, just point to where the objects are,"

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
these are the regions that they point to.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
So the world is this complex

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
patchwork of regions.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
Even the shadow on the ball

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
becomes its own object.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
Interestingly enough,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
you give them a few months,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
and this is what happens.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
Doctor: How many are these?

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
Patient: These are two things.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
Doctor: What are their shapes?

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
Patient: Their shapes ...

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
This one is a circle,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and this

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
is a square.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
PS: A very dramatic transformation has come about.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
And the question is:

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
What underlies this transformation?

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
It's a profound question,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
and what's even more amazing is how simple

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
the answer is.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
The answer lies in motion

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
and that's what I want to show you in the next clip.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
Doctor: What shape do you see here?

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
Patient: I can't make it out.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
Doctor: Now?

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
Patient: Triangle.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
Doctor: How many things are these?

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
Now, how many things are these?

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
Patient: Two.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
Doctor: What are these things?

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
Patient: A square and a circle.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
PS: And we see this pattern over and over again.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
The one thing the visual system needs

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
in order to begin parsing the world

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
is dynamic information.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
So the inference we are deriving from this,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and several such experiments,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
is that dynamic information processing,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
or motion processing,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
serves as the bedrock for building

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:18.958
the rest of the complexity of visual processing;

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
it leads to visual integration

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and eventually to recognition.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
This simple idea has far reaching implications.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
And let me just quickly mention two,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
one, drawing from the domain of engineering,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
and one from the clinic.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
So, from the perspective of engineering,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
we can ask: Goven that we know

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
that motion is so important for the human visual system,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
can we use this as a recipe

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
for constructing machine-based vision systems

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
that can learn on their own, that don't need to be programmed

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
by a human programmer?

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
And that's what we're trying to do.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
I'm at MIT, at MIT you need to apply

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
whatever basic knowledge you gain.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
So we are creating Dylan,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
which is a computational system

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
with an ambitious goal

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
of taking in visual inputs

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
of the same kind that a human child would receive,

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
and autonomously discovering:

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
What are the objects in this visual input?

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
So, don't worry about the internals of Dylan.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
Here, I'm just going to talk about

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
how we test Dylan.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
The way we test Dylan is by giving it

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
inputs, as I said, of the same kind

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
that a baby, or a child in Project Prakash would get.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
But for a long time we couldn't quite figure out:

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
Wow can we get these kinds of video inputs?

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
So, I thought,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
could we have Darius

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
serve as our babycam carrier,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
and that way get the inputs that we feed into Dylan?

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
So that's what we did.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:56.958
(Laughter)

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
I had to have long conversations with my wife.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:04.958
(Laughter)

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
In fact, Pam, if you're watching this,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
please forgive me.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:13.958
So, we modified the optics of the camera

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
in order to mimic the baby's visual acuity.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
As some of you might know,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
babyies are born pretty much legally blind.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
Their acuity -- our acuity is 20/20;

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
babies' acuity is like 20/800,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
so they are looking at the world

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
in a very, very blurry fashion.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
Here's what a baby-cam video looks like.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:46.958
(Laughter)

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
(Applause)

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
Thankfully, there isn't any audio

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
to go with this.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
What's amazing is that working with such

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
highly degraded input,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
the baby, very quickly, is able

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
to discover meaning in such input.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
But then two or three days afterward,

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
babies begin to pay attention

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
to their mother's or their father's face.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
How does that happen? We want Dylan to be able to do that,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
and using this mantra of motion,

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
Dylan actually can do that.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
So, given that kind of video input,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
with just about six or seven minutes worth of video,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
Dylan can begin to extract patterns

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
that include faces.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
So, it's an important demonstration

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
of the power of motion.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
The clinical implication, it comes from the domain of autism.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
Visual integration has been associated with autism

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
by several researchers.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
When we saw that, we asked:

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
Could the impairment in visual integration

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
be the manifestation of something underneath,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
of dynamic information processing deficiencies in autism?

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
Because, if that hypothesis were to be true,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
it would have massive repercussions in our understanding

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
of what's causing the many different aspects

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
of the autism phenotype.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
What you're going to see are

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
video clips of two children -- one neurotypical,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
one with autism, playing Pong.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
So, while the child is playing Pong, we are tracking where they're looking.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
In red are the eye movement traces.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
This is the neurotypical child, and what you see

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
is that the child is able to make cues

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
of the dynamic information

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
to predict where the ball is going to go.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
Even before the ball gets to a place,

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
the child is already looking there.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
Contrast this with a child

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
with autism playing the same game.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
Instead of anticipating,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
the child always follows where the ball has been.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
The efficiency of the use

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
of dynamic information

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
seems to be significantly compromised in autism.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
So we are pursuing this line of work

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
and hopefully we'll have

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
more results to report soon.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
Looking ahead, if you think of this disk

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
as representing all of the children

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
we've treated so far,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
this is the magnitude of the problem.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
The red dots are the children we have not treated.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
So, there are many, many more children who need to be treated,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
and in order to expand the scope of the project,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
we are planning on launching

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
The Prakash Center for Children,

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
which will have a dedicated pediatric hospital,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
a school for the children we are treating

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
and also a cutting-edge research facility.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
The Prakash Center will integrate health care,

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:27.958
education and research in a way

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
that truly creates the whole

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.958
to be greater than the sum of the parts.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
So, to summarize: Prakash, in its five years of existence,

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
it's had an impact in multiple areas,

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
ranging from basic neuroscience

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:42.958
plasticity and learning in the brain,

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:46.958
to clinically relevant hypotheses like in autism,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
the development of autonomous machine vision systems,

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
education of the undergraduate and graduate students,

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
and most importantly in the alleviation

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:56.958
of childhood blindness.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:58.958
And for my students and I, it's been

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:00.958
just a phenomenal experience

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:04.958
because we have gotten to do interesting research,

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
while at the same time

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
helping the many children that we have worked with.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
Thank you very much.

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:12.958
(Applause)

title: My 5 lives as an artist
transcript: I think it was in my second grade that I was caught drawing the bust of a nude by Michelangelo. I was sent straight away to my school principal, and my school principal, a sweet nun, looked at my book with disgust, flipped through the pages, saw all the nudes — you know, I'd been seeing my mother draw nudes and I'd copy her — and the nun slapped me on my face and said, "Sweet Jesus, this kid has already begun."I had no clue what she was talking about, but it was convincing enough for me never to draw again until the ninth grade. Thanks to a really boring lecture, I started caricaturing my teachers in school. And, you know, I got a lot of popularity. I don't play sports. I'm really bad at sports. I don't have the fanciest gadgets at home. I'm not on top of the class. So for me, cartooning gave me a sense of identity. I got popular, but I was scared I'd get caught again. So what I did was I quickly put together a collage of all the teachers I had drawn, glorified my school principal, put him right on top, and gifted it to him. He had a good laugh at the other teachers and put it up on the notice board. (Laughter) This is a part of that. And I became a school hero. All my seniors knew me. I felt really special.I have to tell you a little bit about my family. That's my mother. I love her to bits. She's the one who taught me how to draw and, more importantly, how to love. She's a bit of a hippie. She said, "Don't say that," but I'm saying it anyway. The rest of my family are boring academics, busy collecting Ivy League decals for our classic Ambassador car. My father's a little different. My father believed in a holistic approach to living, and, you know, every time he taught us, he'd say, "I hate these books, because these books are hijacked by Industrial Revolution."While he still held that worldview, I was 16, I got the best lawyer in town, my older brother Karthik, and I sat him down, and I said, "Pa, from today onwards I've decided I'm going to be disciplined, I'm going to be curious, I'm going to learn something new every day, I'm going to be very hard working, and I'm not going to depend on you emotionally or financially." And he was very impressed. He was all tearing up. Ready to hug me. And I said, "Hold that thought." I said, "Can I quit school then?"But, to cut a long story short, I quit school to pursue a career as a cartoonist. I must have done about 30,000 caricatures. I would do birthday parties, weddings, divorces, anything for anyone who wanted to use my services. But, most importantly, while I was traveling, I taught children cartooning, and in exchange, I learned how to be spontaneous. And mad and crazy and fun. When I started teaching them, I said let me start doing this professionally. When I was 18 I started my own school. However, an 18 year-old trying to start a school is not easy unless you have a big patron or a big supporter.So I was flipping through the pages of the Times of India when I saw that the Prime Minister of India was visiting my home town, Bangalore. And, you know, just like how every cartoonist knows Bush here, and if you had to meet Bush, it would be the funnest thing because his face was a cartoonist's delight. I had to meet my Prime Minister. I went to the place where his helicopter was about to land. I saw layers of security. I caricatured my way through three layers by just impressing the guards, but I got stuck. I got stuck at the third. And what happened was, to my luck, I saw a nuclear scientist at whose party I had done cartoons. I ran up to him, and said, "Hello, sir. How do you do?" He said, "What are you doing here, Raghava?" I said, "I'm here to meet the Prime Minister." He said, "Oh, so am I." I hopped into his car, and off we went through the remaining layers of security. (Applause) Thank you. I sat him down, I caricatured him, and since then I've caricatured hundreds of celebrities.This is one I remember fondly. Salman Rushdie was pissed-off I think because I altered the map of New York, if you notice. (Laughter) Anyway, the next slide I'm about to show you — (Laughter) Should I just turn that off? The next slide I'm about to show you, is a little more serious. I was hesitant to include this in my presentation because this cartoon was published soon after 9/11. What was, for me, a very naive observation, turned out to be a disaster. That evening, I came home to hundreds of hate mails, hundreds of people telling me how they could have lived another day without seeing this. I was also asked to leave the organization, a cartoonists' organization in America, that for me was my lifeline. That's when I realized, you know, cartoons are really powerful, art comes with responsibility.Anyway, what I did was I decided that I need to take a break. I quit my job at the papers, I closed my school, and I wrapped up my pencils and my brushes and inks, and I decided to go traveling. When I went traveling, I remember, I met this fabulous old man, who I met when I was caricaturing, who turned out to be an artist, in Italy. He invited me to his studio. He said, "Come and visit." When I went, I saw the ghastliest thing ever. I saw this dead, naked effigy of himself hanging from the ceiling. I said, "Oh, my God. What is that?" And I asked him, and he said, "Oh, that thing? In the night, I die. In the morning, I am born again." I thought he was koo koo, but something about that really stuck. I loved it. I thought there was something really beautiful about that. So I said, "I am dead, so I need to be born again."So, I wanted to be a painter like him, except, I don't know how to paint. So, I tried going to the art store. You know, there are a hundred types of brushes. Forget it, they will confuse you even if you know how to draw. So I decided, I'm going to learn to paint by myself. I'm going to show you a very quick clip to show you how I painted and a little bit about my city, Bangalore. (Music) They had to be larger than life. Everything had to be larger. The next painting was even bigger. And even bigger. And for me it was, I had to dance while I painted. It was so exciting. Except, I even started painting dancers. Here for example is a Flamenco dancer, except there was one problem. I didn't know the dance form, so I started following them, and I made some money, sold my paintings and would rush off to France or Spain and work with them. That's Pepe Linares, the renowned Flamenco singer.But I had one problem, my paintings never danced. As much energy as I put into them while making them, they never danced. So I decided — I had this crazy epiphany at two in the morning. I called my friends, painted on their bodies, and had them dance in front of a painting. And, all of a sudden, my paintings came alive. And then I was fortunate enough to actually perform this in California with Velocity Circus. And I sat like you guys there in the audience. And I saw my work come alive. You know, normally you work in isolation, and you show at a gallery, but here, the work was coming alive, and it had some other artists working with me.The collaborative effort was fabulous. I said, I'm going to collaborate with anybody and everybody I meet. I started doing fashion. This is a fashion show we held in London. The best collaboration, of course, is with children. They are ruthless, they are honest, but they're full of energy and fun. This is a work, a library I designed for the Robin Hood Foundation. And I must say, I spent time in the Bronx working with these kids. And, in exchange for me working with them, they taught me how to be cool. I don't think I've succeeded, but they've taught me. They said, "Stop saying sorry. Say, my bad." (Laughter)Then I said, all this is good, but I want to paint like a real painter. American education is so expensive. I was in India, and I was walking down the streets, and I saw a billboard painter. And these guys paint humongous paintings, and they look really good. And I wondered how they did it from so close. So, one day I had the opportunity to meet one of these guys, and I said, "How do you paint like that? Who taught you?" And he said, "Oh, it's very easy. I can teach you, but we're leaving the city, because billboard painters are a dying, extinct bunch of artists, because digital printing has totally replaced them and hijacked them." I said, in exchange for education in how to paint, I will support them, and I started a company. And since then, I've been painting all over the place. This is a painting I did of my wife in my apartment. This is another painting. And, in fact, I started painting on anything, and started sending them around town.Since I mentioned my wife, the most important collaboration has been with her, Netra. Netra and I met when she was 18. I must have been 19 and a half then, and it was love at first sight. I lived in India. She lived in America. She'd come every two months to visit me, and then I said I'm the man, I'm the man, and I have to reciprocate. I have to travel seven oceans, and I have to come and see you. I did that twice, and I went broke. So then I said, "Nets, what do I do?" She said, "Why don't you send me your paintings? My dad knows a bunch of rich guys. We'll try and con them into buying it, and then..." But it turned out, after I sent the works to her, that her dad's friends, like most of you, are geeks. I'm joking. (Laughter) No, they were really big geeks, and they didn't know much about art. So Netra was stuck with 30 paintings of mine.So what we did was we rented a little van and we drove all over the east coast trying to sell it. She contacted anyone and everyone who was willing to buy my work. She made enough money, she sold off the whole collection and made enough money to move me for four years with lawyers, a company, everything, and she became my manager. That's us in New York. Notice one thing, we're equal here. Something happened along the line. (Laughter)But this brought me — with Netra managing my career — it brought me a lot of success. I was really happy. I thought of myself as a bit of a rockstar. I loved the attention. This is all the press we got, and we said, it's time to celebrate. And I said that the best way to celebrate is to marry Netra. I said, "Let's get married." And I said, "Not just married. Let's invite everyone who's helped us, all the people who bought our work." And you won't believe it, we put together a list of 7,000 people, who had made a difference — a ridiculous list, but I was determined to bring them to India, so — a lot of them were in India. 150 artists volunteered to help me with my wedding. We had fashion designers, installation artists, models, we had makeup artists, jewelry designers, all kinds of people working with me to make my wedding an art installation. And I had a special installation in tribute to my in-laws. I had the vegetable carvers work on that for me.But all this excitement led to the press writing about us. We were in the papers, we're still in the news three years later, but, unfortunately, something tragic happened right after. My mother fell very ill. I love my mother and I was told all of a sudden that she was going to die. And they said you have to say bye to her, you have to do what you have to do. And I was devastated. I had shows booked up for another year. I was on a high. And I couldn't. I could not.My life was not exuberant. I could not live this larger than life person. I started exploring the darker abscesses of the human mind. Of course, my work turned ugly, but another thing happened. I lost all my audiences. The Bollywood stars who I would party with and buy my work disappeared. The collectors, the friends, the press, everyone said, "Nice, but thank you." "No thank you," was more like it. But I wanted people to actually feel my work from their gut, because I was painting it from my gut. If they wanted beauty, I said, this is the beauty I'm willing to give you. It's politicized. Of course, none of them liked it.My works also turned autobiographical. At this point, something else happened. A very, very dear friend of mine came out of the closet, and in India at that time, it was illegal to be gay, and it's disgusting to see how people respond to a gay person. I was very upset. I remember the time when my mother used to dress me up as a little girl — that's me there — because she wanted a girl, and she has only boys. (Laughter) Anyway, I don't know what my friends are going to say after this talk. It's a secret.So, after this, my works turned a little violent. I talked about this masculinity that one need not perform. And I talked about the weakness of male sexuality. This time, not only did my collectors disappear, the political activists decided to ban me and to threaten me and to forbid me from showing. It turned nasty, and I'm a bit of a chicken. I can't deal with any threat. This was a big threat.So, I decided it was time to end and go back home. This time I said let's try something different. I need to be reborn again. And I thought the best way, as most of you know who have children, the best way to have a new lease on life, is to have a child. I decided to have a child, and before I did that, I quickly studied what can go wrong. How can a family get dysfunctional? And Rudra was born. That's my little son.And two magical things happened after he was born. My mother miraculously recovered after a serious operation, and this man was elected president of this country. You know I sat at home and I watched. I teared up and I said that's where I want to be. So Netra and I wound up our life, closed up everything we had, and we decided to move to New York. And this was just eight months ago.I moved back to New York, my work has changed. Everything about my work has become more whimsical. This one is called "What the Fuck Was I Thinking?" It talks about mental incest. You know, I may appear to be a very nice, clean, sweet boy. But I'm not. I'm capable of thinking anything. But I'm very civil in my action, I assure you. (Laughter) These are just different cartoons.And, before I go, I want to tell you a little story. I was talking to mother and father this morning, and my dad said, "I know you have so much you want to say, but you have to talk about your work with children." So I said, okay.I work with children all over the world, and that's an entirely different talk, but I want to leave you with one story that really, really inspired me. I met Belinda when she was 16. I was 17. I was in Australia, and Belinda had cancer, and I was told she's not going to live very long. They, in fact, told me three weeks. I walk into her room, and there was a shy girl, and she was bald, and she was trying to hide her baldness. I whipped out my pen, and I started drawing on her head and I drew a crown for her. And then, we started talking, and we spent a lovely time — I told her how I ended up in Australia, how I backpacked and who I conned, and how I got a ticket, and all the stories. And I drew it out for her. And then I left. Belinda died and within a few days of her death, they published a book for her, and she used my cartoon on the cover. And she wrote a little note, she said, "Hey Rags, thank you for the magic carpet ride around the world."For me, my art is my magic carpet ride. I hope you will join me in this magic carpet ride, and touch children and be honest. Thank you so much. (Applause)

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I think it was in my second grade that I was caught

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
drawing the bust of a nude by Michelangelo.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:20.958
I was sent straight away to my school principal,

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
and my school principal, a sweet nun,

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:26.958
looked at my book with disgust,

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
flipped through the pages, saw all the nudes --

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
you know, I'd been seeing my mother draw nudes and I'd copy her --

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
and the nun slapped me on my face and said,

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
"Sweet Jesus, this kid has already begun."

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
I had no clue what she was talking about,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:45.958
but it was convincing enough for me never to draw again

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
until the ninth grade.

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
Thanks to a really boring lecture,

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
I started caricaturing my teachers in school.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
And, you know, I got a lot of popularity.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
I don't play sports. I'm really bad at sports.

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:00.958
I don't have the fanciest gadgets at home.

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
I'm not on top of the class.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
So for me, cartooning gave me a sense of identity.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
I got popular, but I was scared I'd get caught again.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
So what I did was I quickly put together

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:14.958
a collage of all the teachers I had drawn,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
glorified my school principal, put him right on top,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
and gifted it to him.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
He had a good laugh at the other teachers

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:23.958
and put it up on the notice board.

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:25.958
(Laughter)

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
This is a part of that.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
And I became a school hero.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
All my seniors knew me. I felt really special.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
I have to tell you a little bit about my family.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.958
That's my mother. I love her to bits.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
She's the one who taught me how to draw and, more importantly, how to love.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
She's a bit of a hippie.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.958
She said, "Don't say that," but I'm saying it anyway.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
The rest of my family are boring academics,

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
busy collecting Ivy League decals for our classic Ambassador car.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
My father's a little different.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:58.958
My father believed in a holistic approach to living,

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
and, you know, every time he taught us,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
he'd say, "I hate these books,

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
because these books are hijacked by Industrial Revolution."

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:08.958
While he still held that worldview, I was 16,

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:10.958
I got the best lawyer in town,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
my older brother Karthik,

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
and I sat him down, and I said, "Pa,

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
from today onwards I've decided

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:18.958
I'm going to be disciplined,

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
I'm going to be curious,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
I'm going to learn something new every day,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
I'm going to be very hard working,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
and I'm not going to depend on you

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
emotionally or financially."

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
And he was very impressed. He was all tearing up. Ready to hug me.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
And I said, "Hold that thought."

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:36.958
I said, "Can I quit school then?"

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
But, to cut a long story short,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
I quit school to pursue a career as a cartoonist.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
I must have done about 30,000 caricatures.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:46.958
I would do birthday parties, weddings, divorces,

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
anything for anyone who wanted to use my services.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.958
But, most importantly, while I was traveling,

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
I taught children cartooning,

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
and in exchange, I learned how to be spontaneous.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:59.958
And mad and crazy and fun.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
When I started teaching them, I said let me start doing this professionally.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
When I was 18 I started my own school.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
However, an 18 year-old trying to start a school

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
is not easy unless you have a big patron

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
or a big supporter.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
So I was flipping through the pages of the Times of India

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
when I saw that the Prime Minister of India

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:21.958
was visiting my home town, Bangalore.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
And, you know, just like how

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
every cartoonist knows Bush here,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
and if you had to meet Bush,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.958
it would be the funnest thing because

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
his face was a cartoonist's delight.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
I had to meet my Prime Minister.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
I went to the place where

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
his helicopter was about to land.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
I saw layers of security.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
I caricatured my way through three layers

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
by just impressing the guards,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
but I got stuck. I got stuck at the third.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
And what happened was, to my luck,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
I saw a nuclear scientist

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
at whose party I had done cartoons.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
I ran up to him, and said, "Hello, sir. How do you do?"

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
He said, "What are you doing here, Raghava?"

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
I said, "I'm here to meet the Prime Minister."

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
He said, "Oh, so am I."

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
I hopped into his car, and off we went

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
through the remaining layers of security.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
(Applause)

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
Thank you.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
I sat him down, I caricatured him,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
and since then I've caricatured hundreds of celebrities.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
This is one I remember fondly.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
Salman Rushdie was pissed-off I think

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
because I altered the map of New York, if you notice.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:24.958
(Laughter)

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
Anyway, the next slide I'm about to show you --

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
(Laughter)

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Should I just turn that off?

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
The next slide I'm about to show you,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
is a little more serious.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
I was hesitant to include this in my presentation

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
because this cartoon was published

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
soon after 9/11.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
What was, for me, a very naive observation,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
turned out to be a disaster.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:52.958
That evening, I came home to hundreds of hate mails,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
hundreds of people telling me how they

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
could have lived another day without seeing this.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
I was also asked to leave the organization,

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
a cartoonists' organization in America,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
that for me was my lifeline.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
That's when I realized, you know, cartoons are really powerful,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
art comes with responsibility.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
Anyway, what I did was I decided

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
that I need to take a break.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
I quit my job at the papers, I closed my school,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
and I wrapped up my pencils and my brushes and inks,

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
and I decided to go traveling.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
When I went traveling, I remember,

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
I met this fabulous old man,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
who I met when I was caricaturing,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
who turned out to be an artist, in Italy.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
He invited me to his studio. He said, "Come and visit."

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
When I went, I saw the ghastliest thing ever.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
I saw this dead, naked effigy of himself

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
hanging from the ceiling.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
I said, "Oh, my God. What is that?"

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
And I asked him, and he said,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
"Oh, that thing? In the night, I die.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
In the morning, I am born again."

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
I thought he was koo koo,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
but something about that really stuck.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
I loved it. I thought there was something really beautiful about that.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
So I said, "I am dead, so I need to be born again."

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
So, I wanted to be a painter like him,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
except, I don't know how to paint.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
So, I tried going to the art store.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
You know, there are a hundred types of brushes.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
Forget it, they will confuse you

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
even if you know how to draw.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
So I decided, I'm going to learn to paint by myself.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
I'm going to show you a very quick clip

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
to show you how I painted and a little bit

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
about my city, Bangalore.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:53.958
(Music)

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
They had to be larger than life.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
Everything had to be larger. The next painting was even bigger.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
And even bigger.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
And for me it was, I had to dance while I painted.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
It was so exciting.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
Except, I even started painting dancers.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
Here for example is a Flamenco dancer,

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
except there was one problem.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
I didn't know the dance form, so I started following them,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
and I made some money,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
sold my paintings and would rush off

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
to France or Spain and work with them.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
That's Pepe Linares, the renowned Flamenco singer.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
But I had one problem, my paintings never danced.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
As much energy as I put into them

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
while making them, they never danced.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
So I decided -- I had this crazy epiphany at two in the morning.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
I called my friends, painted on their bodies,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
and had them dance in front of a painting.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
And, all of a sudden, my paintings came alive.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
And then I was fortunate enough

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
to actually perform this in California with Velocity Circus.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
And I sat like you guys there in the audience.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And I saw my work come alive.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
You know, normally you work in isolation,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
and you show at a gallery,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
but here, the work was coming alive,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
and it had some other artists working with me.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
The collaborative effort was fabulous.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:08.958
I said, I'm going to collaborate with anybody and everybody I meet.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
I started doing fashion.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
This is a fashion show we held in London.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
The best collaboration, of course, is with children.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
They are ruthless, they are honest,

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
but they're full of energy and fun.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:25.958
This is a work, a library I designed for the Robin Hood Foundation.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
And I must say, I spent time in the Bronx

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
working with these kids.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
And, in exchange for me working with them,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
they taught me how to be cool.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
I don't think I've succeeded, but they've taught me.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
They said, "Stop saying sorry. Say, my bad."

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:43.958
(Laughter)

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Then I said, all this is good,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
but I want to paint like a real painter.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
American education is so expensive.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
I was in India, and I was walking down the streets,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
and I saw a billboard painter.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
And these guys paint humongous paintings,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
and they look really good.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
And I wondered how they did it from so close.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
So, one day I had the opportunity to meet one of these guys,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
and I said, "How do you paint like that? Who taught you?"

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
And he said, "Oh, it's very easy. I can teach you,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
but we're leaving the city,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
because billboard painters are a dying,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
extinct bunch of artists,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
because digital printing has totally replaced them and hijacked them."

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
I said, in exchange for education in how to paint,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
I will support them, and I started a company.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
And since then, I've been painting all over the place.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
This is a painting I did of my wife in my apartment.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
This is another painting.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
And, in fact, I started painting on anything,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
and started sending them around town.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
Since I mentioned my wife, the most important collaboration

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
has been with her, Netra.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
Netra and I met when she was 18.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
I must have been 19 and a half then,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
and it was love at first sight.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
I lived in India. She lived in America.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
She'd come every two months to visit me,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
and then I said I'm the man,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:06.958
I'm the man, and I have to reciprocate.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
I have to travel seven oceans, and I have to come and see you.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:13.958
I did that twice, and I went broke.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
So then I said, "Nets, what do I do?"

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
She said, "Why don't you send me your paintings?

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
My dad knows a bunch of rich guys.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
We'll try and con them into buying it,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
and then..."

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
But it turned out, after I sent the works to her,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
that her dad's friends,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
like most of you, are geeks.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
I'm joking.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
(Laughter)

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
No, they were really big geeks,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
and they didn't know much about art.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:45.958
So Netra was stuck with 30 paintings of mine.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
So what we did was we rented a little van

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and we drove all over the east coast trying to sell it.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
She contacted anyone and everyone

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
who was willing to buy my work.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
She made enough money, she sold off the whole collection

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
and made enough money to move me for four years

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
with lawyers, a company, everything,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and she became my manager.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
That's us in New York.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
Notice one thing,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
we're equal here.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
Something happened along the line.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
(Laughter)

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
But this brought me -- with Netra managing my career --

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
it brought me a lot of success.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:25.958
I was really happy. I thought of myself as a bit of a rockstar.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
I loved the attention.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
This is all the press we got, and we said,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
it's time to celebrate.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
And I said that the best way to celebrate is to marry Netra.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
I said, "Let's get married."

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
And I said, "Not just married. Let's invite everyone who's helped us,

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
all the people who bought our work."

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
And you won't believe it, we put together a list of 7,000 people,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
who had made a difference -- a ridiculous list,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
but I was determined to bring them to India, so --

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
a lot of them were in India.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
150 artists volunteered to help me with my wedding.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:01.958
We had fashion designers, installation artists,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:05.958
models, we had makeup artists, jewelry designers,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
all kinds of people working with me

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
to make my wedding an art installation.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:14.958
And I had a special installation in tribute to my in-laws.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
I had the vegetable carvers work on that for me.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
But all this excitement led

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
to the press writing about us.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
We were in the papers, we're still in the news three years later,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:29.958
but, unfortunately, something tragic happened right after.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
My mother fell very ill.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
I love my mother

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
and I was told all of a sudden that she was going to die.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
And they said you have to say bye to her,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
you have to do what you have to do.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
And I was devastated.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
I had shows booked up for another year.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
I was on a high.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
And I couldn't. I could not.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
My life was not exuberant.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
I could not live this larger than life person.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:57.958
I started exploring the darker abscesses of the human mind.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
Of course, my work turned ugly,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
but another thing happened.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
I lost all my audiences.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
The Bollywood stars who I would party with

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
and buy my work disappeared.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
The collectors, the friends, the press,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
everyone said, "Nice, but thank you."

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
"No thank you," was more like it.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
But I wanted people to actually

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
feel my work from their gut,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
because I was painting it from my gut.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
If they wanted beauty,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
I said, this is the beauty I'm willing to give you. It's politicized.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
Of course, none of them liked it.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:35.958
My works also turned autobiographical.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
At this point, something else happened.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
A very, very dear friend of mine

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
came out of the closet,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
and in India at that time, it was illegal to be gay,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
and it's disgusting to see how people respond to a gay person.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
I was very upset.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
I remember the time when my mother used to dress me up

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
as a little girl -- that's me there --

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
because she wanted a girl, and she has only boys.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:07.958
(Laughter)

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
Anyway, I don't know what my friends are going to say after this talk.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
It's a secret.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:19.958
So, after this, my works turned a little violent.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:23.958
I talked about this masculinity that one need not perform.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
And I talked about the weakness of male sexuality.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
This time, not only did my collectors disappear,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:33.958
the political activists decided to ban me

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
and to threaten me

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
and to forbid me from showing.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
It turned nasty, and I'm a bit of a chicken.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
I can't deal with any threat. This was a big threat.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
So, I decided it was time

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
to end and go back home.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
This time I said let's try something different.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
I need to be reborn again.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
And I thought the best way, as most of you know who have children,

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
the best way to have a new lease on life,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
is to have a child.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
I decided to have a child,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
and before I did that, I quickly studied what can go wrong.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
How can a family get dysfunctional?

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
And Rudra was born.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
That's my little son.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
And two magical things happened after he was born.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
My mother miraculously recovered

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
after a serious operation,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:22.958
and this man was elected president of this country.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
You know I sat at home and I watched.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
I teared up and I said that's where I want to be.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
So Netra and I wound up our life,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
closed up everything we had,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
and we decided to move to New York.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
And this was just eight months ago.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
I moved back to New York, my work has changed.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:42.958
Everything about my work has become more whimsical.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
This one is called "What the Fuck Was I Thinking?"

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
It talks about mental incest.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:52.958
You know, I may appear to be a very nice, clean, sweet boy.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
But I'm not. I'm capable of thinking anything.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
But I'm very civil in my action, I assure you.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
(Laughter)

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
These are just different cartoons.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
And, before I go, I want to tell you a little story.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
I was talking to mother and father this morning,

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
and my dad said, "I know you have so much you want to say,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
but you have to talk about your work with children."

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
So I said, okay.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
I work with children all over the world,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
and that's an entirely different talk,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
but I want to leave you with one story

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
that really, really inspired me.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
I met Belinda when she was 16.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
I was 17.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
I was in Australia,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
and Belinda had cancer,

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:38.958
and I was told she's not going to live very long.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
They, in fact, told me three weeks.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
I walk into her room, and there was a shy girl,

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:46.958
and she was bald, and she was trying to hide her baldness.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
I whipped out my pen, and I started drawing on her head

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
and I drew a crown for her.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
And then, we started talking, and we spent a lovely time --

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
I told her how I ended up in Australia,

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
how I backpacked and who I conned, and how I got a ticket,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
and all the stories.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
And I drew it out for her.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
And then I left.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
Belinda died

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:14.958
and within a few days of her death,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
they published a book for her,

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
and she used my cartoon on the cover.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
And she wrote a little note, she said,

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
"Hey Rags, thank you for the magic carpet ride around the world."

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
For me, my art is my magic carpet ride.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
I hope you will join me in this magic carpet ride,

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
and touch children and be honest.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
Thank you so much.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:44.958
(Applause)

title: The riddle of experience vs. memory
transcript: Everybody talks about happiness these days. I had somebody count the number of books with "happiness" in the title published in the last five years and they gave up after about 40, and there were many more. There is a huge wave of interest in happiness, among researchers. There is a lot of happiness coaching. Everybody would like to make people happier. But in spite of all this flood of work, there are several cognitive traps that sort of make it almost impossible to think straight about happiness.And my talk today will be mostly about these cognitive traps. This applies to laypeople thinking about their own happiness, and it applies to scholars thinking about happiness, because it turns out we're just as messed up as anybody else is. The first of these traps is a reluctance to admit complexity. It turns out that the word "happiness" is just not a useful word anymore, because we apply it to too many different things. I think there is one particular meaning to which we might restrict it, but by and large, this is something that we'll have to give up and we'll have to adopt the more complicated view of what well-being is. The second trap is a confusion between experience and memory; basically, it's between being happy in your life, and being happy about your life or happy with your life. And those are two very different concepts, and they're both lumped in the notion of happiness. And the third is the focusing illusion, and it's the unfortunate fact that we can't think about any circumstance that affects well-being without distorting its importance. I mean, this is a real cognitive trap. There's just no way of getting it right.Now, I'd like to start with an example of somebody who had a question-and-answer session after one of my lectures reported a story, and that was a story — He said he'd been listening to a symphony, and it was absolutely glorious music and at the very end of the recording, there was a dreadful screeching sound. And then he added, really quite emotionally, it ruined the whole experience. But it hadn't. What it had ruined were the memories of the experience. He had had the experience. He had had 20 minutes of glorious music. They counted for nothing because he was left with a memory; the memory was ruined, and the memory was all that he had gotten to keep.What this is telling us, really, is that we might be thinking of ourselves and of other people in terms of two selves. There is an experiencing self, who lives in the present and knows the present, is capable of re-living the past, but basically it has only the present. It's the experiencing self that the doctor approaches — you know, when the doctor asks, "Does it hurt now when I touch you here?" And then there is a remembering self, and the remembering self is the one that keeps score, and maintains the story of our life, and it's the one that the doctor approaches in asking the question, "How have you been feeling lately?" or "How was your trip to Albania?" or something like that. Those are two very different entities, the experiencing self and the remembering self, and getting confused between them is part of the mess about the notion of happiness.Now, the remembering self is a storyteller. And that really starts with a basic response of our memories — it starts immediately. We don't only tell stories when we set out to tell stories. Our memory tells us stories, that is, what we get to keep from our experiences is a story. And let me begin with one example. This is an old study. Those are actual patients undergoing a painful procedure. I won't go into detail. It's no longer painful these days, but it was painful when this study was run in the 1990s. They were asked to report on their pain every 60 seconds. Here are two patients, those are their recordings. And you are asked, "Who of them suffered more?" And it's a very easy question. Clearly, Patient B suffered more — his colonoscopy was longer, and every minute of pain that Patient A had, Patient B had, and more.But now there is another question: "How much did these patients think they suffered?" And here is a surprise. The surprise is that Patient A had a much worse memory of the colonoscopy than Patient B. The stories of the colonoscopies were different, and because a very critical part of the story is how it ends. And neither of these stories is very inspiring or great — but one of them is this distinct ... (Laughter) but one of them is distinctly worse than the other. And the one that is worse is the one where pain was at its peak at the very end; it's a bad story. How do we know that? Because we asked these people after their colonoscopy, and much later, too, "How bad was the whole thing, in total?" And it was much worse for A than for B, in memory.Now this is a direct conflict between the experiencing self and the remembering self. From the point of view of the experiencing self, clearly, B had a worse time. Now, what you could do with Patient A, and we actually ran clinical experiments, and it has been done, and it does work — you could actually extend the colonoscopy of Patient A by just keeping the tube in without jiggling it too much. That will cause the patient to suffer, but just a little and much less than before. And if you do that for a couple of minutes, you have made the experiencing self of Patient A worse off, and you have the remembering self of Patient A a lot better off, because now you have endowed Patient A with a better story about his experience. What defines a story? And that is true of the stories that memory delivers for us, and it's also true of the stories that we make up. What defines a story are changes, significant moments and endings. Endings are very, very important and, in this case, the ending dominated.Now, the experiencing self lives its life continuously. It has moments of experience, one after the other. And you can ask: What happens to these moments? And the answer is really straightforward: They are lost forever. I mean, most of the moments of our life — and I calculated, you know, the psychological present is said to be about three seconds long; that means that, you know, in a life there are about 600 million of them; in a month, there are about 600,000 — most of them don't leave a trace. Most of them are completely ignored by the remembering self. And yet, somehow you get the sense that they should count, that what happens during these moments of experience is our life. It's the finite resource that we're spending while we're on this earth. And how to spend it would seem to be relevant, but that is not the story that the remembering self keeps for us.So we have the remembering self and the experiencing self, and they're really quite distinct. The biggest difference between them is in the handling of time. From the point of view of the experiencing self, if you have a vacation, and the second week is just as good as the first, then the two-week vacation is twice as good as the one-week vacation. That's not the way it works at all for the remembering self. For the remembering self, a two-week vacation is barely better than the one-week vacation because there are no new memories added. You have not changed the story. And in this way, time is actually the critical variable that distinguishes a remembering self from an experiencing self; time has very little impact on the story.Now, the remembering self does more than remember and tell stories. It is actually the one that makes decisions because, if you have a patient who has had, say, two colonoscopies with two different surgeons and is deciding which of them to choose, then the one that chooses is the one that has the memory that is less bad, and that's the surgeon that will be chosen. The experiencing self has no voice in this choice. We actually don't choose between experiences, we choose between memories of experiences. And even when we think about the future, we don't think of our future normally as experiences. We think of our future as anticipated memories. And basically you can look at this, you know, as a tyranny of the remembering self, and you can think of the remembering self sort of dragging the experiencing self through experiences that the experiencing self doesn't need.I have that sense that when we go on vacations this is very frequently the case; that is, we go on vacations, to a very large extent, in the service of our remembering self. And this is a bit hard to justify I think. I mean, how much do we consume our memories? That is one of the explanations that is given for the dominance of the remembering self. And when I think about that, I think about a vacation we had in Antarctica a few years ago, which was clearly the best vacation I've ever had, and I think of it relatively often, relative to how much I think of other vacations. And I probably have consumed my memories of that three-week trip, I would say, for about 25 minutes in the last four years. Now, if I had ever opened the folder with the 600 pictures in it, I would have spent another hour. Now, that is three weeks, and that is at most an hour and a half. There seems to be a discrepancy. Now, I may be a bit extreme, you know, in how little appetite I have for consuming memories, but even if you do more of this, there is a genuine question: Why do we put so much weight on memory relative to the weight that we put on experiences?So I want you to think about a thought experiment. Imagine that for your next vacation, you know that at the end of the vacation all your pictures will be destroyed, and you'll get an amnesic drug so that you won't remember anything. Now, would you choose the same vacation? (Laughter) And if you would choose a different vacation, there is a conflict between your two selves, and you need to think about how to adjudicate that conflict, and it's actually not at all obvious, because if you think in terms of time, then you get one answer, and if you think in terms of memories, you might get another answer. Why do we pick the vacations we do is a problem that confronts us with a choice between the two selves.Now, the two selves bring up two notions of happiness. There are really two concepts of happiness that we can apply, one per self. So you can ask: How happy is the experiencing self? And then you would ask: How happy are the moments in the experiencing self's life? And they're all — happiness for moments is a fairly complicated process. What are the emotions that can be measured? And, by the way, now we are capable of getting a pretty good idea of the happiness of the experiencing self over time. If you ask for the happiness of the remembering self, it's a completely different thing. This is not about how happily a person lives. It is about how satisfied or pleased the person is when that person thinks about her life. Very different notion. Anyone who doesn't distinguish those notions is going to mess up the study of happiness, and I belong to a crowd of students of well-being, who've been messing up the study of happiness for a long time in precisely this way.The distinction between the happiness of the experiencing self and the satisfaction of the remembering self has been recognized in recent years, and there are now efforts to measure the two separately. The Gallup Organization has a world poll where more than half a million people have been asked questions about what they think of their life and about their experiences, and there have been other efforts along those lines. So in recent years, we have begun to learn about the happiness of the two selves. And the main lesson I think that we have learned is they are really different. You can know how satisfied somebody is with their life, and that really doesn't teach you much about how happily they're living their life, and vice versa. Just to give you a sense of the correlation, the correlation is about .5. What that means is if you met somebody, and you were told, "Oh his father is six feet tall," how much would you know about his height? Well, you would know something about his height, but there's a lot of uncertainty. You have that much uncertainty. If I tell you that somebody ranked their life eight on a scale of ten, you have a lot of uncertainty about how happy they are with their experiencing self. So the correlation is low.We know something about what controls satisfaction of the happiness self. We know that money is very important, goals are very important. We know that happiness is mainly being satisfied with people that we like, spending time with people that we like. There are other pleasures, but this is dominant. So if you want to maximize the happiness of the two selves, you are going to end up doing very different things. The bottom line of what I've said here is that we really should not think of happiness as a substitute for well-being. It is a completely different notion.Now, very quickly, another reason we cannot think straight about happiness is that we do not attend to the same things when we think about life, and we actually live. So, if you ask the simple question of how happy people are in California, you are not going to get to the correct answer. When you ask that question, you think people must be happier in California if, say, you live in Ohio. (Laughter) And what happens is when you think about living in California, you are thinking of the contrast between California and other places, and that contrast, say, is in climate. Well, it turns out that climate is not very important to the experiencing self and it's not even very important to the reflective self that decides how happy people are. But now, because the reflective self is in charge, you may end up — some people may end up moving to California. And it's sort of interesting to trace what is going to happen to people who move to California in the hope of getting happier. Well, their experiencing self is not going to get happier. We know that. But one thing will happen: They will think they are happier, because, when they think about it, they'll be reminded of how horrible the weather was in Ohio, and they will feel they made the right decision.It is very difficult to think straight about well-being, and I hope I have given you a sense of how difficult it is.Thank you.(Applause)Chris Anderson: Thank you. I've got a question for you. Thank you so much. Now, when we were on the phone a few weeks ago, you mentioned to me that there was quite an interesting result came out of that Gallup survey. Is that something you can share since you do have a few moments left now?Daniel Kahneman: Sure. I think the most interesting result that we found in the Gallup survey is a number, which we absolutely did not expect to find. We found that with respect to the happiness of the experiencing self. When we looked at how feelings, vary with income. And it turns out that, below an income of 60,000 dollars a year, for Americans — and that's a very large sample of Americans, like 600,000, so it's a large representative sample — below an income of 600,000 dollars a year...CA: 60,000.DK: 60,000. (Laughter) 60,000 dollars a year, people are unhappy, and they get progressively unhappier the poorer they get. Above that, we get an absolutely flat line. I mean I've rarely seen lines so flat. Clearly, what is happening is money does not buy you experiential happiness, but lack of money certainly buys you misery, and we can measure that misery very, very clearly. In terms of the other self, the remembering self, you get a different story. The more money you earn, the more satisfied you are. That does not hold for emotions.CA: But Danny, the whole American endeavor is about life, liberty, the pursuit of happiness. If people took seriously that finding, I mean, it seems to turn upside down everything we believe about, like for example, taxation policy and so forth. Is there any chance that politicians, that the country generally, would take a finding like that seriously and run public policy based on it?DK: You know I think that there is recognition of the role of happiness research in public policy. The recognition is going to be slow in the United States, no question about that, but in the U.K., it is happening, and in other countries it is happening. People are recognizing that they ought to be thinking of happiness when they think of public policy. It's going to take a while, and people are going to debate whether they want to study experience happiness, or whether they want to study life evaluation, so we need to have that debate fairly soon. How to enhance happiness goes very different ways depending on how you think, and whether you think of the remembering self or you think of the experiencing self. This is going to influence policy, I think, in years to come. In the United States, efforts are being made to measure the experience happiness of the population. This is going to be, I think, within the next decade or two, part of national statistics.CA: Well, it seems to me that this issue will — or at least should be — the most interesting policy discussion to track over the next few years. Thank you so much for inventing behavioral economics. Thank you, Danny Kahneman.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
Everybody talks about happiness these days.

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
I had somebody count the number of books

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:20.958
with "happiness" in the title published in the last five years

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:25.958
and they gave up after about 40, and there were many more.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
There is a huge wave of interest in happiness,

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
among researchers.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
There is a lot of happiness coaching.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
Everybody would like to make people happier.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:38.958
But in spite of all this flood of work,

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
there are several cognitive traps

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:43.958
