that sort of make it almost impossible to think straight

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
about happiness.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
And my talk today will be mostly about these cognitive traps.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
This applies to laypeople thinking about their own happiness,

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:54.958
and it applies to scholars thinking about happiness,

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:58.958
because it turns out we're just as messed up as anybody else is.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
The first of these traps

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:03.958
is a reluctance to admit complexity.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:06.958
It turns out that the word "happiness"

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
is just not a useful word anymore,

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
because we apply it to too many different things.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
I think there is one particular meaning to which we might restrict it,

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
but by and large,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
this is something that we'll have to give up

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:23.958
and we'll have to adopt the more complicated view

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:25.958
of what well-being is.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:29.958
The second trap is a confusion between experience and memory;

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
basically, it's between being happy in your life,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
and being happy about your life

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
or happy with your life.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
And those are two very different concepts,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
and they're both lumped in the notion of happiness.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
And the third is the focusing illusion,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.958
and it's the unfortunate fact that we can't think about any circumstance

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
that affects well-being

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
without distorting its importance.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
I mean, this is a real cognitive trap.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.958
There's just no way of getting it right.

00:01:57.958 --> 00:01:59.958
Now, I'd like to start with an example

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:04.958
of somebody who had a question-and-answer session

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:08.958
after one of my lectures reported a story,

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:09.958
and that was a story --

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
He said he'd been listening to a symphony,

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and it was absolutely glorious music

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
and at the very end of the recording,

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
there was a dreadful screeching sound.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
And then he added, really quite emotionally,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:26.958
it ruined the whole experience.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
But it hadn't.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
What it had ruined were the memories of the experience.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
He had had the experience.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
He had had 20 minutes of glorious music.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
They counted for nothing

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
because he was left with a memory;

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
the memory was ruined,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
and the memory was all that he had gotten to keep.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
What this is telling us, really,

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
is that we might be thinking of ourselves and of other people

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
in terms of two selves.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
There is an experiencing self,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
who lives in the present

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
and knows the present,

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
is capable of re-living the past,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
but basically it has only the present.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
It's the experiencing self that the doctor approaches --

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:08.958
you know, when the doctor asks,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:12.958
"Does it hurt now when I touch you here?"

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
And then there is a remembering self,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
and the remembering self is the one that keeps score,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
and maintains the story of our life,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
and it's the one that the doctor approaches

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
in asking the question,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:29.958
"How have you been feeling lately?"

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:32.958
or "How was your trip to Albania?" or something like that.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
Those are two very different entities,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
the experiencing self and the remembering self,

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:42.958
and getting confused between them is part of the mess

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
about the notion of happiness.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
Now, the remembering self

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
is a storyteller.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:55.958
And that really starts with a basic response of our memories --

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
it starts immediately.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
We don't only tell stories when we set out to tell stories.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
Our memory tells us stories,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
that is, what we get to keep from our experiences

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
is a story.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:12.958
And let me begin with one example.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
This is an old study.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
Those are actual patients undergoing a painful procedure.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
I won't go into detail. It's no longer painful these days,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:24.958
but it was painful when this study was run in the 1990s.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
They were asked to report on their pain every 60 seconds.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
Here are two patients,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
those are their recordings.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
And you are asked, "Who of them suffered more?"

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
And it's a very easy question.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
Clearly, Patient B suffered more --

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
his colonoscopy was longer,

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
and every minute of pain that Patient A had,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
Patient B had, and more.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
But now there is another question:

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
"How much did these patients think they suffered?"

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
And here is a surprise.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
The surprise is that Patient A

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
had a much worse memory of the colonoscopy

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
than Patient B.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
The stories of the colonoscopies were different,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:11.958
and because a very critical part of the story is how it ends.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
And neither of these stories is very inspiring or great --

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.958
but one of them is this distinct ... (Laughter)

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
but one of them is distinctly worse than the other.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
And the one that is worse

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
is the one where pain was at its peak at the very end;

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
it's a bad story.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
How do we know that?

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
Because we asked these people after their colonoscopy,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:34.958
and much later, too,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
"How bad was the whole thing, in total?"

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:40.958
And it was much worse for A than for B, in memory.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
Now this is a direct conflict

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
between the experiencing self and the remembering self.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
From the point of view of the experiencing self,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
clearly, B had a worse time.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
Now, what you could do with Patient A,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
and we actually ran clinical experiments,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
and it has been done, and it does work --

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:03.958
you could actually extend the colonoscopy of Patient A

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
by just keeping the tube in without jiggling it too much.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
That will cause the patient

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
to suffer, but just a little

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
and much less than before.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
And if you do that for a couple of minutes,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
you have made the experiencing self

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
of Patient A worse off,

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
and you have the remembering self of Patient A

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
a lot better off,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
because now you have endowed Patient A

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
with a better story

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
about his experience.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
What defines a story?

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
And that is true of the stories

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
that memory delivers for us,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
and it's also true of the stories that we make up.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:46.958
What defines a story are changes,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
significant moments and endings.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
Endings are very, very important

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:55.958
and, in this case, the ending dominated.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
Now, the experiencing self

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
lives its life continuously.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
It has moments of experience, one after the other.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
And you can ask: What happens to these moments?

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
And the answer is really straightforward:

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
They are lost forever.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
I mean, most of the moments of our life --

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
and I calculated, you know, the psychological present

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
is said to be about three seconds long;

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
that means that, you know,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
in a life there are about 600 million of them;

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
in a month, there are about 600,000 --

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
most of them don't leave a trace.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
Most of them are completely ignored

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
by the remembering self.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
And yet, somehow you get the sense

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
that they should count,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
that what happens during these moments of experience

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
is our life.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
It's the finite resource that we're spending

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
while we're on this earth.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
And how to spend it

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
would seem to be relevant,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
but that is not the story

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
that the remembering self keeps for us.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
So we have the remembering self

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
and the experiencing self,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
and they're really quite distinct.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
The biggest difference between them

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
is in the handling of time.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
From the point of view of the experiencing self,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
if you have a vacation,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
and the second week is just as good as the first,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
then the two-week vacation

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
is twice as good as the one-week vacation.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
That's not the way it works at all for the remembering self.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
For the remembering self, a two-week vacation

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
is barely better than the one-week vacation

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
because there are no new memories added.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
You have not changed the story.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
And in this way,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
time is actually the critical variable

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
that distinguishes a remembering self

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
from an experiencing self;

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
time has very little impact on the story.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
Now, the remembering self does more

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
than remember and tell stories.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
It is actually the one that makes decisions

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
because, if you have a patient who has had, say,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
two colonoscopies with two different surgeons

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
and is deciding which of them to choose,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
then the one that chooses

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:09.958
is the one that has the memory that is less bad,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
and that's the surgeon that will be chosen.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
The experiencing self

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
has no voice in this choice.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
We actually don't choose between experiences,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
we choose between memories of experiences.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
And even when we think about the future,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
we don't think of our future normally as experiences.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
We think of our future

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
as anticipated memories.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And basically you can look at this,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
you know, as a tyranny of the remembering self,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
and you can think of the remembering self

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
sort of dragging the experiencing self

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
through experiences that

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
the experiencing self doesn't need.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
I have that sense that

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
when we go on vacations

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
this is very frequently the case;

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
that is, we go on vacations,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
to a very large extent,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
in the service of our remembering self.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
And this is a bit hard to justify I think.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
I mean, how much do we consume our memories?

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
That is one of the explanations

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
that is given for the dominance

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
of the remembering self.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
And when I think about that, I think about a vacation

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
we had in Antarctica a few years ago,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
which was clearly the best vacation I've ever had,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
and I think of it relatively often,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
relative to how much I think of other vacations.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:27.958
And I probably have consumed

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
my memories of that three-week trip, I would say,

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
for about 25 minutes in the last four years.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
Now, if I had ever opened the folder

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
with the 600 pictures in it,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
I would have spent another hour.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Now, that is three weeks,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
and that is at most an hour and a half.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
There seems to be a discrepancy.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
Now, I may be a bit extreme, you know,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
in how little appetite I have for consuming memories,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
but even if you do more of this,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
there is a genuine question:

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:01.958
Why do we put so much weight on memory

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
relative to the weight that we put on experiences?

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
So I want you to think

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
about a thought experiment.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
Imagine that for your next vacation,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
you know that at the end of the vacation

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
all your pictures will be destroyed,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
and you'll get an amnesic drug

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
so that you won't remember anything.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:25.958
Now, would you choose the same vacation? (Laughter)

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:30.958
And if you would choose a different vacation,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
there is a conflict between your two selves,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
and you need to think about how to adjudicate that conflict,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
and it's actually not at all obvious, because

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
if you think in terms of time,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
then you get one answer,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
and if you think in terms of memories,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
you might get another answer.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
Why do we pick the vacations we do

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
is a problem that confronts us

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
with a choice between the two selves.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
Now, the two selves

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
bring up two notions of happiness.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
There are really two concepts of happiness

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
that we can apply, one per self.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:12.958
So you can ask: How happy is the experiencing self?

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
And then you would ask: How happy are the moments

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
in the experiencing self's life?

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
And they're all -- happiness for moments

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
is a fairly complicated process.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
What are the emotions that can be measured?

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
And, by the way, now we are capable

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
of getting a pretty good idea

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:32.958
of the happiness of the experiencing self over time.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
If you ask for the happiness of the remembering self,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
it's a completely different thing.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
This is not about how happily a person lives.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
It is about how satisfied or pleased the person is

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.958
when that person thinks about her life.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
Very different notion.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
Anyone who doesn't distinguish those notions

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
is going to mess up the study of happiness,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
and I belong to a crowd of students of well-being,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:03.958
who've been messing up the study of happiness for a long time

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
in precisely this way.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
The distinction between the

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
happiness of the experiencing self

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
and the satisfaction of the remembering self

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
has been recognized in recent years,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
and there are now efforts to measure the two separately.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
The Gallup Organization has a world poll

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
where more than half a million people

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
have been asked questions

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
about what they think of their life

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
and about their experiences,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
and there have been other efforts along those lines.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
So in recent years, we have begun to learn

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
about the happiness of the two selves.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
And the main lesson I think that we have learned

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
is they are really different.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:47.958
You can know how satisfied somebody is with their life,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
and that really doesn't teach you much

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
about how happily they're living their life,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
and vice versa.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
Just to give you a sense of the correlation,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
the correlation is about .5.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
What that means is if you met somebody,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
and you were told, "Oh his father is six feet tall,"

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
how much would you know about his height?

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
Well, you would know something about his height,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
but there's a lot of uncertainty.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
You have that much uncertainty.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
If I tell you that somebody ranked their life eight on a scale of ten,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
you have a lot of uncertainty

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
about how happy they are

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
with their experiencing self.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
So the correlation is low.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
We know something about what controls

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
satisfaction of the happiness self.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
We know that money is very important,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
goals are very important.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:38.958
We know that happiness is mainly

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
being satisfied with people that we like,

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
spending time with people that we like.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
There are other pleasures, but this is dominant.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
So if you want to maximize the happiness of the two selves,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
you are going to end up

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
doing very different things.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
The bottom line of what I've said here

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:59.958
is that we really should not think of happiness

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
as a substitute for well-being.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
It is a completely different notion.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
Now, very quickly,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.958
another reason we cannot think straight about happiness

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:18.958
is that we do not attend to the same things

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
when we think about life, and we actually live.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:26.958
So, if you ask the simple question of how happy people are in California,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
you are not going to get to the correct answer.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
When you ask that question,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
you think people must be happier in California

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
if, say, you live in Ohio.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
(Laughter)

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
And what happens is

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:44.958
when you think about living in California,

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
you are thinking of the contrast

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
between California and other places,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
and that contrast, say, is in climate.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
Well, it turns out that climate

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
is not very important to the experiencing self

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
and it's not even very important to the reflective self

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
that decides how happy people are.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:06.958
But now, because the reflective self is in charge,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
you may end up -- some people may end up

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
moving to California.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
And it's sort of interesting to trace what is going to happen

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
to people who move to California in the hope of getting happier.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
Well, their experiencing self

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
is not going to get happier.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
We know that.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
But one thing will happen: They will think they are happier,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:30.958
because, when they think about it,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:34.958
they'll be reminded of how horrible the weather was in Ohio,

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:37.958
and they will feel they made the right decision.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
It is very difficult

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
to think straight about well-being,

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
and I hope I have given you a sense

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
of how difficult it is.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
Thank you.

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
(Applause)

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
Chris Anderson: Thank you. I've got a question for you.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
Thank you so much.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
Now, when we were on the phone a few weeks ago,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
you mentioned to me that there was quite an interesting result

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
came out of that Gallup survey.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
Is that something you can share

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
since you do have a few moments left now?

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
Daniel Kahneman: Sure.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:15.958
I think the most interesting result that we found in the Gallup survey

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
is a number, which we absolutely did not expect to find.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
We found that with respect to the happiness

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
of the experiencing self.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:28.958
When we looked at how feelings,

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:30.958
vary with income.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
And it turns out that, below an income

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
of 60,000 dollars a year, for Americans --

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
and that's a very large sample of Americans, like 600,000,

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
so it's a large representative sample --

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
below an income of 600,000 dollars a year...

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
CA: 60,000.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
DK: 60,000.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
(Laughter)

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:53.958
60,000 dollars a year, people are unhappy,

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:56.958
and they get progressively unhappier the poorer they get.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:59.958
Above that, we get an absolutely flat line.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
I mean I've rarely seen lines so flat.

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
Clearly, what is happening is

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:07.958
money does not buy you experiential happiness,

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:10.958
but lack of money certainly buys you misery,

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:12.958
and we can measure that misery

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.958
very, very clearly.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:17.958
In terms of the other self, the remembering self,

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
you get a different story.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:22.958
The more money you earn, the more satisfied you are.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
That does not hold for emotions.

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:27.958
CA: But Danny, the whole American endeavor is about

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:30.958
life, liberty, the pursuit of happiness.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:34.958
If people took seriously that finding,

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
I mean, it seems to turn upside down

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
everything we believe about, like for example,

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
taxation policy and so forth.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:44.958
Is there any chance that politicians, that the country generally,

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:47.958
would take a finding like that seriously

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:49.958
and run public policy based on it?

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:51.958
DK: You know I think that there is recognition

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:54.958
of the role of happiness research in public policy.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:56.958
The recognition is going to be slow in the United States,

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:58.958
no question about that,

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:00.958
but in the U.K., it is happening,

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:02.958
and in other countries it is happening.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:05.958
People are recognizing that they ought

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
to be thinking of happiness

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
when they think of public policy.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:11.958
It's going to take a while,

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:14.958
and people are going to debate

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:16.958
whether they want to study experience happiness,

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:18.958
or whether they want to study life evaluation,

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
so we need to have that debate fairly soon.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:23.958
How to enhance happiness

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:26.958
goes very different ways depending on how you think,

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:28.958
and whether you think of the remembering self

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
or you think of the experiencing self.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:33.958
This is going to influence policy, I think, in years to come.

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:36.958
In the United States, efforts are being made

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
to measure the experience happiness of the population.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:42.958
This is going to be, I think, within the next decade or two,

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:44.958
part of national statistics.

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:48.958
CA: Well, it seems to me that this issue will -- or at least should be --

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:50.958
the most interesting policy discussion to track

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:52.958
over the next few years.

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:54.958
Thank you so much for inventing behavioral economics.

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:56.958
Thank you, Danny Kahneman.

title: The rise of cricket, the rise of India
transcript: So, what I'm going to do is just give you the latest episode of India's — maybe the world's — longest running soap opera, which is cricket. And may it run forever, because it gives people like me a living. It's got everything that you'd want a normal soap opera to want: It's got love, joy, happiness, sadness, tears, laughter, lots of deceit, intrigue. And like all good soaps, it jumps 20 years when the audience interest changes. And that's exactly what cricket has done. It's jumped 20 years into 20-over game. And that's what I'm going to talk about, how a small change leads to a very big revolution.But it wasn't always like that. Cricket wasn't always this speed-driven generations game. There was a time when you played cricket, you played timeless test matches, when you played on till the game got over. And there was this game in March 1939 that started on the third of March and ended on the 14th of March. And it only ended because the English cricketers had to go from Durban to Cape Town, which is a two-hour train journey, to catch the ship that left on the 17th, because the next ship wasn't around for a long time. So, the match was ended in between. And one of the English batsmen said, "You know what? Another half an hour and we would have won." (Laughter) Another half an hour after 12 days. There were two Sundays in between. But of course, Sundays are church days, so you don't play on Sundays. And one day it rained, so they all sat around making friends with each other.But there is a reason why India fell in love with cricket: because we had about the same pace of life. (Laughter) The Mahabharata was like that as well, wasn't it? You fought by day, then it was sunset, so everyone went back home. And then you worked out your strategy, and you came and fought the next day, and you went back home again. The only difference between the Mahabharata and our cricket was that in cricket, everybody was alive to come back and fight the next day. Princes patronize the game, not because they love the game, but because it was a means of ingratiating themselves to the British rulers.But there is one other reason why India fell in love with cricket, which was, all you needed was a plank of wood and a rubber ball, and any number of people could play it anywhere. Take a look: You could play it in the dump with some rocks over there, you could play it in a little alley — you couldn't hit square anywhere, because the bat hit the wall; don't forget the air conditioning and the cable wires. (Laughter) You could play it on the banks of the Ganges — that's as clean as the Ganges has been for a long time. Or you could play many games in one small patch of land, even if you didn't know which game you were actually in. (Laughter) As you can see, you can play anywhere. But slowly the game moved on, you know, finally.You don't always have five days. So, we moved on, and we started playing 50-over cricket. And then an enormous accident took place. In Indian sport we don't make things happen, accidents happen and we're in the right place at the right time, sometimes. And we won this World Cup in 1983. And suddenly we fell in love with the 50-over game, and we played it virtually every day. There was more 50-over cricket than anywhere.But there was another big date. 1983 was when we won the World Cup. 1991,'92, we found a finance minister and a prime minister willing to let the world look at India, rather than be this great country of intrigue and mystery in this closed country. And so we allowed multinationals into India. We cut customs duties, we reduced import duties, and we got all the multinationals coming in, with multinational budgets, who looked at per-capita income and got very excited about the possibilities in India, and were looking for a vehicle to reach every Indian.And there are only two vehicles in India — one real, one scripted. The scripted one is what you see in the movies, the real one was cricket. And so one of my friends sitting right here in front of me, Ravi Dhariwal from Pepsi, decided he's going to take it all over the world. And Pepsi was this big revolution, because they started taking cricket all over. And so cricket started becoming big; cricket started bringing riches in. Television started covering cricket. For a long time television said, "We won't cover cricket unless you pay us to cover it." Then they said, "OK, the next rights are sold for 55 million dollars. The next rights are sold for 612 million dollars." So, it's a bit of a curve, that.And then another big accident happened in our cricket. England invented 20 overs cricket, and said, "The world must play 20 overs cricket." Just as England invented cricket, and made the rest of the world play it. Thank God for them. (Laughter) And so, India had to go and play the T20 World Cup, you see. India didn't want to play the T20 World Cup. But we were forced to play it by an 8-1 margin. And then something very dramatic happened. We got to the final, and then this moment, that will remain enshrined forever, for everybody, take a look.(Crowd cheering)The Pakistani batsman trying to clear the fielder.Announcer: And Zishan takes it! India wins! What a match for a Twenty20 final. India, the world champions. (Cheering) India, T20 champions. But what a game we had, M. S. Dhoni got it right in the air, but Misbah-ul-Haq, what a player. A massive, massive success: India, the world TT champions.Harsha Bhogle: Suddenly India discovered this power of 20-overs cricket. The accident, of course, there, was that the batsman thought the bowler was bowling fast. (Laughter) If he had bowled fast, the ball would have gone where it was meant to go, but it didn't go. And we suddenly discovered that we could be good at this game. And what it also did was it led to a certain pride in the fact that India could be the best in the world. It was at a time when investment was coming in, India was feeling a little more confident about itself. And so there was a feeling that there was great pride in what we can do. And thankfully for all of us, the English are very good at inventing things, and then the gracious people that they are, they let the world become very good at it. (Laughter) And so England invented T20 cricket, and allowed India to hijack it. It was not like reengineering that we do in medicine, we just took it straight away, as is. (Laughter)And so, we launched our own T20 league. Six weeks, city versus city. It was a new thing for us. We had only ever supported our country — the only two areas in which India was very proud about their country, representing itself on the field. One was war, the Indian army, which we don't like to happen very often. The other was Indian cricket. Now, suddenly we had to support city leagues. But the people getting into these city leagues were people who were taking their cues from the West. America is a home of leagues. And they said, "Right, we'll build some glitzy leagues here in India." But was India ready for it? Because cricket, for a long time in India was always organized. It was never promoted, it was never sold — it was organized. And look what they did with our beautiful, nice, simple family game. All of a sudden, you had that happening.(Music)An opening ceremony to match every other. This was an India that was buying Corvettes. This was an India that was buying Jaguar. This was an India that was adding more mobile phones per month than New Zealand's population twice over. So, it was a different India. But it was also a slightly more orthodox India that was very happy to be modern, but didn't want to say that to people. And so, they were aghast when the cheerleaders arrived. Everyone secretly watched them, but everyone claimed not to.(Music)(Laughter)The new owners of Indian cricket were not the old princes. They were not bureaucrats who were forced into sport because they didn't actually love it; these were people who ran serious companies. And so they started promoting cricket big time, started promoting clubs big time. And they've started promoting them with huge money behind it. I mean the IPL had 2.3 billion dollars before a ball was bowled, 1.6 billion dollars for television revenue over 10 years, and another 70 million dollars plus from all these franchises that were putting in money. And then they had to appeal to their cities, but they had to do it like the West, right? Because we are setting up leagues. But what they were very good at doing was making it very localized. So, just to give you an example of how they did it — not Manchester United style promotion, but very Mumbai style promotion. Take a look.(Music)Of course, a lot of people said, "Maybe they dance better than they play." (Laughter) But that's all right. What it did also is it changed the way we looked at cricket. All along, if you wanted a young cricketer, you picked him up from the bylanes of your own little locality, your own city, and you were very proud of the system that produced those cricketers. Now, all of the sudden, if you were to bowl a shot — if Mumbai were to bowl a shot, for example, they needn't go to Kalbadevi or Shivaji Park or somewhere to source them, they could go to Trinidad. This was the new India, wasn't it? This was the new world, where you can source from anywhere as long as you get the best product at the best price. And all of a sudden, Indian sport had awakened to the reality that you can source the best product for the best price anywhere in the world.So, the Mumbai Indians flew in Dwayne Bravo from Trinidad and Tobago, overnight. And when he had to go back to represent the West Indies, they asked him, "When do you have to reach?" He said, "I have to be there by a certain time, so I have to leave today." We said, "No, no, no. It's not about when you have to leave; it's about when do you have to reach there?" And so he said, "I've got to reach on date X." And they said, "Fine, you play to date X, minus one." So, he played in Hyderabad, went, straight after the game, went from the stadium to Hyderabad airport, sat in a private corporate jet — first refueling in Portugal, second refueling in Brazil; he was in West Indies in time. (Laughter) Never would India have thought on this scale before. Never would India have said, "I want a player to play one game for me, and I will use a corporate jet to send him all the way back to Kingston, Jamaica to play a game." And I just thought to myself, "Wow, we've arrived somewhere in the world, you know? We have arrived somewhere. We are thinking big."But what this also did was it started marrying the two most important things in Indian cricket, which is cricket and the movies in Indian entertainment. There is cricket and the movies. And they came together because people in the movies now started owning clubs. And so, people started going to the cricket to watch Preity Zinta. They started going to the cricket to watch Shah Rukh Khan. And something very interesting happened. We started getting song and dance in Indian cricket. And so it started resembling the Indian movies more and more. And of course, if you were on Preity Zinta's team — as you will see on the clip that follows — if you did well, you got a hug from Preity Zinta. So that was the ultimate reason to do well. Take a look — everyone's watching Preity Zinta.(Music)And then of course there was Shah Rukh playing the Kolkata crowd. We'd all seen matches in Kolkata, but we'd never seen anything like this: Shah Rukh, with the Bengali song, getting the audiences all worked up for Kolkata — not for India, but for Kolkata. But take a look at this.(Music)An Indian film star hugging a Pakistani cricketer because they'd won in Kolkata. Can you imagine? And do you know what the Pakistani cricketer said? (Applause) "I wish I was playing for Preity Zinta's team."(Laughter)But I thought I'd take this opportunity — there's a few people from Pakistan in here. I'm so happy that you're here because I think we can show that we can both be together and be friends, right? We can play cricket together, we can be friends. So thank you very much for coming, all of you from Pakistan.(Applause)There was criticism too because they said, "Players are being bought and sold? Are they grain? Are they cattle?" Because we had this auction, you see. How do you fix a price for a player? And so the auction that followed literally had people saying, "Bang! so many million dollars for so-and-so player." There it is.(Music)Auctioneer: Going at 1,500,000 dollars. Chennai. Shane Warne sold for 450,000 dollars.HB: Suddenly, a game which earned its players 50 rupees a day — so 250 rupees for a test match, but if you finish in four days you only got 200. The best Indian players who played every test match — every one of the internationals, the top of the line players — standard contracts are 220,000 dollars in a whole year. Now they were getting 500,000 for six days' work. Then Andrew Flintoff came by from England, he got one and a half million dollars, and he went back and said, "For four weeks, I'm earning more than Frank Lampard and Steven Gerrard, and I'm earning more than the footballers, wow." And where was he earning it from? From a little club in India. Could you have imagined that day would come? One and a half million dollars for six weeks' work. That's not bad, is it?So, at 2.3 billion dollars before the first ball was bowled. What India was doing, though, was benchmarking itself against the best in the world, and it became a huge brand. Lalit Modi was on the cover of Business Today. IPL became the biggest brand in India and, because our elections, had to be moved to South Africa, and we had to start the tournament in three weeks. Move a whole tournament to South Africa in three weeks. But we did it. You know why? Because no country works as slowly as we do till three weeks before an event, and nobody works fast as we do in the last three weeks.(Applause)Our population, which for a long time we thought was a problem, suddenly became our biggest asset because there were more people watching — the huge consuming class — everybody came to watch the cricket. We'd also made cricket the only sport in India, which is a pity, but in India every other sport pushes cricket to become big, which is a bit of a tragedy of our times.Now, this last minute before I go — there's a couple of side effects of all this. For a long time, India was this country of poverty, dust, beggars, snake charmers, filth, Delhi belly — people heard Delhi belly stories before they came. And, all of a sudden, India was this land of opportunity. Cricketers all over the world said, "You know, we love India. We love to play in India." And that felt good, you know? We said, "The dollar's quite powerful actually." Can you imagine, you've got the dollar on view and there's no Delhi belly in there anymore. There's no filth, there's no beggars, all the snake charmers have vanished, everybody's gone. This tells you how the capitalist world rules.Right so, finally, an English game that India usurped a little bit, but T20 is going to be the next missionary in the world. If you want to take the game around the world, it's got to be the shortest form of the game. You can't take a timeless test to China and sit through 14 days with no result in the end, or you can't take it all over the world. So that's what T20 is doing. Hopefully, it'll make everyone richer, hopefully it'll make the game bigger and hopefully it'll give cricket commentators more time in the business.Thank you very much. Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
So, what I'm going to do is

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:15.958
just give you the latest episode of India's --

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:18.958
maybe the world's -- longest running soap opera,

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
which is cricket.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
And may it run forever, because it gives people like me a living.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:28.958
It's got everything that you'd want a normal soap opera to want:

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
It's got love, joy, happiness,

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
sadness, tears, laughter,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
lots of deceit, intrigue.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
And like all good soaps, it jumps 20 years

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
when the audience interest changes.

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
And that's exactly what cricket has done.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
It's jumped 20 years

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:44.958
into 20-over game.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:46.958
And that's what I'm going to talk about,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
how a small change

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
leads to a very big revolution.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
But it wasn't always like that.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
Cricket wasn't always this

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
speed-driven generations game.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
There was a time when you played cricket,

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
you played timeless test matches,

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:03.958
when you played on till the game got over.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:06.958
And there was this game in March 1939

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
that started on the third of March

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
and ended on the 14th of March.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
And it only ended because the English cricketers

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
had to go from Durban to Cape Town,

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
which is a two-hour train journey,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.958
to catch the ship that left on the 17th,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
because the next ship wasn't around for a long time.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
So, the match was ended in between.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
And one of the English batsmen said, "You know what?

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
Another half an hour and we would have won."

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
(Laughter)

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
Another half an hour after 12 days.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:38.958
There were two Sundays in between. But of course, Sundays are church days,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
so you don't play on Sundays. And one day it rained,

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
so they all sat around making friends with each other.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
But there is a reason why India fell in love with cricket:

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:48.958
because we had about the same pace of life.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
(Laughter)

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
The Mahabharata was like that as well, wasn't it?

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:57.958
You fought by day, then it was sunset,

00:01:57.958 --> 00:01:59.958
so everyone went back home.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
And then you worked out your strategy,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
and you came and fought the next day, and you went back home again.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
The only difference between the Mahabharata and our cricket was

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
that in cricket, everybody was alive to come back and fight the next day.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
Princes patronize the game,

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
not because they love the game,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
but because it was a means of ingratiating themselves

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
to the British rulers.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
But there is one other reason why India fell in love with cricket,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
which was, all you needed was a plank of wood

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
and a rubber ball, and any number of people

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
could play it anywhere.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
Take a look:

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
You could play it in the dump

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
with some rocks over there,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
you could play it in a little alley --

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
you couldn't hit square anywhere, because the bat hit the wall;

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
don't forget the air conditioning and the cable wires.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:39.958
(Laughter)

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
You could play it on the banks of the Ganges --

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
that's as clean as the Ganges has been for a long time.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
Or you could play many games in one small patch of land,

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
even if you didn't know which game you were actually in.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
(Laughter)

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
As you can see, you can play anywhere.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
But slowly the game moved on,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
you know, finally.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
You don't always have five days. So, we moved on,

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
and we started playing 50-over cricket.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
And then an enormous accident took place.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
In Indian sport we don't make things happen,

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
accidents happen and we're in the right place at the right time, sometimes.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:12.958
And we won this World Cup in 1983.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
And suddenly we fell in love with the 50-over game,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
and we played it virtually every day.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
There was more 50-over cricket than anywhere.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
But there was another big date.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
1983 was when we won the World Cup.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
1991,'92, we found a finance minister

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
and a prime minister

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
willing to let the world look at India,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
rather than be this great country of intrigue

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
and mystery in this closed country.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
And so we allowed multinationals into India.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
We cut customs duties, we reduced import duties,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
and we got all the multinationals coming in,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
with multinational budgets,

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
who looked at per-capita income

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
and got very excited about the possibilities in India,

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
and were looking for a vehicle to reach every Indian.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
And there are only two vehicles in India -- one real, one scripted.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
The scripted one is what you see in the movies,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:57.958
the real one was cricket.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
And so one of my friends sitting right here in front of me,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
Ravi Dhariwal from Pepsi, decided he's going to take it

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
all over the world.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
And Pepsi was this big revolution, because they started taking cricket all over.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
And so cricket started becoming big;

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
cricket started bringing riches in.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
Television started covering cricket. For a long time

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
television said, "We won't cover cricket

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
unless you pay us to cover it."

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
Then they said, "OK,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
the next rights are sold for 55 million dollars.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
The next rights are sold for 612 million dollars."

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
So, it's a bit of a curve, that.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
And then another big accident happened in our cricket.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
England invented 20 overs cricket,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
and said, "The world must play 20 overs cricket."

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
Just as England invented cricket, and made the rest of the world play it.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
Thank God for them.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:39.958
(Laughter)

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
And so, India had to go and play the T20 World Cup, you see.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
India didn't want to play the T20 World Cup.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
But we were forced to play it by an 8-1 margin.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
And then something very dramatic happened.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
We got to the final, and then this moment,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
that will remain enshrined forever,

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
for everybody, take a look.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
(Crowd cheering)

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
The Pakistani batsman trying to clear the fielder.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
Announcer: And Zishan takes it! India wins!

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
What a match for a Twenty20 final.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
India, the world champions.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:08.958
(Cheering)

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
India, T20 champions.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
But what a game we had, M. S. Dhoni

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
got it right in the air, but Misbah-ul-Haq, what a player.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
A massive, massive success:

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:25.958
India, the world TT champions.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:29.958
Harsha Bhogle: Suddenly India discovered this power of 20-overs cricket.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
The accident, of course, there, was that the batsman

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
thought the bowler was bowling fast.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:34.958
(Laughter)

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
If he had bowled fast, the ball would have gone where it was meant to go,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
but it didn't go. And we suddenly discovered

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
that we could be good at this game.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
And what it also did was

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
it led to a certain pride in the fact that India could be the best in the world.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
It was at a time when investment was coming in,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
India was feeling a little more confident about itself.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
And so there was a feeling that there was great pride

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
in what we can do.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And thankfully for all of us,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
the English are very good at inventing things,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
and then the gracious people that they are,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
they let the world become very good at it.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
(Laughter)

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:10.958
And so England invented T20 cricket,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
and allowed India to hijack it.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
It was not like reengineering that we do in medicine,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
we just took it straight away, as is.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
(Laughter)

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
And so, we launched our own T20 league.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
Six weeks, city versus city.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
It was a new thing for us. We had only ever supported our country --

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
the only two areas in which India was very proud about

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
their country, representing itself on the field.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
One was war, the Indian army, which we don't like to happen very often.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
The other was Indian cricket.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
Now, suddenly we had to support city leagues.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
But the people getting into these city leagues

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
were people who were taking their cues from the West.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
America is a home of leagues. And they said,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
"Right, we'll build some glitzy leagues here in India."

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
But was India ready for it?

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
Because cricket, for a long time in India was always organized.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
It was never promoted, it was never sold -- it was organized.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
And look what they did with our beautiful, nice,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
simple family game.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
All of a sudden, you had that happening.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
(Music)

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
An opening ceremony to match every other.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
This was an India that was buying Corvettes. This was an India that was buying Jaguar.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
This was an India that was adding more mobile phones per month

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
than New Zealand's population twice over.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
So, it was a different India.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
But it was also a slightly more orthodox India

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
that was very happy to be modern,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
but didn't want to say that to people.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
And so, they were aghast when the cheerleaders arrived.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
Everyone secretly watched them, but everyone claimed not to.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
(Music)

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
(Laughter)

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
The new owners of Indian cricket were not the old princes.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
They were not bureaucrats who were forced

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
into sport because they didn't actually love it;

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
these were people who ran serious companies.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
And so they started promoting cricket big time,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
started promoting clubs big time.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
And they've started promoting them with huge money behind it.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
I mean the IPL had 2.3 billion dollars

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
before a ball was bowled,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
1.6 billion dollars for television revenue over 10 years,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
and another 70 million dollars plus from all these franchises

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
that were putting in money. And then they had to appeal to their cities,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
but they had to do it like the West, right? Because we are setting up leagues.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
But what they were very good at doing

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:49.958
was making it very localized.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
So, just to give you an example of how they did it --

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
not Manchester United style promotion,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
but very Mumbai style promotion. Take a look.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
(Music)

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
Of course, a lot of people said, "Maybe they dance better than they play."

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
(Laughter)

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
But that's all right. What it did also is it changed the way we looked at cricket.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
All along, if you wanted a young cricketer,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
you picked him up from the bylanes of your own little locality,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
your own city, and you were very proud

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
of the system that produced those cricketers.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Now, all of the sudden, if you were to bowl a shot --

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
if Mumbai were to bowl a shot, for example,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
they needn't go to Kalbadevi

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
or Shivaji Park or somewhere to source them,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
they could go to Trinidad.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
This was the new India, wasn't it? This was the new world,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
where you can source from anywhere

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
as long as you get the best product at the best price.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
And all of a sudden, Indian sport had awakened to the reality

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
that you can source the best product for the best price

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
anywhere in the world.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
So, the Mumbai Indians flew in Dwayne Bravo from Trinidad and Tobago,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
overnight. And when he had to go back to represent

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:31.958
the West Indies, they asked him, "When do you have to reach?"

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
He said, "I have to be there by a certain time, so I have to leave today."

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
We said, "No, no, no. It's not about when you have to leave;

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
it's about when do you have to reach there?"

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
And so he said, "I've got to reach on date X."

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
And they said, "Fine, you play to date X, minus one."

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
So, he played in Hyderabad, went, straight after the game,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
went from the stadium to Hyderabad airport,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
sat in a private corporate jet -- first refueling in Portugal,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
second refueling in Brazil; he was in West Indies in time.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:56.958
(Laughter)

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
Never would India have thought on this scale before.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Never would India have said, "I want a player to play

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
one game for me, and I will use a corporate jet

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
to send him all the way back to Kingston, Jamaica

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
to play a game."

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
And I just thought to myself,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
"Wow, we've arrived somewhere in the world, you know?

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
We have arrived somewhere. We are thinking big."

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
But what this also did was it started

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
marrying the two most important things in Indian cricket,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
which is cricket and the movies in Indian entertainment.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
There is cricket and the movies.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
And they came together because people in the movies

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
now started owning clubs.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:32.958
And so, people started going to the cricket to watch Preity Zinta.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
They started going to the cricket to watch Shah Rukh Khan.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
And something very interesting happened.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
We started getting song and dance in Indian cricket.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
And so it started resembling the Indian movies more and more.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
And of course, if you were on Preity Zinta's team --

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
as you will see on the clip that follows -- if you did well,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
you got a hug from Preity Zinta.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
So that was the ultimate reason to do well. Take a look --

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
everyone's watching Preity Zinta.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
(Music)

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
And then of course there was Shah Rukh playing the Kolkata crowd.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
We'd all seen matches in Kolkata,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
but we'd never seen anything like this:

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
Shah Rukh, with the Bengali song, getting the audiences all worked up

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
for Kolkata -- not for India, but for Kolkata.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
But take a look at this.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
(Music)

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
An Indian film star hugging a Pakistani cricketer

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
because they'd won in Kolkata.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Can you imagine?

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
And do you know what the Pakistani cricketer said?

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
(Applause)

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
"I wish I was playing for Preity Zinta's team."

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:01.958
(Laughter)

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
But I thought I'd take this opportunity --

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
there's a few people from Pakistan in here.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
I'm so happy that you're here

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
because I think we can show that we can both be together and be friends, right?

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
We can play cricket together, we can be friends.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
So thank you very much for coming, all of you from Pakistan.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:18.958
(Applause)

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
There was criticism too because they said,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
"Players are being bought and sold?

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
Are they grain?

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
Are they cattle?"

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
Because we had this auction, you see.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
How do you fix a price for a player?

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
And so the auction that followed

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
literally had people saying,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
"Bang! so many million dollars for so-and-so player."

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
There it is.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
(Music)

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:52.958
Auctioneer: Going at 1,500,000 dollars. Chennai.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:59.958
Shane Warne sold for 450,000 dollars.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.958
HB: Suddenly, a game which earned its players 50 rupees a day --

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
so 250 rupees for a test match,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:10.958
but if you finish in four days you only got 200.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
The best Indian players who played every test match --

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
every one of the internationals, the top of the line players --

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
standard contracts are 220,000 dollars in a whole year.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
Now they were getting 500,000 for six days' work.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
Then Andrew Flintoff came by from England,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
he got one and a half million dollars, and he went back and said,

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
"For four weeks, I'm earning more than Frank Lampard and Steven Gerrard,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
and I'm earning more than the footballers, wow."

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
And where was he earning it from? From a little club in India.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
Could you have imagined that day would come?

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
One and a half million dollars for six weeks' work.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
That's not bad, is it?

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
So, at 2.3 billion dollars before the first ball was bowled.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
What India was doing, though, was benchmarking

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
itself against the best in the world,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
and it became a huge brand.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
Lalit Modi was on the cover of Business Today.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
IPL became the biggest brand in India

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
and, because our elections, had to be moved to South Africa,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
and we had to start the tournament in three weeks.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
Move a whole tournament to South Africa in three weeks.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
But we did it. You know why?

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
Because no country works as slowly as we do

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
till three weeks before an event,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
and nobody works fast as we do in the last three weeks.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:19.958
(Applause)

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
Our population, which for a long time we thought was a problem,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
suddenly became our biggest asset

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
because there were more people watching --

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
the huge consuming class --

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
everybody came to watch the cricket.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:33.958
We'd also made cricket the only sport in India,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
which is a pity, but in India every other sport

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
pushes cricket to become big,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
which is a bit of a tragedy of our times.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
Now, this last minute before I go --

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
there's a couple of side effects of all this.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
For a long time, India was this country of poverty,

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
dust, beggars,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
snake charmers, filth,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
Delhi belly -- people heard Delhi belly stories before they came.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
And, all of a sudden, India was this land of opportunity.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
Cricketers all over the world said,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
"You know, we love India. We love to play in India."

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
And that felt good, you know?

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
We said, "The dollar's quite powerful actually."

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
Can you imagine, you've got the dollar on view

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
and there's no Delhi belly in there anymore.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
There's no filth, there's no beggars, all the snake charmers have vanished,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
everybody's gone. This tells you how the capitalist world rules.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
Right so, finally,

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
an English game that India usurped a little bit,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
but T20 is going to be the next missionary in the world.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
If you want to take the game around the world,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
it's got to be the shortest form of the game.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
You can't take a timeless test to China and sit through 14 days with no result in the end,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
or you can't take it all over the world.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
So that's what T20 is doing.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
Hopefully, it'll make everyone richer, hopefully it'll make the game bigger

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
and hopefully it'll give cricket commentators more time in the business.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
Thank you very much. Thank you.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
(Applause)

title: Is Pivot a turning point for web exploration?
transcript: If I can leave you with one big idea today, it's that the whole of the data in which we consume is greater that the sum of the parts, and instead of thinking about information overload, what I'd like you to think about is how we can use information so that patterns pop and we can see trends that would otherwise be invisible.So what we're looking at right here is a typical mortality chart organized by age. This tool that I'm using here is a little experiment. It's called Pivot, and with Pivot what I can do is I can choose to filter in one particular cause of deaths — say, accidents. And, right away, I see there's a different pattern that emerges. This is because, in the mid-area here, people are at their most active, and over here they're at their most frail. We can step back out again and then reorganize the data by cause of death, seeing that circulatory diseases and cancer are the usual suspects, but not for everyone. If we go ahead and we filter by age — say 40 years or less — we see that accidents are actually the greatest cause that people have to be worried about. And if you drill into that, it's especially the case for men.So you get the idea that viewing information, viewing data in this way, is a lot like swimming in a living information info-graphic. And if we can do this for raw data, why not do it for content as well? So what we have right here is the cover of every single Sports Illustrated ever produced. It's all here; it's all on the web. You can go back to your rooms and try this after my talk. With Pivot, you can drill into a decade. You can drill into a particular year. You can jump right into a specific issue. So I'm looking at this; I see the athletes that have appeared in this issue, the sports. I'm a Lance Armstrong fan, so I'll go ahead and I'll click on that, which reveals, for me, all the issues in which Lance Armstrong's been a part of.(Applause)Now, if I want to just kind of take a peek at these, I might think, "Well, what about taking a look at all of cycling?" So I can step back, and expand on that. And I see Greg LeMond now. And so you get the idea that when you navigate over information this way — going narrower, broader, backing in, backing out — you're not searching, you're not browsing. You're doing something that's actually a little bit different. It's in between, and we think it changes the way information can be used.So I want to extrapolate on this idea a bit with something that's a little bit crazy. What we're done here is we've taken every single Wikipedia page and we reduced it down to a little summary. So the summary consists of just a little synopsis and an icon to indicate the topical area that it comes from. I'm only showing the top 500 most popular Wikipedia pages right here. But even in this limited view, we can do a lot of things. Right away, we get a sense of what are the topical domains that are most popular on Wikipedia. I'm going to go ahead and select government. Now, having selected government, I can now see that the Wikipedia categories that most frequently correspond to that are Time magazine People of the Year. So this is really important because this is an insight that was not contained within any one Wikipedia page. It's only possible to see that insight when you step back and look at all of them.Looking at one of these particular summaries, I can then drill into the concept of Time magazine Person of the Year, bringing up all of them. So looking at these people, I can see that the majority come from government; some have come from natural sciences; some, fewer still, have come from business — there's my boss — and one has come from music. And interestingly enough, Bono is also a TED Prize winner. So we can go, jump, and take a look at all the TED Prize winners. So you see, we're navigating the web for the first time as if it's actually a web, not from page-to-page, but at a higher level of abstraction.And so I want to show you one other thing that may catch you a little bit by surprise. I'm just showing the New York Times website here. So Pivot, this application — I don't want to call it a browser; it's really not a browser, but you can view web pages with it — and we bring that zoomable technology to every single web page like this. So I can step back, pop right back into a specific section. Now the reason why this is important is because, by virtue of just viewing web pages in this way, I can look at my entire browsing history in the exact same way. So I can drill into what I've done over specific time frames. Here, in fact, is the state of all the demo that I just gave. And I can sort of replay some stuff that I was looking at earlier today. And, if I want to step back and look at everything, I can slice and dice my history, perhaps by my search history — here, I was doing some nepotistic searching, looking for Bing, over here for Live Labs Pivot. And from these, I can drill into the web page and just launch them again. It's one metaphor repurposed multiple times, and in each case it makes the whole greater than the sum of the parts with the data.So right now, in this world, we think about data as being this curse. We talk about the curse of information overload. We talk about drowning in data. What if we can actually turn that upside down and turn the web upside down, so that instead of navigating from one thing to the next, we get used to the habit of being able to go from many things to many things, and then being able to see the patterns that were otherwise hidden? If we can do that, then instead of being trapped in data, we might actually extract information. And, instead of dealing just with information, we can tease out knowledge. And if we get the knowledge, then maybe even there's wisdom to be found.So with that, I thank you.(Applause)
