in her front yard one morning in the winter,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
and they brought her back to life.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
The next day, she was doing so well, they wanted to run tests on her.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
She got cranky and just went home.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
(Laughter)

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
So, these are miracles, right?

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
These are truly miraculous things that happen.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
Doctors have a saying

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
that, in fact, "You're not dead until you're warm and dead."

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
And it's true. It's true.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
In the New England Journal of Medicine,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
there was a study published that showed

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
that with appropriate rewarming,

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
people who had suffered without a heartbeat for three hours

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
could be brought back to life without any neurologic problems.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
That's over 50 percent.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
So what I was trying to do is think of a way

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
that we could study

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
suspended animation

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
to think about a way

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
to reproduce, maybe,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
what happened to the skier.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
Well, I have to tell you something very odd,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
and that is that being exposed to low oxygen

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
does not always kill.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
So, in this room, there's 20 percent oxygen or so,

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
and if we reduce the oxygen concentration,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
we will all be dead.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And, in fact, the animals we were working with in the lab --

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
these little garden worms, nematodes --

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
they were also dead when we exposed them to low oxygen.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
And here's the thing that should freak you out.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
And that is that, when we lower the oxygen concentration further

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:31.958
by 100 times, to 10 parts per million,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
they were not dead,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
they were in suspended animation,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
and we could bring them back to life without any harm.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
And this precise oxygen concentration,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
10 parts per million,

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
that caused suspended animation,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
is conserved.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
We can see it in a variety of different organisms.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
One of the creatures we see it in

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
is a fish.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
And we can turn its heartbeat on and off by going in and out

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
of suspended animation like you would a light switch.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
So this was pretty shocking to me,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
that we could do this.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
And so I was wondering, when we were trying

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
to reproduce the work with the skier,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
that we noticed that, of course,

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
she had no oxygen consumption,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
and so maybe she was in a similar state of suspended animation.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
But, of course, she was also extremely cold.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
So we wondered what would happen

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
if we took our suspended animals and exposed them to the cold.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
And so, what we found out

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
was that, if you take animals

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
that are animated like you and I,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
and you make them cold -- that is, these were the garden worms --

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
now they're dead.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
But if you have them in suspended animation,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
and move them into the cold, they're all alive.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
And there's the very important thing there:

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
If you want to survive the cold,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
you ought to be suspended. Right?

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
It's a really good thing.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
And so, we were thinking about that,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
about this relationship between these things,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
and thinking about whether or not that's what happened to the skier.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
And so we wondered: Might there be some agent

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
that is in us, something that we make ourselves,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
that we might be able to regulate our own metabolic flexibility

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
in such a way as to be able to survive

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
when we got extremely cold, and might otherwise pass away?

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
I thought it might be interesting to sort of hunt for such things.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
You know?

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
I should mention briefly here

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
that physiology textbooks that you can read about

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
will tell you that this is a kind of heretical thing to suggest.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
We have, from the time we are slapped on the butt

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
until we take our last dying breath --

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
that's when we're newborn to when we're dead --

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
we cannot reduce our metabolic rate

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
below what's called a standard,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
or basal metabolic rate.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
But I knew that there were examples

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
of creatures, also mammals,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
that do reduce their metabolic rate

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
such as ground squirrels and bears,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
they reduce their metabolic rate

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
in the wintertime when they hibernate.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
So I wondered: Might we be able to find some agent or trigger

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
that might induce such a state in us?

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
And so, we went looking for such things.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
And this was a period of time when we failed tremendously.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
Ken Robinson is here. He talked about the glories of failure.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
Well, we had a lot of them.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
We tried many different chemicals and agents,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
and we failed over and over again.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
So, one time, I was at home

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
watching television on the couch

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:19.958
while my wife was putting our child to bed,

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
and I was watching a television show.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
It was a television show --

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
it was a NOVA show on PBS --

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
about caves in New Mexico.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
And this particular cave was Lechuguilla,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
and this cave is incredibly toxic to humans.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
The researchers had to suit up just to enter it.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
It's filled with this toxic gas,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
hydrogen sulfide.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:43.958
Now, hydrogen sulfide is curiously present in us.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
We make it ourselves.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
The highest concentration is in our brains.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
Yet, it was used

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
as a chemical warfare agent in World War I.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
It's an extraordinarily toxic thing.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
In fact, in chemical accidents,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.958
hydrogen sulfide is known to --

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
if you breathe too much of it, you collapse to the ground,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
you appear dead,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
but if you were brought out into room air, you can be reanimated without harm,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
if they do that quickly.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:18.958
So, I thought, "Wow, I have to get some of this."

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
(Laughter)

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:26.958
Now, it's post-9/11 America,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
and when you go into the research institute,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
and you say, "Hi.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
I'd like to buy some concentrated,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
compressed gas cylinders

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
of a lethal gas

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
because I have these ideas, see,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
about wanting to suspend people.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
It's really going to be OK."

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
So that's kind of a tough day,

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
but I said, "There really is

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
some basis for thinking why you might want to do this."

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
As I said, this agent is in us,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
and, in fact, here's a curious thing,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
it binds to the very place inside of your cells

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
where oxygen binds, and where you burn it,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
and that you do this burning to live.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
And so we thought, like in a game of musical chairs,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:11.958
might we be able to give a person

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
some hydrogen sulfide,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
and might it be able to occupy that place

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
like in a game of musical chairs where oxygen might bind?

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
And because you can't bind the oxygen,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
maybe you wouldn't consume it,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
and then maybe it would reduce your demand for oxygen.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
I mean, who knows?

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
So -- (Laughter)

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
So, there's the bit about the dopamine

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
and being a little bit, what do you call it, delusional,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
and you might suggest that was it.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
And so, we wanted to find out

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
might we be able to use

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
hydrogen sulfide in the presence of cold,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
and we wanted to see whether we could

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
reproduce this skier in a mammal.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:55.958
Now, mammals are warm-blooded creatures,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
and when we get cold, we shake and we shiver, right?

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
We try to keep our core temperature at 37 degrees

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
by actually burning more oxygen.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
So, it was interesting for us

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
when we applied hydrogen sulfide

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:15.958
to a mouse when it was also cold

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
because what happened is the core temperature

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
of the mouse got cold.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
It stopped moving.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
It appeared dead.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
Its oxygen consumption rate

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
fell by tenfold.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
And here's the really important point.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
I told you hydrogen sulfide is in us.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
It's rapidly metabolized,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
and all you have to do after six hours of being

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
in this state of de-animation

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
is simply put the thing out in room air,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
and it warms up, and it's none the worse for wear.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
Now, this was cosmic.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
Really. Because we had found a way

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
to de-animate a mammal,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
and it didn't hurt it.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
Now, we'd found a way to reduce

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
its oxygen consumption

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
to rock-bottom levels, and it was fine.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
Now, in this state of de-animation,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
it could not go out dancing,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
but it was not dead,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
and it was not harmed.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
So we started to think: Is this the agent

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
that might have been present in the skier,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
and might have she had more of it than someone else,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
and might that have been able to reduce

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
her demand for oxygen

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
before she got so cold that

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
she otherwise would have died,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
as we found out with our worm experiments?

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
So, we wondered:

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
Can we do anything useful

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
with this capacity to

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
control metabolic flexibility?

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
And one of the things we wondered --

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
I'm sure some of you out there are economists,

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
and you know all about supply and demand.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
And when supply is equal to demand,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
everything's fine,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
but when supply falls,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
in this case of oxygen,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
and demand stays high, you're dead.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
So, what I just told you

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
is we can now reduce demand.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
We ought to be able to lower supply

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
to unprecedented low levels without killing the animal.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
And with money we got from DARPA,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
we could show just that.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
If you give mice hydrogen sulfide,

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
you can lower their demand for oxygen,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
and you can put them into oxygen concentrations

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
that are as low as 5,000 feet above the top of Mt. Everest,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
and they can sit there for hours, and there's no problem.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
Well this was really cool.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
We also found out that we could subject animals

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
to otherwise lethal blood loss, and we could save them

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
if we gave them hydrogen sulfide.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
So these proof of concept experiments

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
led me to say "I should found a company,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
and we should take this out to a wider playing field."

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
I founded a company called Ikaria

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
with others' help.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And this company, the first thing it did

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
was make a liquid formulation of hydrogen sulfide

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
an injectable form that we could put in

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
and send it out to physician scientists all over the world

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
who work on models of critical care medicine,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
and the results are incredibly positive.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
In one model of heart attack,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
animals given hydrogen sulfide

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
showed a 70 percent reduction in heart damage

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
compared to those who got the standard of care that

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
you and I would receive if we were to have a heart attack here today.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
Same is true for organ failure,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:27.958
when you have loss of function owing to poor perfusion of kidney, of liver,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
acute respiratory distress syndrome

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
and damage suffered in cardiac-bypass surgery.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
So, these are the thought leaders in trauma medicine

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
all over the world saying this is true,

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:42.958
so it seems that exposure to hydrogen sulfide

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
decreases damage that you receive

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
from being exposed to otherwise lethal-low oxygen.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
And I should say that the concentrations of hydrogen sulfide

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
required to get this benefit

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
are low, incredibly low.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
In fact, so low that physicians will not have to lower or dim

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
the metabolism of people much at all

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
to see the benefit I just mentioned,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
which is a wonderful thing, if you're thinking about adopting this.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
You don't want to be gorking people out

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
just to save them, it's really confusing.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
(Laughter)

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
So, I want to say that we're in human trials.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
Now, and so --

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:23.958
(Applause)

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
Thank you. The Phase 1 safety studies are over,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
and we're doing fine, we're now moved on.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
We have to get to Phase 2 and Phase 3. It's going to take us a few years.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
This has all moved very quickly,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
and the mouse experiments

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
of hibernating mice happened in 2005;

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
the first human studies were done in 2008,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
and we should know in a couple of years

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
whether it works or not.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
And this all happened really quickly

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
because of a lot of help from a lot of people.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
I want to mention that, first of all,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
my wife, without whom this talk and my work would not be possible,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
so thank you very much.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
Also, the brilliant scientists who work at my lab

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
and also others on staff,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, Washington --

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
wonderful place to work.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
And also the wonderful scientists

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
and businesspeople at Ikaria.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
One thing those people did out there

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
was take this technology of hydrogen sulfide,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
which is this start-up company that's burning venture capital very quickly,

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
and they fused it with another company

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
that sells another toxic gas

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:25.958
that's more toxic than hydrogen sulfide,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
and they give it to newborn babies who would otherwise die

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
from a failure to be able to oxygenate their tissues properly.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
And this gas that is delivered in over

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
a thousand critical care hospitals worldwide,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
now is approved, on label,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
and saves thousands of babies a year

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
from certain death.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
(Applause)

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
So it's really incredible

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
for me to be a part of this.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
And I want to say that I think we're on the path

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
of understanding metabolic flexibility

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
in a fundamental way,

00:16:56.958 --> 00:17:00.958
and that in the not too distant future,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
an EMT might give an injection of hydrogen sulfide,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
or some related compound,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
to a person suffering severe injuries,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
and that person might de-animate a bit,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:14.958
they might become a little more immortal.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
Their metabolism will fall

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:22.958
as though you were dimming a switch on a lamp at home.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
And then, they will have the time, that will buy them the time,

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:28.958
to be transported to the hospital

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:34.958
to get the care they need.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:39.958
And then, after they get that care --

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
like the mouse, like the skier,

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
like the 65-year-old woman --

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
they'll wake up.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
A miracle?

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
We hope not, or maybe we just hope

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
to make miracles a little more common.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:53.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:18:00.958
(Applause)

title: Take health care off the mainframe
transcript: If you think about the phone — and Intel has tested a lot of the things I'm going to show you, over the last 10 years, in about 600 elderly households — 300 in Ireland, and 300 in Portland — trying to understand: How do we measure and monitor behavior in a medically meaningful way?And if you think about the phone, right, it's something that we can use for some incredible ways to help people actually take the right medication at the right time. We're testing these kinds of simple sensor-network technologies in the home so that any phone that a senior is already comfortable with can help them deal with their medications. And a lot of what they do is they pick up the phone, and it's our system whispering to them which pill they need to take, and they fake like they're having a conversation with a friend. And they're not embarrassed by a meds caddy that's ugly, that sits on their kitchen table and says, "I'm old. I'm frail." It's surreptitious technology that's helping them do a simple task of taking the right pill at the right time.Now, we also do some pretty amazing things with these phones. Because that moment when you answer the phone is a cognitive test every time that you do it. Think about it, all right? I'm going to answer the phone three different times. "Hello? Hey." All right? That's the first time. "Hello? Uh, hey." "Hello? Uh, who? Oh, hey." All right? Very big differences between the way I answered the phone the three times. And as we monitor phone usage by seniors over a long period of time, down to the tenths of a microsecond, that recognition moment of whether they can figure out that person on the other end is a friend and we start talking to them immediately, or they do a lot of what's called trouble talk, where they're like, "Wait, who is this? Oh." Right? Waiting for that recognition moment may be the best early indicator of the onset of dementia than anything that shows up clinically today.We call these behavioral markers. There's lots of others. Is the person going to the phone as quickly, when it rings, as they used to? Is it a hearing problem or is it a physicality problem? Has their voice gotten more quiet? We're doing a lot of work with people with Alzheimer's and particularly with Parkinson's, where that quiet voice that sometimes shows up with Parkinson's patients may be the best early indicator of Parkinson's five to 10 years before it shows up clinically. But those subtle changes in your voice over a long period of time are hard for you or your spouse to notice until it becomes so extreme and your voice has become so quiet.So, sensors are looking at that kind of voice. When you pick up the phone, how much tremor are you having, and what is that like, and what is that trend like over a period of time? Are you having more trouble dialing the phone than you used to? Is it a dexterity problem? Is it the onset of arthritis? Are you using the phone? Are you socializing less than you used to? And looking at that pattern. And what does that decline in social health mean, as a kind of a vital sign of the future? And then wow, what a radical idea, we — except in the United States — might be able to use this newfangled technology to actually interact with a nurse or a doctor on the other end of the line. Wow, what a great day that will be once we're allowed to actually do those kinds of things.So, these are what I would call behavioral markers. And it's the whole field that we've been trying to work on for the last 10 years at Intel. How do you put simple disruptive technologies, and the first of five phrases that I'm going to talk about in this talk? Behavioral markers matter. How do we change behavior? How do we measure changes in behavior in a meaningful way that's going to help us with prevention of disease, early onset of disease, and tracking the progression of disease over a long period of time?Now, why would Intel let me spend a lot of time and money, over the last 10 years, trying to understand the needs of seniors and start thinking about these kinds of behavioral markers? This is some of the field work that we've done. We have now lived with 1,000 elderly households in 20 countries over the last 10 years. We study people in Rochester, New York. We go live with them in the winter because what they do in the winter, and their access to healthcare, and how much they socialize, is very different than in the summer. If they have a hip fracture we go with them and we study their entire discharge experience. If they have a family member who is a key part of their care network, we fly and study them as well.So, we study the holistic health experience of 1,000 seniors over the last 10 years in 20 different countries. Why is Intel willing to fund that? It's because of the second slogan that I want to talk about. Ten years ago, when I started trying to convince Intel to let me go start looking at disruptive technologies that could help with independent living, this is what I called it: "Y2K + 10."You know, back in 2000, we were all so obsessed with paying attention to the aging of our computers, and whether or not they were going to survive the tick of the clock from 1999 to 2000, that we missed a moment that only demographers were paying attention to. It was right around New Years. And that switchover, when we had the larger number of older people on the planet, for the first time than younger people. For the first time in human history — and barring aliens landing or some major other pandemic, that's the expectation from demographers, going forward.And 10 years ago it seemed like I had a lot of time to convince Intel to work on this. Right? Y2K + 10 was coming, the baby boomers starting to retire. Well folks, it's like we know these demographics here. This is a map of the entire world. It's like the lights are on, but nobody's home on this demographic Y2K + 10 problem. Right? I mean we sort of get it here, but we don't get it here, and we're not doing anything about it.The health reform bill is largely ignoring the realities of the age wave that's coming, and the implications for what we need to do to change not only how we pay for care, but deliver care in some radically different ways. And in fact, it's upon us. I mean you probably saw these headlines. This is Catherine Casey who is the first boomer to actually get Social Security. That actually occurred this year. She took early retirement. She was born one second after midnight in 1946. A retired school teacher, there she is with a Social Security administrator. The first boomer actually, we didn't even wait till 2011, next year. We're already starting to see early retirement occur this year.All right, so it's here. This Y2K + 10 problem is at our door. This is 50 tsunamis scheduled on the calendar, but somehow we can't sort of marshal our government and innovative forces to sort of get out in front of it and do something about it. We'll wait until it's more of a catastrophe, and react, as opposed to prepare for it. So, one of the reasons it's so challenging to prepare for this Y2K problem is, I want to argue, we have what I would call mainframe poisoning.Andy Grove, about six or seven years ago, he doesn't even know or remember this, in a Fortune Magazine article he used the phrase "mainframe healthcare," and I've been extending and expanding this. He saw it written down somewhere. He's like, "Eric that's a really cool concept." I was like, "Actually it was your idea. You said it in a Fortune Magazine article. I just extended it." You know, this is the mainframe.This mentality of traveling to and timesharing large, expensive healthcare systems actually began in 1787. This is the first general hospital in Vienna. And actually the second general hospital in Vienna, in about 1850, was where we started to build out an entire curriculum for teaching med students specialties. And it's a place in which we started developing architecture that literally divided the body, and divided care into departments and compartments. And it was reflected in our architecture, it was reflected in the way that we taught students, and this mainframe mentality persists today.Now, I'm not anti-hospital. With my own healthcare problems, I've taken drug therapies, I've traveled to this hospital and others, many, many times. But we worship the high hospital on a hill. Right? And this is mainframe healthcare. And just as 30 years ago we couldn't conceive that we would have the power of a mainframe computer that took up a room this size in our purses and on our belts, that we're carrying around in our cell phone today, and suddenly, computing, that used to be an expert driven system, it was a personal system that we all owned as part of our daily lives — that shift from mainframe to personal computing is what we have to do for healthcare. We have to shift from this mainframe mentality of healthcare to a personal model of healthcare.We are obsessed with this way of thinking. When Intel does surveys all around the world and we say, "Quick response: healthcare." The first word that comes up is "doctor." The second that comes up is "hospital." And the third is "illness" or "sickness." Right? We are wired, in our imagination, to think about healthcare and healthcare innovation as something that goes into that place. Our entire health reform discussion right now, health I.T., when we talk with policy makers, equals "How are we going to get doctors using electronic medical records in the mainframe?" We're not thinking about how do we shift from the mainframe to the home. And the problem with this is the way we conceive healthcare. Right?This is a very reactive, crisis-driven system. We're doing 15-minute exams with patients. It's population-based. We collect a bunch of biological information in this artificial setting, and we fix them up, like Humpty-Dumpty all over again, and send them home, and hope — we might hand them a brochure, maybe an interactive website — that they do as asked and don't come back into the mainframe.And the problem is we can't afford it today, folks. We can't afford mainframe healthcare today to include the uninsured. And now we want to do a double-double of the age wave coming through? Business as usual in healthcare is broken and we've got to do something different. We've got to focus on the home.We've got to focus on a personal healthcare paradigm that moves care to the home. How do we be more proactive, prevention-driven? How do we collect vital signs and other kinds of information 24 by 7? How do we get a personal baseline about what's going to work for you? How do we collect not just biological data but behavioral data, psychological data, relational data, in and on and around the home? And how do we drive compliance to be a customized care plan that uses all this great technology that's around us to change our behavior? That's what we need to do for our personal health model.I want to give you a couple of examples. This is Mimi from one of our studies — in her 90s, had to move out of her home because her family was worried about falls. Raise your hand if you had a serious fall in your household, or any of your loved ones, your parents or so forth. Right? Classic. Hip fracture often leads to institutionalization of a senior. This is what was happening to Mimi; the family was worried about it, moved her out of her own home into an assisted living facility. She tripped over her oxygen tank.Many people in this generation won't press the button, even if they have an alert call system, because they don't want to bother anybody, even though they've been paying 30 dollars a month. Boomers will press the button. Trust me. They're going to be pressing that button non-stop. Right?Mimi broke her pelvis, lay all night, all morning, finally somebody came in and found her, sent her to the hospital. They fixed her back up. She was never going to be able to move back into the assisted living. They put her into the nursing home unit. First night in the nursing home unit where she had been in the same assisted living facility, moved her from one bed to another, kind of threw her, rebroke her pelvis, sent her back to the hospital that she had just come from, no one read the chart, put her on Tylenol, which she is allergic to, broke out, got bedsores, basically, had heart problems, and died from the fall and the complications and the errors that were there.Now, the most frightening thing about this is this is my wife's grandmother. Now, I'm Eric Dishman. I speak English, I work for Intel, I make a good salary, I'm smart about falls and fall-related injuries — it's an area of research that I work on. I have access to senators and CEOs. I can't stop this from happening. What happens if you don't have money, you don't speak English or don't have the kind of access to deal with these kinds of problems that inevitably occur? How do we actually prevent the vast majority of falls from ever occurring in the first place?Let me give you a quick example of work that we're doing to try to do exactly that. I've been wearing a little technology that we call Shimmer. It's a research platform. It has accelerometry. You can plug in a three-lead ECG. There is all kinds of sort of plug-and-play kind of Legos that you can do to capture, in the wild, in the real world, things like tremor, gait, stride length and those kinds of things.The problem is, our understanding of falls today, like Mimi, is get a survey in the mail three months after you fell, from the State, saying, "What were you doing when you fell?" That's sort of the state of the art. But with something like Shimmer, or we have something called the Magic Carpet, embedded sensors in carpet, or camera-based systems that we borrowed from sports medicine, we're starting for the first time in those 600 elderly households to collect actual kinematic motion data to understand: What are the subtle changes that are occurring that can show us that mom has become risk at falls?And most often we can do two interventions, fix the meds mix. I'm a qualitative researcher, but when I look at these data streams coming in from these homes, I can look at the data and tell you the day that some doctor prescribed them something that nobody else knew that they were on, because we see the changes in their patterns in the household. Right? These discoveries of behavioral markers, and behavioral changes are game changing, and like the discovery of the microscope because of our collecting data streams that we've actually never done before.This is an example in our TRIL Clinic in Ireland of — actually what you're seeing is she's looking at data, in this picture, from the Magic Carpet. So, we have a little carpet that you can look at your amount of postural sway, and look at the changes in your postural sway over many months. Here's what some of this data might look like. This is actually sensor firings.These are two different subjects in our study. It's about a year's worth of data. The color represents different rooms they are in the house. This person on the left is living in their own home. This person on the right is actually living in an assisted living facility. I know this because look at how punctuated meal time is when they are no longer in their particular rooms here. Right? Now, this doesn't mean that much to you. But when we look at these cycles of data over a longer period of time — and we're looking at everything from motion around different rooms in the house, to sort of micro-motions that Shimmer picks up, about gait and stride length — these streams of data are starting to tell us things about behavioral patterns that we've never understood before.You can go to ORCATech.org — it has nothing to do with whales, it's the Oregon Center for Aging and Technology — to see more about that. The problem is, Intel is still one of the largest funders in the world of independent living technology research. I'm not bragging about how much we fund; it's how little anyone else actually pays attention to aging and funds innovation on aging, chronic disease management and independent living in the home.So, my mantra here, my fourth slogan is: 10,000 households or bust. We need to drive a national, if not international, Framingham-type heart study of independent living technologies, where we have 10,000 elderly connected households with broadband, full medical characterization, and a platform by which we can start to experiment and turn these from 20-household anecdotal studies that the universities fund, to large clinical trials that prove out the value of these technologies. So, 10,000 households or bust. These are just some of the households that we've done in the Intel studies.My fifth and final phrase: I have tried for two years, and there were moments when we were quite close, to make this healthcare reform bill be about reform from something and to something, from a mainframe model to a personal health model, or to mean something more than just a debate about the public option and how we're going to finance. It doesn't matter how we finance healthcare. We're going to figure something out for the next 10 years, and try it. No matter who pays for it, we better start doing care in a fundamentally different way and treating the home and the patient and the family member and the caregivers as part of these coordinated care teams and using disruptive technologies that are already here to do care in some pretty fundamental different ways.The president needs to stand up and say, at the end of a healthcare reform debate, "Our goal as a country is to move 50 percent of care out of institutions, clinics, hospitals and nursing homes, to the home, in 10 years." It's achievable. We should do it economically, we should do it morally, and we should do it for quality of life. But there is no goal within this health reform. It's just a mess today.So, you know, that's my last message to you. How do we set a going-to-the-moon goal of dealing with the Y2K +10 problem that's coming? It's not that innovation and technology is going to be the magic pill that cures all, but it's going to be part of the solution. And if we don't create a personal health movement, something that we're all aiming towards in reform, then we're going to move nowhere. So, I hope you'll turn this conference into that kind of movement forward. Thanks very much. (Applause)

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
that could help with independent living,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
this is what I called it: "Y2K + 10."

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
You know, back in 2000,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
we were all so obsessed with paying attention

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
to the aging of our computers,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
and whether or not they were going to survive

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
the tick of the clock from 1999 to 2000,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:53.958
that we missed a moment that only demographers were paying attention to.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
It was right around New Years.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
And that switchover,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
when we had the larger number of older people on the planet,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
for the first time than younger people.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
For the first time in human history -- and barring aliens landing

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
or some major other pandemic,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
that's the expectation from demographers, going forward.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
And 10 years ago it seemed like I had a lot of time

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
to convince Intel to work on this. Right?

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
Y2K + 10 was coming,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
the baby boomers starting to retire.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:22.958
Well folks, it's like we know these demographics here.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
This is a map of the entire world.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
It's like the lights are on,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
but nobody's home on this demographic

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
Y2K + 10 problem. Right?

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
I mean we sort of get it here, but we don't get it here,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
and we're not doing anything about it.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
The health reform bill is largely ignoring

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
the realities of the age wave that's coming,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
and the implications for what we need to do to change

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
not only how we pay for care,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
but deliver care in some radically different ways.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
And in fact, it's upon us.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
I mean you probably saw these headlines. This is Catherine Casey

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
who is the first boomer to actually get Social Security.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
That actually occurred this year. She took early retirement.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
She was born one second after midnight in 1946.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
A retired school teacher,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
there she is with a Social Security administrator.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
The first boomer actually, we didn't even wait till 2011, next year.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
We're already starting to see early retirement occur this year.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
All right, so it's here. This Y2K + 10 problem is at our door.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:20.958
This is 50 tsunamis scheduled on the calendar,

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
but somehow we can't sort of marshal our government

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
and innovative forces to sort of get out in front of it

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
and do something about it. We'll wait until

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
it's more of a catastrophe, and react,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
as opposed to prepare for it.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
So, one of the reasons it's so

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
challenging to prepare for this Y2K problem

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
is, I want to argue, we have what I would call

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
mainframe poisoning.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
Andy Grove, about six or seven years ago,

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
he doesn't even know or remember this, in a Fortune Magazine article

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
he used the phrase "mainframe healthcare,"

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
and I've been extending and expanding this.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
He saw it written down somewhere. He's like, "Eric that's a really cool concept."

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
I was like, "Actually it was your idea. You said it in a Fortune Magazine article.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
I just extended it."

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
You know, this is the mainframe.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
This mentality of traveling to

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
and timesharing large, expensive healthcare systems

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
actually began in 1787.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
This is the first general hospital in Vienna.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
And actually the second general hospital in Vienna,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
in about 1850, was where we started to build out

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:18.958
an entire curriculum for teaching med students specialties.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
And it's a place in which we started developing

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
architecture that literally divided the body,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
and divided care into departments and compartments.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
And it was reflected in our architecture,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
it was reflected in the way that we taught students,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
and this mainframe mentality persists today.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
Now, I'm not anti-hospital.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
With my own healthcare problems, I've taken drug therapies,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
I've traveled to this hospital and others, many, many times.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
But we worship the high hospital on a hill. Right?

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
And this is mainframe healthcare.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
And just as 30 years ago

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
we couldn't conceive that we would have the power

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
of a mainframe computer that took up a room this size

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
in our purses and on our belts,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
that we're carrying around in our cell phone today,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
and suddenly, computing,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
that used to be an expert driven system,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
it was a personal system that we all owned as part of our daily lives --

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
that shift from mainframe to personal computing

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
is what we have to do for healthcare.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
We have to shift from this mainframe mentality of healthcare

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
to a personal model of healthcare.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
We are obsessed with this way of thinking.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
When Intel does surveys all around the world and we say,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
"Quick response: healthcare."

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
The first word that comes up is "doctor."

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
The second that comes up is "hospital." And the third is "illness" or "sickness." Right?

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:31.958
We are wired, in our imagination, to think about healthcare

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
and healthcare innovation as something

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
that goes into that place.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
Our entire health reform discussion right now,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
health I.T., when we talk with policy makers,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
equals "How are we going to get doctors using

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
electronic medical records in the mainframe?"

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
We're not thinking about

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
how do we shift from the mainframe to the home.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
And the problem with this is

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
the way we conceive healthcare. Right?

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
This is a very reactive, crisis-driven system.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
We're doing 15-minute exams with patients.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
It's population-based.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
We collect a bunch of biological information in this artificial setting,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
and we fix them up, like Humpty-Dumpty all over again,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
and send them home,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
and hope -- we might hand them a brochure, maybe an interactive website --

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
that they do as asked and don't come back into the mainframe.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
And the problem is we can't afford it today, folks.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
We can't afford mainframe healthcare today to include the uninsured.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
And now we want to do a double-double

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
of the age wave coming through?

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
Business as usual in healthcare is broken and we've got to do something different.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
We've got to focus on the home.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
We've got to focus on a personal healthcare paradigm

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
that moves care to the home. How do we be more proactive,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
prevention-driven?

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
How do we collect vital signs and other kinds of information 24 by 7?

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
How do we get a personal baseline about what's going to work for you?

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
How do we collect not just biological data

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
but behavioral data, psychological data,

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
relational data, in and on and around the home?

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
And how do we drive compliance to be a customized care plan

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
that uses all this great technology that's around us

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
to change our behavior?

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
That's what we need to do for our personal health model.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
I want to give you a couple of examples. This is Mimi

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
from one of our studies --

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
in her 90s, had to move out of her home

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
because her family was worried about falls.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
Raise your hand if you had a serious fall

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
in your household, or any of your loved ones,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
your parents or so forth. Right?

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Classic. Hip fracture often leads to institutionalization of a senior.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
This is what was happening to Mimi; the family was worried about it,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
moved her out of her own home into an assisted living facility.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
She tripped over her oxygen tank.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
Many people in this generation won't press the button,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
even if they have an alert call system, because they don't want to bother anybody,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
even though they've been paying 30 dollars a month.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
Boomers will press the button. Trust me.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
They're going to be pressing that button non-stop. Right?

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
Mimi broke her pelvis, lay all night, all morning,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
finally somebody came in and found her,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
sent her to the hospital.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
They fixed her back up. She was never going to be able to move back

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
into the assisted living. They put her into the nursing home unit.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
First night in the nursing home unit where she had been

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
in the same assisted living facility, moved her from one bed to another,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
kind of threw her, rebroke her pelvis,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
sent her back to the hospital that she had just come from,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
no one read the chart, put her on Tylenol,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
which she is allergic to, broke out, got bedsores,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
basically, had heart problems, and died

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
from the fall and the complications and the errors that were there.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
Now, the most frightening thing about this is

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
this is my wife's grandmother.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
Now, I'm Eric Dishman. I speak English,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
I work for Intel, I make a good salary,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
I'm smart about falls and fall-related injuries --

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
it's an area of research that I work on.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
I have access to senators and CEOs.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
I can't stop this from happening.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
What happens if you don't have money, you don't speak English

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
or don't have the kind of access

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
to deal with these kinds of problems that inevitably occur?

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
How do we actually prevent the vast majority of falls

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
from ever occurring in the first place?

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
Let me give you a quick example of work that we're doing

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
to try to do exactly that.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
I've been wearing a little technology that we call Shimmer.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
It's a research platform.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
It has accelerometry. You can plug in a three-lead ECG.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
There is all kinds of sort of plug-and-play

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
kind of Legos that you can do to capture, in the wild,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
in the real world,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
things like tremor, gait,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
stride length and those kinds of things.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
The problem is, our understanding of falls today,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
like Mimi, is get a survey in the mail three months after you fell,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
from the State, saying, "What were you doing when you fell?"

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
That's sort of the state of the art.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
But with something like Shimmer, or we have something called the Magic Carpet,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
embedded sensors in carpet, or camera-based systems

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
that we borrowed from sports medicine,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
we're starting for the first time in those 600 elderly households

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
to collect actual kinematic motion data

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:32.958
to understand: What are the subtle changes that are occurring

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
that can show us that mom has become risk at falls?

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
And most often we can do two interventions,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
fix the meds mix.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
I'm a qualitative researcher, but when I look at these data streams coming in

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
from these homes, I can look at the data and tell you the day

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
that some doctor prescribed them something that nobody else

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
knew that they were on, because we see the changes

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
in their patterns in the household. Right?

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
These discoveries of behavioral markers,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
and behavioral changes

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
are game changing, and like the discovery of the microscope

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
because of our collecting data streams that we've actually never done before.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
This is an example in our TRIL Clinic in Ireland

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
of -- actually what you're seeing is

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
she's looking at data,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
in this picture, from the Magic Carpet.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
So, we have a little carpet that you can look at your amount of postural sway,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
and look at the changes in your postural sway over many months.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
Here's what some of this data might look like.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
This is actually sensor firings.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
These are two different subjects in our study.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
It's about a year's worth of data.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
The color represents different rooms they are in the house.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
This person on the left is living in their own home.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
This person on the right is actually living in an assisted living facility.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
I know this because look at how punctuated meal time is

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
when they are no longer in their particular rooms here. Right?

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
Now, this doesn't mean that much to you.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
But when we look at these cycles of data

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
over a longer period of time -- and we're looking at everything from

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
motion around different rooms in the house,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
to sort of micro-motions that Shimmer picks up,

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
about gait and stride length -- these streams of data

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
are starting to tell us things about behavioral patterns

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
that we've never understood before.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
You can go to ORCATech.org --

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
it has nothing to do with whales, it's the Oregon Center for Aging and Technology --

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
to see more about that.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
The problem is, Intel is still one of the largest

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
funders in the world

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
of independent living technology research.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
I'm not bragging about how much we fund;

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
it's how little anyone else actually pays attention

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
to aging and funds innovation on aging,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
chronic disease management and independent living in the home.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
So, my mantra here, my fourth slogan is:

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
10,000 households or bust.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
We need to drive

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:31.958
a national, if not international, Framingham-type heart study

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
of independent living technologies,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
where we have 10,000 elderly connected households

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
with broadband, full medical characterization,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
and a platform by which we can start to experiment

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
and turn these from 20-household anecdotal studies

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
that the universities fund,

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
to large clinical trials that prove out the value of these technologies.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
So, 10,000 households or bust.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:55.958
These are just some of the households that we've done in the Intel studies.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
My fifth and final phrase:

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
I have tried for two years,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
and there were moments when we were quite close,

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
to make this healthcare reform bill be about reform

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
from something and to something,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
from a mainframe model

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
to a personal health model,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
or to mean something more than just a debate

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
about the public option and how we're going to finance.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
It doesn't matter how we finance healthcare.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
We're going to figure something out

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
for the next 10 years, and try it.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
No matter who pays for it,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
we better start doing care in a fundamentally different way

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
and treating the home and the patient

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
and the family member and the caregivers

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
as part of these coordinated care teams

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
and using disruptive technologies that are already here

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
to do care in some pretty fundamental different ways.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
The president needs to stand up and say,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
at the end of a healthcare reform debate,

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
"Our goal as a country is to move 50 percent of care

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
out of institutions, clinics, hospitals and nursing homes,

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
to the home, in 10 years."

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
It's achievable. We should do it economically,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
we should do it morally,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
and we should do it for quality of life.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
But there is no goal within this health reform.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
